reviews.review: The famous Coathanger. We just love the Coathanger for what it symbolises & its endurance over the years. We stayed in Lane Cove & travelled on the train every day into Sydney sightseeing. We did the bridge climb on a previous visit & everything we learned about the bridge that day has kept us in awe of the grand vision as well as the architectural & construction excellence of a past era. It was an engineering feat way before its time. It sees us still having a strong, well constructed icon as valuable to Sydney today as it has been in years gone by.
Stunning!!. It's a must when in Sydney to walk across the harbour bridge! Catch the train to milsons point, walk to the city and enjoy the amazing harbour view!!

Walks on the harbour. Awesome view - brilliant icon for our city. Just don't bother staying at the Autograph Collection Hostel at Pier One - they double charge you then blame you for not noticing earlier!!!

Bridge Climb. Everyone who is ambulatory should muster their courage and do this. The climb is easy for 99% of the people who do it, is completely safe, and you are rewarded with a wonderful narrative by caring and funny climb leaders and an unparalleled view of Sydney. Not to be missed!

Just walk along the bridge!. The bridge is an iconic landmark of Sydney, so if you are visiting Sydeny this would be among the first places you are going to see. There are many ways to experience it. For example, you can watch it from the distance, you can cruise below it, you can use it to cross the harbour with your car. But one of the most satisfying ways is just taking a stroll by foot using the pedestrian lane. It's rather long, and we started from the Rocks and did just a section of it.
Breathtaking. We did not do the bridge climb but did stay right under the bridge and get to enjoy the beauty if had to offer. I understand why so many brides have their wedding pictures taken here
Great views. engaging and supporting staff, who help those who aren't confident. Great views from on the bridge. Very informative guide

Gorgeous to walk across. We stayed in Kirrabilli and walked across the bridge each day sometimes over and back twice in a day. The photos opportunities are amazing. There is security along the bridge for your safety. The bridge is free to cross. There is a tower you can climb to take photos and get a 360 view but there is a charge. We didn't bother as we could see all that we wanted to from the walking path itself.The walk over took us around 20-30 minutes but we stopped to admire the opera house views, watch ferries and take photos. Once over the bridge it's only a short walk to the opera house itself. A must if your in Sydney!
Old bridge . Just one of the things you have to see when you go to Sidney Very old iron bridge ,option to do the walk the easy way or hard

Stunning from every angle. No need to pay a fortune for a bridge climb. Just take the public ferries to cross below, walk up to it and walk over it - great photo op for the Opara House. My best pic of it is from here. You can also tke the train or car to pass over it - no matter how - always great views.

The jewel in the crown!. If you haven't before, you definitely need to take a walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. This is an experience you won't forget and it is a wonderful opportunity to take photographs. This is a must see tourist attraction when visiting Sydney!

Sydney Harbour Bridge walk. It is free for a start, very good views of the harbour inl. the Quay and Luna Park plus many busy all sorts of boats and cruise liners... easy walk approx. 50minutes ea way... depending on how far you go... from the south end, enter from the "Rocks" area, there ar easy steps up to bridge , also look at the new Barrangaroo area on the western side of bridge..
wow!. i've always seen this place on TV or movies. somehow, seeing it in person is just different. i have yet to scale the highest point --- maybe when im no longer afraid of heights!!

Can’t miss this impressive feat of engineering. If you are in Sydney, you can’t miss it, during your stay you will drive over it, walk under it and climb to the top. Take a ferry from Circular Quay and you pass under or next to it. The bridge offers great views of the harbour and especially the Opera House. We have now had the unique experience of walking under and climbing on two bridges that the famous English Engineer Sir Ralph Freeman (responsible for the design of several of the world's most impressive bridges) was involved in designing. The Victoria Falls Railway Bridge, which he worked on as a young engineer and the Sydney Harbour Bridge which he designed.

Best views. I thought the bridge itself was quite ugly. Needs to be seen if your in Sydney of course, but not hugely exciting. The views from the bridge however are unmissable. We decided not to fork out for the climb but did go up the pylon lookout which is very affordable and provides fantastic views of the whole quay and surrounds. The pylon does have a lot of steps but the views from the middle of the bridge itself are almost as good.

Bridge climb . On booking thought it was quite expensive but OMG worth every penny and more ! Your safety is taken very seriously and you are given every thing you might need before you leave the building, now I'mVery nervous of heights and to be brutally honest the first part is quite scary especially the ladders up to the bridge (but my hubby who isn't afraid of heights these were a breeze) once on the bridge you feel very safe, you cannot see immediately downwards only to the sides and we went on the twilight walk and wow wow wow Sydney at night at that height is just amazing, I was so engrossed in seeing all the sites around me I forgot about being scared at all ! I wasn't the fastest and not one person put pressure on me to feel rushed as I said it's all about safety first and enjoying the experience ! But even though I was slow I did it and felt uber proud of myself afterwards x

Happy Birtday Bridge Climb. Did the climb today and it was awesome. Really worth every penny. Great views we had the friendliest guide ever and my husband who is afraid of heights did do the climb without problems.

Did the Climb. My wife had always complained that she hadn't done the Sydney Harbour BridgeClimb. We were booked on a cruise leaving from Sydney so I surprised her by booking the climb. We both rated the climb highly, our guide was great. What a fantastic experience and whenever we see the "coat hanger" on TV we comment on the climb. If you are a tourist in Sydney, do yourself a favor and book a Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. Most people of average fitness should be able to complete the climb - there are also express climbs available for those pressed for time. A word of warning - not too many drinks before your climb - you will be breathalyzed.
A nice scenic walk. My husband and I parked on the city side of the bridge and walked across to the northern side stopping for a coffee at milsons point before walking back across the bridge

Walk The Bridge. From the Rocks climbed up several set of stairs to get to the bridge. It's all well sign posted from Argyle street, George street & Harrington street. Quite easy to get to & stairs were not too diicult either.

Don't just walk on by. Walk across it, below it, even over the top of it. It's a majestic bridge across the world's most beautiful harbour. If you're going to do the Bridge Climb, I recommend dawn or dusk.

Breathtaking experience . If you can only do one thing in Sydney, this is it. To climb the iconic Bridge ticks all the boxes. This was my sixth climb and it felt like my first. It is such an incredible experience. Bridgeclimb are an extremely professional company with very knowledgable guides who, whilst taking safety seriously, make the experience fun and unforgettable. Suitable for ages 10 and upwards. My family bought a gift certificate for my 82 year old dad (what else would you get a fit octogenarian) he loved it and came down on a high. No alcohol prior, as you will be breathalysed as part of the pre climb check. What are you doing still reading this? Just book it!

Iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge. Walk over it.Jog over it.Run over it.Cycle over itClimb it.Great backdrop for selfies. A beautiful architectural frame for photos of the Sydney Opra House (from the harbour's edge to the north west of the bridge). Night photos, sunrise/morning photos, day photos - all good.A Sydney icon that just screams out - This is Sydney, Australia.

One of a kind. We were advised to try this trip and are so happy we did. There are several choices for length of tour. we did the full three hour tour. The employee's are knowledgeable, friendly, and helpful. There was adequate training and use of a simulator. Each step was carefully explained. Our guide, Graham, was funny and was always mindful of the slowest in the group. he gave us lots of information about the city and especially at the top of the arch. We highly recommend this trip. A must do for Sydney. You cannot bring anything up with you. NO CAMERAS Allowed.

Climb the Coathanger!!. Enjoy a twilight tour by climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge any afternoon through summer. The climb is not too difficult and is very safe with the view from atop the Bridge spectacular!!

An icon of Sydney. Th Sydney Harbour Bridge is so iconic - beautiful to look at, easy to walk over from the Rocks to Milsons Point, & there is also the Pylon that you can walk up, which has a museum & fabulous views of Sydney Harbour & the Opera House.

A magnificent view!. I took some friends today to see the Harbour Bridge from the Sydney Opera House as well as from the ferry.It was a beautiful and sunny day. We all had a great time!And I managed to take some great photos as well...
Sight of beauty. Beautiful to watch both on it and at a distance. Makes you appreciate even more when you travel overseas.
You have to climb it. If you can, go climb the bridge for an exhilarating experience and the best views of Sydney - especially in the early evening. A beautiful, iconic bridge.

Fantastic bridge climb. A really fun, exciting and informative experience. The views were amazing and the history and stories added to the experience. Our tour guide Chris Kelly was fantastic. Lots of fun and worth the price for a 3+ hour climb. You even get a free hat at the end!

Spectacular views. Well worth the time and money. Brett is a knowledgeable fun guy. Have something light to eat before the climb if you are doing the morning climb because you won't get back until after 1:30 pm. Take and wear as little as possible because you can't take it with you and it gets warm as the climb progresses. I was a little concerned about the steepness, but it turned out to be very easy. There was an 80 yr old gentleman and he did fine. It was a great ending to our holiday.

Walk the harbour bridge. Walking across the harbour bridge is not only a great way of seeing the engineering excellence of the structure but also the beauty of the city and the harbour itself.i would recommend accessing the south eastern pylon if you want a more elevated view .you could then walk over on the eastern side and return on the western side

Amazing view from up here. We did the bridge climb on Harbour bridge it was really amazing, the staff was very friendly and professional. We learned a lot about how the bridge during the climb it was very interesting. Would love to do it again in the night time.
admiring the view. Great walk across the bridge. Spectacular view on a lovely Sydney day. Even the dogs enjoy the view.
Impressive. You can drive, cycle, walk or take a train across it. The bridge climb is fun but expensive, probably not worth it. Good views of the opera house.
Seen many times and still great. If you visit Sydney, you must see Sydney Harbour Bridge. You may also do the walk over the bridge which gives great views

Walk the bridge. My favorite walk in Sydney. I love the walk usually I go across and then walk down to the Luna Park ferry and have an awesome ride back to Circular quay.If you need to get back to another part of the City you can take the train. There are plenty of views and chances for pictures on the way.

Great to walk over the bridge. Looking for a little fresh air this is a great walk overlooking the bay and the Sydney opera house - take your time have lunch or breakfast do the walk and then a drink or two a great experience and up there with San Franciso. Enjoy

Walk, don't climb, for sterling views and an up-close encounter with one of Sydney's best pieces of engineering. It's hard to confess you love a piece of engineering without sounding like a giant nerd, but I genuinely love this bridge. When I moved to Sydney in my twenties I lived on the north side of it and worked on the south, and the delight of riding over the cycle path every day was a large part of falling in love with the city. In many ways it's an unassuming structure: steel, stone, concrete, tarmac … but its position over one of the world's genuinely great natural harbours and the poetic rhythms of the arched span elevate it to something more. Twice now I have been lucky enough to walk over it on days when it is closed to traffic, and the cathedral-like space under the central arches is as close to a church as I have ever felt on a piece of transport infrastructure.Sure, you can fork out a wad of cash to do the climb. But for exactly no cost, you are free to walk across it any time of day (or night). Make sure you take the east-side path as the west is a dedicated bike path and people will shout at you (rightly so, it's a narrow path and tends to be ridden at speed, so it's like wandering down a freeway). I recommend walking from the north to the south, partly because the views are better, but also because it means you finish your journey at the much better transport hub.Ideally, you should catch a train to Milsons Point Station (about $4) or a ferry to Milsons Point wharf (more expensive). There are any number of things you can do while there, from walk around the harbour edges to visit Luna Park or the peek at the PM's official Sydney abode in Kirribilli (though you get better views from the Manly ferry), but let's focus on the bridge walk. The staircases onto the bridge are well signposted. They mean that it is, alas, not suitable for the mobility impaired (though the train will give you a really good view, and both Wynyard and Milson's Point stations have wheelchair access), but neither is a difficult climb (I've done it when not-long out of plaster for a shattered foot). The stairs put you onto a pedestrian-only path that has a very gentle rise and fall across the bridge's span, before stairs again at the other end that will take you down near The Rocks and Circular Quay tourism areas.Fast walkers will reach the other side in about fifteen minutes, slow walkers may take closer to thirty. And if you stop for photos along the way, it can take longer again.Wire mesh has been erected across the walk to deter jumpers, which can get in the way of selfies, but there is a gap at chest level, so the dedicated can get shots of themselves with the Opera House in the background. Views include the harbour itself, with Fort Denison clearly visible and glimpses of Clark and Shark islands past the Garden Island dockyards, with the full stretch of Vaucluse's mega mansions in the distance. There is a good view of the Royal Botanic Gardens sweeping out to the east of the Opera House, and an excellent view of the Opera House itself, as well as the major part of the city. If you turn around, or walk from the south, the parklands and heritage housing of Kirribilli provide equally attractive views to the north.For people who want more of a tourist experience, the South Pylon contains a small museum and lookout, open during business hours, seven days. The $13 entry fee is vastly more affordable than BridgeClimb, and the displays are more focused on the bridge's role at the heart of Sydney than the flashier interpretations at BridgeClimb. At the time it was commissioned, during the Great Depression, the Sydney Habour Bridge was one of the major sources of employment in the city. A short film and a series of well-chosen and interpreted photos and artefacts -- including some of Harold Cazneaux's amazing photos, he shot most days while the Bridge was under construction, following its path from pylons through to the building and meeting of the arch, then the creation of the span beneath it -- give you a wonderful sense of how important it was in and of itself, not just as a way of joining the two parts of the city.The lookout is surprisingly impressive, with commanding views that make great souvenirs of the day for visitors to the city (I say, having had to pose in about 15 with friends and families who have flown over. But you do get a great shot of the Opera House and harbour from up there.)On a hot and windy day, it can be a very sweaty and oppressive walk, as the steel, concrete and tarmac all combine to increase the heat. But you can cool off at Milson's Point or Dawes Point, depending on where you end up, so this is not necessarily a deal-breaker. It is hard to stay dry on a wet and windy day, but you do have astonishing views of the boats battling their way across the choppy waters, and won't be bothered by large groups. In terms of free things to do in Sydney, this is one of the easiest and most enjoyable.Trivia to end. At the opening ceremony, the ribbon to declare the bridge open was prematurely cut by a right-wing nutter slashing a sabre from his horse. The photo of the incident that graced the pages of the Sydney Morning Herald the following day was taken by Harold Cazneaux's teenaged daughter Joan, who told me years later that she had been immediately pounced upon by the Herald's official photographer, demanding to know whether or not she had got the shot, and then shouting to let her father know that he was whisking her back to the Herald's dark rooms to develop it when she said she thought she had. She went on to become Joan Smith, Dick Smith's mum, and was one of the nicest and most interesting people I have met in my years in Sydney.

Must see - just walk or run it. I never tire of walking or running across this amazing iconic part of Sydney. Taking the train or bus is cool too but you feel more of it when out in the elements. Haven't done the climb yet!
Climbed the Harbour Bridge. My husband &son climbed the Sydney Harbour Bridge & said it was the most marvelous experience they have ever had, they did the full climb & would love to do it again.

You can't beat Sydney Harbour. You can't beat Sydney Harbour and its beautiful Bridge for an unbelievable view.
Bluest of waters and skies make it deservedly the most beautiful in the world.

Make sure to do the bridge climb when visiting Sydney. Although expensive, climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge is an exhilerating experience. The view at the top is simply amazing and the tour guides are very informative and tell you the complete history of the bridge. Highly recommended !!

Enjoy its curves!. Whether you go under it or over it, climb it or walk it, see it during the day or at night, spend money or none, the 'coat hanger' will leave an indelible image on your experience of Sydney.

Very interesting - walk aover the bridge. One of the iconic views of Sydney. With the Opera House so close, getting a good picture including the two sites is a must do. We took the time to ride a train over to the north shore and then walked back across the bridge. It was a breezy day but warm enough to enjoy the sites. Many people were taking the time to walk the upper structure too. A great way to see the skylines of both shores and more of the inner and outer harbour areas.

Second time and still great. This was my second climb up the "Coat hanger" and it still excites me. My eldest daughter (9) came up with me this time. We were a bit unsure how she would take to it but she loved it.The tour guide was brilliant with all the people in the group. There were 14 people from 9 years old up to 70 year old and the tour guide remembered everyone's name and the pace of the climb suited everyone.We did the climb at 10am and were finished in the gift shop by 1.30pm. We purchased 10 photos on a memory stick as well as getting our caps and a couple of gifts in the shop.Brilliant highlight of our holiday.One tip is it goes by height for children and not age so our 7 year old could have gone up.

A sight to behold. We moved from Auckland where it has a lovely bridge but the Sydney Harbour bridge really is awesome. It's got a great museum about how it was build in one of the pylons (the one nearest to the Opera House) and you can either walk across for free or climb up it.

Awesome informative. We appreciated the background info on the "hanger". I especially appreciated the story of Paul "Crocodile" Hogan working on the bridge and talking a suicide "candidate" down from the bridge. This led to a evening news interview. His charisma came thru and the rest is history! Very cool. Thanks to our harbor schooner tour director!

Sydney's top attraction and is totally on the top !!. The bridge adds the glamor to the city and its skyline ... whether you are on it , below it or anywhere around it .. it adds the favor to your view... the "bridgeclimb" is costly but you can take a walk over the bridge or go to the Pylon lookout for uninterrupted views ...

It's the setting!. It's an iconic structure, especially when combined with the setting.I have seen the Bridge over the River Tyne and they do look quite alike (without going into detail) but with the backdrop of the harbour and the Opera House, this makes the harbour bridge quite special.
Sunday Arvo Walk. If you want to see the harbour don't pay to go in the bridge climb, just take the train to Milsons Point and walk back. Awesome views and a great way to work up an appetite

2016Firework new year day and Ausday it was nice. I did not know have to buy ticket to see new year firework and Ausday firwaork . I did not buy so I only watch corner and pice of new year firework . But Ausday, I went to darling harbour seat on the road 3 hr before start fire work . I watched it was fun a lot of people on the street . After finish we could not work on the street so we Waite 1 hr at the bar, waiting to people gone . I am not recommend bring children, it could lost easily . I had my children , I had hard time to track them out .
Great place. The place gets more value when you read the history related to getting the bridge worked out from the decision whether to construct the bridge to the design aspect.

If you're in Sydney you definitely should do the bridge climb!. Can't recommend the bridge climb enough! You learn some good history about Sydney overall and in addition you also get some amazing views of the Sydney skyline.

A definite must . A wonderful view and a great day. They go over everything and give you jumpsuits, hats and headphones. The guides are excellent. You are attached at all times to the bridge, so it's pretty safe. They have free wifi and gift shop bathrooms and lockers for all your stuff. They breathalyzer and check for health conditions. It's very very high.

Fabulous views. You get some fabulous views walking across the bridge. It's an easy walk so good for everyone. You don't need to pay the high cost of climbing the bridge, the bridge tower is open and is almost as high as the centre span and you get a really good view for a fraction of the price.

Great view of the city. Walk over the bridge is a must when you are in Sydney. It gives breathtaking views on a clear day and it is free (compare to the climb). We stopped at the Pylon lookout and it is definitely a great thing to do. There is interesting information on the history of the bridge. Don't miss it!
Family visit. A beautiful attraction for a mild sunny day, the harbor bridge climb not suitable with kids. Overall great view and crowd.
Breathtaking views. Have done the climb twice now and its easy for all ages and the views are spectacular, on the second climb we had a ship sail underneath the bridge and that was a sight.

Brilliant Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. On 24 September 2016 my husband and I took part in the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. Our session started at 9:45am. As we didn’t want to risk our walk by getting lost and arriving late we did call by the day before so we knew exactly where to go. The facilities at the start were very good. A coffee shop, a souvenir shop and toilets too which were clean and in good condition.On the morning I was quite nervous. I didn’t know how I was going to go. I wasn’t sure if I would be scared or if the walk might be a bit difficult for me – At 50 I’m not the fittest person, not a lot of time for exercise in our busy lifestyle! There were 12 people in our group. First we were ushered into a preparation area. It was rather warm on the walk to the climb and my husband and I had already questioned our chosen clothing thinking we might be hot, but we worried about being cold on the bridge. But we were provided overalls and it was suggested we only wear underwear under the overalls and that was perfect for us throughout the walk. In the preparation area there were plenty of change rooms and we were provided with a locker to place our belongings and valuables. We carried the key to the locker around our necks clipped to our overalls. Except for glasses and any necessary medication we were not allowed to take anything else – no cameras, phones, video cameras etc. We were offered all sorts of items which could be clipped to our overalls. These included caps, neck holders for our glasses, handkerchiefs, jackets and raincoats. We were also offered sunscreen. We were not allowed to carry water bottles but there were three drink fountains along the bridge. Apparently special arrangements can be made for special occasions like engagement rings for potential proposals! After we were all prepared we moved to the practise area where we practised clipping ourselves to the ladders and moving up and down the ladders. There was plenty of time and we were not rushed at all. Once we were all comfortable we moved outside to the bridge.For me, the initial climb up the ladders was the hardest part and to be honest it was not that difficult at all. I think it was hard because I was scared. There were approx. three ladders but they were very sturdy, couldn't move and had good handrails and we were clipped onto the ladders. After these ladders we were at the beginning of the arch but on the inside of the bridge. It was a very easy climb from here on in. Up the arch to the highest part of the bridge, okay a few times my calves did feel a little tight (!), across the bridge and down the other side. There was absolutely no rush at all, we were given lots of opportunities to stop for about ten minutes at a time where we could look at the stunning view. We often needed to stop for the guide to take photos, or if we caught up with the previous group we would stop and wait for them to get ahead. Initially we walked on metal grill and you could see through that to whatever was underneath but that was only for the first part of the bridge. Then timber planks were inserted into the grill so you couldn’t always see what was underneath.There was never a moment where I felt so scared I couldn’t continue on. Initially I was a little uncomfortable but as soon as I could see the view I forgot any fear. Strangely I never felt like I was up high or that I might fall as I thought I might have done. We were never that close to the edge where you could look over. You could only look out to the stunning view.Altogether our climb took about three hours. The first hour though was spent in the preparation area.I would recommend the climb to everyone. It was not nearly as difficult as I had anticipated nor as scary. Give it a go! Don't put it off any longer. Even though you might initially be scared, you'll overcome your fears quickly and love the experience!Our guide Darren (Daz) was fantastic. Very patient and full of enthusiasm he made sure we were all comfortable with everything and took great care of us throughout the walk. Thanks Daz!

Sydney Harbour Bridge walk. On a good sunny day, it is very relaxing to walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge, a unique Sydney icon. Construction of the bridge started on 28 Jul 1923 from both sides of the harbour. Alignment for joining in the middle were carried out by a numbers of cable. Marvellous works from the Australian engineers. It was open on 19 Mar 1932. Total length of 1,149M with width of 49M. It has 8 road lanes, 2 rails tracks, 1 cycleway and I pedestrian walkway. There are two entrance/exit to the bridge. From the Southern side, it is along Cumberland St in The Rocks. From the Northern side, it is along Broughton St. in Milsons Point. If come by train, get off at Milsons Point metro station. If come by car, best option is to come to Milsons Point and get the 2 hours free parking along Broughton St.While walking across the bridge, there is nice view of the Sydney Harbour.Day time & night time views of the Sydney Harbour are absolutely beautiful.Each year during Engineering Week in Aug run by Engineer Australia, there is a guided tour by volunteers. If you are interested in the history, construction and engineering aspect of the bridge, you may like to join this guided tour.

Fantastic experience. Did the Climb with family visiting from USA. It was a brilliant experience and I would recommend it to visitors and local alike. You need a basic fitness level. The toughest bit is the ladders at the start and finish but not difficult as long as you're reasonably fit. We are 60 and managed it easily. The views are spectacular and the commentary is really good, interesting history and facts and figures. The safety briefing and equipment is excellent and you wear headphones so you can always hear the leader no matter how far away you are or how much the wind is blowing! This was a great activity and we loved it!

For a thrill of a lifetime....climb the bridge. Being travelers in our 60's we were not sure this visit would work for us, however, anyone with a spirit of adventure, should not miss it.Yes, it is expensive---so, try to include it.

I just love looking at the structure, its enormity and the arch. It is a piece of art.. I watched a programme on the ABC television a few years ago about the construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. I remember it was not straight forward and was built in stages due to some problems. This makes it even more interesting; however it is the gateway to the city of Sydney. It is a monumental icon on world standards.

Sydney City Visit. Stunning Bridge across the harbor. One can get a better view from the ferry if you take one to Manly. Otherwise a walk to The Rocks and the Cruise Terminal will get you a better view. If you take a ferry to Manly you could opt to take a bus back to the City which will go across the bridge.

Harbour Bridge Pylon. Much cheaper than the Bridge Climb is the Harbour Bridge pylon climb, southern end, eastern side. Climbing steps to top outdoor area is well worth the effort. The real advantage is that you can take your camera and get your own photos of the harbour, Opera House, Fort Denison, etc. from this high vantage point.

A great view from the pedestrian walkway. For some of the best views of the harbour including the Opera House, either start your walk in the rocks from the south, or from Milsons Point in the north.Take your time to walk across enjoying the views and stopping to take photo's.The cyclists use the other side of the bridge so you have no fear of bumping inot each other. Don't forget to look up at the amazing architecture of the bridge itself.There is also a large park under the bridge at Milsons Point with more great views back towards the city.You can also climb up to the top of the south east pylon for a fee.
Beautiful bridge. Beautiful to watch during sunset and my friends told me the climb on the bridge is epic. So if you have some money left before you are leaving Sydney, go for it!

For the Climb of Your Life For Sure. After a fifteen hour flight from Los Angeles to Sydney, and a 15 hour time difference to boot, can you think of a better way to beat jet lag? We couldn't! The day was perfect--clear blue skies and about 65 degrees (F). We chose the Express climb because we also had an opera house tour scheduled. The staff were professional, and move tourists through quite quickly. The climb was exactly on time from start to finish. The only difference between the climb we chose and the longer one was that you didn't have as many stops on the way. If you have physical limitations, either choose the really short climb or the longer one.

Iconic Sydney Site. Viewing the Sydney Harbor Bridge is a must for anyone visiting Sydney. Positioned in Sydney harbor connecting the city to the north the arctiecture is something else. I would recommend forking out the money for the Sydney bridge climb, where you are able to discover the history behind the bridge and climb the bridge for a fantastic view over the city skyline. The twilight one is the best. Enjoy :)
must do morning run. The east side of the harbour bridge is the perfect place for a morning jog - free and easily one of the most beautiful views of the harbour, opera house and the heads.

Great view of the Opera House from here. This bridge allows yo to overlook the opera house, and the rest of the city. Just walking through is really easy to get be side tracked by great views on either side.
Must do in Sydney. If your in Sydney, you must find the time to walk over the Harbour Bridge , especially if your heading to Luna Park , it offers great views of the Opera House

Running over and under the bridge . I'm a runner so it was suggested that I run over the bridge. It is spectacular and iconic and easy to get distracted! The views are amazing in every direction. It was windy up there and quite crowded: not ideal running conditions but great nonetheless.

Amazing view from the top. Dave the guide was fantastic, i was very nervous about doing the bridge climb but he suggested i go behind him as we climbed the bridge so he could keep checking i was ok with the height. The commentary was brilliant and the views of the harbour were amazing.We did the 9.25am tour and was worth every penny.

Take the time, pay the money, and CLIMB THIS BRIDGE. It's pricey, I won't sugarcoat it. But I absolutely have no regrets. I chose to climb in the afternoon; with the sun behind you, it'll give great lighting for photos, which they take for you as you can't bring anything along with you. Just so you're prepared, they make you put on their jumpsuit, hat, harness (so you're connected the whole time and shouldn't be afraid!), and they give you a headset by which to hear your guide at all times. It's an easy climb, with long shallow steps, and the pace is slow to accommodate all levels of fitness. But if you are absolutely terrified of climbing it, then just stick to walking across it. That's free! And gives beautiful views.

Adventure. Climbing the Sydney harbour bridge has always been an experience for me too have when in Sydney. What an amazing experience. The day that I climbed it was windy (39kms) but Peter out tour guide was fantastic. From the beginning Peter and all the other members of the team make the safety aspects of the climb paramount for an enjoyable climb for all. Despite the wind I had an amazing experience. The information re the city, the bridge contruction allows one to trully appreciate the history of this country australia. Peter's sense of humour along the way makes for an enjoyable and friendly experience.

Quick and easy to see. Sydney has done a great job in making this bridge a tourist attraction so we had to see it. It's like any other bridge, nothing special but we had it on our list so we did it. Very easy to get to and after 5 minutes of looking at it you are done

Enjoyed the walk across and the views from the Bridge - Grea t!!!!. If you want to experience one of Sydney's greatest attractions go and walk across the Harbour Bridge - check out the structure enjoy the walk and the views, you can catch a train or ferry from the other side of the harbour or just walk back across. I recommend it!If you're really daring you can pay to go on a tour to climb the bridge

Sydney's landmark. A beautiful landmark to have in the city just 15 minutes away. Great to look at over the harbour and doesn't look out of place or intrusive at all. NYE fireworks are stunning and walking across the bridge or climbing it mean amazing views. Attracts lots of tourists and for a very good reason! Definitely a must-see and worth a visit if you're ever in Sydney.

Must see!. The Harbour Bridge in Sydney is a Must see! You can walk or ride your bike and back and you can also go up paying a fee. From the bridge you have a fantastic view of Sydney, the harbour and the magnificent Opera House.

Wow wow wow. We were visiting Sydney and I wanted to do the bridge climb, being absolutely terrified of heights this was an enormous thing for for me. We arrived to do the climb quite early and very afraid we couldn't have been treated better! Our climb leader Pete was absolutely brilliant !!! We were in a mixed age group and he explained everything in a manner we could all understand and accept ! On the climb he was wonderful encouraging but not patronising he was very informative and made it do interesting that we were on the bridge and part way up before we realised it! It was a long hard climb but wow ! So rewarding! I am so glad that I did it , it took a lot of courage but what a reward !!! I can only say that with Pete as our guide we all did it and actually enjoyed it! It was done at a pace that suited us all and we were all so proud if ourselves. Thank you so so much Pete !! We purchased all our photos in a memory stuck they are fabulous and good value ... and yes I would do it again!!

Great walk over the bridge. The best thing about this is it's FREE. We got off at Milsons Point, you literally walk out of the train station, turn right and you will see the steps leading up to the bridge. The walk is about 1km and is an easy walk. Great views and places to stop for photos. If you want you can pay to go up the Pylon tower but personally you get a great view of everything just walking over the bridge for free. You can go off the bridge and walk down into the Rocks which is great too.

Great experience!. Group of 4 friends in sydney decided to do the twilight bridge climb (approx3hours) fantastic & quite educational! Absolute must do at least once - although quite pricey - worth every cent! Felt very safe & secure regardless of the fact it was extremely windy! No need to be super fit for this - its very slow paced & we had an elderly couple in their 80's with us that did it with ease! Very happy with the overall experience! Highly recommended :)

The coat hanger from Sydney. This is a must see and do in Sydney if you want to just look from the Opera House or walk this iconic landmark or tour the inside of the bridge and learn its history (I recommend the inside climb)

This Is A Bucket List Experience. I did the Bridge Climb with my colleagues as an event like this is best shared amongst friends. The Bridge Climb is a highly organized, well executed 3.5 hour event. The climb is energetic and quite unique. It is not often one is able to get a hands-on the inner workings of a piece of spectacular engineering. The view from the apex of the bridge, 400 feet above the water, is breathtaking. On the particular day we did the Climb the wind velocity was about 50 knots which made the experience even more exhilarating. The climbing guide will take photos of your climbing group as well as individual shots for your purchase once you return to the bridge base. If you only have time to accomplish one activity while in town - make it the Bridge Climb.

Iconic. When you are at Circular Quay and have a look at your left and right it makes you feel like either Opera House and Harbour Bridge are fighting for being Sydney's most famous attraction, and the result is unclear. In our case we enjoyed both attractions equally, but the bridge allow you spectacular views of the harbour from a different perspective. You can walk it for free or, if you are seeking for some thrills, you can climb it. Don't miss this great and iconic attraction!
Breath Taking !. When in Sydney one of the 1st iconic structures you want to see is the stunning Harbour Bridge! Always pretty especially when lit up during Vivid Sydney

Fantastic, scenic walk...free.. After leaving my accommodation in the City I decided a walk across the Harbour bridge to be a great idea in the cool of the early morning. Accessing the start of the bridge is a good workout with luggage in tow, however the views of the harbour are spectacular as one walks across. If you are staying in the City, it's easy to get a train ticket at Milsons Point station and return to the City by train...another fantastic experience for Sydney visitors, or walk back again.

What a way to see Sydney. My wife and I both fully enjoyed our Sydney Harbour Bridge climb immensely. The staff really know their stuff and had us kitted out in our climbing gear efficiently and quickly. The views were spectacular and the climb a walk in the park. If your in Sydney Id definitely give this attraction a try.

Walk the bridge. We walked across the bridge (not the high climb) from the city side, and would thoroughly recommend it. The views are amazing and on the other side there are coffee shops and Kirribilli to explore.

Iconic for a reason . The beautiful Sydney harbour bridge, which is a stone throw from the Sydney opera house. Both are right on the Sydney Harbour and also near Luna park and Taronga zoo.
The bridge is just wonderful to take a picture of with the beautiful blue water underneath.
People can climb the bridge, which is something I would love to do.

Top of the World Ma !. One of the most amazing experiences of my life and I did it with my son, who is working in Australia for a couple of years - double whammy! It is safe, secure and scintillating; there was a wobbly moment or two for me, climbing the verticle stepladder to reach the bridge (more scary than the climb) and get down again and walking across a mesh walkway at the top of the bridge (I had a moment's flutter) but seriously folks - this is a must. When you are actually climbing the arc of the bridge nothing phases you....the views, the interesting chatter on the headphones, the stops for photographic opportunity (they take photos, you are only allowed your sunglasses and a hairband on the bridge - no phones or cameras) and the realisation, that this wonderful structure built in the Australian depression was constructed in desperate times by people with no safety harnesses, clothing or hats - is completely mind blowing. I will not dwell anymore on the history - your guide will tell all - it is fascinating. It was raining on the day we went, not too much and it did not spoil the experience in any way. At the top, you are given time to enjoy and breathe in the captivating sites; you can also ask questions and learn that there are many, many sharks in the bay beneath you !! Safety for each and every person on the bridge is paramount and I have never felt more looked after or so sure that nothing was going to happen to me this day. I would do it again in an instant - sunrise or sunset I imagine must be magnificent but it is the sort of adventure to have at any time and feel the same amount of excitement. Go on, push the boundaries - do this spectacular climb - it is Fair Dinkum

The Coat Hanger. The best time to venture out onto the bridge is on dusk or at night, when the sun is setting and the city lights up the skyline. They have security patrolling the bridge at night so you can feel safe and secure... apart from the movement of the bridge as the traffic makes its way across .. There are a few stairs to negotiate so you do require some degree of fitness lol.. I recommend walking to the middle, taking a few pics, then walking back.. if you want to go all the way across, I'd catch a ferry. or at the least one back.

Top of the Sydney harbour. You can walk on the bridge and have a great view of Sydney Harbour. There is no entrance fee. The bridge is a landmark of Sydney and there is a spectacular firework show on the New Year Eve every year.
Regular favourite walk. Get off the train at Milsons Point and walk over the bridge to the city. Well worth it for the magnificent view.

Sydney Harbour Bridge climb. Sunset climb on the bridge. They are very safety conscious and we did a practice climb in-house, we took a breathalyzer and we were tether to the bridge. The climb was not difficult nor tiring. Beautiful view of the city, harbor and the opera house.It was on my bucket list and was so worth it.

Amazing. The bridge climb was amazing. I am scared of hights but knowing i was secured with a wire at all times helped me. And the guide made me comfortable. At the top the wiev is just stunning. A bit expensive and if you want to buy any pictures (you get one for free) they are very pricy. At that price i would expect free pictures.

over-rated ! Charges are too much for just a walk over a bridge. I paid almost AUD300 for 3 hours just to walk up and down a bridge ??? Of that 3 hours, most of the time is spent in a "training room" learning how to hook and unhook carabiners and waiting around for the next stage. Compare that to spending AUD250 on an exhilarating sky diving trip, where much more logistics is involved in terms of per tandem instructor, helicopter rides, coach transfers and a personalized video ??? Just for comparison, a trip to the tallest tower in the WORLD, with tip top experiences thrown in, cost just USD130 per person for the peak hours. I have done all 3, hence I can compare the experiences and conclude that the harbor bridge climb is just too over rated.

Expensive to climb kids must be 8 yrs old. We were so excited to see the bridge as we were wanting to climb but unfortunately we weren't able to as we had a baby with us. Two options to climb but rather expensive. The walk across the bridge using the pedestrian path was the next best thing. Make sure you have your walking shoes on its much further than it looks and can also be quite chilly and loud.

Amazing views, frightening if you don't like heights!. Seems like a "must do" in Sydney. You are harnessed in, and truly could not fall, but it is not for the faint of heart! Beautiful views and an amazing experience. Negative point would be the amount of time the trip takes- they drag it out with stops to take pictures and videos (you cannot bring your own camera) which become very tedious.

Just Gotta Do It!. An amazing experience that is a 'must do' if in Sydney! The views are, obviously, over the top & very safe as well, being a severe acrophobic I had no problem since your roped in & blown away by the views. The pics from up top are worth it & will be classics when on the wall back home. Highly recommend!!!

A pleasant walk with amazing views. ON a SUnday is the best day to do a walk across the bridge as there is less people and markets at both ends,. The views of Circular Quay and the Opera House are excellent.
for all ages and ablility. I booked this as a must for my first visit to Sydney . great views , very safe and the team there are great
Windy but wow!. We went on a really windy day and it was exhilarating. The views are a restricted to one side up the harbour and out to sea. But what a harbour!! Truly spectacular!
Sydney harbour bridge climb. Fantastic experience!!!!!!! Amazing views. Knowledgeable friendly staff who make the climb fun. Well worth the money.

Great View Up Top. The bridge walk is a great way to see one of the best harbours in the world. The walk up to the top is very controlled and you will go through some training prior to being led up the main event. The walk to the top is taken very slowly and not done in one go, so you will have breaks on your way to the top. If you struggle with heights and climbs then you might want to give this a miss, but if you like a stunning view then this is a must!!

Climb the Pylon Lookout!. The Sydney harbour Bridge is amazingly beautiful and given a couple of days in Sydney we had tons of pictures with it! The Pylon on the circular Quay side is a small and relatively unknown museum. It has a nice gallery about the history of the bridge and the effort taken to build it! As an added bonus there's spectacular views at the top.

A walk on the wild side. A central feature of the harbor and the views are wonderful, especially if you have the money ($285 per person Australian) for walking up to the top of the bridge and you have the legs and lungs to climb the stairs. I did not do it but the pictures from fellow travelers were spectacular !!!!

free to see!. Free to see unless you do the bridge climb. Great way to view the city from the middle of the bridge and wonderful walk towards North Sydney. Just me mindful of other pedestrians for safety.

Spectacular! A must see.. Apart from the BridgeClimb tours and the Pylon Lookout, you can also have a nice walk with great views of the harbour. There are many great spots to take selfies of the bridge nearby too.
Worth a visit. Well worth a visit - do the Bridge Climb exceptional great views of Sydney - would highly recommend - do it and cross it off your Bucket List.
Amazing. Loved walking across the bridge, my kids were loving the heights and views, spectacular views of the Opera House and surrounding area. We were so excited to have walked accross.

Walk it !!. One of the icons of the world. Walk the bridge, climb the pylon, breathe in the views and just marvel all around at this amazing harbour view from high up above. Definitely a must do if in Sydney !!
Brilliant. The iconic place to visit in Sydney . Along with the Botonical Gardens for its views and plants. Take a trip to the Blue Mountains and see the three sisters

Wow spectacular . What a truly iconic Australian landmark. I'm in awe every time I'm in the presence of this Goliath construction. This time we decided to checkout the underside at Dawes point park (southern side cbd)There's info plates on the history of the bridge and a huge grassed area to picnic on. The incredible infrastructure is clearly visible from the underside with views to the harbour and north Sydney. Toilets are located nearby and easy access to the rocks district.

Iconic landmark. A visit to Sydney isnt complete without a visit to the harbour bridge. Pleasantly surprised how clean the area was. We sat here in front of bridge before boarding our cruise ship at The Overseas Passanger Terminal and it certainly put us in a relaxed and proud to be Australian mood.

Amazing views. I've been told the bridge climb is spectacular but being time poor and trying to do Sydney on a bit of a budget my 10 year old daughter and I decided to walk across the bridge. We started at the Rocks and walked across. At the first tower we discovered you could climb to the top for $20 for the two of us, watch a movie about the history of the bridge and get a great view from all angles. Once over the bridge we found a great little village to eat in and then we were able to jump on the train and ride back over the bridge with more spectacular views. Well worth it!
Great to look but beware of tolls when you travel there. This is another great icon but should be taken from afar like the Sydney Opera House. Climbing the bridge is not cheap and takes to long.
Good intro to Sydney Harbour. Worth spending the $ for visitors to Sydney. You need to hope you get a day with good visibility for the best experience, check T&C's.
Try the bridge climb for a thrill. Several of our group did the Bridge climb at a cost of $280!! It does have a free pedestrian walkway, which affords a perfect view for photos of the Opera House.

Australian Travellers. The iconic landmark affectionately known as the "coat hanger" is the bridge linking Sydney city with the area of the North Shore and then to the northern coastal highway. Carrying vehicular traffic as well as rail traffic it is also possible to walk across the bridge and also book a bridge climb for spectacular views. Viewed from either land or sea, it is a stunning structure and along with the Opera House is what epitomises Sydney.

A nice easy walk across the bridge. The Harbour Bridge is easily accessible with train stations and bus stops on either side. It only takes about 40 minutes to walk between them, and aside from about 50 steps on each side the rest is an easy flat walk that anyone could do. The views are obviously great, but just make sure you are on the Opera House side of the bridge as the other side is for cyclists only. There are guides there to advise of this at each entrance and also half way across which I thought was good. One of the more pedestrian friendly bridges I've been on.
A trip to Sydney would be a trip to Sydney . A trip to Sydney wouldn't be a trip without seeing this world famous landmark! Spectacular views of this all around the city

walking across. can walk across the bridge by foot and over on the highest beams while watching the ship pass under it dodging it by a few feet, can be done day or night provided the weather is good and its not windy

A unique icon. Photos of this bridge often include the Sydney Opera House in the background this bridge goes across the channel from The Rocks ( a great party place, to Luna park on the other side. guide hikes up and over the bridge are available.

Probably the best bridge in the world...... Ok so some are bigger, wider, taller and newer, but to me this is the icon of all bridges, and today I saw it in real life for the first time ever, and I'm getting in a bit! Made me just stop and stare for a good half hour. Then another half hour over a beer in a bar looking over the harbour. Then I noticed the people walking on the top of it. What's in my beer, I thought? But no, they were real people. Appareantly you can do it, if you've $280 to spare, have absolutely no fear of heights, and are slightly mad. My place was on the ground though, admiring this magnificent structure for what it was originally intended. Perfect.
Awesome views. Worth the $13/person for the great views from the viewing area! It provides a 360 view of Sydney and a perfect view of the Opera House.

Great walk and view. A wonderful walk across the bridge, perfect views, and fortunately the weather was good. Climb the 200 steps up the southeast pylon (13 AUD) for even better views and some history of the bridge.

The Bridge !!. This is a must see to cross off your bucket list. We were going to do the climb but the weather and time factor prevented us from doing so because our visit was a short one. We did travel over it by train and when we saw the walking path we did regret not doing the walk. Seeing this world icon structure was amazing and made you wonder at the amount of work and effort that must have gone into its construction. The massive steel girders. the huge blocks of stone, the amazing number of bolts and how they got the two ends to meet is what you will ponder when you are on this magnificent structure. The sights you see while travelling across The Bridge are amazing so I can only imagine what it must be like to actually do the Bridge Climb......something to cross off the bucket list on our next visit.

The Sights of Sydney. Had a day to kill as the woman had gone shopping so my son and daughters partner walked the bridge. Great views of the city as you walk over and easy to find the walkway. You get the opportunity to explore the history of the Rocks and being a Saturday there was a market. Along the way you can walk up the stairs in one of the pylons at a cost to get a better view, plus you can also go on a bridge walk.We walked to Kirribilli and had a beer or two at the pub which is just up the road on the North Shore. Quaint and friendly with plenty of TV's showing sport. A great distraction from having to go shopping with woman and would recommend for those guys that need something to do while they wait, plus you can also have a beer. What else do you need.

The most amazing event. . The Sydney Harbour bridge climb is one of the most amazing activities. Well worth ever penny spent on our twilight climb. We thoroughly enjoyed the three hour session from 3:45 to 6:45. Our guide Aaron was a talking walking book of knowledge. It is truly an eye opener from the initial fit out of personal kit with all trimmings. The view is beyond belief in a safe and secure environment. Plenty of photos taken By our guide from altering vantage points. Apart from the tour, the bridge itself, tower climb and history identifies that the Sydney Harbour bridge is a magnificent engineering feat. This is truly the highlight of our year. Get into it. This will be an event we do again.
what a sight. we didn't climb sydney bridge but had great views off it from the wharf and when we took the boat to manly.
Citys landmark. It is fantastic. Harbour bridge dominates the harbour offering breathtaking views. Higly recommended.

Fantastic site every time. Spent a number of days either side of wok in Sydney and every time I took the ferry the bridge looked better and better. Truly an iconic site and at night the ferry ride is well worth it to see both the bridge and Opera House lit up against the backdrop, My only regret was not walking up the bridge, if I am ever back that will be top of my bucket list
Awesome . A awesome site and a fantastic feat of engineering. World famous and worth a trip to Sydney just for this.

Fantastic views from the tower.. This is defiantly something I recommend doing. There are great views from the tower over the harbour, opera house and city. The museum in the tower was also good and informative. Even if you don't want to pay to get to the viewing platform just walk across it, have fish and chips on the other side and catch a ferry back. It's cheap and worth a look.
Great job in world crisis time.. This bridge is huge and australian coverment find very good thing to faith against wordglobal economic crisis,people find a work and income in the crisis time

Spectacular view from above. While the view from below was spectacular giving you a refreshing sight of the city, especially the panoramic connection of the Harbour bridge and the Sydney Opera house, the view from above makes one wonder in awe. Pretty much a very, very nice view for but a bit pricey place.

Bridge Climb. Wow...what an amazing site. I must admit, I was somewhat uneasy about this climb due to fear of heights. I cannot stress how thankful I am that I followed through with the climb. Our guide, Sean, was fantastic with everyone and was extremely encouraging to those of us who were a little uneasy. If you have the opportunity to climb this bridge, do not pass it up.

Great walk over an iconic bridge. We took a ferry over to Luna Park and walked up to the top of the hill to cross the bridge. It was great to see Sydney harbour from the bridge. Loved walking across. You can also go into one of the pylons for interesting facts on the building of the bridge and some excellent views, but we didn't bother as our hotel had spectacular views of the harbour, bridge and opera house.
very memorable climbing experience. we had a day climb tour and we enjoyed it very much , the views , the experience every thing was amazing .if your are in sydney don't miss it . its unique

Through a photographers eyes. I have lived near Sydney for forty years and only recently started to focus on the Sydney Harbour Bridge. This was brought about by spinal injuries and the inability to carry heavy photography gear. We recently changed our focus and started to embrace Sydney and its early years with Heritage locations in the Rocks. I always loved Circular Quay and the bridge was in the background, people crossed it, climbed it and went under it but it wasn't in my thoughts. We have been developing Sydney photography walking tours under Australian Photography Tours and the Gwondana banner. In doing so as I ventured through the back streets and alleys of Sydney I noticed that the bridge nearly always appeared at the end of a street. We walked round the pillars and included it in our general tours without really focusing on it. That all changed with one photograph. Now I travel to Kirribilli, along the north ans south harbour foreshores. We catch the little Sydney ferries and travel to different areas of the harbour. Everywhere we go there is something new. Ten days ago I was at Kirribilli having breakfast after photographing the bridge from a totally new angle. Now besides the Rocks and CBD we are in the process of creating photography tours on water using the bridge as the hub. As for refreshments, there are so many places to go, it's a smorgasbord. Experience a tour on the harbour as you check out our bridge. Call me anytime.

Loved the experience!!. What can I say! Was amazing! I chickened out of the full walk but the half one was fantastic!The guide was funny and informative! Would love to go back one day and do the full thing!Thank you!

Include the bridge in your holiday. I live in NSW but would like to urge all travellers to Sydney to make the Bridge a part of their itinerary.Of course many visitors sign up for the bridge climb, and this is a great way to enjoy the Bridge, and the city and harbour views. TripAdvisor reviewers who have done the climb seem to give it a high approval rating.Another way to enjoy the Bridge is to walk across it to Kirribilli on the north side of the harbour. There are some nice restaurants over there. It is also possible to continue your walk to Anderson Park and Lavender Bay. Also on the north side of the harbour you will find the North Sydney Olympic Pool and Luna Park.Great views are available from the top of the south eastern pylon of the Bridge.If you can not manage these then it is possible to travel over the Bridge by train. Another option is to pass under it by taking a west bound ferry to Darling Harbour or Parramatta.However, it would be a shame to travel to Sydney and not get up close to this iconic and central structure.

Iconic Tourist Spot . This destination is an iconic Australian tourist spot for a good reason - the scenery is beautiful and the architecture is stunning and unique. When in Sydney, a visit is a must. Highly recommend walking across the bridge for an amazing view of the city
I love bridges. It was a lovely bridge, the walk over is wasn't bad you get a great view of the Opera House day or Night. If you want some great pictures to show friends and family visit the Bridge.

A Busy Bridge. Walk, car,bus,train on this great iconic bridge. Fly over it or cruise under it- spectacular always . Built in the 1930s the Sydney Harbpur Bridge was ' weathered ' many Governments and Political persuasions. An amazing amount of traffic uses The Bridge from Sydney's North Shore to the City and VV daily.However the traffic most days seems to manage very well this historic structure without too many problems.Probably one of the most photographed icons in the world would be the SHB.

Great Views of the City and a fun and interesting experience. While it takes several hours, its well worth it. The pace is great and plenty of time to take in the amazing views. Even if heights is an issue, this is easy. Don’t stop doing it because you are scared of heights. The walk is not strenuous so again, people of all ages and ability can do it. You can’t come to Sydney and not climb the bridge.

Exhilerating!. I had an incredible time at the Harbour Bridge as I was blessed to do the climb. I did the twilight climb which gave amazing views of the sunset over the harbour.This is an incredible experience. You aren't allowed to bring your camera, but the guides take photos for you to purchase.I highly recommend it!

Walk on your own!. Lovely walk across to Kirribilli where you can visit Luna Amusement Park (check times) and walk around the cute town. Lots of great little restaurants and produce market. Very quiet parks make a lovely space for a quiet picnic away from the hustle of the harbour.
Fun. We walked and drove over the Bridge and viewed it from the Opera House. It's stunning. It's typifies Sydney
Great sight . Such an iconic part of Sydney. We have seen the bridge from various angels, there are great walks around by the water. Highly recommended
Fantastic experience!. Such a great experience...an awesome 21st birthday present! Great scenic views from the top. Not an overly difficult walk

Great Experience. A bucket list item to tick off. If you have the time, an amazing thing to do. We had a guide that made our climb interesting and informative. Great views out to Sydney Heads and towards Parramatta.

stroll across for awesome views. I did not have the courage to do the bridge climb but did stroll across the harbor bridge for awesome views!there is also an opportunity to climb one of the pylons ($13.50) which is a more affordable option to the bridge climb. pylon or no pylon the walk across is great exercise and will give you an amazing vantage point... especially if there is a cruise ship in the harbor

Beautiful Bridge. This historic and magnificent bridge is juxtaposed nicely with its fellow iconic symbol of Sydney, the Opera House. This structure allowed Sydney to become the great city that it is and the architect behind it was a man ahead of his time. The bridge is a great walk and you need to do it just as you need to walk the bridges in Paris, Florence, Rome and NYC.

Best of Sydney. The bridge is my favourite part of Sydney and to me eclipses the Opera House. If you can't afford the rather expensive price of climbing the bridge a walk across it is a good substitute. The Bridge is rich in history and learning about how it was made is very interesting. We took the opportunity to climb the bridge on a very sunny and picturesque day and it was one of the best experiences of my life. I would definitely recommend climbing the bridge and taking the view of the Harbour and the rest of Sydney.

Must do in Sydney. If you visit Sydney, walking across the bridge is a must do - it's a great way to look at the whole harbour area and its lovely on both sides of the bridge. At sunset it's awesome with great views.Kirribilli is on one side with some cute cafes pubs and a market on Saturday mornings, and of course the city on the other side. Whenever I stay nearby I make it a point to walk across in the evening to see the city lights go on and watch the sunset!
Sydney Sights. Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of Sydney's Icon which is known throughout the World. A must see when visiting Sydney and be brave to do the bridge climb, its awesome.

Once in a lifetime experience. Wow! Climbing the bridge was wonderful. I say this even though it poured rain for some of the climb up And down but not while we were on top. The staff is outstanding. Friendly, attentive, knowledgeable, funny. As a "senior" I had some concerns but we went slow and steady and all the safety equipment and thorough preparation alleviated any qualms. Just do it!
Historical walk. Try to go for the tour if you can as it brings you to the bowels of the bridge and you get to hear about the history on how it was built.

Ticked off the list. One thing I wanted to do while visiting Sydney was get up close and see this amazing marvel of a bridge and I'm glad I did. The walk over the top is over priced but we did the Pylon lookout instead (search for this and look into it, 5/5 stars!!!)

Exciting activity. Went on the bridge climb with my 18 year old twins. I don't like heights much but thought I should challenge myself and also thought so many people do this it can't be that bad! It is extremely efficient and well run .If you think you are going to smuggle anything up there think again! I was disappointed I had to take off my Nike fuel band, I wanted all those extra steps ! They essentially body search you after you take your clothes off and put on the jump suit with a metal detector. No go pros of cameras could be smuggled through. Glasses have to be secured with special straps that are attached to your outfit, you are given a special handkerchief that is secured to your wrist. Clearly they want nothing to fall onto an unsuspecting foot passenger or car below you. It is impressive you well thought out it all is. You are very safely clipped in the whole time.My issue is how very expensive the whole process is . They say it took almost 10 years to set up and get the approvals which I believe but they are making a lot of money now . It was a lit if fun, we had a gorgeous day for it too. I felt I really got to see Sydney as well, but at nearly $300 per person it was pricey! If you don't have an issue with spending that much go for it!We did the express climb which is quicker than the full climb but the same price . It did not feel too quick lots of time on the bridge and to be honest the pace was fairly slow. No one on our group ( of many ages and sizes) seemed to be struggling with anything .Our leader was calm, young and experienced , she was patient with the photographs she took and did a good job.

bridge walk half way. If you are scared of heights but still want to try this attraction, then do as we did! Go only half way. Its still scary and impressive but you dont get stuck up there for ever! :D I enjoyed it. The views were great, the tour guide well knowledgeable, informative and experienced. She loves her job, we could say. Very interesting history of the bridge makes it a bit easier to not look down under you! :) Got a nice picture as a group FOR FREE! which we wouldnt need one of 2 of us if we knew, haha. So we have got two lovely pictures from up there.Its very windy although it was rather still day down below. But you get a full equipment to keep yourself safe and comfortable - just like cosmonauts :) Yes, we would recommend this although it is pricey.
Can't come to Sydney and not walk this treasure. Easy walk over the bridge, great views. Especially sunset and the opera house. Loads of people walking ...tourists and locals alike. Must do this

We climbed the bridge, yay! . I did this climb with my 16 year old daughter and it will be a memory for life even if we have travelled "everywhere" (45 countries). It's a really fun day out. The security instructions and outfit is top top. You get to do a little trial climb up and down a ladder before, you are breath tasted, everything is attached, caps, glasses, clothing and also you to the bridge by a wire. We were introduced to our group so everyone warmed up and we chatted all the way up and down. Our guide was outstanding with his knowledge and jokes ( even if he was from NZ!:). It's not a hard climb. If you can climb up and down a ladder ( as you have to to get up on the bridge to start with and at the end) and are not afraid of heights and can walk for 2 hours you can do it. We had a retired older couple in our group who were absolutely fine. Because you climb the bridge with your own legs it becomes a memory for life, a small achievement for a normal person and the view is just beautiful.
Big. Very big and impressive and difficult to avoid really. A genuine landmark but really, it's just a big bridge.
Amazing. Watching it or walking along it is a moment you will remember your whole life. Maybe you will go and take photos everyday you stay in Sidney.
Bridge walk. Enjoyed the climb over bridge, amazing history great views friendly staff. A bit overpriced given the amount of tours run daily obviously people are prepared to pay.

The best experience on top of Harbour Bridge. It was my boyfriend birthday celebration. We climb to the top of Harbour Bridge. It took about 2 hours return. It was really worth it. We can see the magnificent view of Sydney. The history of Sydney and everything just awesome

Nice Walk.. The Sydney Harbour bridge is iconic around the world.It looks great and it is great to have a nice long walk acrossI walked accross the bridge to go to the Luna Park and it was a great walk with some great sights along it especially of the Sydney Opera House.You can pay to do the Sydney Harbour bridge walk, which takes you to the top of the bridge on a supervised tour which is a great experience and more to see but unfortunately like any tourist attraction they charge far too much and also don't allow cameras or phones in order to make money from an overpriced photo at the top.
Fun and enjoyabke. It was a fun adventurous journey with friendly staff that allowed anyone of any age to have fun. Amazing views that allowed you to see sydney in a different light.
The famous Sydne Harbour Bridge. Most people around the world, watch the new year fireworks on this bridge every year , life or on TVs . So we came to watch the real bridge.

Beautiful harbour bridge . The bridge looks impressive from opera house side. I was told that u can walk up to the top of the bridge which take hours, assuming u don't have fear of heights. It's very good for photo taking.
Nice to see, great to climb.. Seen from about anywhere in the area, an icon. Best to reserve a climb day/time if want to do that. $$$

On top of the bridge. Having being to Sydney many times from Perth our last trip driving our niece's vehicle across Australia via Broken Hill, Dubbo and Jenolan culminated in a Sydney Harbour Bridge climb and Vivid. The climb was not a bucket list thing but it was close and although both being in our late 60's we were a little apprehensive we 'bite the bullet' and plunged in or up. One of the best things we have done for years and resulted in significant bragging right with the grandkids for years. Reasonably expensive but worth every cent. The time, effort, infrastructure and safety aspects required well explains the overall cost. If you have any doubts just do it you will love it. One of an Australian's ultimate dreams to clime THE BRIDGE not matter where in the country (or overseas) you come from.
Beautiful bridge. It's a very pretty bridge...I walked on the bridge, is a pretty long walk but a nice one... You can see this from opera House and also from ferries that you take from circular quay
Awesome. We got the best views looking from the Opera House, at the Opera Bar. What a bridge, no other bride quite like it anywhere. We went across the bridge to get to North Sydney.

Great views but air is polluted - not good for running or walking. Walking along the bridge is a great way to see the Sydney iconic landmarks, but I wouldn't do it often - it's really noisy on the bridge, the air gets really polluted from all diesel engines and walking in a fenced off corridor with barbered wire and security guards kind of distorts the experience.

Bridge Climb. Must do at least once, if you have verdigo I wouldn't recommend it. As you come out onto the initial walkway under the bridge you walk over a roadway, the platform is steel mesh and gives you a strange feeling if you look down. The climb has some a interesting parts and great views of the Opera House. On a rainy day we had to walk under waterfalls from the roadway on the bridge as the water falls through the drains. Don't bother going if you have been drinking as everyone is breath tested beforehand.

Humongous. What an iconic piece of Australia right? You hear Australia and your mind goes right to Sydney. To see the bridge up close and personal, it sends shivers down your spine to be actually there. Gazing up upon the bridge you realise how small you really are. And to put it into perspective, you can zoom your cameras into the tiny ant like figures on the bridge that are people. A must see tourist attraction for tourists and locals alike.

Do the bridgeclimb!. This is an amazing experience- very safe and accessible, with the best views of the area. We went at sunset which made it even more magical, as we got daylight, stunning sunset and then watched the city light up! The Bridgeclimb is professionally run, with safety and fun both high priorities. Complimentary photo included. The whole experience lasted about 3.5 hours so anything but rushed! No difficult climbs or narrow ledges but you need a head for heights to enjoy the panorama.

walk the pylon. Due to the cost of doing the Habour Bridge walk, we opted for the pylon walk, we got the same great views at a fraction of the price and with only 200 steps to climb instead of 1337 it was no brainer. excellent value for money. It also has a little museum to look around and a film to watch which is also included in the price

Walk the bridge it's awesome. Did the walk from North Sydney to Darling Harbour and wow it takes in some special places. Nilson's Point, quaint park, up the stairs and over the Bridge, through the Rocks, across towards Barangaroo and then onto darling harbour, simply stunning Sydney, 1 hour of pure joy.
Famous icon. This famous Sydney harbour bridge is a wonderfull icon of Australia Paul hogan use to paint it before he became famous.

The bridge that helped shape a city. One of the most glorious bridges in the world. Did you know the four beautiful pylons, two on each end of the bridge, don't hold the bridge up - they in fact hold the bridge down, stopping the ends of the archway from lifting up. It's Ridiculously Expensive to do a bridge climb to get onto if the arches, if you do it though you won't be disappointed you did, though you'll be able to climb easier for all the money you just spent leaving your pocket and no longer weighing you down. Though sometimes they do some good prices on the redballoon Australia website. The bridge can be driven on, cycled on, walked on, train ride on. If you're going to drive across it, be careful it's five or six lanes in one direction with three or four in the opposite direction, the direction of the lanes changes with the led signage depending on peak demands and it's very confusing where to take your off ramp beyond the bridge as there's just cars everywhere. There is a vehicle toll fee to head into the city, prices of the toll change throughout the day depending on peak times. Tolls in Sydney are done through an electronic tagging system that is attached to the inside of your windscreen.

Sydney Harbour Bridge, Sydney, AU. Sydney Harbour Bridge, Sydney, AU is an amazing sight and a grand adventure if you are up to a hike. You can climb the bridge on a tour which takes you to the top for an amazing view of all of Sydney. Learn about its history from a brief video in one of the towers or ride or walk along the main roadway to cross the bridge.

Iconic structure offering a BridgeClimb & the Pylon Lookout, hosting exhibitions. Climb the Sydney Harbour Bridge for the ultimate Sydney experience - see panoramic views from the top of an Australian icon.
WOW. Walked across the bridge (about 1.5km) from Milsons Point and back to Circular Quay (along the free walkway). Fantastic experience, great photos and very gentle elevation. Well worth the effort.
Cruise prot of call. What a fabulous trip and sailing into Sydney harbour is well worth getting up on deck to see the views all around you are awesome.

Go Climb It!. We did not end up doing this, but I researched it and you can climb this bridge at different times in the day. One is a daylight climb, the other a sunset one.
