Only in Australia could you be allowed to climb onto bridges like this one! Really cool. Only downside is the cost. For our little group of three it became pretty pricey and when my teenage daughter said that she wasn't into the idea I somewhat gladly dropped the idea. You can find online what the cost is.

Agoraphobe loved it.... I had my doubts about the Bridge Climb because I'm afraid of heights; however, I was totally fine. You're clipped in start to finish using rock climbing tools. I had the thought at one point that I could actually TRY to jump off the top and I'd be unsuccessful because I was so securely tethered. This is an iconic bridge and the climb is its signature event. Try it unless you're clinically agoraphobic. If nothing else, it's worth it for the picture you get of yourself with the Opera House in the background!

An iconic bridge - best in the world.. There are other bridges in the world with a similar design but this is special. Coupled with the harbour and Opera House, it makes for a stunning city - wonderful to see whether by a ferry or a meal under the bridge, this is unique.
climb up to the top. climb up to the top of the towers near the rocks to get a great view of circular quay and the harbour

Walk the bridge. Walked the bridge , took the ferry back, nice round trip way to do it, it's can be breezy ! The bridge is an icon, walking acros it a Murphy, but sorry Sydney the Brooklyn bridge is a nicer walk, with more info and things of interest, and it's a lot busier , of course Brooklyn it does not have Sydney harbour that's hard to beat.
Must do Sydney event !!. Sydney is seen in all of its glory ....the yachts, the harbour below , the ferries and other boats , the Opera House, Botanical Gardens, the Cityscape.....

Harbour Bridge Climb amazing. My wife and I both around 60 years of age completed the bridge climb recently. The experience and the views are magnificent. There are a lot of ladders and steps but you don't notice as there are frequent stops to take in the beauty of the harbour. I am not a great lover of heights but never felt safer. Very professionally run.

Harbor Bridge Climb. I have climbed the bridge twice. Loved it that much I took my children and made it a family day out. Great experience for all ages Best times would be Sunrise or Sunset so worth paying the extra. Simply Magic !!!!!

We went on a sunset climb .. The climb was very easy and safe , you are clipped to a safety line when on the bridge.The view over our city is excellent . The sunset was spectactular . A must do if you are visiting Sydney

Worth the climb. This is a very well run and organised experience although it is not cheap, you can get some good deals depending on the time of year day ect. We did a sunset climb and the views of the city and opera house were just stunning, with the sun setting in the west over the blue mountains. you have an uninterrupted 360 view, but having said all that it is not a pleasant climb if the weather is poor , such things as fog and rain make it very hard to see the views, and they do not cancel climbs for those reasons, It is very safe but I would recommend an average level of fitness and comfortable walking shoes. go and enjoy one of the wonders of one of the great cities in the world!

Bridge views. One of the most beautiful bridges ever built, the views of 360 degrees show you the different landscapes out our city. A must at night time with all the city and North city lights on. A BIG must is the Harbour Brige walk. This is not an exhausting walk as it looks and the sunset climb is a must as the different colours of the going down of the sun. As I said this is not an exhausting walk as described in the lecture and procedures you do before the climb. You Will Not Be Dissapointed.

A wonderful walk. Walking across Sydney Harbour Bridge is a daily occurrence for many people; either on their way to work, home again, or just the sheer pleasure of it. The eastern walkway is pedestrians only, the exhilaration of the spectacle wonderful, and never fails to excite me having walked the Bridge very many times. So much to see and experience. This is the walk, NOT the climb, another whole adventure.

Walk across for free!. This is a magical bridge, beautiful from every angle. You don't need to spend $200 on the bridge climb if you don't want to...just start at the Kirribilli end (plenty of parking or come in on train and get off at Milsons Point), ascend the steps and walk 20 mins to The Rocks...the views are marvelous. Take lunch in the Rocks and walk back!

Stunning views. Walking across the Sydney Harbour Bridge truly is a lovely thing to do.Easy walk, breathtaking views and if you time it right on the weekend you can end up at the Markets in the Rocks.

Walk on the wild side. Sydney offers so much that even locals take time to see the best of it. We did recently.Long-time residents, we shamefully had never walked across the bridge so on a stunningly sunny Sunday Spring morning we left the Milsons Point markets and ascended to the footpath on the eastern side. From here the views down the harbour and over the Opera House are stunning and un-encumbered by the sound of trains which run the western side of the bridge. Other than the 20 or so steps either end, up from Milson's Point station and down into the Rocks, the walk is level and easy, taking just 15-20 minutes, depending on the number of stops you make to enjoy the amazing views. In taking the bridge pathway, joggers, couples and families with kids can enjoy some of Sydney's best views and experiences absolutely free. Highly recommended.

The Sydney Bridge Climb. Hi all who are interested in the Sydney Harbour Bridge climb - I did the climb shortly after it started and I can thoroughly recommend the experience - it is an unforgetable experience

Climb. You cannot travel half way round the world and not climb the famous bridge. Book well in advance , and although my wife wasn't sure if she would do it , ended up so very chuffed with herself , and thanks to the guide who took our climb for looking after her .

Amazing. We had an excellent day doing our bridge climb. I'm scared of heights, but felt very safe the whole climb. The views and the whole experience is amazing. The guides make you feel very comfortable and safe, they are also very entertaining and very knowledgeable about the bridge and the city. This climb really was an unforgettable experience
Great views of the city and harbour. Take the time to walk across the Harbour Bridge. Spectactular views of the city, the Opera House and the harbour. The most beautiful harbour in the world.
A must. Definitely a must when one is in Sydney. I took a ferry and got the chance to go under it, with the view of the Opera House in the background Amazing!

Climbing the bridge. Really glad we did it even though it cost an arm and a leg. I didn't know it was on my bucket list but it was. Getting ready and preparing took a little too long. I would like to have climbed a little faster to get a work out. However it was a lovely day and just warm enough with the fleece they gave us. Very organised and mega safe. Lovely staff.
Wow. Sydney harbour bridge is a beautiful sight, Syneysiders and visitors alike marvel at this spectacular sight every time we see it.

Trip to Sydney. Cross the bridge by feet and enjoy the amazing view on Sydney Opera and harbour. Take the Harbour City Ferrie from Milsons Point Wharf to Darling Harbour to have a view on Harbour bridge from sea-side.
Bridge Climb. Fantastic experience, but not cheap. Fantastic guide Jason. The complete operation is so professional, slick and could not be bettered.

A cheaper way to "climb" the bridge. The Sydney Bridge Climb is very popular but also very expensive ($300/person) and also not necessarily appropriate for everyone, e.g. People scared of heights, the infirm, etc. A great alternative for a similar view at a much lower price ($13/person) is the viewing platform inside the south-east pylon of the bridge. This is the large stone tower, closest to the Sydney Harbour. Enter it by walking across the bridge on the side closest to the Opera House. The entrance is clearly marked, and the climb is pretty reasonable (200 stairs). En route to the to the top, there is great information on how the bridge was built. At the top, enjoy 360-degree views of the city!

Oz icon.. We walked to this from Darling Harbour, under it there is plaque detailing the bridges' history, a little further on you'll find cannons with a historical plaque on them, that area will give you some good photos on a sunny day.If you ever get the chance to walk across it then do so we didn't manage it this time but I have previously done so, on one side you'll see the tourist view of the Opera house and harbour turn the other way and you'll see the industrial side of the city, two contrasting views of Sydney. Australians are proud of this monument and you can see why.
Great enduring bridge. Amazing site after all the years it has been in service. I was too chicken to do the climb but if you are healthy and adventurous it has great views.

Fantastic walk. Took the train to Milson's point this morning then walked across the harbour bridge to the rocks and Walsh bay for lunch. The views across to the Opera house and harbour are fantastic as well as seeing the structure of the bridge up close. It is a feat of engineering and you can learn more from the museum in the pylon. It'd seriously recommend climbing the steps in the pylon as the views at the top are magnificent. The museum inside is full of facts about the history of the bridge and even our kids were fascinated. We walked through the rocks to Walsh's bay where we had a delicious lunch at bar cycle. Great morning.

Pylon tour. We chose to do the pylon tour as the bridge climb is very expensive. At a mere $13 per adult you can climb the steps to the top of one of the pylons and be rewarded with amazing views of the harbour. There are 200 steps but half way up there is a museum, small shop and toilets. It is not a taxing climb. The views are superb

You have to do the Harbour Bridge Climb Tour!. The Harbour Bridge Tour takes about two hours, but is worth the climb to see the Bay and it's surroundings. Do it in the day time so you can appreciate the sights! It's not cheap, but worth it. They give you orientation, suit you up for the weather, radio for guide directions, then hook everyone (group 10) up to a cable through out the walk so you don't fall off the bridge. It's pretty high, but the cable made me feel secure. It gets windy, and it drizzled on day I went. It was a great thrill and view. Be Australia, this is the least to do on your trip.

A Magnificent Structure. This Bridge is the biggest single span bridge in the world and was completed in 1932 when the world relied heavily on manpower, brilliant engineering and limited mechanical equipment, all of which when compared by today's technology and equipment, should regard its construction as being in the same category as that of the Taj Mahal. It's an experience just to walk across it and even more spectacular to climb it to the top. While there, pay a visit to the Bridge Museum and absorbed some of it's history. Highly recommend a visit to Australias' first icon.

AMAZING!. Climbed the Sydney harbour bridge last year in May. We did it while Vivid was on. I'm petrified of heights but I'm so glad I was brave enough to climb it. The view at the top makes it all worth it! Guide was lovely & informative. She checked on me to make sure I was okay throughout the entire climb. Climbing the bridge will forever be one of my fondest memories.

Walking through the famous Harbour Bridge. Enjoy the famous coat hanger by walking from Milsons Point to the Circular Quay. Stop to have lunch at the top deck of the Glenmore Hotel to enjoy the food and the view of the Sydney Opera House sails. Please note that the right side of the bridge are for bikes only. The bridge walk path can be busy during lunch. Give courtesy to each other.

Great view. i walked on this bridge from the rocks to the other end and it was worth it. If you're interested in seeing the opera house from a different angle than up close this bridge provides that view.
Never stops being interesting. Visited the bridge from road, by air and be sea this trip. Never gets old, and more enjoyable as the harbour was calm.

Loved the view. Could not get on it but only saw it from a multitude of directions including from the ferry. The view is breathtaking especially with the blue sea and the blue skies on a clear day. Very appealing architecture from the river and also from the road when travelling through it.

Top spot and great view. If you have time catch the train to Milsons Point station and follow the signs to the Harbour Bridge walkWhen you get almost across you can climb the stairs inside the south pylon to the very topThe view 360 is wonderful and a damn side cheaper than any of the other viewing towersStairs aren't to bad not for the disabled though , we left my Mum in her wheelchair watching the harbour -nobody stole her
The view. Take a walk, enter the Polygon. Fantastic view over the city.Did not do the bridge climbing but probably even better experience done that.

Bridge climb. Absolutely amazing. On a clear day the bridge climb is a must on your bucket list. Although im scared of heights (even on a step ladder) i felt totally safe on the bridge climb. You have a saftey strap on at all times. The climb is very professionally done. You cant take camera or a phone with you so the extra fee to get the professional photos done is a must. I would say this was one of the greatest experiences of my life.
Excellent. An excellent walk. An amazing arial view of the harbour. More 400m span bridges in Sydney. More bridge walks.

Walk across the Bridge. Walking across the bridge is not a problem. The staircase is easy to find. You will be rewarded with a lovely view of the Sydney Harbour and skyline. It is popular with locals who walk, bike, and jog across it daily. The SHB is much smaller / shorter than the Brooklyn Bridge and certainly less congested. ENJOY!
the most iconic attraction of sydney. Other than having a beautiful view of the bridge from the circular quay, going there and walking on it is an experience by itself
Midnight walk. It was an awesome and safe night to walk the bridge at midnight with my bestie. The scenic views as well as the silent night and the lights were breath taking.

Very imposing and attention grabbing symbol of Sydney. This is an iconic symbol of Sydney. To experience it best I recommend the Bridge Walk. This is an organized tour that enables you to climb up onto the structure an walk right to the very top. The view from there is amazing.

It's obvious you won't miss it. Central iconic structure like the opera house.. It's something no one misses seing in Sydney. U can walk across it and see spectacular views from north and south side ... Or can climb up with a tour which is about 200 dollars and takes up half a day.

WOW and don't miss the climb. This is amazing to see from a distance and many take pictures when they take the ferry. But the real thrill is when you decide to climb this bridge to the top. I am not talking about walking thru but the climb up the parabola. Don't miss it.

It's a bridge. It's a bridge, yes it is huge 1.3k long, yes you get a great view of Sydney but it is still just a bridge! The $280 fee charged to walk up it is nothing short of disgracefull but for as long as tourists pay it they'll get away with this crazy fee!!

A functional and yet beautiful bridge. We passed through the bridge on the way north and then to Blacktown in the west of Sydney.It was crowded in the mornings and evenings both ways as traffic goes in and out of the city. The bridge gives vantage view of the Sydney harbour but the bridge itself was beatifully designed and built. There are not that many steel structures that can qualify to be called beautiful but the Harbour Bridge is one of them.

Brilliant Architecture, Gorgeous Bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the main attractions of Sydney, and this is with good reason. The place looks gorgeous both day and night, and is an important transportation link in addition to being an icon of the city.
Great views. Thoroughly enjoyed the bridge - both walking and riding the train. Did not go up the tower, but took many photos of the harbor looking east, the opera house and CBD.

Beautiful views from Four Season Hotel Sydney!. Excellent view from our room at the hotel of climbers who we then met at cocktail hour back at the Four Seasons Hotel! We slept with our xcutains open so we never missed a boat coming or going!!

Bridge Walk. Even in the rain this was amazing. The guides are fantastic and if you are afraid of heights you will forget how high up you really are. The pictures are worth the climb. The group picture is included in the ticket price.

Visit the Pylon for the views!. If you don't want to do the bridge climb, go to the southeast pylon and for a few dollars, you can take the stairs to the top of the pylon and take pictures of the magnificent view. (You can't take a camera on the bridge climb).

Climbed the bridge-experience of a lifetime. If you have the time, do climb the bridge in Sydney.
It is an amazing experience, and you will see the best views of Sydney.
The whole experience is very well organized, and there is no need to be afraid. I do not like heights and I did just fine.
Nice if you like that kind of thing. It's an old bridge over a very pleasant harbor. You can take walk across the top although its quite expensive.
Bucketlist. This was the highlight of my trip in Sydney. Absolutely amazing views and made some great memories. I will suggest this bridge climb over and over again.
Spectacular view!!. You can see the view of the bridge and opera house at Circular Quay NSW in Sydney. It looks gorgeous in the day and night. Just marvelous!!

The Bridge from Down Under. The Sydney Harbour Bridge majestically welcomes you to Sydney, Australia. It is a marvelous structure and it's image changes so wonderfully during each part of the day and night. Although, we didn't do the bridge climb, we walked under this magnificent architectural marvel and it was amazing. A must-see when visiting Sydney.
Day trip. I have lived in Sydney since 1961 and never tire of visiting Sydney harbour. I love visiting at night when it is all lit up like a magical fairy land. Breathtaking.

Amazing. Climbed the bridge on our wedding anniversary and had a fantastic time, the view was spectacular. All the staff are Australian, our guide was very informative, and very well versed in the bridges history which made the climb even more unforgettable. The staff r excellent and well trained they are also compassionate when it comes to special needs, I suffer cancer and staff virtually gave me VIPs treatment to ensure my experience was made even more exiting. Truly atleast a once in a lifetime experience that I will never forget.

Marvel of engineering . You have to experience the bridge from above, below and from the water.It is really something to see and the views from the bridge are spectacular!You also get special tours on the bridge, so take some extra cash.

Do Not Have To Climb All The Way. If you are afraid of heights and do not intend to pay a lot to secure a trip right to the middle of the bridge then just climb to one of the towers would suffice. They even have a small museum dedicated to the history of the bridge and a souvenir shop. Although nothing beats the view at the top of the bridge, any views on this bridge is considered a job well done.
Beautiful!. A beautiful gateway in Sydney Harbour. You can walk across the top arch, I was not brave enough but enjoyed watching from below.
Anyday its Perfect. One of Australia's icons its a perfect view anyday of the week.Walk across it or just admire the view from below.

cool bridge!. The Sydney Harbour Bridge sits right across the Opera House and is about 15 minutes away if you walk to it from the Opera House. It's a pretty sight from wherever you look at it (we sat right under it for a few good minutes just marvelling at the iron works)! We didn't have the courage to take the Bridge Tour and climb it though.
Just amazing!. Incredible harbour that is able to keep your eyes from the Opera House. Try the climbing, it's an incredible experience.

Beautiful views. Not as spectacular as Brooklin Bridge but the views at the opera is nice. In my opinion, there is no need to pay for the pylon lookout. The view from above is only marginal better.Don't try to take pictures at night, while standing on the steel structure - vibrations are too strong. Wait till you reached the pylon.On the other side in Kirribilli are restaurants for a rest.
hi ho bronze bridge. iconic, but old. what do we have to do to revive the old iron lady???cutting up for scrap is not an option.

a stroll across and around the bridge - very impressive. got the hop on , hop off bus to the bottom of the bridge pier on the cbd side, walked through park and up ornate staircase onto bridge before crossing it on the footpath. fantastic views of sydney as well as the bridge, which in itself is a feat of engineering.

Must do this!!. Wow, this is a bucket list attraction. You will not be disappointed. Friendly, educated staff members who involve the whole group taking part on this once in a life time adventure. This a world class attraction and feel so lucky to have done it. It is worth every penny and is good value for money. This is for all ages and is for even for people scared of heights. The climb is not steep, it happens in stages. The views are spectacular. 10 out of 10!

Bridge walk. Unfortunately i found out that you can walk through the bridge in my last day in Sydney, so I couldn't make it. I have a friend who did it and told me it was fantastic. This is in my list if I ever return to Sydney

The Australian Icon that need to be visited at least ones in your life.. If you visit the city of Sydney Australia, make sure you do not miss this Australian Icon. You can see it from different side of the City and is always spectacular in particular during night time. It is possible also to organize a claiming on it by booking in advance.

A wonderful blend.... ... of purpose, structure, sturdiness, strength, beauty and history. The Bridge is at the top of my bucket list within this great country to ascent and have a panoramic view of the most beautiful city in the world! The stupendous sight of the Bridge especially when it's all lit up by the fireworks display every New Year's Day, it remains forever embellished in one's mind.

Memorable. The day started a little cool and slightly overcast, but as we arrived at the Bridge Climb centre the skies cleared and the sun came out. We were booked in swiftly and assigned a start time. We met our guide Jordan (Smashing Bloke). We were kitted out and given a briefing and rest run of Ladders and walkway on a mock section of bridge. As we were taken out and up Jordan was very informative and knowledgeable and made every effort to spend a bit of time chatting to each and every one of us in his group. Well done.A thoroughly enjoyable 3 hours. With the bonus of a beautiful sunset whilst on the bridge. Thanks Guys.

Bridge climb was amazing. We had an excellent day doing our bridge climb. I'm scared of heights, but felt very safe the whole climb. You are attached to the bridge the entire climb and cannot become unattached. Our guide was Mitch, who was hilarious, but also very knowledgable about the bridge and the city. He really made the climb an unforgettable experience. Giving us the history of the bridge and interesting facts throughout the climb, but also cracking jokes the whole way round - he was so entertaining and really put any nervous climbers at ease. That said, he was extremely professional, and gave us a thorough safety briefing at the start and kept a close eye on us all the entire climb. Lots of opportunities to take photos, and the climb wasn't 'rushed' in any way. It was a great experience and I would thoroughly recommend it.

Enjoyable experience . Reasonably priced and very well organised. The process was swift and the staff members were helpful and knowledgable. We did a mid morning climb and were fortunate enough to experience amazing views. Make sure you stand in the order you want for photographs otherwise you will not get the photos that you want (like us). Also, sadly make sure when changing you do not leave things lying around if you get distracted as not everyone is 100% honest.
Best of Sydney. So many things to do and see! Climbing The Sydney Harbour bridge is a great experience and feeling of being on top of the world.

Walk across for excellent views!. Having crossed the bridge so many times by car it was excellent to walk across it and take in the beautiful views of magnificent Sydney Harbour. On a fine day it is a great way to take in the scenery.

Best bridge in the World !!!. I still remember the first time I went over the bridge about 10yrs ago. I had just arrived in Australia and the person who picked us up took us over the bridge to get to where we were staying. It blew me away and even to this day I still feel that way everytime I drive over it. I have been to some of the best bridges in the world - Golden Gate Bridge, Brooklyn Bridge to name a few and they are fantastic but the Sydney Harbour Bridge still is tops. To walk over the bridge is a wonderful experience. The view are fantastic and is highly recommended to anyone coming to Sydney.

Let's walk the bridge!. Sydney Harbour Bridge is THE best place to be around on New Years Eve, when THE most amazing fireworks you've ever seen will be launched from the bridge. Lots of tourist do the Bridge Climb but for the non-daredevils there is another option, just take the footpath on the main deck. And don't forget to climb to the top of the pylon on the city side.
Beautiful View. It never gets boring driving over the Sydney Harbour Bridge day or night. Worth doing both day and night.Fantastic views.

Sydney Harbour Bridge - Dream come true. The Sydney Harbour Bridge stands tall and is so awesome to look at. I could'nt stop taking pictures. The view by night from Circular Quay is amazing and breathtaking. Seeing the bridge was a dream come true for me.
Good to climb and walk across. walked across at dusk great views back to the city and the opera house, would recommend not scary and caged off on path so no one can climb

Walk or ride a bike. The Harbour Bridge offers pedestrians (east side), or cyclists (west side) dedicated paths across the bridge, offering quite unique views of Sydney and the harbour. Though expensive, the intrepid can climb the bridge arches to maximise the views from the bridge. Best of all, bridge climb aside, it is free.

Great views. My friend and I decided to walk over to the other side, stopped half way and took some amazing photo's. Also a great view of bridge when you take ferry to darling harbour.On our way back from blue mountains we took the ferry ride and the bridge looks magnificent at night when lit up

Love it. My first memory of bridge was Olympics 2000 Sydney, I was 15 and got to experience the afterparty there dont ask how I was allowed to go but it was a family atmosphere very safe and just good fun....since then I have been to weddings/parties/bdays and always been nothing short of great fun something about the harbour bridge just brings fun!

A prominent landmark . When visiting Circular Quay area, one cannot miss this outstanding bridge bring one of the must-visit attractions in Sydney. We walked to the bridge through The Rocks stopping along the way to admire the interesting buildings along the way. The bridge is high above the bay and walking along it can be quite challenging when strong wind blows. The view from the bridge is awesome especially in the evening. The Sydney Opera House look more beautiful at sunset. It was a meaningful experience.

Climb and Marvel at the Panorama. Booked the longer Bridge climb. There is a lot of initial faffing around and getting equipped and going through safety procedures, which all make sense the moment you set out to climb the Bridge! There are moments of heart stopping tension as you walk and climb narrow see through paths and ladders (always 100% safely clipped on!), balanced by the sheer joy of watching the city panorama unfold as you reach higher and higher. Be aware that no cameras phones etc. are allowed on the climb, so for those unforgettable moments you will have to rely on your guide and your wallet to take those memories home. An expensive, but absolutely well worth doing experience if you can afford it.

Walk under it AND over it!. It's an iconic landmark and seeing it up close is fantastic. We walked over it early one sunny morning - you need to be on the eastern side (the opera house side) for pedestrian access. We had some great views of both the bridge (to please the architect in the family) and the wider city landscape. Once on the northern side we had coffee at the Flaky Tart bakery - fantastic coffee and pies so good that we were going to share but then went back and bought more!Paying to do the bridge climb was beyond our budget - the experience of walking over it was priceless!

Enjoy the Walk, Take in the View. On a beautiful evening, a must do stroll. Walk towards the lights of Luna Park, watch the busy Ferries come and go from Circular Quay. We were fortunate enough to be able to view the rise of a full moon over the Opera House, breathtaking. On the return journey, enjoy the city lights.Obviously the traffic noise can be intrusive so best to avoid rush hours. Plenty take in the joy of the bridge walk and seem to really enjoy the experience. It is unfortunate that security railing interferes with the view, otherwise it was a perfect romantic stroll amongst the joggers and sightseers. There were several security personnel located on duty on the bridge for those needing help or advice.

Long walk along the Bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge walk is quite long but it is free. The bridge is popular with joggers and tourists alike. As there are metal railings along the bridge, it does not offer unobstructed view of the sea unless you are quite tall!

Best Part of my Australian Vacation. Great way to spend a few hours when visiting Sydney. The views from the bridge as you climb it are fantastic and gives you a perspective that would be hard to replicate anywhere else. Its extremely well run and organized so that its not difficult to do physically and is very safe. As good as the climb and views are itself, the quality of the experience was raised significantly by the guide you are with. Our guide imparted a lot of interesting information regarding the bridge and Sydney, but also was very funny and kept the entire group engaged fully, so that everyone enjoyed themselves. Of all the different things I did while in Sydney, I thought this was the most enjoyable.
A must see. We went for a big walk around near the harbour bridge and walked underneath. Even though i have seen the bridge many times, it still blows me away when i see it in person. A must see!

As bridges go, this one is spectacular. When the other point of interest is the Sydney Opera House, well, a bridge has to be pretty impressive to rival the architectural marvel across the harbor. Well, the Sydney Harbour Bridge certainly holds its own. It looms large in the distance while touring the Opera House and you feel truly small when walking across the structure. The views from the bridge are outstanding, although if you have a fear of heights at all, it will make you feel a bit uncomfortable. I highly recommend a walk across the bridge and make sure the check it out from a variety of angles. Each one is spectacular.

Walk across the bridge or do the bridge climb. The bridge is amazing and worth the walk across stunning views and for those who like heights and an adventure the bridge climb is great to do there is a cost to this and worth it

Sydney's jewel connecting the City to the North Shore.. How to cross thee? Let me count the ways..By walking... One side is set aside for pedestrians, closed to bicycles and Segways, so you can leisurely stroll along the Sydney Opera house side and snap photos of it, Circular Quay, the Governor General's House, and the outer Harbour.By Bicycle... the path on the Inner Harbor side is reserved for fast moving wheeled traffic, and here you can see Luna Park, the North Sydney Olympic Pool, and the apartments of Kirribilli.By Auto... the original path prior to the opening of the Harbour tunnel, and, like the tunnel, uses toll tag technology to collect tolls. Much, much faster than the old coin method.And of course, by Train... Which can take to Kirribilli, North Sydney, Cremorne, and points north.OH, AND MOST EXCITING, THE SYDNEY BRIDGE CLIMB! Although you climb the superstructure of the bridge, you end up back from whence you began. You start on the Outer Harbour side, climb to the Center, cross over to the Inner Harbour side, and return to the City Side Climb office to pick u your things

A lovely walk across the bridge. We walked across the bridge and admired the views from the bridge. Security guards are along the bridge so very safe. Once across from CBD to Kiribilli there are cafes to get food and drink before walking back, there is a train if required back from Milsoms Point to town. Go right down to the waterfront on either side by the bridge.

you just can't miss watching it. honestly the harbor bridge is just a metal structure built across 2 banks but viewing it is something special. Choose a nice morning to walk across the bridge about, a little over 1km for free, if you find climbing too pricey.

Good experience . Great to do this attraction but don't go at lunch as they were closed for a bit. Lovely to see and a good day out. We were still jet lagged though and found Sydney tiring for that reason. Getting out of the city is s must but as everyone says about the bridge we felt we had to do it. Sadly though the Aussies didn't like the English. This ruined the trip but as I say the jet lag didn't help either. Seeing the bridge is probably enough unless you have an urge to walk it :-)

A must. A walk across the Sydney Bridge is great exercise, you will have great views and you have the great neighborhoods of the Rocks and Kirabilli to explore at either end. You can pay to go up the pylon on the Rocks side for an even better view. You can also climb to the very top with a guided tour group. It's about 3 miles round trip across and back. The view of the Opera House from across the Harbour is exceptional.

Bridge climb at sundown. Quite simply amazing - when we booked I thought it was expensive - but you get what you pay for - worth every penny.Just wish we could have taken out own camera up there for pictures.

Sydney Bridge Climb. Sydney Bridge, one of the world famous attractions. I am highly recommend to climb it on once in your life. The fee probably was expensive but it was amazing to experience it. I was fear of hight before climb up. After 30 mintues training, I really enjoyed to get it on and the scene was unbelievable. You can not bring anything with as it is very windy on the bridge. They will take photo for you. You just need enjoy the whole trip and pay for the photos if you like it. There were many famous actors climbed Sydney bridge too. ^_^

Walk across the bridge is a must. A walk across the bridge is a must when visiting Sydney, the views from the other side of the bridge are fantastic. Took us around 20 mins to do, well worth it. Did not attempt the walk up the bridge as a) very expensive and b) my knee wouldn’t have coped haha.
Great views . You can't miss the bridge. Great Jew of the city and easy to walk bike or drive across. Beautiful at sunset and sunrise. Iconic Sydney!

Stunning. Every time. . The bridge is incredible. It's construction legendary and the icon it is today doesn't disappoint as you look at it, travel over it or travel under it in a ferry. Don't miss any opportunities to see the bridge in person.

Bridge walk. Wet windy day in Sydney- perfect for a walk across Sydney Harbour Bridge! Fantastic views, and worth the weather to do it. Doesn't take long and the 24 hr security means you feel very safe no matter what time of day or night.
Best bridge. Not a lot to say except that its iconic and everyone has to see it. Do the bridge climb and see Sydney from atop.
Coat hanger. This is near Sydney opera house the view is amazing the best place for photos is from the opera house. You climb to the very top of bridge give yourself 4 hours to do it a lot of steps

One of the Icons of Sydney. Prior to arriving, I was very interested in the Sydney Harbor Bridge Climb; however, once I looked into prices, I realized I just couldn't justify the cost. Instead we opted to merely walk across the bridge, take in the gorgeous sites from it, and then had tea in Kirribilli. Walked around there and caught the ferry back. Wonderful way to spend a morning.If you are interested in getting a bit higher in the air, you can climb the pylons for a much lower price than the Bridge Climb.Our party opted out of doing that (two were scared of heights), but talked to many who enjoyed it.

A must do trip. Even when the weather was a bit showery this was a fantastic trip. I do not like heights, but felt totally safe...worst bit was climbing the ladders onto the bridge. Great views for the top, and the guides are very knowledgeable.

Harbour Bridge Crossing. We did the Harbour Bridge Climb as a Family with two Children aged 8 and 11. The overall experience lastet 4 hrs but we spend only 1,5hrs on the bridge, the rest of the time was the briefing.The Climb is quite expensive, but it is obvious what they need the money for. Every climber receives full gear including headphones to hear the guide. Unfortunately you don't totally cross the bridge but only walk to the top and back.Besides for safety (and monetary) reasons you are not allowed to bring any camera, so you might get an amazing view, but you can't take a picture and the few ones that are taking are not too good and quite expensive as well.
WOW!. No visit to Sydney would be complete without climbing the Sydney Bridge. It is a little pricey, but well worth the price and effort. If you aren't afraid of heights, this is a MUST DO.

Scenic Bridge to View. My boyfriend & I vacationed, in Sydney, Australia, in May 2016. We viewed this bridge on the day we walked to the Sydney Opera House and The Botanical Gardens. We did not walk across the bridge (did not feel up to it), but, the view, from across the Sydney Opera House, was good during the daytime.

Beautiful imposing architecture . This amazing bridge spans the harbour and is one of the great sites of sydney and the harbour. In my mind it equals the opera house especially when the morning or afternoon lights reflects on the girders. The whole bridge provides a scenic outlook in the circular quay and darling harbour area and is the perfect accompaniment to the amazing opera house

Sydney Harbour Bridge Review . I will never forget experience with Harbour Bridge. What an experience it was, Its look like iron monster. In life once should see this. t can handle Buses, cars, Trucks, & trains too. Should go on Bridge walk tour. It’s quite expansive but really great unforgettable experience. Before bridge walk they give you proper training & proper safe cloths too. The view of Sydney is really good from top. When you reach on top you really fill that you are in Australia & national flags of Australia help you to fill so. Bridge is more than 80 years old but still stand strong. One important thigh is that when you are on top someone will take your picture from near opera house with very good camera & good lance worth to buy it. There is also walk way on bridge via road. Its covered walk way for pedestrian safety & bridge history mention in every few distance. There are good & friendly security person standing in few distance. From there also you can have good view of circular quay & opera house. Should visit this bridge day & night time.

The Coat Hanger. The Sydney Harbour Bridge construction started in 1924 and took 1,400 men eight years to build at a cost of 4.2 million. BridgeClimb started in 1998 and attracts tourists and locals alike to climb the monument. After climbing through catwalks and up ladders and stairs, the view is absolutely breathtaking. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of Australia's most well known and photographed landmarks. It is the world's largest (but not the longest) steel arch bridge with the top of the bridge standing 134 metres above the harbour. It is fondly known by the locals as the 'Coathanger' because of its arch-based design.
Superb views. Best viewed from the Sydney Opera House. If you have a panoramic camera, go capture a shot late at night...
Sydney Harbour Bridge . An awesome sight to behold. Travelled across many times to get into the city. Spectacular to look at but wasn't brave enough to attempt the bridge walk !

most beautiful bridge. You can get on a ferry enjoy the water views the bridge looks better from different angles .You can go to luna park see the bridge or circular quay walk around wherever you look you will be amazed

Directions to the awesome views.. Firstly you dont need to pay to go on the bridge, you can simply do the Cahill walk which runs parallel to the road on the eatern side of the bridge and will take you all the way to the other side. N.B The western side of the bridge is for bicycles. Access: If you're coming from the harbour, walk up Argyll street heading west, going through The Rocks. Head past Lowenbrau restaurant, and you should see a bridge/tunnel just ahead. Keep heading up the road, and just before you reach the bridge/tunnel, there will be a set of steps on the right which will take you up a level onto Cumberland street. Directly infront of you, you'll see the stairs which will take you up to Cahills walk - N.B the arrow is pointing the wrong way to Cahills walk, when you go up the stairs and see a path going along the bridge, take it. Dont go up another flight. The bridge walk is approximately 90m above the water, and the views from above are brilliant. You can see for miles, have a great view of the harbour, and the Sydney Opera house. This is a definite must when visiting the city.

Two words: BRIDGE CLIMB! . We took a ferry several times from one side to another and enjoyed the view of this beautiful bridge. Then we thought, it's just not enough! So we decided to do a bridge climb and it was an experience I'll never forget. Bridge climb center offers different starting times and we decided to go for a twilight one. Started at 3.45pm finished at 7pm, we saw sunset from on top of the bridge and Sydney lighting up. If you are not scared of heights I would definitely recommend it! It is one time opportunity you'll never forget.

So fun!!!. This is a highlight from my visit 5 years ago. The guide tells you facts about the bridge and city as you walk up the bridge arch. I thought it would be scary being at the top,but it wasn't.

Amazing Experience. My husband,. 11 year old son and myself were looking forward to the Bridge Climb as one of the highlights of our visit to Sydney. The day was overcast with rain forecast so we were slightly disappointed about out climb being a let down. We were introduced to our guide, Scott, who was chatty and informative and full of stories and information about the Bridge. We reached the summit and had a great view even though it then started to rain but this did not detract from the experience and we had a great time and thoroughly recommend this experience.

Must see the coat hanger. If not on a cruise ship than take a ferry so you can see this bridge from the water. Also take the time to see her from both shores as the view does significantly change and leaves one to enjoy the labors of those that built this beauty. Watching the tourist climb to the top of the arch does leave one wishing they had time to do such things. When visiting Sydney it is hard to miss this bridge.

Go for the pic and get outta there!. Well if you enjoy strangers in your family pictures, then this is the place for you!! Take your pic in front of the bridge, the Opera House and then get the heck outta of Dodge, seriously, just so crowded, not sure what else to do in front of a freaking bridge...

Had a picnic under the bridge. I luv this bridge....it is a beautiful Australian landmark.... my family and I had a picnic under the bridge- we could see tour groups walking up the bridge...I am not that brave but good on the ones that do it.

The best way to take in this beautifully designed bridge and stunning harbour. head to the Rocks area and follow signs to get on the bridge. If travelling by bike there is a dedicated path running across the bridge on the western side. If you are walking there is a dedicated path on the eastern side of bridge. start walking or bike riding and stop along the path to take in the views of harbour and bridge design. Imagine when this bridge was first open, how grand it must have been - massive pylons, a single span across the harbour, ships are able to pass directly underneath and the bridge is still impressive. For those who like to conquer things you can pay to climb the bridge but for my money I think you get a good expereince by walking or cycling. When you get to the other side which is Milsons Point you can grab a bite to eat and do the trip in reverse or catch the train beck to Circular Quay from Milsons Point station.

Bridge climb . Great tour guide provided lots of detailed information about the history of the building of the bridge, the challenges of its construction and that of its maintenance, both then and now. The experience was heightened by the beauty of the city and the gentle breezes. A great adventure.
Must walk across the Bridge. Catch a train to Milsons Point station in arvo walk across the bridge late arvo & catch the sunset the on to the Harbour Veiw hotel for a drink you won't be disappointed.

Sydney Icon. Second only to the Opera House which sits opposite, is the Sydney Harbour Bridge. An engineering marvel for its time, built in the great depression. A fine day and a stroll across the bridge is a wonderful thing. If walking back is too much take a train or bus for quicker movement across the bridge. Ultimate experience is of course the bridge climb. On a fine day one of the worlds best views form top of the bridge. Is expensive yet so worth it.
Put this on your bucket list !. Well organised and typical Aussie attention to detail, a real well worth adventure climaxed by spectacular views of one of the worlds great cities.

Sydney Harbour BridgeWalk. On of the most scenic walks in Sydney; we usually begun the walk from the Botanical Gardens than along the Cahill Express Way that leads to the bridge and to North Sydney.It is very nice walk for a beautiful day and takes about 2.5 - 3 hrs if you want to walk back.

Exhillarating. A walk across the Harbour bridge is a great experience. Choose a good day which is easy in Sydney since the weather is usually good. One can walk from the city to the north and return on the same walking track or descend and spend time in Kirribilli and take the train back. Since there is no charge it cannot really be beaten in terms of value for money.
Bridge walk. An amazining walk across Sydney's landmark harbour. Every angle of Sydney can be seen from this point.

Viewing Sydney from a great height. A great experience at a far lesser cost than doing the bridge climb is to climb the south pylon. You feel the sense of being at close range to Harbour Bridge; within the building are interesting information and historical photos; and view of city and harbour from top of pylon is fantastic

Value for money Sydney Bridge Climb. It values for money for bridge climb though it is quite expensive for a whole family to have a climb. The fantastic sight and experience will make you a memorable trip to Sydney.

One for the bucket list!. I am a 64 year old with two knee replacements a year ago and I did this climb with my husband. The guides are extremely helpful and let me take my time to make the climb. We had a four o'clock appointment and by the time we reached the top it was dark and the city lights were incredible. It is a series of ladders and steps but very doable if you are so inclined.It was one of the highlights of our trip "down under".

A not to be missed Sydney experience. With my son and daughter we did the climb late in the afternoon in light rain!!We were kitted out with coveralls, light rainwear, headwear and earphones to hear the guide. I am a Sydney sider and familiar with the views, but this outing exceeded my expectations.It was all the better for Tom our guide who brought it all alive.We were a group of 10.Tom managed to involve us all as we warmed to the activity together and had fun.I'm 73 years of age and the climb was well within my capability.

Walk or climb the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The flat walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge is exciting and enjoyable. It can be approached from either side. There is a café on the north side. Visit the Museum mid-way across the Bridge to learn about the history of its making and the early times.Take the Bridge Climb for a stimulating and exhilarating experience to get fit and enjoy the view of the Sydney Harbour and city. The dusk option allows daylight climbing and at the top, the lights reveal another side to the city. The downward climb is easy and enjoyable in most weather conditions.

Mrs Roswyn Sanders. The best icon and design of a bridge in the world. I travel on it 5 days a week by bus and it is so wonderful to cross this superb piece of architecture. Go for a walk under the bridge and look up at its structure just a master piece

Harbour bridge climb. What a fabulous experience with my mother and daughter. We climbed the bridge in the late afternoon, watch the sun set over the harbour, we had an great guided tour that was well organised and fun.

Don't leave Sydney without it .... My second climb and first climb for my husband and 3 children, littlest one being 10. It is an incredible climb, showcasing the best of the city of Sydney and getting a taste of the local history as well. It's a must for any age!

Very Sydney. This is a must do for visitors to Sydney. It is free to walk across from either side and gives a wonderful view of Sydney Harbour. Walk from the city and buy fish and chips at Milsons Point and eat on the harbour front, or walk from Milsons Point and eat in one of the historic pubs in the Rocks or on the Quay. It is an easy walk with stairs at each end.
The most beautiful coat hanger in the world. One of the most beautiful landmarks in the world. Opened in 1932, and one of the most stunning roadways in the world.

Best views are from underneath. Some of the best views of Sydney Harbour Bridge are from underneath. On land, approach it from Hickson Road and walk or stop on the harbour front near the finger wharves. You can get a real feel of the immense size and hear the trains crossing. On the water, pick a clear and warm day and take a ferry to Milsons Point (where Luna Park is) or Darling Harbour, or East Balmain. It takes you right under the bridge and gives you great views back to the Opera House, framed by the bridge.

Magnificent Landmark. This master of engineering is a must see for all visitors to Sydney, it conects the Northern side of the city to the more populated side of Sydney including the Sydney CBD and Circular Quay where the first settlers landed from England.
Vantage view of Sydney Harbour. It is a fantastic location through which you can have a view of Sydney Harbour, opera house and city. Fresh cool breeze will have a elated feeling

Sunrise in Sydney. Best ever thing to do when you have a few hours to kill is to walk across the Sydney harbour Bridge and watch the sunrise.The early morning air & the beauty of the sunrise is truly worth it.Add to that the view of the harbour in general & you get some good exercise to boot.A great and inexpensive way to spend a few hours with friends and family - take your time and enjoy it. Check when the sun is due to rise the day before you go and plan to get to the middle of the bridge in plenty of time so you are relaxed and can enjoy the sights.Get the camera out and take some lovely pics.Enjoy

Magnificent view. Great feeling!. As a keen photographer my bucket list included walking over the Harbour Bridge. Got some great photographs but with difficulty as the emphasis is on security, so the very few places to take a shot were very confined. Felt a great Aussie pride to make the walk along such a world famous icon.

Play Tourist In Your Own City. Nothing beats walking along this iconic bridge. Start at Milsons Point and make your way across the bridge as you take in the spectacular harbour, Opera House and CBD views. Spend time at The Rocks or Botanic Gardens before walking or training it back. An afternoon well spent.

Great Experience - Highly Recommend!. I absolutely loved the bridge, some people have said to me "but it's just a bridge" since arriving back in the UK, but it's easy to see why so many people flock to see it. It's a fantastic feature of the city and can be seen from so many different places, giving great views from all around the city. It's also great as an experience (bridge climb) and a focal point when arranging to meet people.I watched the new years eve fireworks display from the east quay, and was blown away by the whole thing (pardon the pun). It was truly spectacular, and a great way to start a holiday. The only negative I found was that waiting for the display was a long long day. I got to the quay early to secure a decent spot, and in the sun, it was pretty brutal. It was well worth it, but you have to be willing to hold your ground towards fireworks time. We had so many people trying to push in when we had been waiting there all day. No way was I giving that spot up.... Well worth the battle :-).As mentioned above, it's also possible to climb to the top of the bridge and take in some of the scenery which is just incredible. My wife is terrified of heights but was honestly fine all the way up. You can't see through to the water or road underneath you and are pretty securely strapped onto the bridge. The safety is unreal too, everybody is breathalysed and you have to have a zero reading to be able to climb, so no chance of drunk people ruining the experience for you. Our guide was brilliant, very funny and helped to put nervous people at ease, we even still follow her exploits on Instagram which is pretty cool. You can definitely enjoy the bridge for free, but I would honestly recommend doing the bridge climb at least once. There were people of all ages, shapes and sizes climbing in our group, and none had any issues. Give it a go, you won't regret it. The one downside I would say is that they make you pay for all of your individual photos. You basically only get a group shot for free and lets be honest, nobody actually wants random strangers in their photo. This means you have to pay extra for the shot you actually want.

No visit is complete without seeing this. Head down to circular quey and catch a ferry under the harbour bridge for best views of this bridge and the opera house. Take some black and white photos at night - simply beautiful.

Great Day. Climbing the bridge was amazing. Some of our group were a little older and our guide was great at keeping the pace so no one felt over worked or bad for not keeping up. The views from the top are like nowhere else

"Amazing". Beautiful scenery . One of the most spectacular things i saw in Australia during my visit . And the tour of Sydney opera house was also very interesting thing to do . enjoyed a lot with my family .

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climbing experience. It is fantastic. Excellent preparations for safety gears and putting on appropriate clothing depends on the weather of the day. Learn about history and excellent bird yes view. You have to experience it. It is very safe and not scaring at all.
Free walk. We took the train to Milson's point and the walked back to the rocks over the Harbour bridge. Nice walk and great views of the bridge, the opera house and the harbour.
WOW. It is absolutely breathtaking. A must experience if you are in Sydney. It is not cheap, but you hardly find anything such outstanding and unrepeatable elsewhere in the world.

copy of another bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is Sydney. It is a landmark structure (albeit a direct copy of the Tyne Bridge) that screams Sydney. I have always enjoyed driving over it as well as journeying on the train. The views from the train are great.

Great guide not so sure management is smart . Certainly a great experience and not physically demanding and nothing that an 8 to 80 yr old couldn't do. We had an awesome guide (Mitch). Management a bit lost on their need to prevent you taking your own camera - they blame security - what BS anyone can get bridge footage. Is purely a greed factor of the management.

The Bridge Climb is simply fantastic and not to be missed. WOW! Sydney harbour just has to be seen from the top of the bridge to really appreciate its expansive beauty. I have done this twice with two different guides and got a different perspective on the history from each - both imparted a mountain of information. The safety from start to finish was incredible commencing with the breathalyser so don't plan this after a big night out!! It was not as physically hard as I had thought it would be but you do need a level of fitness to get up and down the ladders with confidence.

Scenic walk across Sydney Harbour. An impressive engineering achievement in its time, and still an imposing monument to civic engineering. The bridge simply dwarfs the surrounding city, and walking across the bridge is another great way of experiencing Sydney Harbour. The Opera House looks quaint when seen from the bridge. A museum in the southern pylon explains the construction, and at times the bridge itself can be climbed in guided tours (not for the faint of heart).
Unbelievable . What a great icon this is. Looks great by day or by night. You can drive over it, walk it or climb it. We love our bridge. It does cost to cross it by car though but worth every cent
Old charm do exist. Amazing. Need to during the day as well as at sunset. At least from two sides. The best is from opera house and from Milsons point.

Expensive but well worth it!. Now done the Bridge Climb 3 times and it's been very enjoyable each time. I do think next time though I will do a Twilight Climb because every time I've been before I've been squinting because of the sun behind the photographer! The views are stunning and the staff are friendly, can't say better than that.
Nice construction. Good to visit on top of it by walking / climbing on it but very expensive. Good views from Park Hyatt and the harbour itself. You can also fly over with a heli

Sydney Harbour Bridge pylon. I was in my 60's when, although born and bred in Sydney, I had not walked across this iconic bridge until then. I can thoroughly recommend this experience. I am not sure-footed enough for the Bridge Climb however can recommend going to the top of the south eastern pylon for fabulous views of the city, the harbour and across to North Sydney. Note: lots of stairs.
Great to walk across. If you get a chance to walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge... You must do it... The photo opportunities are endless.

Bridge visit. We came over the bridge by train to Circular Quay Station then walked back to the base of the bridge. Worth a visit to read the information boards and the parks place in history. Huge from the ground looking up and the base pillions are huge.

Amazing. Make sure you go over and under this bridge whilst you are here rather than just take photos from a distance.We walked across at night with some great views of everywhere lit up, including the Opera House and Luna Park. We also went over on the train and under on ferries. The walk over the top looks amazing but with an 8yr old with us, we were unable to do- so we took a helicopter ride instead!!! Fantastic views. Iconic.

Amazing, worth the travel to this gorgeous place. We were on vacation and absolutely loved this place, we didn't want to leave, perfect for all ages and it's lovely to make some good memories here. This was on my bucket list to visit and loved every second of my visit here!

The Must Attraction to do in Sydney. Although a little bit pricey, the organised climbing tour of the Sydney bridge is a lot of fun.
We booked the smaller tour (90 min) which was just perfect for us. The whole experience was wonderful, a very well thought attraction, very safe and well guided tour.

Beatiful!. There is many ways to see this icon, from anywhere in the harbour, by ferry, helicopter or even to walk accross it. You can also head up one of the southern towers for a gold coin donation and learn the history of the bridge.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb was AMAZING!. We took the plunge and did the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. It was a fun time and we are glad we went. It was such a great tour and our guide was fun. They are attentive to everything and do a wonderful If you don't do the bridge climb you can walk the bridge and enjoy the harbour views.

Postcard from Sydney. During the last decades, I walked over the Bridge several times, and always was able to find something new. The landscape differs by the time of the day when you look at it. It worth to try, -if you have the time- to walk in the early morning, so as well in the afternoon. When the sun is down, and all the lights are on, you’ll see something different again. To make your bridge walk even more attractive, go up to the Pylon Lookout.The 360 degrees view from the top, will be breathtaking.If you fit and capable go for the bridge climb as well. 20 Years ago I went for the bridge climb and enjoyed every minute of it. Not as scary as maybe you think, but a certain adrenalin level makes it even more fun.The Harbour Bridge can provide you with so much entertainment from no to high prices; that would be a sin, to miss it if you’re visiting Sydney.
Nice view. Visited the bridge and climbed up to the pylon - lookout. Nice view on the whole city. Interesting exhibition that explains the birth of the bridge and the construction methods.

Make time for this walk!. If you go to the Rocks, you should make time to climb the stairs to the Sydney Harbour Bridge and walk across the bridge to Milsons Point, where you can catch a train to your next destination. The walk provides good exercise as well as magnificent views of the harbour and the Opera House, and it is free.

One of the world's greatest bridges. One day, I would like to tackle the Sydney Harbour Bridge climb, however for now, I will settle for admiring it from a ferry or up in the air when the magnificent sight of it greets you from the plane.

Worth walking across!. I've been to Sydney many times, but I've walked across the Harbour Bridge during my most recent trip. It was quite a long walk but worth it. We didn't pay to go up to the viewing deck, but even so the view was gorgeous from the foot path. I'd highly recommend tourists and locals alike to do this walk at some point!
Sydney Harbour Bridge. Sydney Harbour Bridge is classic example of engineering. This bridge opens within its center so that big ships can pass from here. Must to see this excellence

Exciting Spots. From a far, the bridge look so stunning especially during sunset. But if you want more thrills, you can climb the bridge for a certain amount of money. Usually, you will climb in a group depending on the tour agent.

BRIDGE CLIMB. Firstly let me say that calling it a climb is misleading and might put some people off who would do it if was a walk and not miss out on a great experience.I "climbed" the bridge on my 64th birthday and had no problems keeping up with a much younger crowd in my group. Admittedly there were sections that you go vertical up some ladders but the rest is a walk. My wife refused to participate because she is partially scared of heights but it was the openness that frightened her. Although you are tethered to the rail with a safety harness it can be a bit daunting looking straight down onto the traffic below.Well worth the effort.
Stunning. We saw and walked across the Harbour Bridge during the Sydney VIVID Light Show which made it quite spectacular.

Finally back!. We returned to Sydney for a 3-day vacation. Climbed the bridge. It's a slow, gradual walk but you feel it in your legs if you don't do a lot of steps. Don't be afraid. They do extensive training b4 u get to the bridge. Keep whatever hat you wear.

Bridge climb .wow !!!!!. One of the highlights of my trip to Oz. Thorough pre climb briefing, clothing and practice climb. Safe and well tethered, not too hard but some effort needed so not for those with mobility issues. What a buzz when you get to the top. The free photo us of the group you went with, to get your own is extra ... The walk was well paced with great commentary of the sorrow do and bridge history and what views, shame could not have own camera to take snaps, must do activity if you can

WOW, the Coathanger, Here I am!. I was so glad that I finally walked across the Sydney Habour Bridge－“The Coathanger (a nickname known by the locals)”. My previous visits to Sydney were short and I have never bothered to find out if people could walk on the Bridge although I have crossed over it many times by train, bus, or driving a car. On this visit learned it from Susan Hong (a friend of my sister) who was the one invited me to walk together. We met at Milsons Point station where we started our walk. Within few minutes we already reached the signs of Cahill Walk seeing flights of stairs going up. Susan has a bit OA and knee problem so our pace was slow. It took a little effort to take the stairs up but we managed onto the flat footpath of the Bridge. [Note: our direction was towards the city so the walkway for the pedestrians is on left side of the Bridge, right side for the bikes.]What an awesome view it was when we were on half way of the walkway and that moment I felt like shouting out to the whole world that I was standing on the world famous iconic landmark that is one of the most attractions to the tourists from different parts of the world. It is a breathtaking view for the city, the harbor, and the opera house. On the Bridge I did not have to be like in the ferry crowds trying so hard to find a place catching a good shot of the photo. There I could take my time and took nice pictures as many as I wanted. Just be careful with your smart phone or iPad while stretching your arms peering through the frame (the gap) of the metal fence, definitely not good for pro camera. Go for it and do the free Bridge walk; an exhilarating experience, worth a visit !

3 times a bridge climb master..... This is a serious must do when visiting Sydney. I have been to Australia 3 times and have done the bridge climb all 3 times and it never gets boring. Hearing the knowledge of your climb leader and the stories of the bridge is fascinating. Then you have the views, well they are something else. Seeing a 360 degree view is just amazing.
Definitely a bridge. Very impressive to see Lots of people trying to get photos in hilarious ways to avoid getting other tourists in themCertainly an Aussie icon

Fun. Dont forget to wear comfy shoes for the hike. Wear proper skin protectiom as I had wind burn. Such a fantastic way to see many faces of Opera house. Make sure to admire the structure of the bridge..
excellent. did walk along this bride and it is excellent, all the harbor and also the other side just need to have to go

The oldest site of the City. When we read history of the bridge we realize the age of the bridge its quite old but the bridge looks like still strong and servicing all the people that's why I see this site its the city icon beside Sydney operah house.
AMAZING. What an amazing site - each time I saw it, I was amazed. A gorgeous back drop to an amazing city. Take the Manly Ferry or another local ferry and sail underneath it. Its so beautiful

An icon of design. Famous world over, this engineering marvel also delights with its still modern practicality. best to avoid the inevitable peak hour crawl and if you are good at heights definitely worth the adventure of a bridge climb, but not for the faint hearted. The old girl is very high and vibrates! But perfectly safe, I think.

Walking across the bridge is free and easy, and you get great views of the Opera House. I'm afraid of heights, so climbing up atop the bridge (Bridge Climb) was never an option, but the walk across the bridge (no harness or other safety gear required!) I enjoyed. We got great views of the harbour and of the Opera House, and there's a designated walking area (no vehicles), so it never felt unsafe. There were security guards/police officers visible as well.The walk can be done in under an hour and it's a gradual slope, so the worst part is climbing the "bridge stairs" on Cumberland Street in The Rocks district to get up to the bridge level.
One of the best things to do in Sydney. This was one of our best experiences. Amazing views, great staff, great process. Loved this!! Make sure you have this on your "to do list" you won't regret it!

Checking out the sights. Our exchange students wanted to get up close to the bridge, so what better way than to take a walk across.We were also pleasantly surprised to find out that you can climb the pylon. Great views and we then wandered down to the ferry terminal and grabbed a ferry back to circular quay. Great experiences for our exchange students.
must add to your bucket list. did the tower tour, so I loved the background history, wanted the comparisons of our own Forth Road Bridge, brilliant walk, would love to return..

An interesting walk. We walked across the Sydney Harbour Bridge with our grandchildren and we also paid a visit to the Bridge Museum at one of the pylons. Very informative and the views on a clear day are amazing.
The other Australian icon.. What can you say about the coathanger? A perfect backdrop to the opera house and you can walk over it or climb it or simply walk around beneath it and enjoy the day
Amazing. The other big attraction of Sydney except opera. It can be seen from Circural Quay and Opera House. Must-visit if you're in Sydney.
The bridge in the horizon. Every picture of Sydney includes this bridge. it is possible to cross from one side to the other, by walking. It takes one hour maybe, but it's really worth it.

Walked the bottom span. A must do in Sydney.  From the Rocks area, take the steps up to Bridge level.  From there you walk on the east side of the bridge all the way to Milson's Point.  Beautiful views of the city, and it's amazing to see all the ferry traffic below.  Walking on the lower deck is free.  Understand you can pay several hundred dollars each to walk along the top span of the bridge, which I'm sure would be amazing, but we chose not to do that.

Iconic Sydney!!. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is also Iconic, beside the Sydney Opera House and Bondi Beach. Doing the Bridge Climb is totally memorable and you definitely get a great view. A visit to Fort Denison, the tiny island in the middle of the harbour is also worthwhile, it was once a prison back in the early settlement days. Great way to see and experience Sydney.

Amazing. The Sydney harbour bridge is one of the best places to see in Sydney other than the Sydney opera house.I was thinking of looking at climbing it but it just looked too scary. Overall it is just an amazing place.

Echo Challenge. If you are travelling on a ferry, from Darling Harbour, it will go under the bridge. And if you yell or scream, it will echo. I saw a man do it after his spouse challenged him. I was too chicken to follow. There is also a pay tour that walks you up to the top of the bridge. People looked like ants from the ferry. But if you like heights and have budget, then go for it.Please vote "helpful" if you like my review.
Inspiring . When in Sydney, seeing the Sydney Harbour bridge is a must, it is what makes Sydney what it is today. A beautiful, inspiring city, with so much to offer when visiting Sydney.

Wonderful views of the harbour and city. Walk across the bridge from Milsons Point to The Rocks.Great views of the harbour and city.Except for the initial steps from the Milsons Point end to the bridge it is a flat walk.Visit the pylon whilst you are there for even better views and some historyI never cease to marvel at the beauty of the harbour .There is always something happening on the harbour.
Better than you expect. Apparently it is a surprise to many visitors just how impressive the Bridge is. So don't be surprised. And make the effort lo look at/walk/climb it if you possibly can.

Do the Bridge Climb. My wife and I did the twilight bridge climb. While pricey, we loved it and would recommend it. We did the longer walk over the longer time frame. Mitch was a superb tour guide and can't thank him enough for making this such a great experience. My wife is not athletic and has battled chemo within the past few months, but was still able to make the walk with relative ease. There are a few sets of steps that are straight up and down, but most of the steps are much easier and on a long slow slant. The sights are amazing, the bridge history and climb history are very interesting and there are plenty of stops to relax, rest and view the area. This is not to be considered a thrill seekers option, but my daughter and I both enjoy more thrilling things, yet found this to be a fantastic must do while in Sydney!

One of the iconic buildings in Sydney. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the iconic buildings in Sydney is always worth a visit. There are so many ways to cross this bridge but my favourite way is to walk because you can see the entire Sydney Harbour from up there. If you feel adventurous you should do the Bridge Climb, but be warned it's pricey and you are not allowed to bring your camera. I always enjoy walking over the bride and snap some pictures.
Thrilling climb. I'm scared of heights but this is so safe as one is clipp d to a static line. The view is awesome and the comb fun

Fabulous trip. We climbed the Sydney bridge tower rather than the bridge tour. We felt that going up the bridge was too expensive for all of us so this was a compromise. It was very informative value for money and we had an excellent view

Walk the bridge. A wonderful Sydney landmark, just amazing how it was made. We did the walk over the bridge and would recommend it. We got a ferry to Luna park and walked up the steep hill, which is a bit of a hike, then up the stairs to get onto the bridge. Was great to walk on the bridge pathway, easy walk, great views. Easier steps to get off the bridge at The Rocks. Would recommend doing the walk starting at The Rocks, over the bridge and get a ferry from Luna park, or walk around kirrabilli and get train / bus / ferry to your next spot.

Look west as well as east. The waterside suburbs immediately to the north of Sydney Harbour Bridge are voted high for liveability. You can get a nice overview of them as you cross the bridge. Recently I crossed the harbour by train and looked inland, upriver, rather than outward to the Heads. This meant I was looking at residential towers and attractive coves.

A must-do walk. Every time I visit Sydney I try and make time to walk across the bridge, using the footpath on the eastern side. It never disappoints. The views are exhilarating. The bridge itself is such an amazing feat of engineering. And a climb up the south-east pylon with its photographs and models is most informative. If you do nothing else when you visit Sydney, walk across the bridge! You won't be disappointed. Better still, splurge on a bridge climb: it will be one of the most memorable experiences of your life.

Easy climb and great views. I've been to Sydney several times but never done the bridge climb. I would put it high on the list for other visitors and wish I had done it sooner. It was fantastic, great views and a wonderful guide that was very educational.

Views from the Pylon Lookout are great!. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the most popular landmarks of Sydney alone with Opera House. We saw Harbour Bridge from different points: from water, air and land, we walked across the bridge. It was too expensive to do BridgeClimb; we just went to the Pylon Lookout. The Pylon Lookout is at the southern eastern end of the Bridge (the Rocks end) and visitors can go and see very informative exhibition about the Bridge and also see the spectacular 360 view from the top of the pylon. Amazing views of Sydney Harbour with Opera House, the Sydney Central Business District and bridge itself! We would recommend visiting the Pylon Lookout on the Sydney Harbour Bridge.
Good walk. Enjoyed a walk across the bridge. Great views but worth going up the tower for history and even better views across the harbour 360 degrees .well worth the climb
Stunning!. Fantastic design! Great Outlook and fantastic look. Met my expectations! Photo opportunitys! Best veiw is from the oprea house or from milsons point ( luna park)

SYDNEY HARBOUR BRIDGE CLIMB - Night. Before you consider in doing ‘Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb’ in Australia, you must read ‘Things You Need to Know’ and ‘Health & Safety Essentials: Can You Climb?’ on their website. There you will find the safety requirements you must meet before you purchase any tickets. What was not mentioned on their website is to wear comfortable clothes that is easy to take off because you will only be wearing your undergarments (underwear and bra) underneath the ‘bridge suit’ given to you to wear. Also, if you have long hair, to have it tied back. It it’s loose, your ‘Climb Leader’ will provide elastic bands for you to tie it back anyway. Of course, commonsense tells you that it is a climb, so wear comfortable, enclosed shoes. And for safety reasons, you cannot carry anything with you on the Bridge. They will provide secure lockers for you to keep your personal items locked away safely. If you need to wear glasses, your Climb Leader will hand out straps that securely holds your glasses on to avoid any mishaps. Now comes the hardest part, which part of the day to climb that magnificent Bridge and the speed of walk?I highly recommend the ‘Night Climb’ because Sydney is at it’s best at night glittering with lights. And what better way to view Sydney from a height of 134 metres above sea level – most memorable and enjoyable scenic view you could possibly experience! I have also chosen BridgeClimb not BridgeClimb Express… what’s the hurry? I am so glad that we have chosen ‘night’. On our particular night climb, it was a fresh evening but while climbing, it sure heated us up in no time at all and the fresh breeze was rewarding yet comfortable. Each group is assigned to a ‘Climb Leader’ who will take great care of you.
