You could also just run to the other side and back (really fun) as there are literally thousands doing it every morning / afternoon as their preferred route.If you are a little bit sensitive with the noise of cars (like me), try to go after 8pm or really early in the morning when there is no traffic, otherwise get some ear pods to block some of the noise.Peckish after the walk? head to some of the restaurants next to the bridge (Kirribilli side) or get something to eat at the Rocks (or head to Pancakes on The Rocks, recovering all the kilojoules/calories you have burned multiplied by 3) finishing it with a relaxing time watching the boats go by in Circular Quay.
Walked the bridge at night.. We walked the pedestrian walkway as the sun went down and the opera house became lit. Very nice. Policeman guarded the walkway. I would imagine daylight might be nice to.

again a bit disappointing. maybe I have seen too many bridges, this one is no better than a lot of others. guess it is best known for the bridge climb, fireworks and Sydney opera house in the background.

Most amazing views. We did a twilight tour of the bridge and had the best of both worlds, seeing the city during the day on the way up, and as the sun was setting on the way back down.Our tour guide was informative and we got some great photos.
Iconic bridge in a great city. It's a marvel of 20th century engineering and an well recognised icon of the modern world. Walking or running across it is an experience. The bridge climb is awesome !

A unique perspective.. Truly amazing! No matter whether you're driving on it, sailing under it, or just looking at it from anywhere along the harbour, you'll get a superb view! But nothing compares to actually climbing it. The most unique, unparalleled view, is worth every cent. The strange bit was that the scariest part for me was not climbing the bridge itself, but rather the pylons and walkways which lead on to the Bridge. The steps on the Bridge itself are solid, but the ones leading up to it are iron lattice, so they're see through. Which is a bit daunting when you're 3 or 4 storeys up, and going up fairly quickly. In no time at all you're on the Bridge. The individual photos are a bit steep in price. There's a cafe and toilets, and a great souvenir shop.

Great view of the harbour. I highly recommend walking on the bridge , if you are physically able to do so. It is free to do so. Not only do you get a nice walk 30 45 minutes, but awesome view of the harbor. Must do..if you can.

Iconic. The Bridge and Opera House are undoubtedly iconic Sydney landmarks. I took a ferry from Circular Quay to Kirribilli, then walked to and over the Bridge back to the City - stunning views both on the ferry and from the Bridge. I would suggest doing this either early morning or late afternoon when its a bit cooler. If wanting to take pics, be mindful of the sun as you can only walk on the eastern side of the bridge.

Amazing Grace. Somehow this huge span of mighty metal manages to look graceful and even lacy in the right light. Pedestrians can climb the bridge, yes, right to the top and over--but if you're subject to acrophobia, I don't recommend it. Our city guide advised that once you start, you can't stop. A decade or two ago I would have been hot to try it but now it seems equally entertaining to lie back on the greensward below and watch all those crazy climbers straggle to the top.
Iconic attraction . There isn't much to say which hasn't been said before. Personally the bridge is best viewed from the Royal Botanical Gardens for a full panoramic shoreline view.

Must do if you've traveled 21 hrs to get to Sydney. We not only drove over it, viewed it from the Opera House, we spent the money and the 3 1/2 hours to climb it. The only regret would have been to return home without climbing it. Arrive early and take in the cinema describing the history of the bridge and photo presentation gallery. (free) Then you are taken upstairs for a safety demo, breathalyzer test , given your jumpsuit and go thru a simulated practice of the steps before heading out. You go out in small groups with audio headphones with other staff all along the way for those that feel uncomfortable after starting or to assist if needed. While you can't bring your own camera, several photos will be taken for you from various points along the way. You do get a free group shot. It was blazing hot the day we climbed but there were "misters" for your face along the way. Such a memory, once in a lifetime, and we're both grandparents!! (runs in all weather except thunder/lightning)

Climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Not on your bucket list?. When I visited Sydney in November, climbing the bridge was not even on my bucket list. Why would it be? Bridges are built to facilitate crossings, not to make them more arduous. However, our daughter who lives in Melbourne, joined us on this leg of our trip and definitely wanted to climb the "coat hanger", but not on her own. We lent each other moral support and signed on for a climb at 09h15 - a good time to go if in summer, before it becomes too warm. This attraction id definitely a "fashion equalizer" as all visitors have to leave all clothing (but the basics) and possessions that may be accidentally dropped and change into a standard "onesie". Added to this are a baseball type cap, safety belt and small radio receiver and headphones (to hear commentary and instructions from the guide). Each group is small (no more than 16 persons) and, whilst attached to a safety line for the duration of the climb, the group is not "tied together" so a moderate to slow progress is made. This overcame the greatest concern of all climbers who did not wish to be responsible for delaying the entire party for some reason (other than a major emergency). Safety is paramount but all concerns were swept aside by the fascinating history of the construction of the bridge and anecdotes related by our guide. I have now added the Bridge Climb to my bucket list (and ticked it off).

Engineering Marvel!. We did the version of the bridge climb that didn't pause as often and our party ranging in age from 11 to 55 didn't have any trouble keeping up with the pace. The views were stunning and taking in the bridge and its history made the climb go quickly. Was our favorite thing we did in Sydney and would do it again - highly recommend!

Worth a walk across.. Decided not to do the climb based on the reviews of it not being worth the expense. Took the metro to the stop (Milsons Point) just north of the Bridge. When you exit the station, the entrance to the Bridge is just a few meters away. I walked south on the bridge along the Opera House side. Nice walk. Doesn't take along, and gives you a great view of the harbour and the Opera House. You can also pay $13AUD to go up the steps in one of the pylons, but the people who I saw come out said it wasn't really worth it. Lots of joggers!

Great view of the Opera house. The walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge is not very difficult nor long. You can go to Milson's Point at the North end and walk back to the city for the best views, however I walked both ways and found it relaxing with great photos opportunities. Walk along the east side of the bridge for pedestrians as the west side is for bicycles.

Travel bit of history everyday . Love driving over the Harbour bridge (Cahill Expressway lanes) to eastern Sydney for glimpses of the opera house, blue waters among the majestic pillars. Had quite a few friends walk the bridge and do the climb and raved about the experience. Best to pick a sunny day

Sunset bridge walk. We booked the sunset bridge walk and it's a must do you first gear up and try out your equipment .After this you have a safety brief than out onto the bridge you need to be very fit to do this as lots of stairs and moving through small areas.You walk along the bottom of the bridge first under the road until you are over the water then you start making your way to the top it's a great thing to do and well worth it once you reach the top for the sunset which is timed just right and then you return is in darkness

A must do. I never thought I would enjoy climbing a bridge, but it was awesome. We had a group of 14 people and an excellent guide. It took about 3 hours and it was worth every minute. The feeling you get when you are on top of the bridge is hard to explain. Cars running under you and a train right beside as you climb down is amazing. The cost is a wee bit high, but it is a must do thing.

Amazing. We were not sure what to expect, the first part as you climb onto the bridge is through several passages but after a short time you are out onto the bridge. Its a fantastic view all the way to the top and perfectly safe, a must if you are in sydney

Beautiful views across Sydney, it's harbor,and beyond to the sea in the east, blue mountains to the west. Do the bridge climb! So worth the time and money to see Sydney from this vantage point. The tour guides were fun, informative and helpful. The efficiency with which they get you suited up, climbing and back down was impressive. From oldest (myself at 46) to youngest (my niece at 8) we all LOVED this tour. We did the Express Climb which, in my opinion, was long enough to give you your time and money's worth but not so long that you are worn out, bored or over it! They take plenty of pictures of you at different spots along the climb which are available for purchase but they do give you 1 of your pictures along with a Bridge Climb certificate at the end of the tour. Don't miss this one.

an icon in Sydney. Impossible to miss this bridge when you visit Sydney. Cruise ships leaving from White Bay will pass under it, cruise ships arriving or leaving from The Rocks at Circular Quay will dock right by it, ferries from Circular Quay will pass under or by it. It is an impressive bridge.

You'll know when you see it!. I was so happy to see the Bridge (and the Opera House), I nearly cried! It was when I truly knew I was in Australia (for me, the other side of the world) which was a huge achievement for me. It's a great view from the Sydney Harbour and you can see it from miles around. We have hundreds of pictures of this bridge now, it never gets old!

Witness the world renowned bridge . Visiting Sydney opera house and the bridge the same time. A sight to see. Many young people at the bars enjoying Saturday evening. Full of fun spirits a place to enjoy.

Be sure to walk from one side to the other. Crossing the Bridge offers some of the best views in Sydney. Taking the opportunity to look up and marvel at the engineering connecting Sydney City to the Suburbs.
Simply Magic. This bridge is just incredible, when I first saw it on the plane I was stunned on how the Bridge looked. I leave you to think why you should visit this.

Surprisingly elegant. The scale of the bridge is astonishing and it dominates the harbour. It provides a great backdrop to the opera house as well. Despite its industrial appearance it is a surprisingly elegant structure.
Truely amazing. This is just one of those icons that lives up to it reputation. If you are climbing it, chilling back at a bar or restaurant or driving over it it never ceases to amaze me!

A bridge that greets you as you come into the harbor.. This bridge is a key attraction as one sails into the Sydney harbor. You can walk across it and also at a cost can climb up it on good days. The views are spectacular from walking over or climbing over it. It's well doing if you are capable to do it.

Great sunset . Got there on a beautiful evening on the opera house side and had a few drinks in the bar, waiting for a concert at the opera house. It's a really pretty place with access to transport, food, drinks etc. Great for tourists. Best views of the bridge are from opera house for me

Did the Skywalk! Wow!. Something I will never forget! The view was absolutely the most amazing! You can see all over the city and the walk was not at all hard. The only hard park was the vertical ladders and those were only about 10 rungs high and I think only 2 spots. My only wish is that it was longer.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. This was the highlight of our trip, it was well organised, set-up and safe. We took the 4PM trip up so had the sunset on one side and moon coming up on the other as we went up and down. The stories and the history of the bridge were interesting, the pictures were great also get the extra package as it is worth it. Brilliant strong recommend

Iconic but.... It has a very significant symbol for the Sydney along with the Opera House but it seems a little bit dull when I knew the bridge's design is inspired the Tyne Bridge of Newcastle, UK. Both of them really looks so similar.

A tour over Sidney Harbour Bridge. My grandson and I did the Sidney Harbour BrIdge tour onThurday ,it was a fabulous expereance ,and the weather could not have been better .the tour operator was very informative as well ,well worth the money .

Free walk. You can walk across the bridge for free. There is no need to do the bridge climb. Parking near it is expensive though and difficult. Finding where to walk up there is not straightforward either.

Pylon lookout is great!. For those with height phobia, doing the Pylon lookout at the bridge is more than good enough! The views are fantastic without having a pay a bomb to climb the bridge to the top.

Icon of Sydney, do the walk even if not the Bridge Climb. Sydney's icon, the steel arch Sydney Harbor bridge is a must see (of course you can't miss it, but you should walk it). We did not do the paid Bridge climb (no kids under 12 allowed and it does run $150 pp) although that would've been fun. But we did walk across the bridge and to the Luna park on the other side. Beautiful views of the harbor and the opera house. This is a must walk.

Top Sydney View in the Land Down Under. Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the "must do "things on your list if you are travelling into one of the Worlds Best Harbours. To just have the sight of the Bridge and the other world icon The Opera House right beside one another is a rare sight indeed, if you have photographed these on a clear day you are so lucky. Truly a magnificent sight. And beauty is in the hands of the beholder. If you are so lucky to get the opportunity of a climb on the Harbour Bridge ...DO IT !!!!! Money well worth it as the sight here is so breathtaking and the Bridge Climb staff will make sure you get all the sights in...

Easy climb, great experience!. You are strapped in and have to wear a special suit, which just adds to the experience. Pretty easy, slow paced climb that even those who are not in great shape. Plan to spend extra $ on the picture afterwards (you can't take your own camera on the climb for safety reasons) - it is a great memento to have

Engineering Ingenuity. Well worth a visit to climb up the Harbour Bridge Pier and visit the Museum. You are rewarded with fantastic views over the Harbour and City - plus an insight into the remarkable engineering feat that created this iconic bridge.

Great Walk. Walked over it from Milsons Point to The Rocks. A great walk with amazing views of the Opera House, Harbour and the City. Takes about 20-30 minutes in total. Even if you don't do the bridge climb, walking across the bridge is highly recommended.
Brilliant even in rainy weather. Did the bridge climb in poor conditions but still enjoyed it. The views of sydney harbour were unforgettable!
Love it. Love it walked and stood under it up at the Rocks. Love it when the ferry went under it, special yes

Climbed to the top!. A wonderful experience. Everyone gets put in special jumpsuits. Not very becoming but you all look the same. They harness you to the bridge. You go up ladders and then up steps to the top of the bridge. The views are fantastic.It was an experience I will never forget and thoroughly enjoyed. Well worth the visit!

nice. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is another big icon of the city. It is the world’s tallest steel arch bridges connecting northern suburbs of Sydney with the city centre. This beautiful bridge is fondly called ‘Coathanger’ by the locals because of its arch-based designs. The bridge is accessible by car, bus, cycle and even by foot. One can enjoy the scenic beauty by a ride on a ferry or a cruise. Bridge climbing is a famous sport at this bridge since 1998. Bridge climbing is sure to give an unforgettable experience with a wonderful view of the Sydney harbour.

Soaked in history and beauty!. I have been through and under this amazing national icon hundreads of times and over once! Its amazing worth a visit not sure if the amount you pay for the bridge climb is worth it but I heard thst you get justvas stunning views for free or almost free on the pylons.

It's just a bridge. Someone once told me that walking across the Sydney Harbour Bridge is akin to walking across the Brooklyn Bridge in New York. I disagree. It offers a fabulous view of the Opera House and the harbour in general, but I dare say Sydney's skyline isn't particularly impressive. Walking across is free, so it's a nice activity on a nice day, but be warned: some guide maps indicate that The Pylon observatory is free...but it ain't. It's $13.

Majestic. Our Harbour Bridge looks so strong yet majestic and we always celebrate our New Year's fireworks here... quite famous for it's extravagant fireworks... one of the favourite icon of Australia that you should not miss...not to mentioned that it overlooks the Sydney Opera House & Luna Park on the other side...

what a great life experience. what a great way to see this beautiful city. the staff at the start of the bridge climb were very safety orientated and friendly at the same time. our guide was fun and the views were too amazing for words. I got a bit scared when I got closer to the top but got over it when I took a breath and took the awesomeness of the 360degree views

Another icon of Sydney -- definitely do the bridge climb. Yep, it had to be done. So we did it. We got into a top-gun type jumpsuit, put on a waist harness and strapped ourselves to the cabling that runs all the way up to the top of the bridge. About 1300 stairs - and according to fit-bit - about 6000 steps total -- some amazing views. I only wish we could have taken up our cameras - but nothing extra is allowed (no jewelry, cameras, bags, etc - since any of these can fall down onto the highway running through below). Definitely do this - you won't regret it. It's not nearly as taxing of a walk/climb as it looks.

The Coat Hanger. That's the name fondly g iven this crescentt-shaped bridge. I've been going over it a couple of times a day while staying with a friend in North Sydney. The bus ride is fun as we rattle, bounce and whiz over this bridge in the special bus lanes. It only takes 20 minutes to be right in the CBD. Been over this busy bridge at least a dozen times now and still looking forward to more trips!
An amazing day. The Harbour Bridge climb is a great experience. It's really fun and provides a unique and amazing view of Sydney.I'd recommend to tourists and sydney siders alike.

Bridge Climb. Best views in Sydney. Great experience and good value. Climb was quite easy. Brett our guide was very nice and gave us a lot of information about the bridge. The day of climb was clear and warm and views from the top of the bridge were amazing. You get a group photo and hat included in price. Photos are taken of individuals which can be purchased at a reasonable price. Brett also took a short video of each person which you can send to you personal email address at no charge. Overall if you are in Sydney you should try and fit this in to your trip.

Bridge Climb. I have climbed the bridge three times, twice on Anzac Day and the Last Post was played when we reached the top. This has only been carried maybe three times and only for diggersNevertheless it is a trip that any tourist from overseas or local should not miss, day or night.

Amazing Experience!!. One of the coolest things I've done in my life!!(and I've done a lot!!) The views were spectacular!! Make sure to do the full "Bridge Climb" tour. Guide was very entertaining and took lots of pictures of myself & girlfriend during all different points on tour. Worth the $ to buy the full picture sets too!
Amazing. A wonderful bridge, you can climb to the top of the bridge, if you are brave or fit enough, the views are great, overlooking the Sydney Opera House.

History of the Bridge.. The walk across the Bridge is great but the climb up the Pylon is worth every step. A short video shows the building of the Bridge and a collection of items from the past makes a very interesting start for the climb. Every 2 levels is a rest area and a history display to stop to read and give your legs a break. When you get to the top the view is amazing, viewing Sydney from a different perspective. Viewing the Harbour then all the way out to the suburbs. If your a visitor to Sydney I highly recommend this tour.

Take a Bridge Climb. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is an iconic part of Australia's history. You can climb this magnificent structure by paying a reasonable amount for a guided tour. The views are sensational.

An iconic run. If you are a runner and you are in Sydney, you have to run across the bridge. Don't go over on the bike lanes ... there are hefty fines. Follow the rather vague signs for the pedestrian route. Easy to find once you have found it ;)
Love this bridge. get walk - wonderful exercise - magnificant views - great way to spend the day walking over having lunch in small cafe and then walking back again

A lovely walk across the bridge, a lifetime memory. A short walk from Milsons Point train station got us to the stairs to the bridge. It's a lovely gentle walk with plenty to see, the views are the best in the world, especially on a sunny day. (Don't forget your hat, unlike me!) at the other side of the bridge you descend through the historic Rocks area to the Quay. Very pleasant!

Bridge Climb!. Unless you have an unforgiving fear of heights, DO NOT miss this "bucket list" experience! ! I climbed with my 14 year old neice in October this year for my birthday. The preparation, support staff and commentary were all outstanding! We had a perfect Spring day and relentless blue skies. While no personal items are allowed, the photos and videos provided as part of the package made this even more memorable...Jump on their website Bridgeclimb and begin YOUR journey!!

Bridging Amazing Views.... One of the worlds finest bridges. If you're in Sydney make sure you go and check it out. You cant miss it... its the big bridge. In the middle of the harbour. Just follow that. And you'll get there.

Great climb. We climbed up to the top with bridgeclub and it was fantastic, although a tad bit expensive it is on a good twilight definitely worth it. Highly recommend the Twilight time as you go up up during the day and down after sunset. Amazing obviously it is also beautiful from the ground!
Spectacular if you don't mind heights......... Really a must do in Sydney is the bridge climb. The view is spectacular. The dust walk is the best as you get the best of both worlds. Day and night.

Climbing the Harbour Bridge. My wife and I climbed the bridge, I thought it would be an issue due to my weight, I weight just over 160kg. so I was fitted with the biggest suit they have and all is going well, we walk out through some narrow parts, duck under some gantry type things, then stop. We have a four staggered ladders to climb, climbing one at a time and allowing the person in front to get the top of there ladder, that all went well. After this we have to climb the arch of the bridge, I was surprised, it was not too bad at all, and the view at the top is just amazing, got to be on everyone's list of this to do. Going down was just as much fun, a tad easier, but I would do this again tomorrow.

Great Bridge Climb. Decided to do the Bridge Climb as it is probably the only time we will be in Sydney. Meticulous preparation by staff to ensure safety. Lexi, our guide was excellent and provided background information. Wonderful views all the way to the top. We were a little concerned whether it would be strenuous, but other than a couple of places, e.g. climbing ladders, was actually not difficult at all. It is expensive, but I am glad we did it.

STUNNING. Stunning place. I went there during summer and although I was really tired cuz i walked a lot under the burning Sun, It was really worth it. The bridge is awesome and I reckon the place where it was built it was makes it unique and amazing.

The coat hanger Bridge. The view of the bridge is awesome regardless which point you look from. There are many ways to see it. One is the expensive HarbourClimb. The cheaper way is by going up the Pylon Lookout and the free way is to walk across the bridge itself.

Incredible Experience! Can't Miss!. Such an incredible experience! My friends and I did the night climb (because it was a bit cheaper) and it was crazy! We were really lucky to have a warm night with almost no breeze, but the view from the bridge is incredible, and the guides are full of knowledge and really chatty and friendly. The whole process ran really smoothly and is seamlessly organised and the catered to everyone in the group, including an older couple and someone scared of heights. It is expensive, but not for a single second did I regret spending the money, it's a must do if you're ever in Sydney!If you're contemplating it but are unsure about fitness, there's only one long part of stairs, and just as you begin the question how much longer you climb for, you're there. Incredibly doable for any fitness level. The stairs also directly follow the curvature of the arch and are not steep at all and hardly feel like stairs. If you're scared of heights and contemplating the climb, the scariest part is the beginning catwalk, in which you can see the ground below you. But it only gets less scary from there, and the higher you go, the less you can see beneath you and the more view you get of the opera house.

One of the most iconic structure in the world. Like the opera house, this is something that Sydney and Australia should be very proud of. Viewable from so many points around the city it is something that you are simply in awe of. One day I would like to complete the climb as I have done so with the story bridge in Brisbane, I can only imagine the views would be amazing. Driving over or under the bridge you can just get a sense of the shear size but still doesn't do it complete justice.
An engineering marvel!. Drove over this bridge and walked below it! Through out the time, i was admiring its beauty and amazed at the ingenuity of it!

Brilliant Bridge Climb. My husband, adult daughter and I did the twilight Bridge Climb on December 7th 2015. Our group was led by Dan, who was charming and funny and told us lots of interesting things about the bridge. The views were amazing and the pace was leisurely so we had lots of time to look around. The whole experience took about four hours, with the first hour devoted to getting kitted up with clothing, a radio, headlamp etc and practicing how to climb up and down the ladders safely. The sound quality of the radio was crystal clear. As we came down the climb, it was getting dark, and the lights were coming on in the city, on the opera house and around the harbour - the view was stunning. This is a fantastic, fascinating and fun thing to do, and I would definitely recommend it, and would go again if I ever had the opportunity to do so.

Don't Miss the Bridge Walk. We finally got around to the bridge on our last day in Sydney and, now that we've taken the walk, I realize we'd have really missed out on an amazing experience had we not done this. Wow, talk about stunning vistas of Sydney's harbor, the city, and the suburbs in every direction.We began our walk at the Circular Quay elevator, riding up to the highway level at the top floor. We were gawking in every direction during the walk. This is the most ideal location in the entire city for people watching and for taking pictures.We didn't know until we got on the bridge span that you can climb right up to the top inside one of the concrete pylons for an even higher vantage point, for a fee of $13. Seniors pay $8.50. There's an educational video to watch too. We didn't have time to stop, as we'd planned to meet friends on the north side of the bridge.People looking for an adrenaline rush can arrange to climb up to the flag on the very top of the bridge's steel arch, as part of a group adventure. The cost is about $150. Our entire walk was probably a mile from start to finish. You can walk back across, of course, or you can hop on a train at the north side of the bridge. Or if you head down to the north waterfront, you can catch a ferry back to Circular Quay.

Iconic. This bridge has to be the most photographed bridge in Australia! It provides a great backdrop to the Sydney harbour. What better way to spend a lazy Sunday afternoon then to sit back on the harbour and take in the sights of two icons?

Amazing. You can walk on the bridge all the way across. It is free to the public and a great place to take pictures of the opera house and the harbor. It is a long walk though so be sure to wear comfortable shoes.

Bridge Climb. This was the best thing I have experienced in Sydney so far! Highly recommend it! It was not at all scary it was exciting and I felt very well looked after and safe. The tour guide was so much fun as well as being so informative and we got some awesome pictures! Value for money and a must do in sydney

Lower level crossing nearly as good. We had originally planned to do a bridge climb, but due to a shortage of time on our first day, we decided to delay the climb to our final day, and just walk across the lower, traffic level. After doing so, we decided that the view offered of the harbor, opera house and city skyscrapers wax real all we would have expected of the climb, do we scratch the higher clim version, which jensen approximately $200 per person. Unless you really enjoy heights, and a fairly strenuous climb, or just want to be able to boast that you did the Sydney Bridge climb,mypu may wish to try just the free lower level crossing first. It sufficed for us, and was a worthwhile, much shorter activity.
impressive. great view, impressive construction, hallmark, a must be seen and worth be seen, fit people can climb it

Awesome landmark!. This bridge is awesome to see! The location is beautiful! We did the pillon climb. It's a good deal at $13 and the view is awesome. The actual bridge climb is very expensive so we opted for the pillon climb.
Great views. Did the walk to the top . Express climb was great . Good value for money. Tour guide was very good . Thanks Adam

Do not go to Sydney and not walk across the bridge. Walking across the bridge, is a must (it is also free; not to be confused with the bridge climb which has a cost)! We crossed it both during the day (get to walk along the side with views of the Opera House), and night (have to cross on the opposite side of the bridge where, during the day, it is cyclists-only). Breathtaking views of the harbour, the City, North Sydney, and the beautiful landscape. If you do not feel like crossing it twice, you can walk one direction and then catch a train back to the other side.

Good view. I've been to the harbour bridge a lot and even ran the marathon over it, but my best memory of it was walking on it late at night to get a great photo of the sydney opera house. Honestly it's a bridge. Nothing more and nothing less. But as bridges come, this ones a pretty nice one to look at and look from.

Do the climb. The really is only one way to see the harbour bridge and, while you're at it, the whole of Sydney and that is to do the bridge climb. Is not cheap but is really worth it. I get vertigo at about 10 feet so I was a bit nervous but the whole organisation is so good and so safe there was no problem for me. The climb is full of interesting facts and fantastic views and of course a sense of achievement.Really worthwhile
Bridgeclinb is a "must-do.". Great climb leaders, and a relaxed climb to the top, 134 metres up, with superb views. The exhibition at Bridgeclimb headquarters is also definitely worth a look.

Defining Landmark. The bridge "climbers" up near the flags (yes you can do this) must have a pretty unique view; seeing the enormous cruise ships that are almost the span of the bridge is compelling. Those who constructed it in the 1930's could never have foreseen that one....

Must take the walk across. While most of you visiting will once or twice will cross the bridge in a Vehicle , and might think "it's a just a bridge" . That's why you need to take the walk , see the ships/ boats floating underneath you, see the Opera house from the bridge, feel that wind blowing across (even on a hot summer day so it feels much more comfortable than anywhere else in the city), take the few meters stroll to Rocks on city side and Kirribilli see the shopping/cafes or just sit on a lawn or a park bench and just chill off....take your time, enjoy.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon climb - the OTHER bridge climb!. One of the 5 most known icons for any visitor to Sydney along with the Sydney Opera House, Sydney Harbour, Bondi Beach and Manly Beach.You can drive over it, bus over it, train over it, cycle over it, walk over it and climb over but did you know that you can climb into it .... which is why I am writing this review!I am amazed by the number of visitors to Sydney that I meet who know about the (quite expensive) Harbour bridge climb but who know nothing about the MUCH cheaper (about $20) climb you can do up into the south-eastern pylon (the one nearest Circular Quay) which contains a small museum of the building of the bridge, including a 15 min audio visual movie, which is very interesting and takes you up to the observation level of the pylon giving you breathtaking 360 degree views over Sydney and the harbour, and at a height that is only a little less that what you get to, if you do the expensive bridge climb!I would say to anyone contemplating the bridge climb - do this first and then decide whether the approx $A300 for the climb is worth it (while you are on the observation deck you will see several groups in various stages of the climb). Adrenalin junkies will have to do the bridge climb but $A300 does buy you access to lots of other fun things to do in Sydney - it's worth thinking about that before you spend it on the climb.There is no lift that I know of, so wheel-chair access may not be possible - The Rocks Information Centre, which is only a few hundred metres away just off George street, on the corner of Argyle & Playfair Streets, can give you directions on how to get from them to the pylon (stairs are involved) and advise on wheel-chair access. I'd guess there are several hundred stairs in the pylon you must climb but they do have seats on the platforms at different levels so you can rest if needed.Welcome to my city, I hope you all enjoy it as much as I have.

Truely amazing. One of the icons of Sydney! The most spectacular view you will ever get of our gorgeous harbour in Sydney. The Sydney Harbour bridge instantly identifying Australia. You can walk across the bridge for free via access steps both on the Kirribilli side as well as in the rocks.

Climbing. Climbing the bridge is amazing thing to do , as its once in a life time. How ever it does take 3 hours as in 1.5 hour to train you and get fitted up and 1.5 hour to walk it . Once on the bridge the views are breath taking and they take photos of u up there. It is around $300 but its worth it . Well enjoy the walk .

Historic Landmark. They do excellent bridge climb walks though on this occasion we just had a ferry ride underneath looking at the spectacular structure. The deepest part of the harbour is underneath the bridge.
Great bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is a must-see attraction when visiting Sydney. You can walk across it or even climb it!

Great views of the Harbor - a must do in Sydney. We went across on the regular walkway. It was a little windy but the views were just fantastic. Watched sailboats in the harbor and just enjoyed a leisurely stroll. On the other side was the amusement park called Luna Park and it was very interesting to learn of the history and see the rides, even though it wasn't open. Took the ferry back across the harbor and enjoyed a nice meal at Circular Quay.
Must do. Fantastic view of all of Sydney. We did the climb at sunset and even though it was very expensive, it was well worth the experience.

Great views with a bit of everything going on, especially history. Something for everyone. It has great walks, restaurants and wonderful historical buildings. There are impressive big ships coming and going daily, modern art museums, ferries to other destinations, walks under the bridge, Opera House, botanic Gardens within walking distance, markets on a Friday...the list goes on! Plenty of restaurants of all flavours to choose from and cafés, wine bars, pubs and a good creperie in Harrington street.
Grand sight. This looks even better at night once lit up. I went there on a full moon night, and it looked heavenly.
This is the highlight of Sydney. The Opera house gets a lot of attention, but the Bridge steals the show. It's absolutely incredible. Amazing feat of engineering

Wow. Walked across bridge on walkway. Fantastic view of city and Opera house. There is a museum half way across for $13 giving a history of the bridge. If you really want to splash out there is the bridge walking tour where you ascend the actual bridge. Believe this is quiet pricey and we were happy just walking over. Fantastic experience and it was free!!!.
Walking the Bridge. A walk over the SHB is both challenging and rewarding. For those who others refer to as seniors - the exercise can be challenging but the views are with it.
Well worth the walk. I walked across the bridge and back. It's well worth the exercise for the view. It's not as daunting as it looks. Gorgeous views of the harbor and opera house. Do it!
A majestic structure. I just love this bridge - it has such character, both day and night. Would love to do the bridge climb!
Mechanically Majestic. I am mesmerized by the structure of the bridge. An engineering art. I love this masterpiece settling side by side with the Opera House.
Quite a landmark. I see the iconic landmark from 20k feet. On the ground the bridge is worth a dozen photos from different angle.

Just Amazing. You can go under it by boat/ferry, you can climb it , you can walk under it and look at how the huge rivets and bolts hold it together , and then just imagine how this Bridge was put together without the tools of trade we have today
Ride your bike across. Heard it was the thing to do . Rented bike and rode across bridge and North Sydney. Ride took less than 2 hours. it on a cruise and some a few hours.

The sampler walk was super. If you dont have the time or the courage to do the whole thing. Take the sampler walk. It last about 90 minutes and is on the lower arch so you get to see how the bridge is made.

Great View. We toured the bridge and got wonderful pictures and 360 view of Sydney. The cost was $150 to climb the bridge but it was well worth the view that you have. We crossed the bridge to get to the more suburban portion of Sydney and found that it was multifunctional. People crossed the bridge, the subway sued the bridge and of course cars.
Sydney harbour bridge. The Sydney harbour bridge is a wonderful sight at night especially with the lights over the water. Well worth a visit for anyone coming to Sydney.
Best View from bridge. I walked to bridge yesterday it had great view from bridge if you love to take pictures you must go to walking on bridge highly recommend it

Beautiful view from all directions.. Impressed with their method of traffic flow, with ability to change lanes in either direction depending on traffic flow. Saw lots of people walking up the steep arch but due to age I didn't attempt it.

Walk across even if not going to the top. While many people like to climb the bridge itself, we decided not to due to my fear of heights. Still get tremendous views if you choose to walk across and there is no charge.
Do the walk. Surprisingly easy walk, numerous security guards for safety, top views do the walk back or catch a ferry.

Such a amazing bridge!. It is much more beautiful than I thought it would be. Before I saw Habour Bridge in person, I thought 'It's just a bridge! What's special?" But now, this bridge is my favorite :-)I want to climb up this bridge next time

Great experience. The Sydney harbour bridge climb is amazing and highly recommended! If you pay a little extra to go at night on a Saturday then you get to see the opera house fireworks as you climb! Worth the extra money!
Must do the bridge climb!. Very well organised, informative and a good family day out. Good use of technology and suits provided

A beautiful backdrop. Visible from many areas, the bridge serves as a great backdrop for much of Sydney. You can walk up to, across, or on the bridge. Most is free, not sure about the climb up the bridge - we didn't do that!

Tick!. We didn't have the stomach ( or the lungs!) to do the walk across the top of the bridge, but we wanted to go from one side to the other. The bridge is accessed via a well signposted route through the Rocks and up quite a few stairs. One thing I like is that unlike the Golden Gate in San Francisco, cyclists have a different pathway to pedestrians, which means the walk is much safer. Fantastic photo points on the bridge. We are very glad that we did it and would highly recommend a walk across this iconic Sydney landmark.

Marvelous. Like the Opera House, the bridge is iconic and better than pictures portray. There are some very expensive options to climb over the bridge but you can actually walk along it for free. Another inexpensive option is to pay about $13 to go up one of the pylons to a lookout there (search for "pylon lookout").For some nice views from the water, take the Manly ferry and sit on the port side from the city or starboard side from Manly (and the opposite sides if you wish to see the Opera House). I'd suggest sitting on the starboard side to Manly (to see the Opera House) and the starboard side again on the return (to see the bridge).

Climbing it could be fun. The bridge nicely fit into the harbour in a way that it always stands out no matter you are far from it or you are beneath it. We would be crazy if we climb it with our daughter (probably they have a restriction on age of the climbers), and it looked pretty scary the way they climb it. Nevertheless, it would definitely be a unique experience if you really do it, as far as I can tell.

Not just another landmark. As you walk across the Sydney bridge imagine fireworks on the 4th of July. Spectacular views await you. For the reasonable fee required you can, on tour own with guides, climb inside of the pillars on both sides of the bridge until you reach the top. From here the views are even better. Or if you, dare you can join a group of other crazy adventurous people and participate in the walk that takes you to the top. I did not do this as I could not justify the almost $300 price tag. But that's me. I'm sure it must be worth it.

Lovely bridge right in the vity. I did not do a guide tour of the bridge but drove through the bridge on a cab, it's driver had good knowledge of the bridge which he shared. Not to be missed. I also viewed the bridge from the. Opera House.

Views from walk are great. An iconic landmark of Sydney up there with the opera house, but really it is just a big bridge. We found it very interesting to take the harbour walk and go underneath. Lots of interesting signage and it is free.

Impressive, But. !!!!!. One of the things we wanted to do while on a stopover in Sydney was the Bridge climb.what we didn't expect though was the cost. A whopping £128 each. The experience was good, with a great guide, but not worth that i'm afraid. We had done so many other things while we were away on our Honeymoon for a month and this was by FAR the most expensive excursion we did.
Great Looking Bridge. The location on the harbour is spectacular. Guaranteed great photographs of this landmark. Didn't opt to climb it, expensive and gruelling were our immediate thoughts.

Special to see but not worth $ to climb. Views can be great but when was there cost was $200 per person for the climbing tour. Can see various views of the bridge on both sides of it. Better near Opera House as easier to go see and do more from this location

Amazing landmark. This bridge walk is well worth your time while visiting the Rocks area of Sydney. If you don't pay to walk the bridge, just pay to walk up the Pier. It is so worth the views and to read how the bridge was created.

Imposing. Comes as a huge and pleasurable surprise whether you approach by road, rail of boat. The detail in the construction, the varying colours depending on time of day and watching the brave as they climb over the top all mean that it takes your attention for ages.
A must do in Sydney. I did the bridge climb and it's debatable whether it's worth the money or not. It was a beautiful view and a fun way to see the city but it was very pricey.

Sydney harbour bridge climb. This was one of the highlights of my trip to Sydney. Everyone who had done it said how good it was so I had high exhibitions. I did the twilight walk which is a bit more expensive. We were all specially geared up with clothes and belt and radios no shown how to how to use the gear. The climb takes about 3 hours . We left in a group of 14 with a team leader who explained things as you do the walk. Photos were taken at various points as you are not allowed to carry anything with you. The views are fantastic and it was lovely seeing thee sunset on the way down. I would recommend it to anyone.

Amazing!. We did the twilight Bridge Climb, which was amazing. We didn't realize when we booked it that it would take nearly 3 hours. Heights don't bother us, so being on the arch of the bridge was no big deal. The company takes every precaution for the customers safety and peace of mind. There are staff members stationed at strategic spots to assist anyone who can't complete the climb back to terra firma. This was a very cool activity!For those who want a free experience, you can wal across the bridge. We did that a few days later, and enjoyed the spectacular views.

Bridge is impressive but avoid Bridge Walk for all good reasons. The bridge is architecturally magnificent and it'll help if you learn about the enormous efforts that were spent on constructing this icon. Even by initially looking at it at a distance from the Opera House, my eyes were caught. My wife and I did the hyped Bridge Walk but very much regretted wasting a good amount of dollars and valuable 3 hours - it was just boring and over touristy, especially after spending a good amount of time with the nature in Tasmania. We were exhausted after the walk, not physically but mentally by the noise of the contruction site under the bridge, passing trains and vehicles, boats, and everything else inevitably coming at you. But again, the bridge itself is well worth a visit.

ICONIC SYMBOL OF SYDNEY. Looking at it, going underneath it in a ferry, walking across it, travelling across it by train and climbing it, the iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge is just amazing, the star of Sydney Harbour.

Nice stroll across the bridge. I walked across the Sydney harbour bridge stopping half way to watch the 5 P and O ships come in to the harbour. Coming from the south west I caught a train over to milsons point and started my walk from there. The steps leading up to the cahill expressway were right there and weren't as many as I thought. There were many photo opportunities and security guards positioned along the way. It wasn't as easy to get back to circular quay though. There are steps down into argyle street but be on the lookout for a small entrance on the right hand side of the road only a few meters after the stairs. So if you want to head to the quay from the stairs, don't blink or you will miss the entry point.

Fantastic . Fantastic best describes this pece of engineering, one of many icons Sydney has to offer.Lighting up at night is simply orsum , it's massively huge driving over the top of it, but you need your witts about you when driving on its deck.Overall take plenty of happy snaps from plenty of vantage points around.Great to take visitors and overseas friends too.If you want a bit to eat nearby there's plenty other restaurants and food outlet you can go to.

A very nice bridge. You should definitely go and see the bridge. It is possible to walk on the bridge and go to one of the pillars to have the fantastic view over Sydney Harbour area. My husband - being a construction engineer - was really excited!

Great views. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is an icon. We walked across (not over!) on a beautiful sunny, but not hot, day. The views of the Opera House and the Harbour were great and it was an excellent way to stretch the legs. It is a good outdoor activity with great photo opportunities.

Great views. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is an icon. We walked across (not over!) on a beautiful sunny, but not hot, day. The views of the Opera House and the Harbour were great and it was an excellent way to stretch the legs. It is a good outdoor activity with great photo opportunities.
Take the ferries to see the bridge. We took the manly and the darling harbor ferries to see the bridge from different angles. Wished the weather was nice enough for us to attempt to climb it!

Nice tour. We did the bridge climb since we'd read and heard about it. Climb was fun and interesting. Climb is well organized and professional. You are issued jump suite for the climb so your only concern for the climb is comfortable footwear. While it was quite an experience to see the Harbour and the Sydney skyline from the top of the bridge, the tour is quite expensive costing us $526 for the two of us. So not a budget activity.

"Sydney Harbor Bridge 1 of 2 icons in Sydney (other is Opera Hse.). The bridge climb was the highlight for me of the trip from Ohio to Sydney. It was not difficult though I was the oldest in our group at age 69. The preparations is thorough and orderly with a guide who explains everything you need to know as well as interesting historical facts about the bridge & surrounding area. The total time is 3.5 hrs. so it is a leisurely pace. There is also a "Sampler Bridge Climb" the goes up the inner span of the bridge vs. the outer span for the regular climb. Nothing is allowed on the bridge incl. cameras, cells, etc. I paid $213 USD so I do not know if there is a better "deal" elsewhere but it was well worth it. There is also a small gift shop in the lobby of the bridge climb area. The view is fantastic and the guide takes photos of the climbers along the way. You get one group photo and one generic photo and individual packages if you wish to purchase. I did not as the line was way too long at the check-out.

Bridge walk is a must do . I didn't book in advance and just got straight on to a climb, but this was mid-week, I think I'd book for a weekend.The views were breathtaking, it was an incredible experience and the guides were fantastic.Only criticism is the usual trick of paying extra for a the pictures. I can understand the rationale for not allowing cameras, but at $268 for a day walk they really should just email the pics the guide takes to you.I'm travelling with products without a USB port, so paying another $60 or so for a few digital pics on a USB stick is not a great deal of use.

Bridge climb was one of the highlights of our trip. The bridge climb was a very special experience. Everything was organized from the beginning. Lexie our guide did a fantastic job. It is not cheap but if you can spare the money this is a once in a lifetime experience!

Harbour bridge walk. We did the walk across the Sydney harbour bridge. We also went up into the pylon and saw the history of how the bridge was built. It was very interesting. Walk didn't take very long and we got the train back.
Impressive but not what I thought. I thought this bridge would be totally amazing and as I thought it was. The only downside is the age of the bridge and the number of security guards around.

It's just a bridge - but still worth seeing. I've been there before but since i was in Sydney again, i guess i had to go and see it again. And I was glad i did. I went at night so it was all lit up and it looked really nice.

A Climb to the Pinnacle of a Beautiful City. It was our first visit to Australia and I wanted to do something memorable. The Bridge Climb Sydney was just the right choice to commemorate my first visit to Sydney.Booking the ticket to the actual climb was so seamless. The Bridge Climb Sydney system is like a well-oiled machine and every detail was perfected by the team to make the experience memorable and hassle-free. The Sunset Climb was great! Our tour guide/instructor was great. I am just so sorry I forgot her name as this is a delayed review. I climbed the Sydney Bridge in May 2015.
Climb the bridge. The bridge climb was amazing, if you go in the afternoon, you get to see the view in the day and the view of the sunset. So worth the money. Extremely happy and would recommend.

Bridge clim is a must do. Worth the money. Wow. The bridge climb was definitely the highlight of our trip in Australia. It is well worth the money. Once in a lifetime opportunity. The guides are so nice, they really make this moment special. We did the first twilight climb (17:15pm) on a bright and sunny day so we really got to see both the view during day, the sunset, and the start of the night. The climb is not as difficult as they seem to mention on the website. Could only recommend doing it. The climb also include a free picture and free entry to the Pylon Lookout.

Harbour Bridge Climb ... Best views in Sydney!. We were pleasantly surprised at how well this was organised, with every attention to detail. Being rather nervous of the climb I was immediately put at ease by the instructors and was supported every step of the way. There were plentiful stops and photos taken by the leader. Their intention is to get everyone to face their fears and be successful.A fantastic experience and one we would recommend to anyone who might have concerns.

Challenge Youself Amazing Experience......... Never say Never. What a well organised and professional journey. The Bridge Climb was one of the best experiences my daughter and I have had and how wonderful to share it with her. We felt confident with all the instruction and equipment. Everything was explained in full detail. We felt safe at all times. The staff were very caring and kind natured. Our guide for the climb was fantastic what a great personality his name was Brett and he loves what he does you can tell. We could not have ordered better weather but I think no matter what the weather might be once you reach the top of the bridge you will only have eyes for the most magnificent view.

Awesome Bridge. The bridge is just in front of The Rocks. You can have great photo taking from The Rocks or in front of the Opera House. Great view at night. From The Rocks, you can walk up to the base of the bridge.

Nice views. We walked across the bridge and got some good pictures. We didn't spend the money on the Bridge Climb or Pylon Lookout, but what we saw was great. Follow the signs to the bridge stairs or ask someone. There are so many levels in The Rocks area, that it's a little hard to find.

Bridge Climb. Having a few second thoughts about doing the Bridge Climb I was pleasantly surprised when I actually came to doing it ,the climb was not as scary as I expected it might have been and it was well marshalled and organised everybody was put at their ease by the tour guide especially anybody feeling a bit nervous. Well worth the experience.

Unparalleled Views. We arrived as instructed early for our briefing. This was essential as theres a lot of equipment and clothes to put on. We were guided by a lady called Gemma who was brilliant she was able to converse with all the group young and old. She had a good sense of humour and made the accent and decent very enjoyable. We started the climb at about 5pm and were lucky to bee on the bridge during the sun setting and all the lights coming up on the harbour and opera house. in all it took around 3hrs 30 mins. but well worth it enjoyed it and made friends with those win our group.
Must do!. What a great adventure...do the 3.5 hr tour...it is the best...staff was fabulous, really FUN tour...even in the rain and wind! So glad we did this!
Highly recommend the Pylon Climb. For $13 the pylon climb is great value and spectacular views. Highly recommend it if you can manage the stairs. Video and photos to check out during the climb

Bridge Climb. Great experience, fantastic views. May be a bit pricy for the experience but I thought it was worth it. Our guide was full of knowledge, gave a talk at different stages of the climb and answered any questions put to her.Photos were taken at certain parts and also a video message if you wanted to. Only downside was you are not allowed to take your own cameras up there, so you will have to buy there photos.They come on a memory stick so easy to please in your luggage.

Great views of Great Harbour. Everytime I get to Sydney, I catch the train to North Shore and walk back over the bridge towards the city.What magnificent views!I do this about every 5 months ad it never gets old. The harbour is always beautiful and the views of the city are always as great as ever!This is a magnificent way of seeing Sydney on the cheap

Great view of harbor and skyline. Took a walk over the Sydney Harbor Bridge. Great views of the harbor and the skyline of Sydney. There was some stairs to climb at first but the crossing of the bridge was an easy walk and it was free. Great place to take pictures.

bridge climb with fantastic views. Immensely enjoyed the climb with my gracious host. Unfortunately you are forbidden from bringing anything including your camera so I missed taking photos. The "Climb" is minimal exertion.
fantastic. my daughter did the climb,loved it.If you are afraid of heights you might want to reconsider climbing it.
Bridge climb is worth the money. The views are great and the time flew by. The tour guides are very knowledgeable and get the right mix of talking and time to enjoy the views whilst you are up there.
Expensive but worth it. Yes it is a bucket list experience. A costly one at that. The staff were all great and very professional. You need to book this up in advance and it seems to easily sell out.

Spectacular Structure with Unbeatable Views. Terrific place to observe harbour activity and some of the freshest air in Sydney when breeze is onshore from east. Easy to access and great destinations at both ends of the bridge.

Fantastic Landmark . If you're in Sydney you've got to check it out. Free to walk across with fantastic views! I also did the Bridge Climb, great for open views of the harbour and especially the opera house!

WOW. What an amazing structure especially when you realise it's held together with quite a few screws and just four bolts. I just wish I didn't have a problem with heights as the view from there must be amazing

Sydney through and through. The Sydney Harbour Bridge holds a dear place in my heart. I first saw it at the age of 18 when backpacking ten-years ago, ever since then whenever I see it I get the shivers - it is simply the iconic sight of Sydney. You can't not appreciate it! Take a walk along it from The Rocks (I'm lucky enough that I do this daily now) and visit Milsons Point - there are some fine restaurants the other side of the bridge as a tourist you should know about too (The Botanist!!) and you can also visit the Kirribilli Markets too (every fortnight on the weekends).Cyclists/Pedestrians don't have to worry about each other as you have your own designated side of the bridge :)The Harbour Bridge, is simply a must-do when in Sydney, there are so many things happening around it that you would be silly not to!

Just as good. If you're not up for the full bridge climb then go to the southeast pilon and climb that instead. The view is just as beautiful; less effort (although still several flights of stairs); and at $13 is one tenth the price. Perhaps the poor mans alternative but still the second best way to view Australia's most beautiful harbour.
Free of charge. Walk across Sydney bridge and its free of charge. The view is stunning. It takes around 40 mins and you can start from the Rocks.

Landmark in Sydney. One of the icons of Sydney! It's visible from all directions along the harbour. Connects main Sydney with suburbs. During the night the view is even more spectacular due to lighting done!Tip: thrill seekers can opt for bridge walk which takes around 2 hours to climb to the top of the bridge. Must do!

Fantastic place to see all of Sydney. The Sydney Harbour bridge walk is a fantastic experience led by very capable guides. The Bridge walk is well organised and excellent briefings add to the experience. The guide that we had really knew her facts (Phoebe) and gave us an excellent documentary throughout the experience. Make sure you leave enough time as the preparation and walk takes over three hours but the experience is one of those once in a lifetime events that you should do.

Sydney Harbour Bridge and the surrounding areas are a must see. I have lived in Sydney all my life and I have worked in Sydney all of my adult life and I never get bored of seeing the Bridge and the Opera House. Whether it is during the day or in the evening you will never regret the experience. Sydneysiders know what a resource it is and that is why we are drawn to the area.

You have to do the Bridge Climb. In addition to the great view the bridge is after seeing the New Years eve on TV, is great to be able to visit it. We did the bridge walk which takes you to the highest point of the bridge in a very safely way. You got to do it...
New years is awesome at the Harbour. It was exciting to bring in the new year in Sydney Harbour. We also did the bridge climb and was exciting to be on top of the bridge.

What an awesome time on a bridge. So taking the "Bridge Climb" is a wonderous experience. Something that you really should do if you are in Sydney.As tehy prepare you for the walk / climb, you get a sense of anticipation. When the tour starts adn all teh formal "training" fopr safety has been compelted, you move out. The climb is not difficult and is really easy and paced to cater for all ages and fitmess types.Taks the time to do this and see the sites of Sydney and the Harbour, learn the history of the bridge and the effort to build her.Well worth the small amaount of time out of your life to experience something magical.

Don't book too far in advance. This is a really nice excursion but careful not to book too far in advance. If the weather is poor (and it wasn't great when we went) then you'll have committed a sizeable amount of money to an excursion that is VERY weather dependent. And when I say sizeable I mean it - twilight and dawn trips are exorbitantly expensive.
Awsome awsome awsome. The most spectacular view you will ever get of our gorgeous harbour in sydney. The climb is very gentle ...In fact you don't realise your going up that high.well worth it
ACE!. Walk the bridge! Again, another great landmark, opened in 1932 - iconic backdrop to the Opera House if over towards Hyde Park...

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb - a great experience!. Although the price paid to climb the bridge was rather steep, the experience was still worth it. I had all kinds of fear about the climb but they were tossed to the wind the minute we set off a a group, led by Alastair, an excellent guide who provided very clear instructions and told us stories about the bridge along the way. Did you know that SIX million hand driven rivets and 53,000 tonnes of steel were used in its construction?!The weather was very kind on the day of our climb. Upon reaching the top of the bridge, I felt a sense of achievement. I am not the fittest of all, but still found the climb easy compared to the Yellow Mountain climb in China. All the safety measures were in place and everything was so professionally organized. Very impressive indeed!

Amazing. An early start to watch our approach into Sydney harbour on a cruise ship and first view of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. We travelled over the bridge and took photos from the air. We also watched the groups of climbers on the bridge structure from all angles. Apparently it is possible to climb up the inner stairs of one tower. Looking forward to returning next year.

No need to pay for the climb!. Those climbs are pricey - $300 and up (USD). They're long. Weather can be uncomfortably hot or cold. And they don't let you bring your phone or camera - you have to buy the pics they take of you on the bridge. Instead, walk across the bridge for FREE, to the Pylon Tower Building. Climb 200 steps. You will be starting out above the halfway point for those that are doing the big climb. It's about $15 per person. There's places to rest in the stairwell if you need. Get to the top and enjoy the panoramic views, and you will be higher than some of the people on the arch (not the tippy top, obviously). There's a little museum halfway up with the history. Oh, and bring your camera and phone and take as many pics as you like, at no extra charge.

Bridge Walk. On a hot, November morning, wearing hats and carrying water, we set off on a walk across the Harbour Bridge. Beautiful, clear day so the views were fabulous. Interesting points included seeing the Opera House from a different angle, watching the very busy activity of the ferries and other craft on the harbour and of course seeing the amazing structure of the bridge.Bikes are on one side of the bridge and walkers and joggers are on the other side. There are lots of easy-to-climb steps at the beginning (The Rocks) and the pylons provided shade.Very pleased we decided to take a walk.

a part of history. Even those who have issues with heights will like this. Very safe and not strenuous. We had an interesting guide and provided a lot of fun and interesting facts. Pictures are taken at the top of the bridge with great views of the harbor in the background.

Not to be missed!. I was apprehensive about doing the climb, but it's not at all what I thought. The most difficult part for me was walking on the mesh girders from the Bridge Climb office to the bridge's cement abutment. If you looked at your feet, you saw all the way to the ground below! However, once you are on the bridge span, it is solid metal beneath your feet and you can only see down by leaning over the sides. Great fun! Breathtaking views! Plus, the bridge tour guides were friendly, personable and strove to make everyone's experience a positive one!

Interesting and a little scary. I did the bridge climb at night. It was actually a little scary walking up over the water but also an insane adrenaline rush! There is nothing quite like it. I was in awe when we got to the top and saw the view and felt so fortunate to have done it. Highly recommended.

From a distance. Due to rain sadly we couldn't do the bridge walk, however we had the views of this amazing construction from our hotel and at night it looks fantastic.I would imagine at night is the best time to climb across this attraction as you would see everything lit up and with no smog.

What a bridge. What fantastic landmark. A tip for overseas and interstate visitors. Skip the bridge climb and instead go to and climb the South Eastern Pillon.
The views are the same as the bridge climb and you see exactly the same but you will save a lot of money $13 to do the pillon as apposed to +$100's

The Bridge Climb a must do!!. Enjoy climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge. A climb for everyone. Choose of many types of climb, get fitted up with your equipment and away you go. At no time are you in danger, it is a controlled climb and you go at the slowest persons pace. You can't take anything with you and it is locked away in your locker. They take a photo of your group at the top and give you a certificate for free. You pay for the photo they take of your own party. It is a must do when in Sydney. Check out the ages etc... young and old can do it!!

The Coathanger. Amazing peace of engineering, some 50 000 tons of steel and millions of rivets. Is a spectacular landmark, The Sydney Harbour bridge instantly identifying Australia. You can walk across the bridge for free via access steps both on the Kirribilli side as well as in the rocks. You can go up in one of the pylons (paying a few AUD for the pleasure). An interesting fact though is that the pylons themselves have no load carrying capability for the bridge itself. The bridge rests on massive bolts at the foundation of the pylons. the pylons do support the access roads from both ends though.

The Coat Hanger. This without a doubt one of the worlds iconic images, to see it up close and personal is awe inspiring you just don't appreciate the scale and the grandeur of this landmark until you touch it.
Iconic. Just sensational to look at, walk across or drive across. A must see when in Sydney. The Bridge Climb is supposed to be awesome, not for the fainthearted

Do the Pylon climb for sure!. We chose to self walk tour the Bridge and do the Pylon climb for $13 and loved it. We learned all about the bridge on our self guided tour and got some amazing views of Sydney in the meantime!

Beautiful structure. Our son did the three hour climb of the bridge. The process is carefully manged with a prep beforehand and clothing and equipment that is firmly secured. It sounds doable for much age groups as long as they can walk comfortably and manage some ladder like steps.

Iconic Symbol, Engineering Marvel, Unparalleled Viewpoint. The Harbour Bridge, like the Opera House, are immediately recognizable symbols of Sydney, as well as beautiful pieces of architecture and engineering. They are also both outstanding locations from which to soak in the beautiful city and harbor. Some favorite spots along the Harbour Bridge follow…BRIDGE CLIMB This is a well-known and exhilarating tour that takes you to the top of Sydney Harbour Bridge, with spectacular panoramic views from the summit of Sydney Harbour, Opera House, city, etc. A must do on your visit to Sydney; you can also do sunset, evening climbs. On the tour, you will move as part of a group through tunnel that passes through the bridge foundation, and on to catwalks suspended under the bridge deck, up a set of ladders (as always attached by harness to a guidewire), through the bridge deck (where traffic passes), and then onto the wide, gently sloped stairs that you will climb (well more walk than climb) to the summit of the bridge. At the summit you'll enjoy the grand view from a height of 130m / 400f + of a large swath of beautiful Sydney Harbour, skylines along both north & south sides of the Harbour, the Opera House, Circular Quay, etc. You're given quite a while to soak in the view. On a sunny day, with bit of wind, it's an amazing place, view, experience. The guide will take another group photo, and then will call over each set of folks (couples, families, friends, individuals) for photos from summit. After that, the easy walk & climb down; or, basically the above in reverse ;) BRIDGE PYLON The Sydney Habour Bridge has four pylons – large cement towers atop the foundations for the four main bearings (two at each end) that anchor the bridge; and, one of these, the South East Pylon is accessible to the public and has a lookout atop it. This is a great companion activity, or alternative if time and budget demand, to the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. The top of the pylon, at 87 meters (285 feet) above the harbor, offers great views of the Sydney Harbour Bridge (up close), the Opera House, the Circular Quay, and the Harbour itself. The entrance fee is modest at AU$13 for people over 13 years in age. It is open every day until 5p. There is a bit of a climb (200 stairs), but exhibits and stops break up the climb if needed. Since the Harbour Bridge Climb does not, for obvious reasons relating to falling objects, permit cameras atop the bridge – this, then, is the best alternative for taking photographs from a similar vantage point. The views are outstanding. BENEATH THE BRIDGEThere are parks beneath the south and north ends of the bridge, along the harbor shore. Dawes Point, at the south end, has Dawes Point Park. It is in close proximity to the sites of The Rocks area and the Circular Quay; and, has a grassy area for picnics. At the north end of, and below, the bridge, lies Bradfield Park, which is larger and offers great views of the Sydney skyline, Opera House, Bridge, etc.

A must climb for everyone!. Sydney Harbor bridge's making history tells you a lot about the difficult times and the bravery of the workers who made this marvel so many years ago! A visit to the information centre and watching the making of bridge movie makes you wanting to climb it! No visit to Sydney is complete if a tourist does not climb it. It is a simple, safe and informative climb for even not so daring ones! The views from top of the Sydney opera and the Sydney harbor are breathing taking! The group photo on top makes you feel nostalgic! This climb is a must even if you don't climb Mt Everest!
Brilliant. Did not do the bridge climb but walked over it and went up one of the turrets great views and information about the bridge

Wow!. What a fab bridge and a great iconic attraction. Around the harbour you can also see the Sydney opera house. You can climb the bridge if you wish to. Would be nice to see it in the evening as well.

Must walk in the morning!. While the sun is rising ..... you can see the beauty of the city from this bridge. The warmth of the sun rays touches your cheeks and clod breeze freezes your finger while taking photos of the scenic beauty of the city

A comforting presence. I live near the Bridge so it's a constant presence in my life. I go past it every day to catch the ferry, walk over it from Milsons Point to the Botanical Gardens or the Rocks, or catch a train into the CBD. A long time ago I did the BridgeClimb. I love the thing and feel comforted by its presence.
Nothing Special. I was here on a sunny day and the bridge offers a good shelter. I was amazed by its engineering work but, besides that, I do not find it special.
An amazing feat of construction and an Icon of Sydney. It is part of Sydneys charm, well worth a walk along the bridge and up one of the pylons for a birds eye view of the harbour

Must Do. We went as a couple. We were excited to do this climb the bridge. Its lasts for 3 hours. It was very enjoyable. Its a must do , once in a lifetime experince. We were inducted before the walk and how safety and precautions used. Great veiws of Harbour and a interesting walk

Sydney Harbour Bridge. This is a landmark of Sydney. We walked it as part of our tour of the city. From the point we climber it, after several flights of stairs, you'll get to the actual bridge where you can enjoy stunning views of the harbor, the Opera House and many other buildings. When we visited it there was a lot of wind, luckily we brought a jacket.

The most famous bridge in the world. I have had the opportunity to actually walk the bridge in both direction with NO cars crossing.The was a great feeling but so rare.Alternatively on the side walk facing the Opera is the side to be, the authorised is a cycle way and railway lineI have never done the clim because I am embarrass to say that high and I are not the best of friends.It is the best view alone and secure. Yes security will be walking to make sure that all is safe at all time. Also the piece of resistance when fireworks are on. Special the waterfall fireworks.Remember that the best way to see the must beautiful sunset is at the Spring and Autumn So next time you are in Sydney do yourself the walk across and or the climb that you can access form Milsons point station or the Rocks Now for those wanting to do the climb the following areThe normal clim start at $128.00 up to $353.00 per person.all will depend on the group type, time of the climb, period and season of the year.All tickets climb to the top will includes the following a Climb Group Photograph with a Certificate of Achievement and a BridgeClimb Cap and finely the free entry to the Pylon Lookout. So a great choice of options provided.
Exhilarating. Awesome Terrified first time so glad my son's made me climb!!!! 2nd time at night amazing and so different as went up through the middle. Definitely put on to do list. Any age.

Under the bridge. Having lived next to the Sydney Harbour bridge for 2 years there is more to it than meets the eye. Although famous for the bridge walk the SHB is an amazing structure to view from underneath. If you are staying on the city side take a walk across the pedestrian path (its free) to the other side. The views may not be as spectacular as from the top of the bridge however you will still get great views of the harbour and the Opera house. When you reach the other side head down the stairs and take a right hand turn back towards the water. Follow the path beside the bridge until you hit the grass area under the bridge. This is one of my favourite spots to hang out and read a book or listen to music. The views across the harbour and the steel construction under the bridge are amazing. When you are done head over to one of the cafes in Kirribilli for a coffee. My personal favourite is Bacino. Great coffee and gelato. Enjoy

Better than expected. I was a bit ho hum about climbing the bridge BUT it was amazing. We climbed at dusk, saw rain coming towards us through the lights of Sydney, got wet at the top and had a absolute ball. I HIGHLY recommend this climb particularly at night - so pretty.

Lots of steps!. We climbed the pylon rather than do the long climb over the top. It was much less expensive ($8.00 instead of @ $200), took much less time, and gave an opportunity to see a couple of floors of museum showing pictures and artifacts from the construction. There are 200 steps inside the tower, but they are broken by landings and time in the displays. There are also a lot of steps needed to be climbed in order to just get up to the level of the entrance into the pylon, so plan on 300+ total.The views from the observation deck at the top were great and the overall experience most worthwhile.
Great experience with to-die-for views. What a wonderful structure! You can walk or cycle over it, climb it or just admire it. One of the world's great engineering feats.

Achieving new heights. We visited Sydney during August and I arranged a Bridge climb with my twelve year old son. ( I'm 65 ) There is a minimum age limit for children. Excellent experience cost about £250.00 for the two of us, and the views were worth it. It is not too frightening, because the walkways are very wide. Strangely enough, you take a breathaliser test before being allowed to climb.
