He really gelled the group together. The views were amazing, definitely an amazing way to see the city from a different angle
An Icon. Every Australian loves the harbour bridge and it is a great icon for everyone to see. There is a footpath extending the whole thing and you can also do a bridge climb tour. Enjoy!

Sydney icon not to miss. This is another Sydney icon not to miss.The bridge climb is very pricey for what it is and they don't let you take your own camera up so you have to buy their expensive photos if you want a picture of the experience (why don't they just charge a little more and throw in a picture for free?).You can walk over the bridge for free and still get great views of the harbour. And you can walk up one of the pylons for $13 which offers some good views (and you can take your own camera).

Beautiful but overplayed . Everything in Australia and NZ is beautiful. You can pretty much point a camera in any direction and capture a bit if magic. I lived near San Francisco for some time and for me the Golden Gate bridge has an additional bit of mystique to it because of the red colour and constant fog. This is a beautiful harbour, no doubt about it, but it has been votes d so high so many times that I was expecting to be blown away when I was not. The bridge walk is definitely very pricey and although my friends did it and I did not, I have no regrets.

Magnificent. My home town has a replica of this bridge (Newcastle) so it was great to see the Sydney harbour bridge. We walked alongside it, sailed under it and took numerous photos of it, it is very impressive. You can walk on the top of it, maybe the next time. Was informed it was just as good an experience to walk across the bridge.
Stunning. Amazing to see such an iconic landmark. Make sure you take a walk on the bridge to get amazing views of the harbour and city

Thrilling Views. We did the express climb on beautiful mid-day. In the distance weather could be seen moving our way. After a very well organized outfitting, our climb commenced. Views of Sydney and it's harbors were stunning. After reaching the top and having photos taken, the approaching squall hit us with 80 kph winds and rain. While this only lasted maybe 10 minutes, it was definitely thrilling. Rain jackets were broken out but most of us still got soaked. Our leader was calm and assuring. This is a very professionally run attraction. I want to do it again, maybe at night.

One for the Bucket List. We did the 3 hr Bridge Climb & agree with the comments already made on here.You are standing around a lot as there are many groups going up with only 5-10 mins or so between them so it does get hectic before you climb.We thought it best to advise people on what goes on before the climb as we wishes we had known about things beforehand to be better prepared.We were booked in & taken through to a room to get our jumpsuits, then through another door to the lockers & changing rooms. Everything has to go in the locker, you are not allowed to take anything up with you, not even a small bottle of water. It is best to go with a minimum of clothing as it gets very hot & being humid we did sweat buckets!We had to then go through a scanner to ensure we hadn't kept any items with us. This includes jewellery, watches, belts etc. We were then introduced to our guide, Maria, who was great, very helpful & friendly.She took us through to the harness & radio area where she took us through how to put on our harnesses. Some of us had difficulty sorting them out, but this was not a problem, she helped as much as she possibly could.Once we had our harness on we went through to be fitted with a radio which Maria tested to ensure all of us could hear her at all times. One Japanese lady couldn't hear her at all so it took a bit longer than normal to sort this out.The next stage is practising climbing up & down 2 ladders so we could find out how the harness & rope would work.We were then ready to go! We thought there should have been more water in the room before the bridge climb, as there was only one small fountain. With the heat we quickly got dehydrated. The climb was easy but I am not afraid of heights. My husband struggled with the ladders which you have to do before climbing the bridge & at the end. There were a few fountains on the climb but they are warm so not particularly nice to drink but of course we had no choice as that was all there was available. There were 2 water sprays on the journey which did freshen our faces up.The views were absolutely amazing so well worth doing the climb. It is expensive but we thought, well worth it.
Free and Easy.... A wonderful way to see the Quays and Opera House. On a sparkling warm day it's a pleasant walk with great views. Head back to The Rocks area for refreshing drink and some lunch.

Iconic Bridge. we got great views of the bridge from the ferry. We watched people climbing the bridge. We also got great views of the bridge from taronga zoo. The bridge and the opera house are probably the 2 iconic sights in Sydney.

Pricey But Awesome!. We went on a 3 hour tour of the Harbour Bridge the climb itself is not very long. You cant take anything up with you, and you have to wear a jump suit. The walk on the bridge is not very hard or long its just you stop frequently for pictures. I would recommend you do this.

Essential for the visitor to Sydney. The Rocks is the only place you get a sense of what early settlement of Sydney would have been like. Saved from destruction in the 1950s it's a lovely spot to poke around. Avoid the tourist shops and have a drink at one of the pubs or walk up on to the Harbour Bridge.
The best way to see Sydney harbour and beyond. This was a brilliant outing and the best way to see the harbour. The climb was easy and most people could easily do this.
Great Sight. Great Land Mark, this is one of the many land marks that Sydney is Famous for. you can go on a bridge tour we didn't do the Tour

Top of The World !. The bridge climb has been one of my great achievements ,I do suffer from vertigo, so it was a big deal for me to do this,I am so glad that I did it. The guide was wonderful and gave me confidence,what a special experience ! The view from the top is superb A real adventure .
Lovely Walk and Views. Lovely walk offering views of the city and harbour. Best of all its free and easy. Watch for the runners and commuters - but would recommend to all!
On a Cruise and went under Bridge. Lot of History, wish I would have had time and permission to glimb to the top. Oprah got to climb to the top so I should have be able to also.

Awesome!. Yes it seems a lot of money to climb a bridge, but it is SO worth it!
We did the late afternoon Express Climb. Still gets you to the very top, but faster than the standard climb.
Highly recommended!

A must experience in Sydney. This was a 3 hour event that we thought would be "strung out". We were wrong, the whole experience from start to finish was interesting with the guides providing lots of information about the bridge, its construction and the surrounding areas. The views across the beautiful Sydney Harbour were amazing. Anyone who is afraid of heights should not be anxious about the climb as it is a slow steady ascent, not challenging in the slightest, and the safety harnesses that attach climbers to the bridge provide maximum security. I am not good with heights but I never for one moment felt any apprehension with the climb. If you visit Sydney you have to experience the Bridge Climb.
Over the top? Completely!. Although it may seem expensive, this is a Sydney experience not to be missed, and the attention to detail and safety justify the price. Just do it!

Stunning views and a good workout. As we were walking across this bridge (we took a tour bus across and walked back) there were many runners and walkers who obviously were on their lunch hour getting some daily exercise. What an inspiring time that must be - such majestic views. Of course there are hundreds of vehicles tearing by you, but it is such a lovely walk with views of all the iconic Sydney sights - the massive cruise ships and the Opera House and so on. I would do this on my own next time - you can access the bridge easily and just walk to your heart's content. There is a viewpoint at the far end of the bridge, through a tunnel, where you can take ground level photos of the impressive under part of the structure.

Bridge Climb is a must do!. It is one thing to see Harbour bridge in Sydney...it's a totally different experience to make it to the top of the bridge and see the beauty of Sydney from there. Exciting, adventurous...and not dangerous at all! If you want your daily portion of adrenaline...do it!

Brilliant. Living in Sydney most of our lives we have driven and walked over the bridge many times but doing a bridge climb was always on our bucket list. I have wonky knees and wondered if I would make it but after the initial ladders it is pretty easy going. It was the windiest day ever but soooo fantastic. It takes a while to suit up and again I thought I wouldn't fit into any suit but it was fine. Do it Do it Do it! It was wonderful

Good experience. Nice climb, gives you lovely view of the city. Preparation for walk was like going for Everett climb which took almost an hour of the tour. It was not so difficult to climb and our guide John was excellent and had a way of telling stories.

Exhilarating view from the top. Definitely worth it. I'd met quite a few locals who'd said do not do the climb for the view, the Sky Tower has a better view but that is very untrue. I did the twilight bridge climb which started during the day and ended at night and the view from the top was breathtaking. The harbour and the opera house were at their fullest glory. Again, a must do for everyone visiting Sydney.One caveat. When booking the climb there were two options: The regular one which took about 3.5 hours and the express one which took about 2.5 hours. The only difference mentioned between the two was "if you are fit, you can do the express". So I thought the only difference would be we would climb faster.However, the real experience turned out to be much different. The express climb took us under the bridge and thru the steep staircases and narrow passes and it was not the experience I had expected at all. The description for the express did not mention anything about different routes. The full experience would have been much better, and definitely worth the extra one hour. It would have taken you above the bridge and thru a more scenic route. Would highly recommend the full tour and experience. Worth the money.

Save yourself some money and climb the pylon.. Everyday I crossed this bridge for 3 months and never got tired of its grandeur. It dwarfs everything Sydney has to offer but so does the cost of climbing its famous arch. Save yourself a couple hundred bucks and climb the pylon which gives you the same view.
Sky high. To embark on a journey where every step has a story and every height has a new perspective with your loved ones is beyond breathtaking!!!!!
The BridgeClimb was Awesome!. We did the late afternoon bridge climb..... the views were spectacular..... a bit pricey, but it was awesome!

A must do!!. This is a must for anyone going to Sydney.
The build up/ history sets the scene and then the walk over one of the iconic bridges in the world is a real wow!!
Not too difficult and certainly something you will remember for the rest of your life.
Need Time and Planning. Did a walk on the bridge, but no time for a bridge climb, which is a must within a life time. Worth the visit. Sunset would be the best time.

hey I climbed that bridge!. My daughter was looking for a truly a unique experience to celebrate her birthday while we were in Sydney so we decided to give a go for this! Booking the experience online was so easy and so we signed up for the sampler climb! We were given voucher to visit the Pylon Look Out on that day before doing the sampler climb. The climb was well organised, professionally conducted with all the safety issues are dealt with so you will feel safe doing the climb. Our climb leader Mr Rhys was jovial and friendly guy who made the climb interesting and less tiring!To do this you need a moderate level of fitness – it was just like climbing series of few short ladders and the stairs is around 45degress incline. What you get at the end of the climb?? A fantastic experience, awesome view and a storey to tell each time I see the Sydney Bridge - hey I climbed that bridge before!!!

Walk across, and visit the Pylon Museum. As a photographer, I loved the Sydney Harbour Bridge. You can walk across for nothing, and visit the Pylon Museum (HIGHLY Recommended) for a minimal fee. If you have the time, you can get some nice shots by walking directly underneath the bridge. Luna Park makes for a great photo vantage point.

Not a should do, but a Must Do. The hardest part of the climbIs a couple of ladders at the start and end, getting from under the bridge up and the. Back down again. The walk up the arch is so easy. The views are stunning. The organisational side of things makes everything flow. Plenty of rests to take in the views. Absolutely sensational and I highly recommend the Bridge Climb. The link to my free video did not work, however they are trying to correct the error.

Majestic. The obvious is the convenience of crossing the harbour. It is generally congested but as a passenger provides beautiful views of the city and Opera House. You can walk over the bridge which is a tourists delight. I suggest climbing the Bridge for an unforgettable memory.

Some people are surprised to find out that you can walk across it!. Get of the train at Milsoms Point and walk across the bridge for some great views. You'd be surprised how many of the locals are running across it even in the heat of the mid-day sun.

Climb It!. Climbing the bridge is expensive. It's also a once in a lifetime opportunity that will give you the most incredible view of Sydney and an indescribable memory. I'd pay to do it again. It's just spectacular and really well run. Great experience. Do it!
Great views of the Opera House. Worth walking across the bridge for great views of the harbour and particularly, of the Opera House. Not for those scared of heights.

MUST SEE!. This is a spectacular place, full of modern architecture and the symbol of Sydney. Must see for sydney. Best to view at night with the vivid lights and spectacular habour, watching the boats and ferries sail by while eating dinner. Definitely recommended!

An iconic landmark!. This stunning bridge, is a world famous landmark, the fireworks at the spectacular New Year Eve show are let off from here.
If you have time & money, do the bridge climb for the most impressive views of the whole city.

Gigantic, impressive. Finally got to see this iconic bridge. Age was not on our side to have crossed the bridge from the top, but did walk through it on the pedestrian way and enjoyed the beauty of Sydney.

Wonderful. It is an amazing bridge. The climb was great and the veiws have no comparison. Defintely worth it. We had great weather so that made it even better as we had a full view of everything around us.

Built with steel from Ludwig Wittgenstein's father's works. It's an utterly irrelevant but interesting fact that this magnificent bridge is partially held together by steel from the factory founded near Prague by the philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein's father, and named Poldi after Wittgenstein's mother, Leopoldine.

OTHER OPTIONS FOR VISITING THE SYDNEY HARBOUR BRIDGE!. There are several options to choose from regarding the Sydney Harbour Bridge:1. Walk or drive it from Point A to Point B.2. Climb it and pay a fee of almost A$200 per person. Check off your Bucket List and show proofs to those interested to see that you have climbed or walked all the steps to cross this bridge.3. Climb the Southern Pilon located at the Rocks as Option B for this attraction. Entrance fee is much cheaper, A$24 per person. One is allowed to use his/her camera to take pictures, there are less steps to climb and the views you see are the same.4. See the Bridge either at the areas in front of the Opera House, at the Rocks, or at the Royal Botanic Garden (walk from the Garden to the Opera House). There are numerous places at these attractions to take beautiful pictures with the Sydney Harbour Bridge as your background.Now, make your choice and enjoy!
Grand!. Beautiful Bridge overlooking the Opera House at Sydney Harbour. They also offer a bridge walk which is much recommended to take in the amazing view of the city it offers!

Free Walk Over The Bridge. If you don't like extreme heights or don't want to pay $200+ per person to climb the Sydney Harbour Bridge, then simply walk the Bridge. We took the train to Milsons Point and walked one way and had great views of the Harbour and Opera House and then had enough money for a good coffee and Opera House tour!

One of the reasons to visit Sydney.... Probably one of the main 2 reasons to visit Sydney - fantastic bridge, worth walking up the pilot and over to the other side for the view back across the harbour.Although I didn't personally do it, family have said that the bridge climb was expensive for what it was - very popular though.I'd recommend just walking through "the rocks" and then across the bridge.

Spectacular. The Harbour Bridge is the most spectacular landmark in Sydney. We were not brave enough to attempt the walk but envy those who did and had a spectacular view of this beautiful city.Have lunch/ supper in Doyles and have one of the most spectacular man made views in the world. With the Opera House on one side and the Harbour bridge on the other....don't miss this!

Memorable Experience!. Despite the rain and gusty winds (up to 50km) it was still an amazing experience. Choose your package carefully and make sure it's what you want. Website can be unclear. I am terrified of heights but managed well. The staff are extremely professional and safety is priority. You will never forget this!

Ticked off on Bucket List. Very well organised, naturally the view was incrediable.......Very friendly and helpful staff. Cause my wife had my wallet (I do trust her) after I went through she thought about organising a photo package for me to pickup after my climb, but could not let me know, so the male staff member was nice enough to run upstairs and gave me the receipt and explained that it was paid for. Lastly I'm not ticking this on my bucket list...I'm doing it again

Southern Pilon, beautiful discovery!. While waiting for the ship to depart the Harbour, we were walking thrue the Rocks and looking for a walk up to the rd that would take us across the Harbour bridge. On this route we have discovered the Southern Pilon, and realized we could enter it, climb it and see some amazing views of Sidney for under $25. for one adult and one Senior. !! Yes we heard some great reports from Harbour bridge climbers, and was going to do it one day, but after climbing up to Southern Pilon, we were more than happy. Up on the top, there is a all around Sidney breathtaking view, inside is a museum and some interesting statistics on Harbour Bridge, lovely souveneer shop with great books and souveneers, as well a big movie screen, for forther information. As it is so affordable, but so beautiful, it is a must visit spot, providing you can walk up the steps .Down the track, we will re visit, and will be taking our visitors there from interstate and overseas. There is no food purchase but snacks and drinks , yes. While in the area, please explore the Rocks area,. Best to be seen by foot !!

the bridge climb. brilliant what an experience. look for website deals, ISANGO was amazing and very efficient.we climbed the first night climb at 6pm. took and hour to prepare and get ready then onto the bridge for 1.5-2 hour easy climb which started with dusk and then decending in the evening lights. there was no rush and lots of time to enjoy the view. JUST DO IT, it was amazing

A Great Climb!!!. My wife climbed it as I basically chickened out from a fear of heights. The Bridge team did take me on the gantry in the centre to test me out, but no way!!, but they were incredibly helpful. But..the adrenaline rush that she had doing this was great and the health & safety steps taken were extremely impressive.

Absolute must do. What a brilliant experience made complete but our delightful guide, "Nice". It is a long journey but not arduous at all and of course the best view possible of the magnificent Sydney Harbour

A walk to remember forever!!. This is the 1st thing I did in Sydney on a weekend. Wooooow is the word. A beautiful bridge walk. Spectacular views of the city, Opera house, harbour and more. The bridge looks so good when viewed from milsons point. That is my most favorite point in Sydney. I sit there and keep looking at the bridge and the water for hours and hours. And the bridge was at it's best on the new year eve fireworks. Woooooow man, it was unbelievably awesome. A lovely part of Sydney. Do not miss this.
beautiful at sunset. oooooh i saw Cunard cruiseship Queen Mary 2 leaving the beautiful Sydney Harbour at sunset the view from Harbour Bridge was unforgettable.

Bridge climb at night, highly recommended, amazing!!. I did the night climb, it was pricey but well worth it. It's an amazing experience, our guide was very knowledgeable and told us the history of the bridge, with lots of interesting facts and trivia. The safety precautions are very reassuring, and the climb is not strenuous. Overall it is very meticulously organised and the staff are great, really pleasant.It was a beautiful evening when I climbed, and as we reached the summit we were treated to a spectacular fireworks display in the harbour below, which I have just learned from an earlier review, was due to the Queen Mary cruise liner setting sail, thank you Cunard! It couldn't have been timed better!

A must. Even if you are not 21 anymore... go for it. That's a thing what you never will forget. Buy a ticket and go , for on of your spectaculast walks in your life. Use a go pro camera, your friends want believe it.
Very High!. We didn't walk the bridge but watched many tours from the ground.Amazing to watch and admire from the ground! You need to be very fit and have a good head for heights to climb it.

Climb the Bridge. As a family two adults and 12 year old daughter we decided to do the bridge climb. It did at first seem expensive but when we saw how much goes into to this prior to and on the climb the cost did not seem so bad. It is perfectly safe I am terrified of heights our guide made sure I was ok without patronising me. There were bits that I found nerve racking but I did it and was rewarded with some spectacular views. Had I not done it I would have regretted it. In the cost you get a commemorative photo, a certificate and baseball cap you can buy a separate photo package if you wish. My husband and daughter loved the whole experience.

Harbour Bridge Climb. We were due to climb on a wednesday evening, but due to a bad electrical storm, that climb was cancelled.There was no problem re-booking the climb and we climbed the next mornng.It truly is the climb of a lifetime and my partner and myself were lucky enough to be there on a warm and sunny morningThe guides are all very knowledgeable and put you at easeAs mentioned don't drink before you climb as you are all breathalyzed and may be stopped from climbing.A Big plus on my climb, I asked my partner to marry me (she said yes), all done with the help of the members of staff that were on duty that day, and got some fantastic pictures of the moment

Pylon Visit. If you are not up to the cost or the ordeal of a bridge climb. Go visit the Pylon town . It is the one near the Rocks end . The start is just back form the well advertised entrance to the commercial Harbour Bridge climb reception area. The cost is very fair and the view is still spectacular. follow IT UP WITH A STROLL OVER THE BRIDGE to the railway station or ferry back to the circular key area. In all allow 2 hours at least .

Not To Be Missed - EVEN for those with a fear of heights!. I have a deathly fear of heights, but thought, "When will I ever be here again? When will have have another chance to do this?" So I signed up to to the bridge walk.The staff are great at preparing you for your walk. You walk with a group and at least one (sometimes two or more guides). The staff get you suited up with your jumpsuit and put on your harness for you. The harness ensures you couldn't fall off the bridge if you tried. If the weather is bad, you'll get a jacket and hat- also secured to your jumpsuit, so nothing falls off *you*. I was initially apprehensive as we approached the catwalk, but found I was soon distracted by the sights I saw and the insights provided by our guide, Matt. Yes, there were a few moments when my palms started to sweat, but they were fleeting.After the catwalk where you're beneath the bridge deck, you climb a ladder that leads to the foot of the steel arch. You're still secured by your harness to a guideway that runs from the start of your walk, all the way to the very end. Again, you're always supremely safe. Once you've climbed the ladder your guide takes a few photos of you and there's a bubbler/water fountain, in case your mouth is dry. :) Then you start the real walk up the arch. The arch is wide, and the climb is very gradual. Our group included some people in their 70s who managed it without any difficulty. The wideness of the steel arch is reassuring, and it's completely steady. Even though you're walking up the bridge, even scaredy-cats will feel at ease here.The views are breath-taking in only the best way. Your guide will take additional photos of you and your friends, so there's no need (or ability) to bring your own camera or phone.After crossing over the top of the arch, you'll walk over to the east side where you'll walk down, down a ladder, cross a catwalk once again and into the visitors center.I'm very glad I did this, and you will be, too!

Bright lights, Big City!. From the 12th deck of the Queen Mary 2, the bridge and all its glory really shine! We set sail at 9pm and the port was packed with well wishers waiving us off. The band was playing and there was a festive feeling in the air. The lights of the bridge in addition to the massive fireworks display Cunard put on, really highlighted the bridge. If I wasn't terrified of heights I would have loved to climb that puppy! Best to see it during the day and also at night.

Walk over/ stay underneath. Sydney's not to be missed sight.when walking over it, stop and enjoy the 360 degree view. it is spectacular. walking on top might give you additional views - but also standing below is exciting. Wooh

Not the bridge climb but the bridge walk. Well we dint have the time to do the bridge climb and so did the next best thing the bridge walk.You can walk next to the road from shore to shore over the bridge free of charge!View of the harbour opera house and the city were fabulous If you are on a budget and reckon the £40 or so per jead is a bit steep then walking the bridge must be a consideration to say the least

Well worth the walk !. I took my husband as a gift for his birthday.The day we went the weather wasn't that great however you do receive a fleece and wet weather gear as part of the equipment. For us it poured down and there were winds of over 70km/h (note that I understand they only stop the walks if the wind speed is more than 90km/h so be prepared).The pre walk training is clear and easy. We did have lady on our walk who after about a third of the way in was too scared to continure however the staff were great and coming to collect that lady from the group while the rest of us continued. I hadn't realised that even on the short walk it would take in the region of 2.5 hours however the views and the commentary from our guide were amazing and well worth it
no walking over the bridge for me. no dislikes only likes. i had the idea to walk over the bridge but after a while it scared me a lot. but I did see a lot of people making the challenge

Birthday Bridge Climb. Climbed the bridge for my birthday last year - absolutely amazing :) Did a 4:00pm climb on a warmish day and opted for the chance to dispense with clothing under the overalls you're required to wear - good choice as it got a bit warm as we were climbing. Our guide was very knowledgeable and made us all feel perfectly at ease. The climb wasn't strenuous and the views from the top were memorable. Thoroughly recommend it. Word of caution - don't drink alcohol before climbing as they breathalyse you before you're allowed to climb

Australian Icon Must Do.. This amazing part of Sydney is a must do, whether you climb it, walk over it or cruise under it, it is amazing. Learn the history of this amazing Sydney Icon and it makes it even more interesting. Lit up at night it is beautiful. Must Do!
beautiful. we walked across the bridge,got great pics of harbour from the middle and all for free!!!Great views of the city,good exercise,lots of locals and tourists,a must!

If you dont walk it...you will regret it. THE BEST EXPERIENCE EVER!The staff that you walk with are pleasant and knowledgeable. they give you safety instruction after safety instruction and i don't think i felt unsafe at any point of the walk to the top and back again. the views from the top are spectacular...we were lucky to have such a clear and sunny day.It takes a good chunk out of your day in Sydney but is 100% worth it.Definitely buy the photos afterwards. they are worth every penny.From the ground the bridge is stunning to look at and a true icon. you have to see it to believe it.

Breathtaking Views. We just walked over the bridge and back. The views are amazing. This is a must-do in Sydney (kinda of like walking over the Golden Gate Bridge in SF). It's free and takes less than an hour round trip.

A walk to remember and essential part of a visit to Sydney!. Went here yesterday and was gown away. I did the longer walk which was organised with military precision, very safe, fantastic fun guide Nick who has been working there for 10 years and a wonderful memorable experience for my Birthday.There were people on maximum sized group of 14 who were a bit anxious about heights but they were fine and excellently cared for and supported by Nick and his colleagues

Five Star Experience--Do the Bridge Walk All the Way to the Top--If You Don't You will Always Have Regrets. Book the Sydney Harbour Bridge Walk and you will be glad you did. This is an extremely well organized and safe adventure. You take off nearly all your clothes and leave all your cameras, keys and everything you are caring in a locker and wear their gear. Guide was exceptional telling us the history of building this bridge before cranes back 100 years ago. It was so much fun walking up the bridge girders, walked across the very top of the bridge, and then back down the girders on the other side. Fabulous views. Make sure you make an advanced reservationMy recommendation for improvement-- reduce the price of the photos, especially when they make them available to you on the internet. Should be no more than $20 and not $60. This left a sour taste in my mouth after the already high price of the bridge walk.

1.2km of walk. Make sure you will climb onto this bridge as you will be able to see many of Sydney's attraction from up top such as Tarongga Zoo (forgive my spelling) and Circular Quay. Each journey takes 1.2km. Bring your sunnies, hat and also water. Its gonna be hot.

Take the Pedestrian walkway. If you don't have the hundreds of dollars needed to climb the top of the bridge, the next best thing is the public pedestrian walkway! Great for a stroll or jog with equally impressive views

Stunning views of the city and the harbor. I would really recommend the bridge climb to anyone visiting Sydney who can afford the time and money.If you are older or afraid of heights, don't get discouraged. There is a photo of a 100-year-old lady who's done it, so it's really not that physically demanding and it's a great opportunity to face your fear under very safe circumstances. It's not so much a climb, as it is a walk. Most of the time you walk on steps (with the exception of a few ladders that they prepare you for), there is a railing on both sides and you are attached to a rope the whole time. So, really, no worries :). Now, I might have made some people think that it's boring, but it's really not. It's quite fun (especially if you get a silly tour guide) and the view is absolutely worth it. We scheduled for early twilight and our program (the actual climb is preceded with a well organized preparation) started around 6pm in March, which was great as we ascended during daylight, watched the sunset at the top and descended at night. It was perfect.Unfortunately, you don't get to take your camera with you, but your guide will take photos of you on several occasions and afterwards you can choose which ones you like and purchase them (about $20 each, I think).Additional tips: No alcohol beforehand, they test everyone. Eat something, so that you have energy, you're about to climb a bridge and the whole thing takes about 3 hours. Obviously don't overeat either, you're about to climb a bridge!If you are skinny as I am, I recommend to wear a warm shirt. They do give you a fleece jacket, but still, I was happy that I was also wearing a hoodie underneath the suit. It's windy up there and even at a hot day it can get quite chilly, especially as the sun is setting and it might not be as enjoyable if you are shaking cold as some girls in my group were.I hope this helps. Enjoy your climb! :)

The history of the bridge saved Sydney in the depression. It's a iconic bridge and it's a perfect Sydney marriage with the opera house, if you get a chance google the history of the building of the bridge it's a page turner and a history that needs to be read and shared

Excellent day. Possibly my favourite day in Sydney was spent crossing the bridge and crossing back again after a relaxing coffee on the North Shore. Crossing such an iconic landmark while having a great view of another felt really special. Although minute in comparison to the number of Padlocks you’ll find on some landmarks, I loved reading the padlocks attached to the bridge. The wind also offers a change from hot old sydney! You can walk on the east side or cycle on the west side of the bridge. If neither of those views take your fancy you can walk across the top of the bridge with Bridge Climb but that will set you back a cool $250!

You can do it. This was a great experience, we had someone who was nervous of the height but they were well catered for & looked after. The climb was not hard, tight in a few places if you are tall like me but felt very safe all the way around. Great view from the top, we did the climb on a clear day forcast 30 so we did 9.45 climb which was just right for us, we felt we earnt a nice lunch at The Hero of Waterloo which was close by afterwards, bit pricey but great experience

Scaling an Icon. The Sydney Harbour Bridge climb is a fantastic experience. The day I went it was windy which added to the thrill. Standing next to the flags flapping in the quite strong breeze. You are provided with jumpsuits and are connected to the walkway at all times so it's completely safe. Our guide was informative and added humor along the way which eased those who were nervous. Although the climb is at a very slow pace to allow for sightseeing, some level of fitness is recommended for the 1300+ steps.

sunset harbour bridge walk. lovely experience to climb such and iconic structure and the view from the top is breathtaking, its all safety first and was surprised at the security but you cant have anything drop on to people below
Wow. Well what can I say an iconic sight! It was smaller than I imagined, looks amazing day or night, very clean, looks modern, great to sail under
Sydney Harbour bridge climb. What a spectacular thing to do. We have travelled the world and this is in my top 5 things I have done.Our guide Jess was amazing.

One of the Best Things Ever. This was trul an amazing experience, totally exhilarating and totally safe--it's 1,390 steps on your journey and the bridge climb gives some of the very best views of Sydney Harbour anywhere.When one is on the top looking down 440 feet to the water or looking for miles in any direction at Sydney and the environs, it's a fantastic feeling. The preparation and safety briefing are very thorough including a rehearsal of the proper way to climb the six stories or so of ladders (always 3 points of contact), the use of the safety cables--seems impossible to fall very far. They equip you with an over suit that has a large safety belt and everything is tied to you be it your hat (a souvenir), all your equipment-safety line, radio, rain coat and even handkerchiefs that are attached to your outfit. One goes through a metal detector to make sure you are carrying nothing that could become a missile to the cars and trains below if they drop and you are off with an obviously experienced guide.The guide narrates all the way up and down the journey giving interesting historical facts and anecdotes about the bridge. The climb is surprisingly not arduous, although if one has a fear of heights, this is not for you. You walk along a narrow catwalk to the decorative pylons which mask the ladders that bring you to the top portion of the bridge. Once you finish the ladder climb, one gently climbs up on the top arch of the bridge to the summit where there are flags flying. We were sort of lucky that a major wind and rain storm greeted us at the very top-yet no one felt unsafe. Once the storm subsided, we walked across another catwalk for 75 meters to the other side and then traversed downward. Everyone of our group of 7 were thrilled with it.They provide you witha picture and certificate of accomplishment.Big score for my bucket list!!!!

Bridge Climb fantastic at dusk then a night. Super lucky to get a ticket for the last climb of the day, on the day. Only three of us plus climb leader who was great. Views amazing and 'tour' really informative. Super safety conscious and loads of opportunities to have your picture snapped along the way. I don't think of myself as over fit but managed it well. Plenty of opportunities to collect a souvenir in the shop also. Loved the pics of all 'stars' who have done the walk. Experience of a lifetime.

It is just amazing even only the view of it !. i have been once there and i just felt so surprised of this viewM just amazing I have to say... It is really worth! If u have a chance to visit sydney, don't lose it!

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. A must do if you are in Sydney. The view from the top is breath- taking!!!The team at Bridge Climb go to great lengths to insure customer safety and insure that all climbers feel comfortable and safe in their environment.The guides are very friendly and extremely knowledgeable about the history of the bridge and of the history attached to the Sydney harbour.This is a great way to spend 3 hours.

Pretty Stunning. It is definately a spectactular landmark, although I didn't have the courage to climb it, my boys were thrilled when we crossed it in the car, not so thrilled the 4th, 5th, and 6th times that I kept missing the turnoff Cahill expressway on the M1. Lots of fun driving in the Sydney City!!
Go on it and run!. Great for a run! 4km both way. The best view of the harbour. Best time is early morning where there are less cars. Sunset also beautiful but too many cars can be smoky.

Sydney harbour bridge climb was well worth the money!. My dad and I climbed the Sydney harbour bridge a few hours after we landed from a 22 hour flight! We thought it would get rid of the jet lag and blow away the cob webs. Well it certainly did that. After a very informative and thorough safety induction we put on all our gear and headed on up the bridge. Our instructor Dave was very friendly, as were all the staff there, and was full of information about the bridge and its construction. Plenty of stops on the bridge to admire the wonderful views and for Dave to take photos of us all. Thoroughly enjoyed it and would defiantly recommend!!

Water , water everywhere. Take a water taxi and you get to see the bridge as you should. You experience both sides as well as looking up from the bottom as the traffic goes by, oblivious of you bobbing below

Must Visit. The Sydney Harbour bridge needs no introduction and it is a must see for any traveler. I have been to Sydney several times and to the harbor bridge a couple of times including seeing it from a cruise boat. This time I took a walk across the bridge at my own pace and enjoyed every bit of it. It was late afternoon and autumn time in Sydney is pleasant. There were several people leaving office and walking or jogging back home across the bridge. I managed to get some great pictures of the Opera house and waterfront from various points on the bridge. Pity I did not plan the walk up the bridge which I hope to do next time.

Experience of a Lifetime!. If you visit Sydney you must plan to climb the Harbour Bridge! We did the 3 hour climb during the day. You are harnessed to the railing, in groups of 12 with a guide, and it was not scary at all. The tour is filled with information, beautiful views, photos (group photo is included, you can purchase individual photos) and you get a souvenir hat!! You need to book your climb on their website well in advance. A great experience!

SYDNEY HARBOUR BRIDGE CLIMB. My wife and I booked to do the Bridge Climb at Sydney Harbour on 5 March 2015. As someone who is not at all keen on heights I was quite apprehensive about the prospect. I needn't have been. I frankly admitted that I was a liittle nervous about the prospect and was reassured that they are well used to this situation. Our Guide, Darren was an excellent guy who put me at ease from the outset. It was a breezy morning and before long I was fairly relaxed and enjoying the experience. We had a guy in his 70's in our party who was completing his 47th climb of the bridge. He hopes to do 50 climbs. The experience on reaching the peak of the bridge beside the Australian flags was very exhilarating and the views of the harbour and the Opera House were unforgettable. When we started our descent the wind speed increased to around 40-45kph. I was glad they were no stronger. Apparently the day before the weather had turned quite nasty at one point and some climbs were cancelled for safety reasons, so we were lucky. I should add that safety is the No.1 priority, and at no time did I feel unsafe as you are securely attached to a steel cable which runs adjacent to the handrails along the full course of the climb.This was an experience we will never forget. I would have no hesitation in recommending it to anyone who is reasonably fit and to those who, like myself, are nervous of heights I would simply say "Pluck up the courage and do it. You will never regret it". Again a very big thank you to Darren who was an excellent Guide.

Got over my fear of heights!. My husband organised this for us to do for our anniversary. I was a bit scared of the heights, but our guide was great. She said just keep looking at the horizon and around, not down! gradually you adjust to the height and it was worth it. It was done at a slow steady pace. Definitely worth it.

Awesome!. Bucket list - climb the Sydney Bridge; check. Don't miss out on this. I was really impressed on how their processes. They are very stick and for a good reason. The views are amazing and it's really not very difficult to climb. However, if you're afraid of heights you might want to pass. The guide was great and I never felt rushed. It's a must.
Just have to see it. We have done the walk over the bridge before but I alway love to just look at it. It's great for taking photos of. Watching the sun set behind it. Have taken $1000 of photos.

Awesome!. A friend from Sydney recommended I take a train to Milsons Point and then walk the Harbor Bridge back to The Rocks. I am glad I took his advice. I wandered around before walking the bridge back and found Luna Park as well as beautiful views of the city!

Amazing experience. I had done the climb before but my wife and a very good friend hadn't so I was very keen to join them when it was suggested we give it a go.From the very moment you book in you feel that you are in safe hands and the pre climb talk and training session was very good. Our guide for the day was Nick and within minutes he knew all our names and was always quick with a joke or advice.Although it was wet and blustery on the day we did the climb, it did nothing to diminish the sheer exhilaration that we all felt as we made our way to the top of the bridge, The views were amazing and Nick came up with a running commentary about what to look out for and how the bridge was constructed. I can honestly say that although I had done the climb before the adrenaline rush was just as good as the first time and I would certainly have a third go at it should the opportunity arise. Age is no barrier if you are reasonably fit, so I would definitely recommend having a go. It's not cheap but it's a memory that will stay with you for ever.

Wonderful experience. Booked once we were in Sydney, very impressive tour, impressed with safety, but the views are to die for, shame you can't take your own camera...did a mid day climb, sky was clear blue and could see for miles, it was closed the day before because of high winds, will do it again, fancy a twilight climb, can't wait to see the city lit up at night.

Such a fantastic walk. A great walk especially from Milsons Point train station. The best views and a fairly easy walk, but there are a few steps at the end of each of the bridge. But its worth it. Fantastic View from the bridge to the CBD, Circular Quay and all the way out to the heads

Walk the high way. Today we walked over the Sydney Harbour Bridge, from Milsons point( easy access from the railway station) to the Rocks area of Sydney City it gave us spectacular views over the Harbour towards the Opera House, and Queen Mary 2 which was docked there. The bridge itself is most dramatic in its structure, just perhaps marred by the multitude of road traffic that you walk alongside but def a must do if you are visiting Sydney

Something everyone should do!. Loved the entire experience and the protocols followed by the guides inspired great confidence in the safety of the experience. The views from the bridge are amazing and I'll never forget watching the lights come on all over Sydney at dusk.

Amazing Structure. We were fortunate enough to see it in many ways. Our cruise ship sailed under it at night with it light up, we had a view of it from our hotel room, we wend under it when we went on the Manley Ferry and we drove over it during a tour.

Very beautiful . B4 visit here i though LONDON BRIDGE was the most beautiful nd famous bridge but whn we saw SYDNEY HARBOUR BRIDGE so i can say this is the most beautiful nd romantic place .Its really really wonderful nd full of fun personaly i really like this place soooo relaxing

Such an amazing experience. I am always amazed as I drive over the bridge how something so grand was built without huge machinery of the time. Driving over it or walking you are impressed with the structure and if you have a few hours to spare I would highly recommend putting on a grey jumpsuit and climbing over it to get the best view in Sydney

Sydney March 2015. Bridge climb is worth doing, and is not too taxing for unfit people. You are provided with a climbing suit-be prepared to wear only underclothes underneath this, as anything else would be too hot.You are take to the top by professional climbers, and get a fab view from the top. Pictures at the top are taken by the climbers, which you can purchase at the end. Very well looked after all the way.
Breathtaking. We never cross or walk by the bridge. We just took pictures from Circular Quay harbor and by passing on a ferry but still its spectacular..

Every Step Was Worth It!. When planning our budget camper trip from Sydney to Melbourne I was a bit dubious about spending so much money on one activity, especially when it involved climbing on top of such a humongous structure!!However, having successfully completed the Bridge Climb I would wholly recommend it to everybody and anybody!We booked in advance online, which was very simple to do. We opted for the full bridge climb to start around 16:00. This is slightly cheaper than the twilight climbs but because of the time of year we still experienced a change in light and the start of the sun going down on our way back to base.We were given a warm welcome from the team at the front desk and it was suggested we get a bite to eat at the onsite cafe if we hadn't already eaten- it's a long climb after all! We didn't make any purchases at the cafe as we'd already indulged!We did, however, buy some souvenirs in the shop where the usual magnets, t-shirts and cuddly toys are available.At our bridge climb time we were greeted by another member of staff who introduced us to the rest of our tour group and helped us get kitted out. The staff were incredibly knowledgeable and able to hand us all a bodysuit to wear just by looking at us- no embarrassing announcements of 'LARGE!' here! :DWe were then passed over to our tour guide who walked us over a 'test' bridge to see how we felt about being that bit higher up. Graham then helped us with our harnesses, health and safety info, radios and walked us through a practise structure so that we could all have a go at using the safety clips before being up on the bridge itself. There was plenty of opportunity to ask questions, get used to small increments of height and get comfortable in our group.Graham was so friendly, knowledgable and full of quirky stories about both the bridge and Sydney & surrounding areas.The bridge itself? Just wow. Views- amazing. Climb- fantastic. By the end? Tired, wobbly legged but buzzing from the experience!Would I do it again? YES!
Global icon. We stayed at the literal foot of the bridge, and it is most impressive, but I wouldn't pay the outrageous fee to climb it - almost $200.00.

What a view!!!. the bridge walk over the top of the bridge is a once in a lifetime thing to do, after a brief safety lesson you are taken out in a group of 10-12 to start the climb, the hardest is the start where you have to go up a few vertical ladders, after that you are linked to a guide rail and walk over the top of the bridge to the middle where the views are amazing, overall takes between 90 -120 mins

Worth a walk across. I was quoted 238 dollars to take the guided tour right to the top of the bridge which I thought was way expensive. I choose to go up the tower and paid 13 dollars. There was a small museum on the way up detailing facts and stories about the construction. The views were spectacular across the bay and the opera house. Well worth a walk up if you are in the area.
Must see. If going to Sydney this is a must see. Worth a ferry ride to Parramatta or Manly. If energetic can do the walk across or the bridge climb

Majestic Bridge across the harbour. This is old bridge which connects north and south of sydney. This bridge is famous for film shoot sequences including Indian films. There is tour that takes you up the bridge, but it is pricy.
The Famous Coathanger. If you don't walk across the 'Coathanger' you will have missed one of Sydneys real treats- there are things to see and do at both ends

WHAT'S NOT TO LIKE?. The bridge has stood since 1932 and never ceases to amaze with its architecture. As the largest single span bridge in the world it is spectacular. Tourists and locals can walk across, drive across, take a bus or even a train to the other side. For the more adventuresome they can walk up the span of the Bridge.

Liked the bridge but the bridge museum was only ok. We walked along the bridge but didn't do the bridge climb because I chickened out. The museum was a little run down and the movie wasn't being shown anymore at the museum. I wasn't that excited about walking along the bridge.

Must Do. You look at the bridge and think that's big but wait until you have done the climb. From start to finish this is very well organised. You will need to allow at least three hours as some time is spent getting fitted out with safety gear etc. The guides are very informative and the pace of climb is easy. There are a few ladders to climb at the start and end which are vertical but apart from those the climb is fairly easy. We did the climb early as it was summer and can be very hot in Sydney so consider that when booking. Yes it is expensive but we felt worth every cent. Be sure to have something to eat before you climb as the guide did ask if we had eaten, breakfast in our case.
Picturesque Sydney harbour bridge. It's a very distinctive bridge, no fuss but very pretty with the flag on top. So pretty, I can just stay there and enjoy its presence.

Eh, no big deal. I would have liked to do the bridge walk, but it was way to expensive. The bridge itself is nice but not special, but it is in a great position by the Opera house and the connections north of downtown Sydney. I want to see it during one of the light festivals they put on during the year.
We only looked , we didn't do the walk acrooss,. Looked lovely , we enjoyed the day.We didn't do the walk over ,but there say it is very good,Would recommend.

Bridge climb. An expensive but worth every 'buck' to do the full Bridge Climb. Extremely well organised and excellent attention to safety and detail. The climb itself was awesome with fantastic views and our lovely KIwi guide was extremely well informed and friendly

Great experience. The bridge climb is very professional and well organized. The preparation is very thorough. The climb itself is not very arduous and can be accomplished by anyone who is averagely fit. The view from the top is very unique. No cameras are allowed for the climb although the staff take photos that are available for sale. A group photo is included in the price.

Well I never thought I would do this!. Doing the bridge climb was not something I thought I had any real desire to do but we were in Sydney for probably the only time in our lives so my husband was keen to do it. Obviously this is not cheap at $148 but it is a huge thing to have done. We were asked to complete a health form and then had to be breathalysed. Then it was into our sexy suits and all the various paraphernalia to keep us hooked up and in communication with our guide. I did admit to feeling a tad nervous so our guide, Maria, put me at the front of the group with her. My nerves were nothing to do with height or anything but simply about the physical effort required as I am 62 and in good health but do suffer from fibromyalgia and back problems. The climb has 2 distinct stages - initially you have to climb up steep ladders - 4 sets of these - and then the rest of the climb is up gradual wide spaced steps which just seem to go on forever. Maria was an amazing guide and was talking to us through our headphones constantly giving lots of interesting facts about the bridge and pointing out the interesting sights below us. She also kept stopping to do this which gives you a chance to catch your breath and have a good look around. She also took pictures of us at various points ( you cannot take anything with you on the climb so cannot take your own pics). At the summit she took a picture of our whole group and this one is given to you together with your certificate in with the price of the climb. Going back down was actually harder for me especially down the ladders as you are looking down on a 6 lane road with railway lines on both sides and when trains went rattling by on both sides I did cling on to those ladders! Eventually after 3 hours or so we were back on terra firma and I was just so proud of my achievement and so glad I had done it. We were shown the photos Maria had taken on screen and could have printed copies for $18 or have a flash drive containing all 7 photos plus the 10 second video we had also recorded at the summit for $59 which is what we did. Having done the climb we were given free tickets to go up the viewing pylon at the side of the bridge which we did a couple of days later and I actually found climbing those 200 steps harder than all the bridge climb but the views were great and we had the opportunity to take our own photos up there. We were lucky to have perfect weather for our climb and all in all it is definitely one of the greatest things I have ever done.

Climb it or walk it - it's all good. I both walked across (and back) and climbed the Sydney Harbor Bridge.The walk across is free, and there are 4 or 5 security guards along the way. The walkway is on the Opera House side of the bridge, which is good for pictures. Get directions as to how to get onto the bridge.The bridge climb is very expensive, but is a once in a lifetime event. I did the twilight climb. I was scheduled for the 6:30 climb, but since I had arrived early, they offered me a chance to go with the 5:45 group, which I did. That may have been a mistake in late January, as the sun was only setting as we were already going down, so not many lights had come on. The plus side was that we were climbing the bridge as a criuse ship was departing, so the pictures taken by our group leader had the cruise ship in it.When you climb the bridge, you have to be sober (they give you a breath-analyser test), you should have had something to eat in the last 3 or 4 hours, and you have to take off anything that could possibly fall off. You wear a jump suit, with nothing but your undies on under it (in summer), and everything they give you to take along is strapped onto the jumpsuit - earphones/radio; hat; handkerchief; headlight; and belt to hook onto the safety cable. They give you practice on the proper way to climb a ladder (encountered at the beginning and end of your climb), along with other safety instructions. They tell you about the last chance bathrooms several times before you start.When you climb the bridge, you start on the Opera House side of the bridge. At the top (where the flags are), you cross over to the inner harbor side, and go back down to where you started.At the end, you get to keep the hat, but pictures (that they took) and a T-shirt that says you climbed the bridge have to be bought.

Do The Walk. What a simply wonderful experience on the Bridge Climb (our second time). Better than the first time from what we remembered, partially because we kind of knew what to expect, which allowed us time to take more in and float away in our own little world. You cannot go to Sydney and not do this bridge climb. Even if you're afraid of heights, because the walkway is wide, there is no sense of foreboding....do it, you won't regret it.

Bridge Walk. This is amazing. The walk along the gantry is a bit hair raising but once you climb the ladders to the bridge its fantastic & the guides are great. They point out all the landmarks & give interesting info & anecdotes, always willing to take photos for you & constantly making sure everyone sees everything & is happy. We really enjoyed the walk even though I am not a lover of heights.

sydney harbour bridge. took my nephew and niece there and took many photos
.Have good look of sydney from there. very exciting

Bridge climb. This was an excellent experience. Not cheap, but well worth it. The views from all the way up to the top were great and our guide (Scott) was both humourous and very informative.There were a few people older than me (61) and none of us had any problems with the walk. It was done and a relaxed pace with amusing commentary and anecdotes all the way.Definitely a thing to do in Sydney.

thoroughly enjoyed it, exceeded my expectations. climbing the sydney harbour bridge was not particularly on my bucket list, but we chose to do it for my birthday. and I was surprised at how much I enjoyed it! we did the express climb which took about 2 hours and our tour guide Charlene (I think??) was very informative along the entire trip, telling us all about how the bridge was made and what materials were used etc. and at the top everyone in the group sang happy birthday to me :)

nice arial view. Walked out on the bridge and paid the $13 to go up to the viewing area. Very nice high views of the city, opera house and Circular Cay. Didn't do the "bridge climb" as was $250!!!!!!! The $13 is worth the views.

Walk or Climb. We did not want to climb the bridge as it was quite expensive and they will not let you take your camera up there to take pictures, so we settled for a walk across the bridge. It is a long walk, but we saw as much walking across the bridge as those climbing the bridge. Those that climbed the bridge, just saw further. If you like to walk, it is a nice walk, and you are protected from the traffic.

everything they say is true. a really wonderful experience just to be alongside and actually walk back and forth- visit the visitors centre just 15 aud and well worthwhile. Din't go on the bridge climb but saw many smiling faces from the "walkers"

Worth it! - specifically the bridge climb attraction. I wasn't sure if I really wanted to do the bridge climb, it is quite expensive and takes longer than it seems like it should. But having gone recently on a twilight climb, I'd say it was well worth it. What an amazing view, and to see the city go from day-light, to sunset, and into evening. While I really loved it and would recommend it, I would also say it's not something you MUST do, especially if funds are tight. Maybe just walk across the bride, or take a taxi/bus/train across. There's actually some great little neighborhoods on the other side worth checking out for dinner/drinks or just a stroll.It definitely takes longer than I it should; there's a lot of waiting while groups ahead of you are getting through their climb and the guides taking photos of all the climbers. I felt completely safe the entire time, they've definitely taken precautions throughout. It's a bit frustrating/annoying that you can't take your own camera, but considering the time and safety implications, it's understandable. To purchase the photos is ridiculously expensive in my opinion, but was hard to turn down after spending so much to do that amazing climb. Having done the climb with a friend of mine, we split the cost ($60 total) of purchasing a flash drive with 10 photos of our choice, plus the group and sunset shots our guide took. Our guide was really knowledgeable and friendly, as I'm sure all of them are. He was giving fun facts and telling stories throughout, but definitely wasn't following a script, which was nice. He also allowed questions, and he always seemed to have the answers. I definitely learned things I didn't know beforehand.Things to know... - I'd really recommend wearing sneakers/runners; for both comfort and safety. I wouldn't worry so much about clothing. - They give you a jumpsuit to wear, and you take off all other clothing except underwear...at least that's how it was on my climb in early March. - It really does take about 3 - 3.5 hours from start to finish.- Do NOT drink before your climb. Common sense says it just isn't safe, AND they breathalyzer you before you do anything.

Amazing construction, great views. A must walk...!. It is definitely worth a walk over the bridge to see the bridge itself (especially against a blue sky) and the views of the Opera House etc.Note: if you cross over to the North side and take the metro back, the metro is outside the "City" zone.

excellent tour. We did an afternoon tour and were taken aback by the sheer size and views once at the top. An easy enough climb, just a few ladders and tight spots to negotiate. We want to go back and do a dusk or night tour. Staff were all very helpful and friendly. Do the Bridge Tower walk while your there all so.

SYDNEY HARBOUR BRIDGE. Caught the train over to the other side of the bridge and walked back towards the city. Have done the bridge climb before but were now walking the length of the bridge. Well worth doing but make sure you stop and read the plaques along the way.

Exhilirating!!!. Did the Sydney Harbour Bridge walk to celebrate my 60th birthday. Would definitely encourage anyone who can do it, to do it. Absolutely brilliant. Guides are very friendly, helpful and supportive. Our guide was energetic, motivated and very pleasant. A once in a lifetime experience with many cherished memories. The highlight for me was my group singing a rousing chorus of Happy Birthday at the top. Not something you celebrate every day and in such a momentous fashion. Gold stars to all concerned!!!!

Great walk and it is free!. I did not do the climb as I have a big problem with heights - and yes, it is also rather expensive if, like me, you pay in a currency much weaker than the dollar. The walk itself is great - doesn't cost anything and you have great views from the bridge. Easy to get off at either Milsons Point or Circular Quay, depending upon with way you want to do the walk - and get on the metro at the other station.

Great Views from the Bridge. We would of loved to do the bridge walk, but the cost put it way out of reach. (over $250 each). So we did the free walk to the Pylon look area paid the $13 to walk up to see great views of the bay and Opera house. Nothing in Sydney is cheap! Be prepared to do a lot of walking to get lots of great pictures of everything.

Amazing and Challenging Climb. We took the plunge and spent the $318 to do the climb at 5:35 pm. We got to see the sunset and came down the bridge in the evening to see the city lights. It was a good choice of times on March 16. So make sure you think this through even you want both day and night views. The groups after us did not get both experiences. The trip takes about 3 hours. 1 hour is prep, 30 minutes to select and pay for pictures, and 2 hours on the bridge. I felt very prepared as they give you everything you need: jump suit, hat, headlight, headset to hear the leader, belt with cable to attach you to the line that you are attached to, hanky and there is probably more. This was really well thought out. They give you a group shot, video of you say a few words about the climb and a certificate at the end. It was a great experience and I liked seeing everything in the day and night. Our guide took some pictures which were available for purchase at the end. The cost of a package that includes 10 pictures on a USB was $59. There were only a few more shots that our guide took. I think they should have put all the shots on the drive for the money paid. Then there would be less of a line at the end. Also it would have been a better value. I loved the experience. Our guide was excellent. The place is a bit hard to find, so plan accordingly!
Bridge climb. we did the bridge climb and loved it. It take 3 hours all up but well worth it. Very professional setup and they make everyone very relaxed and you really enjoy the experience.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. we climbed the Sydney Harbour Bridge and what an amazing experience.we did a twilight climb.. When we were about to start our climb, it was raining, we put on our wet weather gear and off we went, we could see very little of the Sydney skyline, but then the rain stopped and cleared, we could see everything then, sunset through the clouds was awesome, and then, on the way back down, we had a photo taken with the Lights of Sydney on.. we saw the best of everything... great great experience..

Memorable Climb. Some activities on your holidays are fun at the time but not really memorable. I climbed the Sydney Harbour Bridge several years ago wiht my daughter and 2 friends: it's a holiday (or anytime) activity you will remember and talk about forever. I bought the hat! The date was earlier than the review box allows.

Doesn't Cost a Cent. We did not climb the bridge as we are not particularly fond of heights, but we did walk it from one end to the other. There is a lovely section of the bridge just for walkers. Some of the best views of the city, harbor, and gardens are provided from this birds eye view. It took us about a half hour to walk across and then back again and it doesn't cost a cent!

Scare of Heights- No need to be here. My husband was a little reluctant to make the climb atop the Sydney Harbour Bridge. But, that was only because he was watching from the ground. Once we did it, he enjoyed it so much, he wanted to do it again.
Magnificent. One has to do the climb on the Bridge. The view is overwhelming,best time first thing in the morning or sunset.

Get On Up. If you only have a few days make sure this is one of the sites to visit. It is free, safe and offers wonderful vistas of the harbour, Sydney and various neighborhoods. It is ICONIC like its sister, the Sydney Opera House. As a bonus it is the best place to get a true feel of the mastery in the architectural design of the Opera House; not to mention various different perspectives of the harbour, the Quay area and outlying areas. The walk is fairly gentle and if you find taxing you can take the Milsons Point ferry back to the Quay for about 6 dollars.

Wlalk on Harbour Bridge. If you want to Sydney Opera House together with Ships and builings, I recommend you to walk on Harbour Bridge. Of course, its free but you need some water to drink. Let say if you start from Sydney Opera House, at the end of other side of bridge, you can find one of fine fish and chips and pie shop, you should try! Price is reasonable and the other cookies and cakes are delicious too! After take a rest there, or you buy and eat outside of shop, on the street there are some benches to enjoy your foods. Then take a train to bask to Syney Opera House or take your othe destination.

Top Aerial Views of Opera and Sydney CBD. Just a short walk from CBD or Circular Quay. Make your way to Pylon Lookout. Its a short walk 10-20 mins on the bridge. You can have amazing aerial views of Sydney Opera, CBD buildings and the ferries. No need to do the harbour bridge skywalk ($250), if you are a budget traveller. Just get to the Harbour Bridge for free, make your way to the stairs ask for Pylon Lookout and have amazing views.

The great Sydney Icon - Sydney Harbour Bridge. Have you ever stopped and starred at the Harbour Bridge in Sydney, really had a good look?? It is an incredible image of visionary design. Can you imagine how people back in those days felt about this design? Just walk across it and feel it under your feet. It's beautiful, really beautiful. I am so proud to have been able to experience it grandness and appreciate the sheer hard work involved in building it (no computers in those days!!) Just do it and you'll see what I mean.....

stunning to look at & walk.. We walked across this one early morning. Taking in the views of the harbour. It took us about 30mins. We didn't climb it, but maybe next time.This time it was a wonderful way to earn brekkie & a ferry back from Luna Park. P.S. it's safe to walk, every 20mins you pass a security guard.

Walk on the bridge, not on top of it. We walked the bridge surface and did not climb it. The views were incredible. It was quite windy and we can only imagine what those who climbed it must have felt. Once over the bridge, for 4 AUD you can take a train back to the city. It is easy to transfer lines as well on the trains.

Sydney Harbor Bridge Climb. This is a must do when visiting Sydney! It is quite expensive but it is awesome. For those with fears of heights (like myself) it really was never an issue. So much fun. It takes a hour to go up and a hour to come down. The guide was great giving us lots of history and pointing out many sites. Fun three hours on top of Sydney!

Amazing experience, must do!. I surprised my partner Marc for his 30th Birthday with the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climp. The experience and the crew were fantastic! When they heard it was his Birthday, our guide Phil got the group to sing Happy Birthday at the very top of the bridge! Something we will never forget. We loved it so much, we were extatic to find out we could purchase photos AND videos that were taken. What an amazing way to see such a beautiful city. Thank you to the crew :)

Great walk across the bridge. Travelers have a great time walking across this mamoth bridge and looking at the harbour. It was a wonderful time while visiting Australia and a great addition to our experience. Saw some fireworks too.

Do the Bridge Climb!. We visited Sydney and were determined to do the bridge climb. I almost backed out when I saw the price, but it was totally worth it! It is a 3-hour commitment, and of course a long walk, but you will love the views, the history, and the experience of it all.

I like a solid foundation below me :). Ok, kudos to all of you that have managed to talk the climb (walk) up the bridge beams. I'm not one for heights so the next best thing was a walk to the Pylon lookout and watch others make the walk up to the top of the bridge. The Pylon lookout gives you a very nice 360 degree views of the city and those doing the bridge climb.

Ugly to look at but hard to imagine Sydney without it. This is a key road and rail access from the city to the northern suburbs. Ugly and crowded when you are on it, without much of a view, the "coat-hanger" dominates much of the inner harbour. The best way to see it is from the pedestrian walkways, by doing the Bridge Climb, or getting a ferry upriver.

the coathanger. when your at circular quay, a great close view of the bridge but if you walk around the botanical gardens to macquaries chair, you will get a pic of the opera house with the harbour bridge in the background. especially a great pic at sunrise or sundown on a beautiful day
Iconic. Harbour bridge and the Opera house in one photo. What more can u ask for? Try to coincide your visit with fireworks that come on at 2030 hrs.

Exhilarating walk across the bridge. Take the ferry from Circular Quay ort the train across the bridge to Milsons Point and walk back over the bridge - great views overlooking the harbour and a great way to see the bridge. It is a fabulous spot to take photographs - once the weather is good! Come off at The Rocks steps and have a cool drink in the Australian Pub, a pub with history and character.

Sydney Bridge Climb Must do. I was given a gift voucher to do the Sydney Harbor bridge Climb well we started at 6.30 pm and the experience lasted till about 9.30 p.m , it was a great view of beautiful Sydney Harbour and the lights of the city were stunning.

Iconic bridge!. Famous bridge in Sydney Harbour delivers. Throughout our stay in downtown Sydney you can not avoid but seeing the bridge (and the Opera House)- it grows on you! Spectacular views of the Sydney Harbour by walking across the bridge. Was able to see the bridge from several perspectives while travelling around Sydney - a mainstay to the harbour! Bought a small bridge replica from the Bridge Climb store and will be able to have it at home as a lasting memory of the bridge and of our time in Sydney,
What a view.. We had a fantastic day climbing the bridge. The view was amazing. It wasn't a hard climb and was well worth it for the view. I would recommend it to anyone that visits Sydney.

Lovely to walk across. We decided to catch a ferry to Milsom's point (Luna Park) and walk up the Kirrabilli pedestrian walking access and walk back across towards the city via the bridge. The great surprise was there was market underneath the bridge on the Kirrabilli side, which we spent some time strolling through before walking across.

A must do activity in Sydney. If you do this, the best time to do it is about 5.30, you climb up in the daytime, watch the sun start to set at the top and then climbs down as the sun sets. The views were absolutely amazing. Our guide was called Scott & he was really good fun with great chat. Definitely something to do in Sydney.

Walk the bridge. Received a bridge climb voucher for a birthday gift. Went at the twilight sesion so we started at 6.15pm. Was brilliant. Eat befor hand, you are up there for 3 hours, there are snacks and light food at the office. Very windy. Ladies dont rely on hair clips and bobbie pins. you have to take them all out before the climb. So secure your hair in a braid or tight pony tail. Dont need to be overly fit. it is an incline but reletivly easy.Best view in the city, and guides are very informative and supportive if you have a fear of heights.

Great View. While not the most visited site in Sydney, you for sure can't miss it, even if it's just too view it from the Harbor. No matter where your at in the City center and Harbor area you'll be able to see it. It has quite a history and if your up for a great walk there are a set of steps from the Rocks area to the walking path across the bridge. It's free to walk across and from the center you'll get some great photos of the harbor area. If your really up for a view, and a climb, for a fee you can walk to the top viewing area.

Great walk with amazing views. We parked on the other side of the bridge and got a ferry into the city. We decided to walk over the bridge back to the can and were so glad we did. The views were spectacular. Great to see views we hadn't seen before. Lots of pictures taken.

Free walk. We walked the bridge this visit. On previous trips we were not aware that there was a pedestrian lane.Best of all it's free and only took 20 minutes from Argyle Street. Easy to find and great views, not necessary to do the skyline walk unless you're looking at doing something a bit more daring and want to be higher.Once over the other side we realised we were right by the Olympic pool and Lunar Park so no need to hop on and off public transport to get to these attractions. We intend to do this walk again on our next visit

Honeymoon in Sydney. As others stated, the views are some of the best we have ever encountered. We took the Twilight time and afterward, realized we made a great decision. We got best of both worlds being able to see Sydney in the day AND night. I do think it is a little over priced for the experience. It is a LOT of hurry up and wait. The groups are a little big and even though the tour took 3.75 hours, only 1.75 hours of that time were on the actual bridge. If groups were a little smaller, the set up, safety briefing, etc. would not have to be as long. However, we still had a great time and our guide was really energetic and fun. The best part was being able to sit on top of the bridge and just look out over the water. Very relaxing even that high up!! It was a great one-time event.
Best bridge. I fell for this bridge, we walked across it, photographed it. Went on a train across it and a taxi. Sadly did not do the climb, oh well will have to re visit .

Great, but Not the Moment of the Trip. The views at the top were amazing. But, with any major attraction you are kept on a schedule to move the masses through. I didn't like that for safety reason we were not allowed to take a camera requiring us to buy the over priced pictures they took. If you get the chance do it and enjoy it, but if not I don't believe it will ruin your trip.
