If you're worry about safety, you'll be well-briefed on the equipment and procedures. You have a "slider" that's attached from your waist to a metal thingy (gosh, I can't think of the correct word right now) of the bridge structure. that's means, you won't fall or anything. Some questionnaire to fill up and a breath analyses test done. If you're clear, then you're good to go! They provide a cap if you're climbing in the day. I went at night (it's winter) and I was provided with a fleece sweater too (which comes in a small bag that's attached to the waist band). Anyway, go for the climb! You won't regret it! The team will take care of you.

the climb. A must do while in Sydney. I enjoyed the breath taking views and beautiful weather I had while I was there june 2014. The climb is about 3 hours long and I enjoyed every minute of it. You get a hat and a certificate along with a group photo to keep

What a view. If you are planning to visit late evenings would be the best , when the lights come up the view is just amazing and the opera house looks great, the night we were here it was a full moon and the scene when moon just comes above opera house is a sight to see.

Key: Bridge climb vs walk. As iconic as this bridge is, you really should spend a little time here. We simply walked along the footpath, absolutely free and quite safe with all the railings and security guy present. There is a lookout with an amazing harbor and opera house view awaiting. It's windy up there but comfortable. Some people discuss taking the climb which is a fee and given the location may be worth it. We just didn't have the time. The walk is about 30 min to halfway point & back.
Pylon walk. If you can't afford the expense of walking along the top of the Harbour Bridge, do the pylon walk instead. It isn't expensive and the views of Sydney harbour are spectacular.

Money Well Spent I Say!. Reading the terrible reviews before hand about the Harbour Bridge is really disappointing... I do believe I read on one that it is 'ugly' and they comment that it should have been torn down decades ago! And others saying its boring because when you do the climb you have to go through all the 'safety crap', dunno about them but i'd rather spend and hour on safety then fall 40 stories aha. I know the amount of terrible/poor reviews are minuscule next to the 1000+ excellent ones but seriously...Now to my actual review... yes! I did the climb! And it was glorious. It was no where near as exhausting as I thought it would be, the thousands of stairs are nothing, its just like walking up a slight hill. We did the night tour, my partner had done it before and said it was better than the day one, just the way the city is lit up! Plus the photos all came out amazing. At the top the bridge it was the best feeling of accomplishment. Our climb leader, Bernie, was funny, very Aussie and had a good crack at the Americans (being the only Aussies on our climb it was amusing to watch their reactions) The full beard and thick accent noticeable to even us made him seem very outback bushrangerish. For an american would have been quite the experience in itself. Overall I think it was worth the money, don't do the express one because its the cheaper alternative, for the best experience we reckon go for the night one.

Unique experience. Yes, everyone said this is a must do, if you ever get to Sydney, and they are all correct! As ridiculously expensive the bridge walk was, my 10 year old daughter and I just had to do it on a perfect day. The walk was super easy, very slow paced as the guides where informing you on every possible nook and cranny of the bridge. I recommend doing this in the later afternoon as the sun shines from the west brilliantly lighting on the Opera House and the downtown buildings. As much money you spend for the walk, and cameras are not aloud you have to splurge for the photos at the end of your excursion, because it's the only proof you have of your climb. By the way, don't drink to much before you climb and use the restroom before you enter as you will have no opportunity for almost three hours to use any facilities. Bottom line, expensive but worth it!

Must do!. Walked from The Rocks and explored the neighbourhood before reaching the bridged. Crossed it to Kirribilli. Took the train back to the city (Milsons Point to Town Hall). The view is spectacular and the walk doesnt feel as long as it looked.

Easy Walk. \this was not as long as I thought, and the walk around it (ground level) was great, giving good views of the Opera House and the harbour, well worth it, not sure I could manage the up and over walk though, its a long way up!

The Bridge Climb is spectacular. Doing the bridge climb for sunset was an amazing experience …the organisation and safety was excellent even though the excitement of the upcoming climb makes one a bit impatient but needs to be done …the wait was well worth it …I am looking to do another climb for sunrise when that is available and I have ben to Sydney hundreds of times…..for visitors from anywhere definitely a must do experience!!! I have no worries re heights however I don't believe it should be an issue for 99% of people …you are very very safe

one off the bucket list!. We did the twilight climb, which in the first part of the climb offers daylight views and towards the end of your climb nighttime views (and everything else in between). I would recommend this as we felt like we got the best of both worlds. The climb is not at all challenging and caters for all ages and fitness levels. They do have alternative routes for those afraid of heights, but are not very sympathetic with the phobia. You are clipped in throughout your time, so completely safe. The organisation of the climb is second to none and you can tell safety is their main concern. You even practice going up and down stairs wearing your 'climbing clobber'. Every eventuality is catered for as you are given a fleece and rain jacket to carry with you on the climb. Photos and videos are taken by the guide and purchased for $30. At the end you get a group photo and certificate (which is all in with the price of the climb). Although it was more expensive than I was expecting, it is an absolute must do in Sydney and certainly one of the bucket list!

Was it worth it?. My immediate thoughts on seeing the ticket prices were that it was very expensive. To travel halfway around the world and not do this was not an option. Our guide ( a Tom Cruise lookalike) was brilliant. His knowledge was as you would expect but with the added exceptional humour it made for an enjoyable visit. The safety of the clients is paramount and at no time did it feel unsafe. Would I recommend it? Most definitely - worth every Dollar.

Make sure you have good walking shoes. We took the ferry over to Milsons Point with a view to walking back across the bridge. By the time we walked past Luna park and up to The Secret Garden (Whitley Garden) and back then found our way to the stairs to take us up to the bridge our feet were telling us that perhaps it wasn't that great an idea to walk across - not over the very top, but across the pedestrian path - then make our way back to our hotel a kilometre or so further on. I would expect the view from the very top would be great but with traffic roaring past on one side and mesh on the other, the views of the harbour were fairly limited. I wouldn't bother again.
Massive bridge. Absolutely massive bridge which makes it pretty impressive. It is after the opera house Sydney's most iconic attraction. However it is not the most beautiful bridge.

Great view from the top!. We did the express climb which was perfect as it gave you enough information about the bridge and you get the spectacular views but you didn't have to spend all day doing it!You get fully kitted out in a jumpsuit and have a wet weather coat, beanie and cap which are all clipped on to your suit. All other loose items have to be left in secure lockers as they can't risk anything falling off and hitting someone below! The climb was swift but easy enough for anyone of average fitness - it didn't feel rushed and the guide assesses and caters for all the people in the group. You pose for a group shot at the top which you have the option to buy at the end.It was a great experience, one we are really glad we did. The guides were humorous and informative and made it a really good few hours.

Sydney's Crown Jewel. I stayed at the North Sydney Harbour View Hotel last week which allowed a great view of the bridge from my room. Night time was almost majical, especially as the whole basin area was lit up during Vivid, the Festival of Light. The bridge is definitely impressive (I think I am qualified to say that, being a bridge engineer myself). Having said that, I think there is also another bridge in Sydney which deserves a bit more attention; the Anzac cable stayed bridge.Anyway, coming back to the SHB, I think it symbolises the city more than any other landmark. Sydney's Crown Jewel.
Great sight. Having seen the bridge on TV or Movies many times were still delighted to see it 'in the flesh'It's an essential part of Sydneys history

Sydney Harbour Bridge is a "Must See". If you travel to Sydney, be sure to check out the Sydney Harbour Bridge. We Sydney Siders affectionatly call her "the coat hanger" (please see images as this will explain the name :-)Plans were made in 1815 to have a bridge that crossed Sydney Harbour. It wasnt until 1923 that the winning submission was accepted and the go ahead was given. the bridge was opened in 1932 and has been in constant use ever since. The bridge has only been closed once for road re surfacing in 2013, and the original surface from 1932 was still almost perfect, great 1930's workmanship.From any angle from any vantage point around Sydney harbour, even from almost anywhere in The Rocks, and the North Shore. This magnificent single span arch bridge dominates the surrounding areas and is truely beautiful.Of course if you are energetic book yourself a "Bridge Climbe Experiance" This will take you through the history of the Sydney Harbour and it's first bridge crossing. Then you will be suited up, all things droppable are removed from your person, and people who wear glasses with have then thethered to your head.Even handkerchief's are tied to your person.You are then secured by a cable tether to the actual bridge its self. Once you are on your way be prepared for some slightly tough climbs and lots of walking. Once on your way the scenery and views are nothing short of stunning!Unfortunately you cant tak a camera with you, however all photographs are taken by your tour guide once on top of the bridge. Really worth the effort for the amazing views. A twighlight bridge climb is great as you get to see the stunning city & harbour views by day, then get to witness the city lights on your way back down. The bridge climb offices are located in Cumberland Street The Rocks, just up the hill from the Harbour View Hotel (pub)

We didn't dare to hike to the top, but we walked across and back.... It's expensive and not for the faint of heart to hike to the top of the bridge, so we opted to walk across. It's a spectacular view, and we're glad we did it, but brace yourself for the 8 road lanes and 2 rail tracks of traffic zooming by just on the other side of the barrier.

Incredibly Beautiful. It is an amazing bridge in an amazing place. Go for a walk through the Botanical Gardens and you'll have beautiful pictures of the Opera House with the bridge behind it.I just don't rate it as 5 stars because the climb of the bridge is shockingly expensive (around 200 dollars!), but the place is a must-go if you go to Sydney, of course!

Climb of your life. Take the outer rim to climb.There is no reason to be afraid. even those who fear heights will love to do this climb.It looks steep but they give ample time for slow climbers.The view from the top is exhilarating

Great activity. Even though it rained on and off, we had all the kit...gloves, beanie, rain pants, fleece, jacket so we were warm. Our guide, Michael, was awesome and really made the trip for our small group. Funny, knowledgable. Climb was easier than I thought. Photo package for $50 is good option as you get to choose ten photos from a group of about 18 that the guide takes. Unreal views and the history is interesting as well.

Must do when in Sydney not just for the tourists locals will love even more. Just fantastic. Went just before sunset, was cheaper than the sunset ticket but we got best of both world. Great fro locals and tourists. Can't wait to take our son when he's old enough. My hubby was a bit sceptical that it would be too touristy but both absolutely loved it worth every cent. Takes up a fair bit of your day so allow enough time not to feel rushed. Proud of my beautiful home city of Sydney would recommend to everyone not to be missed

Walked across. We were going to do the bridge climb, but decided not to as you cannot bring camera/phone and it is quite expensive. So, seeing the office we were visiting was in North Sydney, we crossed the bridge instead. It is a nice stroll, but not with a great view, as they have made sure no one is able to climb over to jump. So, basically just a heap of metal (ugly coat hanger), at least when on the bridge :)
We climbed the Sydney Bridge. It was a great experience.Takes 3 1/2 hours bur does not seem that long when you are walking and listening to the guide who gives you the history of the Bridge.

Bridge Climb. DO NO MISS IT !!The bridge climb was my best bit of Sydney and it lasts a good couple of hours. You get to see fantastic views of the city from the top and the guides are really good and know their stuff.Takes a bit of time with the dressing up, induction and security (30 - 60mins) but its well worth it.

Beautiful. I am a big fan of metal architecture, and although my tour of the place was just superficial, it was breath taking to see this construct up close. Planning to take a full tour on the insides in the future.

Spectacular. Expensive to do the Bridge Climb but worth every penny. Very professional experience, not once will you feel unsafe. The experience is tremendous, the photos they take are very reasonably priced and there is even the facility to upload them on to Facebook immediately. You also get a free group photo of the people who climb with you and a certificate to state you have done the climb.Views are spectacular, staff never once sound bored, even though they must do these climbs so many times every day. If you can afford it, this is the one thing you should do when in Sydney!

A thrilling experience. After half an hour of dressing up, security brief we were all set to start the climb. An amazing, very safe experience for 90 minutes till the top of the bridge. Fully worth it.

Iconic bridge and great views as you walk across.. We did not do the full bridge climb but just going up to cross on the pedestrian path is worth it for yet more views of the Opera house and wonderful harbour. The museum at the bridge climb has an interesting display about the construction of this amazing bridge.
Free and inspiring. Walk along it, look at the views, marvel at the engineering. It is free and just requires foot power.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Walk. This was a fantastic attraction. I did it with my family which added to the enjoyment but between the other people in the group and the fantastic guide it was a really enjoyable experience. I am quite large but the suit was fine and I had no real issues with any part of the walk. I also have a fear of heights and this also was no problem. You are securely attached to the bridge at all times. The views were spectacular. We did the twilight walk so started in daylight and finished in complete darkness. As a bonus we fluked a night when there were three separate lots of fireworks. Also I am not the most flexible person but had no problems getting through the tight spots and up\down the ladders.I would recommend this to anyone and will surely do it again sometime soon.
Great sight. The bridge is everything you expect it to be and when viewed with the Opera House particularly at sunset it's amazing.

Exciting. A must do on a visit to Sydney. No point in going all that way and not!! Been there got the t shirt as the saying goes? We are from manchester and met one of the engineers who has worked on the for 13 years (only a Mancunian) ha small world

Nice walk. It's a really nice walk over the bridge - and the best thing: it's for free! You could do the bridge climb (and I'm sure it's pretty awesome, I did one in Auckland) but it's so much cheaper if you just walk over the bridge. Start at Milsons Point (north) and the Opera House and a great Skyline will be in front of you. We went there just before sunset and it just looked great. There's also a little tower but that one isn't for free and you'll be perfectly fine if you don't go up there.

Cheap (free) and easy walk with good views. Worth a walk from one side to the other for the views alone. You will need to peer thru mesh (stops the jumpers) but still able to take photos. Kirribilli (on the north side) offers options for coffee/cake or lunch, or a visit to Luna Park if you want fun rides.

Top of the bridge. I was given the bridge climb as a birthday present, as I am scared of heights. However it was one of the best things I have experienced. Our guide was full of facts and information as well as being very funny and entertaining and the view from the top is something you cannot put into words. I didn't experience any fear and I think that is because you are focused on the climb and the view. I recommend that everyone should do this at least once in their lives.

Free Walk - Look Out for 13 AUD - Prices Bridge Climb. Well here are your 3 options. Bridge climb gives you a unique experience but really pricey, or some kibd of rip off, especially when you think that you are not allowed to take your own camera or phone. A cheaper alternative is the Pylon lookout, which will give you a great look out. Or the cheapest one (free) is the bridge walk. Take the train, go to Milsons Point station and walk back to Circular Quay station over bridge. You get the view, fresh air and you van take pictures for free!! The walk takes about 15-20 minutes.

Sydney icon. You can't come to Sydney without visiting the Harbour Bridge.If, like me, you don't like heights, you don't need to do the Bridge Climb to get great views of the Harbour.You can walk across the bridge from one side to the other in less than 30 minutes and still have great views of the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour. Or you could walk halfway to the middle o f the bridge and walk back.Note : There's quite a few stairs to get to the Harbour Bridge walkway so it's not suitable for strollers or wheelchairs.

An amazing experience!. It is super expensive yes, but definitely worth it! Had the most amazing evening, tour guide was friendly, funny and very knowledgable! Would recommend any one going to Sydney to put aside the money to do the climb but be aware, you can't take personal cameras and photos are expensive to buy though again, a must!

A bucket-list must-do. Are you kidding me, only ranking this #7 as an attraction in Sydney? Have you ever met anyone who wanted to go to Sydney who DIDN'T want to do the bridge climb? This is a one-of-a-kind experience that, as far as I know, isn't duplicated anywhere else in the world. And it's a surprisingly easy climb, despite the pictures and descriptions you may have seen. A tip -- take the twilight tour, it's two experiences in one; a daylight climb to the top, and a sunset/nighttime climb back down. Totally unforgettable!
I hate heights, but this was great!. safe, intersting and an absolute must for tourists.You see the pictures on tv all the time, so its a great feeling to get home and know you have done it

Expensive to climb. We did not climb the bridge as the cheapest climb was $220 per person. So we opted to walk over the bridge, and ferry under the bridge. maybe not quite the same as climbing, but to expensive for us

brilliant tour. A spectacular thing to do if in Sydney even if expensive. You get a personal tour of ten in group. Tour guide experinced and knowledgable.Once completed there was tge usual expence on pictures which could come down in price seeing as price of ticket at £160.00. If you want digital they charge another $10 to put on a unique memory stick with added professional pics. Loved the experience and despite cost, would like to recomend the visit
Fantastic views. Great views of the bay & opera house, didn't have the nerve to do the walk over the top of the bridge, just stuck to the normal pedestrian track, but it did look amazing

Not a disappointment!. It's true that things you see on postcards/the internet can be hyped up and end up being a disappointment, but this definitely wasn't!Just SEEING the bridge is pretty amazing as it's so well-known. You can see the bridge from all different angles, such as from the harbour, by the opera house, mrs macquarie's chair and even down by the water (stumbled across when following the water round an industrial place).Unfortunately I did not walk up and over the top on the discovery tour, but I saw others do it and I will definitely do it next time. Although, I did walk across the bridge both in the day and at night which gave us some amazing views.

A must do!!!. Well worth the cost, very informative guide, fantastic views, good group experience even if you wanted to do the climb alone. Safety is paramount but very reassuring especially if you don't like heights. If you travel to Sydney it's a must do.

Scared of Heights?. Yes, I am, this Bridge Climb was organised for me and a group of girlfriends as a surprise. I was terrified at the thought,spent a sleepless night and headed off at 7.00am the following morning.The briefing you receive is fantastic and when delivered by and eye candy guy all your fears seem to disappear!!You are soon kitted up in an overall, beanie, and lockers are provided to store all your things. You can't take cameras, handbags or anything that could go over the edge - dangerous for you and whoever or whatever could be down below.The climb is fantastic, we had a perfect sunny morning and the view just has to be seen to be believed, one of the best experiences I have ever had and as tourist attractions go is right up there with the best of them.You are kept very safe and hooked on the whole trip moving in groups of 6 at a time and are given plenty of time to take in the view and points of interest and history to sydney.So if you are not keen on heights, take it from one who isn't and don't let that get in your way of a magical few hours.Professional photographs are available for purchase at the end of the climb.

Amazing to watch. You an climb the bridge which is a 1/2 day event. We did not climb it but the view is awesome when you come in on a Ferry. You also see the people climbing with tie offs. Amazing bridge!

Renewing our Vows at the Top!. My husband and I renewed our wedding vows at the top of the Sydney Bridge. The staff was so knowledgeable and helpful. I'm afraid of heights and really wanted to overcome it as well as do something truly memorable and romantic. Our guide was so friendly and patient. I had some trouble early on, but she was so great and supportive. She talked about how she had performed at the 2000 Olympics opening ceremony. She was very animated and engaging. We bought the whole tour to ensure privacy for our special day. They were great about giving us plenty of time at the top for photos, even taking some for us. It was the highlight of our time in Sydney, just AMAZING. If you are in the area, this is a MUST SEE!!

Discovery Climb. I booked the Discovery Bridge Climb before we left England. Booking and payment was straight forward. I only had a vague idea of what we would be getting. I’m pleased we chose the Discovery Climb. Winding our way through the girder work was easy on the boarded pathway and strong stairs. There were only 10 of us in our group, our very senior guide was brought in on that particular Sunday morning to replace someone who’d been out too late the night before ! He was brilliant ! It was a beautiful still morning with excellent visibility. Our guide reckoned “That’s the clearest I’ve seen the Blue Mountains for a long while”. We got up on to the top for a photo shoot just the same as if we’d done the Bridge Climb up the top arch. I was intrigued by the mechanism of the safety line and the connection system. You travel at your own pace, not lashed together as someone told us we would be. Choose your day, chose your time, pay y money, hope it’s not raining and spend a long while looking forward to it. It is worth it ! ! Don’t buy a Harbour Bridge hat before you go,,,, they give you one to wear and keep !

Don't drink and climb. Absolutely fabulous experience - quite expensive but well worth it and justified given the time and effort in the preparation. However make sure you are sober on arrival as you are breathalysed before the event (don't know what the limits are). Organisation is meticulous, and gives confidence even to those who have some problems heights if safety is not fully assured. The views are superb and the commentary by the group leader was excellent. The climb is not too strenuous, with only the ladder section putting any strain on an overweight 60+ male, but not a problem as everything is taken at an easy pace with plenty of stops for views and commentary. Do not expect to take any photos, as all items that could be dropped are left at base. Only glasses are allowed with suitable attachments.
Worth very cent. What a great way to see Sydney, The staff are very helpful and friendly. What a view. We did it at 2.30pm so only to see both daylight and night doing our time on the bridge.

Better in Real Life. Yes it's just a bridge but considering that I have spent my life seeing it on TV and Movies, it was quite a kick to see it in real life.Definitely do the Hop on Hop off cruise and get the details of the bridge, one or two will surprise you

Worth the climb!. We did a night climb during the vivid festival. Such a great time to be on top of the bridge! The lights of the opera house turing on were spectaculor as were all the lights of the city (made more magical by the vivid festival). Our guide Daniel told us lots of intresting information along the way which added to the experience. The climb itself wasn't scary, a few steep steps up and down but most of it is a gradual incline/decline. We had plenty of stops to just enjoy the views. You can purchase your photos of the climb - you can get a CD of 10 photos for $49.95 so if you go in a group get this once and share electronically - well worth the memento.
free from giddiness? - try the bridge climb. It was a great experience! It takes about 40 min and you should be free from giddiness :) But the view is definitely worth it!

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. Highlight of my stay in Australia! We had great weather for it too - about 15 degrees C. You get dressed up in jumpsuits which are really flattering... and hooked onto a wire that you follow up the bridge. I went with a couple of people who were scared of heights, but they got over it after the first 5-10 minutes because it doesn't feel like you're that high up. Even though you really are..!At the top are some fantastic views of Sydney. A lot of fun. Although it's expensive, it was well worth it!

Climb It!. Climb the Sydney Harbor Bridge, it is totally worth it! Once in a lifetime experience, breathtaking views. Worth the cost. Not as scary or as physical as you might think. Great guides and instruction and preparation.
The coat hanger:-). So amazing to marvel at and even more amazing to climb. Stunning with Vivid Sydney and a must to see.
Lovely walk. A great getaway in downtown Sydney. See eels, bats? Great plants, beside the sea. Looking out at the Sydney opera house and Sydney harbour bridge.

Astounding views of a short history. Just getting to the bridge involves a healthy climb of stairs! Circular Quay is a reasonably easily accessible starting point and getting there is cheap and efficient with Sydney's excellent public transport network. At the quay is a tourist information booth which will provide you with ample guidance. There are multiple refreshment venues to meet all budgets and while there it might be a good opportunity to make use of the well maintained bathrooms. From there the walk through the rocks to the bridge is pleasant with views across the harbour to the opera house. The entrance to the bridge is small but easily found and there are landings where you can catch your breath. The pylon museum has a small fee and gives a good account of the history of the bridge, from the top of the pylon the views are spectacular and pretty much the same as what you would see from the more expensive and more challenging bridge climb. I was surprised at the small number of people at the pylon lookout even though it was a warm sunny Saturday afternoon in the middle of the populous 'Vivid' festival which I would have thought to be an ultra busy peak time! There were many more actually on the bridge doing the challenging climb while I comfortably observed from the tower. After the tower climb I walked across the bridge (that's free) but getting to the other side was tired so not fancying a walk back got the train across the bridge back which, using my economical multi transport ticket and the assistance of strategically placed railway transport assistance staff I was able to link up with connecting services direct to my hotel.

bridgd climb is very fun and easy. i took the express climb one, took me less than an hour and half to finish the climb. not scary at all! suitable for young and old.very good view on top.coach is albert, very funny and friendly.

A WONDERFUL experience. After many years of visiting Australia and seeing THE BRIDGE, either cruising beneath when sailing into the Harbour, riding over or the many views from various tours, at last I managed to experience THE CLIMB. What a fascinating and enjoyable experience!The scenic gallery of photographs in the shop certainly whet the appetite! Then, after booking the tour, the pre-climb routine is extremely well organized. The formalities include signing an indemnity which confirms you are aware of the risks and void any direct responsibility for any accidents.Then what is VERY REASSURING is the very thorough PRE-CLIMB TRAINING to ensure that you are completely aware of what is involved, and again confirm you are comfortable to continue. We then discarded our outer clothing and dressed in a boiler suit and fitted with our safety harness. Then you are required, after a demonstration, to complete a mini SAMPLE OF THE CLIMBING THAT YOU WILL EXPERIENCE. Again, you have ther opportunity to cancel if you are not satisfied that you feel comfortable to continue. You are equipped with your safety harness, Gloves, warm and rain proof jacket, beanie ( in case it is cold). By this time you really know that you are in good hands with your guide. The climb and the views are FANTASTIC. Particularly, as I experienced the twilight tour and the decent in the dark. The lights of Sydney and vies of the Opera House etc, are truly Magical. At various stages our guide pointed out the many highlights and took photographs of the group of climbers. One feature was the Hotel that was a focal point for the many who were involved in the actual building of the Bridge. A fabulous place to visit after the climb. After changing back into your own clothing, you the can select and purchase copies of the photographs taken on the climb. A truly memorable experience NOT TO BE MISSED.

Another architectural masterpiece.. And it's right near the opera house. Sydney is so lucky to have two amazing pieces in the one city. I have walked across the bridge twice in my lifetime and captured some amazing views. Definitely a must see, the tonnes of steel are just breathtaking when close up. I haven't done the climb yet but plan to do it soon!!!

Do the Bridge Climb!. I was worried I wouldn't be able to keep up, but it was absolutely fine. Perhaps I was distracted by the awesome view, as I didn't notice the physical challenge, not really. I'm not too bother by heights, but I have to admit there were a few moments of OMG that I had to level with gazes in the distance. This was a stunning event. It wasn't cheap but they provide you with all the safety gear and information. If you go to Sydney, you have to do the Bridge Climb.

Do it yourself!. There is no need to do the expensive bridge climb. You can walk across the bridge and get stunning views of the harbour and Opera House. On the other side of the bridge to the walkway is a cycle path, which is equally a great way to see the harbour but you cannot see much of the Opera House from that side. (Pedestrians are not allowed on the cycling side of the bridge.)There is a great short walk on the north side of the harbour which gives you superb views. Start at Luna Park and then follow the footpath round Lavender Bay. When you come to the end go up the steps and walk back down Lavender Bay Road - great views all round. You might want to pop in to the Kirribilli Club (open to visitors) for a beer or meal in full view of the harbour bridge.

Great walk and views. We spent the morning at the Rock and had a huge lunch, walking to the bridge was a great way to burn some calories, not to mention the spectacular views. We just did the Free walk and did not climb the rails. This is plenty tho get to se the bridge and the harbor from a different vantage point.
Walk the heights. We walked the bridge after dark and the view of the city and the lights around the Harbour is spectacular. Fairly busy with pedestrians and runners but worth the time

Dream opportunity for camera buffs. Walking across the bridge presents so many photo opportunities for all whether the smartphone addict, the tourist intent on capturing holiday memories, the keen amateur or the professional photographer. There was something for everyone.........landscapes, icons; all modes of transport from yachts to cruise ships, planes, cars, trains and of course people, locals and visitors enjoying this wonderful experience. Then on the other side........... The village atmosphere of Kirrabilli, the parks, buildings old and new, Luna Park and refreshments to suit all tastes. A wonderful experience and a wonderful way to showcase our city.
Bridge Climb. Fantastic experience - so glad we did it and would do it again. Guides both very friendly and helpful. Views were breath-taking - superb at twilight.

Awesome Experience. If you do one thing in Sydney walk the bridge.At first it seems expensive but when you experience it you realise it is well worth it. The tour takes approx three and a half hours and includes all the safety checks clothing and equipment needed. The staff are fantastic and by the time you start your walk everyone is bursting with enthusiasm and any nerves have disappeared. It is not a hard walk the first for ladders are the hardest it gets and that feeling when you reach the top is WOW. At the end you are presented with a certificate,photo and a short 8 sec video to send immediately to any E Mail address. Great experience !

Monumental. This bridge is just a marvellous demonstration of human engineering. It is beautiful and awesome to look at especially up close. When you see it is riveted top to bottom with millions of rivets you just see how wonderfully made it is. Photos at night make it even more delightful. A walk around it is worthwhile and recommended.

For God's sake don't drive across. Although thousands of cars and trains cross this historic coathanger bridge every day of the year, by far the best way to cross the Harbour Bridge is on foot or on a bike. started circular quay cross to the northside, take a swim in the historic North Sydney pool would take the kids to the rides at Luna Park. Catch the ferry on the way home, or drop in Darling Harbour to some additional playtime and some great restaurants on the foreshore.

The bridge climb minus the steep price. We decided the "official" climb wasn't worth the hefty price tag. You go really slow and it's not that far. Most of the time is spent preparing to climb. SO... For only about $12 USD we climbed to the pylon lookout which is really almost as high as the top. You can spend as much time there as you want. You can take your own photos. You can wear a hat. You have an incredible view of the harbour. There is a great museum and cool movie inside the pylon as well! Then after you can walk across the bridge (free), it's only about 1 ½ miles across and has great views. You can run too!

Sydney bridge climb. We did a night climb - first of that evening and it was an excellent experience. Got some daylight, then sunset and finally night all in the one climb.Great views, great climb and fantastic staff
Dizzy heights. Actually walked across the bridge and it was fantastic. As we walked across we watched the climbers walking over the bridge. Not for me but fun watching.

If you want the T shirt it's a 'must do'. We climbed the bridge with family on our visit to Sydney, which is arguably the most beautiful harbour in the world. The vantage point when you reach the top is second to none, absolutely awesome with a bird's eye view of the opera house and any gigantic ocean liners that may be visiting at the time.The downside is you will need to get saving, very expensive, as are most things now in Australia. The current exchange rate doesn't help but nonetheless it is still expensive, in excess of £100 each.

Pricey walk to top but fun. VERY organized tour to top of bridge. Pricey but worth the effort. Not as scary as I thought it would be. Scariest par is first part walking btwn rafters etc. Once you get the uphill part- clear sailing. The tour group provides suit to wear. Quite hot so took off pants underneath. Make you take a breathalyzer test to make sure you aren't drunk. Wear closed toe shoes. They give you free group picture and option to record 10 sec video on top you can email/facebook your friends. Pretty cool experience. Took a couple hours. They heard you through though

A once in a life time experience well worth it. The bridge climb was great your put through a brief health and safety check at the bottom and the. Shown how to use to karabina clip on your harness. Your then clipped onto the safety rail and up you climb, fitness isn't really a main part as you can be all fitness levels to do this. The view is well worth it!

Crossing the bridge. I walked across the most beautiful harbour in the world, on the most beautiful bridge. As I was born in England near Newcastle- on- Tyne I was only to keen to tell anyone who asked that it was a large copy of the prototype ( Newcastle bridge) I didn't have a complaint about the day, the traffic was noisy, but then it always is, I would have liked to get closer to the edge but safety demands come first.

View and History. The museum inside the pylons are great way to know about the story of the construction of the bridge, nicely maintained and the view of the surrounding area from the viewing area is simply stunning.

Great Walk, Great View. When you think about Sydney, you think about the Opera House but you also think about the Sydney Harbour Bridge! Its a must do walk! Takes a good 30 minutes to cross the bridge! You can just go sit down across the Opera House and just enjoy!

A great stroll across the Bridge. On a nice day, a stroll across the Bridge is a really nice thing to do. It's an easy walk, & just a gentle incline until you reach half way, walking towards the city. It is a very popular thing to do for joggers, parents with prams, older couples, in fact anyone. There is a bike path on the other side, & that seems very popular. Access the bridge from Milsons point rail station. The great thing is that it doesn't cost anything. It is possible to leave the Bridge at steps leading down into the Rocks area, where there are numerous places to eat. It is also possible to continue around to the Circular Quay exit, & of course the views are fantastic.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. I did this some time ago, and can thoroughly recommend it to people visiting Sydney. It is not a difficult exercise and can be done by most people who have a normal level of fitness. The views are exceptional, especially in the evening as the sun goes down and the city lights come on.

Walk along the harbour bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of Australia's most well known and photographed landmarks. It is the world's largest (but not the longest) steel arch bridge.It is fondly known by the locals as the 'Coathanger 'because of its arch-based design.We took train to Milson Point and walked on the bridge to Circular Quay. It has most breathtaking views along the way.The Sydney Harbour Bridge is a steel through arch bridge across Sydney Harbour that carries rail, vehicular, bicycle and pedestrian traffic between the Sydney central business district (CBD) and the North Shore. The dramatic view of the bridge, the harbour, and the nearby Sydney Opera House is an iconic image of Sydney, and Australia.
Great the tour is a must. Great to walk around but if you want to see inside do the tour very interesting and you get to see what it's all about
It's just fantastic. I love this bridge. It could easily be my favourite in the world. It's massive, beautiful, free and has the most spectacular views. Icon of Sydney!
Bridge climb worth the money!. Treated myself to a bridge climb when I arrived in Australia & will never regret it, is a great experience & the guides were awesome.
Bridge Walk. What an experience if you are not afraid of heights. It was quite a climb but well worth it. You can see for miles. If you visit Sydney it is a must

Bridge Climb and Pylon Lookout. Along with the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb you can also do the Pylon Lookout Climb. There are 200 stairs to the Pylon Lookout which takes you 87 metres above sea level. There are 3 levels of exhibits on this climb where you can see information on the history and construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge, you can also buy souvenirs of your visit. From the Pylon Lookout you can walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The walk to the North side of Sydney will take approximately 15-20 minutes. The climb is open 7 days a week from 10.00 am to 5.00 pm and cost $13.00 per adult, don’t forget to show your Bridge Climb ticket as it gets you into this climb for free. At the top you have great views of Sydney and the harbour. While in Sydney this is worth taking time to do. Note: I could not find a way onto the bridge for wheelchair users. After warming up on this climb you can then tackle the Sydney Harbour Bridge. They say to allow 3 ½ hours to do the climb but a bit of this time is taken up on the safety talk before you climb. There are 1,332 steps. No I didn’t count them on my way up. Take your time and allow for your own fitness, don’t worry if you slow the group down a bit. Try not to climb during the hotter parts of the day, as it gets very warm. Try early morning or late afternoon. If you want the best experience book in for the sunset climb. The standard price of the climb ranges from $198 to $348 depending on the time of day you book. This will increase for peak periods. When on top you will get a chance to pose for your souvenir photo. A hint it is hard to look your best while dressed in their jump suits.

Worth visit place with breezely wind. We reach the place around 4pm and decided not to climb up the bridge but if u have a chance, strongly recommend a try.It is indeed great view to the Rocks and Opera house, a fantastic place that certainly filled up my memories

Amazing history and architure. Did an off-peak tour to see the innards of the Opera House. My 60-year-old brother-in-law and lifelong Sydney resident had never been inside!!! Interesting, informative and fun tour. Highly recommended.

Do the Bridge climb no matter your age. This is a brilliant thing to do. The bridge climb is expensive, over $250, different prices for different times of the day, but it is really fun. You have about 10 people in your group from memory and a headphone to listen to the guide. You have to be an adult but it is manageable by young and old alike. You have to prove you can go up ladders and steps wearing a special flight suit and you are totally safe with a safety clip attaching you to a safety wire. The views are amazing. You can't take your camera or phone or anything that might be dropped as that could cause a hazard, so be prepared to buy the photos. We went up late in the afternoon so we could see the sun go down, the lights start to twinkle on and it was wonderful. The staff are fantastically helpful. A cruise boat went under the bridge as we got to the top and they were waving at us and we were waving back at them. It really was fun. If you are scared of heights it would probably not be for you as you can see straight down in most parts, and it really is quite high. I was looking for something that my husband might like to do on our wedding anniversary and this was a real winner.

Worth a climb. This was part of my bucket list and as a surprise,my aunt who lives just outside Sydney arranged for me,my husband and my uncle to do this climb.unfortunately we picked the one day in 100 years that Sydney experienced its coldest weather and rain and even though we had to be up at 5 for our 7 o clock start,it was so worth the effort.the whole experience lasted about 2 and a half hours and as we came down from the bridge,the sun came out.the views are out of this world and there was also the option to purchase a pic or two that was taken on the climb.if you get the chance to do this,please do...it's worth climbing all the steps!
Amazing!. The bridge is just amazing. Absolutely loved it - it was my best day I spent in Sydney. Wld recommend to everyone! And its FREE

Amazing Bridge Walk experience. My husband and I did the Bridge Walk in April. Even though it was raining it was still a fantastic experience. Lauren our guide was very knowledgeable and she made the whole experience really enjoyable. From start to finish all the staff were great and it is all run like clock work. We thought it was a bit expensive when we booked but it was worth every penny and we can't wait for walk number 2. Even better is Dorman Long from Middlesbrough helped make it.

..not just a pile of rivets... ..as a fan of the river Tyne and the iconic Tyne bridge in Newcastle, England, I was more than looking for inspiration from the Sydney Harbour Bridge..constructed by the same people from Middlesborough apparently..I was not to be disappointed as this huge structure dominates the Harbour..with six lanes of traffic..two railway lines and a pathway it is not only high but very wide..although I was not able to do the "walk over the bridge" - actually to the top!..I was able to walk to the centre via the footway..the view was absolutely stunning..they say the best harbour in the World..who am I to argue?
Amazing Experience, Great Views, Beautiful Harbour. Did a sunset walk, it was amazing. Breathtaking views of Sydney Harbor & it's surrounds. A must do for any one visiting our great city!!!
Worth a walk over the top. We didn't manage to get the time, but don't miss this if you can make the time. The views are amazing, Sydney Opera House just below.

Nice walk. Start with a drink at the Hero of Waterloo in the Rocks. Walk across the bridge is free; walk to the top is $250 per person. Great views on the free walk. Nice restaurants and Luna Park on the north side.

Climb a tower. We watched people climbing to the top of the bridge, paying a lot to do so, and unable to carry anything (such as cameras). Instead, we climbed the bridge tower nearest the CBD and had the same view, with pictures. Walking across the bridge is a common pasttime, and there are even guards to keep people in line and give advice. At night, the bridge was lit up and pictures were projected onto the towers. Very nice.

You've Got to Experience This. The first time I want to Sydney, I passed this up because I thought it was too expensive. The adult price is from $200 to $350, depending on the time of day & type of climb you choose. However, at my second visit, me, my wife and a friend did a day standard climb at $258 per person and we purchased a complete picture package for $89 (20 pictures provided on a CD or for $10 more on a thumb drive). We purchased our tickets from bridgeclimb.com, quick and easy.For those that are deathly afraid of heights (like my wife), this is a piece of cake. My wife was strongly against the climb until our granddaughter (after having done it) shamed her into doing it. My friend is also afraid of heights. After the climb my wife and my friend were both extremely thankful that they had been talked into it. Your are tethered the entire way and, for the most part, the path is as wide as a sidewalk. You can't beat the view!While being a bit pricey, we all would do it again. As the Roaming Gnome says "GO AND SMELL THE ROSES!!".

Second's most known Sydney icon. If you do not fancy yourself paying over $230 for a climn on top of the bridge, do yourself a favour and at least walk over to theother side of the harbour. You can get same nice shots with both the Opera house and the bridge

Centrally located. This bridge is in the middle of Sydney, which means that you can get great views of it from many angles and also use it as a vantage point for the other attractions of the harbour.It is a good example of its genre; steel suspension bridge from early 20th century, but not a unique design.

Biggest Coat hanger in world.. Known for it's unique engineering, one of the iconic bridges of 19th century is pride of Australia and milestone in development of great city Sydney. I have seen Brooklyn, Washington bridge in NYC. The famous Howrah of India but I must say Sydney Harbour bridge out stands amongst all of them. You can climb on this bridge and witness beauty of Sydney City. One can go for cycling on this bridge, one can drive, take a train on this bridge and fit n healthy people can walk and run over the bridge. I don't think all of this is possible anywhere else.
Iconic bridge!. Getting on a ferry from the Circular Queue to the Darling Harbour is a must for every visitor to Sydney! You can not miss this fantastic experience!

Anniversary Present. Definitely a must do , put on your bucket list , whether you are visiting Sydney or a resident , we did a dusk climb and saw the city by night light and it was just spectacular , staff all very helpful , friendly and knowledgeable

Easy and Worth the Time!. We chose to not do the bridge climb, but rather just walk along the bridge, and we had stunning views of the city and saved ourselves the $300! The bridge pedestrian access is very easy to find and is a very nice walk! For $13 you can climb up one of the stone columns on either side of the bridge and get a stunning arial view of downtown Sydney, Darling Harbour, the Opera House, Circular Quay, and more. There is also a train stop just on the other side of the bridge. The walk itself probably took us 20 minutes from The Rocks to the train stop at the other end of the bridge. One of the best free activities in Sydney!

Bridge Walk so easy. Dont be misled and miss a great experience. It may take over three hours and be expensive, but to walk the Bridge is a must-do experience when in Sydney. It is surprsingly easy to climb and there is never a chance for you to fall off as you are wired on the entire time and never t really within a metre of teh edge. The whole trip is informative with great views and you hardly realise you are climbing. Dont miss out! Its a great experience.

BRIDGE CLIMB IS THE BEST!. If you're in Sydney, the bridge climb is a must! It is actually easier and a lot less scary than I thought it would be before starting out. I suffered from vertigo for a few years ago would never have attempted this, but I felt fantastic up there! It was a real thrill to be up there. The guides are great and very patient and take it slow. In our group we had ages 8 to 68 and we all had a great time up there.

Walk across the Harbour Bridge, great views. We walked across the harbour bridge from the Rocks to Milsons Point and then caught the ferry back to Darling Harbour.Great views of the harbour, Opera house, city and surrounds.Is a bit of a climb to get up to the bridge, but after that an easy walk across.

Expensive walk. Cheapest climb cost $198 for an adult and you will have to book in advance. As not that great with heights, opted for the cheapest option walk across the bridge itself as there is a secure path along side of the cars, you get the same view but not as high up and no cost unless you come back by train once you reach the other side.

Commuters Crossing. Walked to the office from the hotel across the harbour bridge. It was a spectacular walk, with great views. This was the first time I had walked across it and it gave me an appreciation of the size of the challenge it was to build the bridge. I was envious of the walking commuters who did it everyday.

The walkway on the eastern side of the bridge is great. We did the bridge climb some years ago at sunset on a beautiful evening and it was wonderful. But if I have friends visiting Sydney who don't have the time or money for the climb, I take them on the free pedestrian walkway along the eastern side of the bridge. It's almost as good although you miss out on the views to the west. We then have a coffee at Ripples at Milsons Point near Luna Park before we return the way we came.

Exciting. For a price you can actually climb the bridge and walk around on top, but the day we were there was very windy and quite cool, so we didn't. However just seeing it up close and riding the ferry under it was exciting. I got some really good photos.

A must do!. We did not do the bridge climb, too costly. But a walk accross the bridge is free! We saved this activity to do on the weekend and it was the right choice. We lucked out with a beautiful day and the sail boats were everywhere. Picture post card beautiful!
Great View. We only walked halfway across the bridge but it was beautiful! Great walk and a great view from halfway across. Definitely worth a visit!
Amazing bridge. You can go under, over, around, up and down this bridge and see it from every angle for free or at great expense. Well worth visiting.

One off the bucket list.. Done the bridge climb and would highly recommend it. It was a well organised day out. Wasnt too exhausting and the view from the top was amazing. Felt safe from start to finish. Only downside was that it was a bit pricey but its not something i will do everytime i visit sydney.

Climb the bridge in nice weather only!. We reserved a bridge climb only to face rain that morning; the tour takes place regardless of weather. The stunning views people mention, sadly, were hidden to us. The climb took hours because the staff is constantly stopping to take pictures of each group/couple/family which they then hope to sell to you. Too expensive in rain!
what a view. If you haven't got the nerve to do the bridge climb, do what we did and send our adult kids on it and go up the tower to watch them do. Great views and photo opportunities from up there.

Must do! Very pricey but it's a once in a lifetime experience and very safe.. We recently climbed the bridge for the first time with our extended family. Groups of 14 people go up to the top and then come back down the way you came (not down the other side of the bridge). They give you a jumpsuit to wear and there are unisex changing rooms. You put everything in a provided locker, as you are not allowed to take ANYTHING up with you (unless it's medically necessary). So no cameras, no phones, no nothing! Then they get you outfitted with radios, rain jackets, safety ropes and they put you through training and a mock climb. It's very well run, so there are no surprises when you get out there. Although the ladders can be steep, there aren't that many of them; the steps are pretty gradual (not steep) and there are metal railings on both sides of you at all times. FYI, there are a few small spaces you have to climb over/through where you have to watch your head.PROS: Amazing views, good guides giving you interesting facts, very safety concious. I have a slight fear of heights, but I never had any fear up there, as you are constantly locked in. The Pylon Access is good for two months, so if you encounter rain like we did, you could go back and get photos on a good weather day. The people at the photo desk were helpful in getting all of my groups' pictures together on one disc and even suggested a very good restaurant.CONS: Even though we made reservations for the same time (11am), our family was separated into two groups of climbers (the 11:05 climb and the 11:35 climb). The person at the desk was kind of rude and unhelpful regarding the situation. It was raining on and off when we were on our climb, and unless it's a lightning storm, it's a rain or shine climb. So the rain jackets they gave us were definitely put to use, our pictures were sadly overcast/dark and the metal ladders were steep and slippery. The climb itself doesn't take that long, but there's a lot of stopping and standing around to look at the view while they go through the group to take individual pictures. The whole thing is expensive: $248 AUD for one off peak adult (includes certificate of achievement, one group photo of the 14, free entry to the Pylon lookout) , $89 for all the photos taken up there (which you're kind of stuck buying since you will want to get photos of you and your family/friends without the strangers and you are not allowed to bring your own camera). The merchandise in the gift shop is also expensive. T-shirts start at $30 AUD. Even if you purchase the big image package as I did, it will come on a CD. They charge an extra $10 AUD for a flash drive.It's a once in a lifetime experience, so I would recommend it, but make sure to double check your group's reservation times and bring lots of $$.

Opera House is the Icon... This is the Heart of Sydney. The Opera House is the Icon of Sydney, and I wish to take nothing away from it, but for me my heart belongs to the Harbour Bridge. It’s not as festive, but is it far more dominant – you can seemingly see it from every corner of the city. From a distance it has a kind of gallant restraint, majestic but not assertive, but up close it is all might. It soars above you, so high that you can pass a the ten-story building beneath it, and looks like the heaviest thing on earth. You'll see it in more paintings in the Sydney museums than anything else. Everything that is in it – the stone blocks in its four towers, the latticework of girders, the metal plates, the 6 million rivets – is the biggest of its type you have ever seen. This is a bridge built by people who have had an Industrial Revolution, during the early 1900's making the scale that much more monsterous The arch alone weighs thirty thousand tons. This is a great bridge.

To the Top!. Once in a lifetime experience. Climbing to the top of the bridge was fun and the view from the top was stunning. Unique experience. It's not everywhere that you can climb to the top of a world famous bridge.
Nice photos from the Opera. Nice photos to do when you are at the Opera, the structure is really amazing ! We haven't done the bridge climbing, but may be we'll do it next time.

must do!. Me and my boyfriend went on a sunset walk and the views of the harbour were stunning.We did however have an issue. The one night that we had chosen to do our climb happened to be the one night that the whole of Sydney turned off their lights for earth hour! Leaving us with no view of the city and in darkness. Being tourists we had no idea of this event happening and would of been greatful if a member if staff had informed of this occasion especially bearing in mind the cost of the climb. The your guide did say that the staff should of mentioned it and a manager did apologise but it doesn't really make up for the lost views that we essentially paid for that night.Only downside is that the hourbour bridge climb is quite exspensive, but then again it was worth it and im happy we did it.

Topped off my Holiday!. I booked a bridge climb and was not disappointed. Yes it's expensive but it was amazing. I was on a 12.15 climb and luckily the weather was great with the sun in the right direction for those obligatory photos on the top of the bridge. I paid for the package and got 10 pictures on dvd. The tour guide was full of facts and made the whole experience memorable. I would definitely recommend as it is the best way to see the city.

A must do. We did the sunset harbour bridge climb and it was brilliant. It had a quick shower just as we were getting on to the bridge so we saw a circle rainbow around the opera house which was beautiful. The views are great, and the sunset walk is definitely a good option. Our tour guide was good and very knowledgable. It takes a good 45mins to 1 hour just to get all the gear on but that's part of the experience. It's expensive but worth it. The only thing I would change is that they give you a free pointless picture of your whole tour group that no one wants ie. a bunch of strangers and then make you pay for photos of your own party. It would be better if they gave you a free photo of your party, it wouldn't cost them anything extra to do. Otherwise a good experience.
You can't miss this. As we all know, every picture of Sydney will include the bridge, you have to take a look and get those photos in.

Great experience! Although lacking some communication by staff.. This truly is a wonder and must do when in Sydney.All though in my opinion quite expensive the views are spectacular and the tour informative.We went on a sunset walk and the views of the harbour were stunning as we neared the summit.We did however have an issue. The one night that we had chosen to do our climb happened to be the one night that the whole of Sydney turned off their lights for earth hour! Leaving us with no view of the city and in darkness. Being tourists we had no idea of this event happening and would of been greatful if a member if staff had informed of this occasion especially bearing in mind the cost of the climb. The your guide did say that the staff should of mentioned it and a manager did apologise but it doesn't really make up for the lost views that we essentially paid for that night.Overall great experience but check your calendar before booking!

Grand architecture. After over 80yrs of serving the people of Sydney, this unique and stunning structure dominates the skyline of Sydney as it crosses over from north to south. You will not miss it from many vantage points. Beautiful during the day, awesome as the sun goes down to magical at night. Two great times to view the Harbour Bridge are during the Vivid Sydney display in May and especially during the New Years celebrations as it becomes the centre piece of arguably the best fireworks display in the world

Wow what a nice construction.. Walked several times on it and the view is very nice. Its a great construction by Australians and the complete length of the bridge is more than a mile. Breath taking view and the blowing wind make any visitor thrilled and a place a visitor must go.

The 'Bridge'. Much photographed. Much admired. Deservedly so. This is quite an amazing piece of engineering. Looming over Sydney Harbour, it stands sentinel. Best seen from beneath. Take a ferry to Darling Harbour and look up as you journey underneath this wonder of steel and symbolism.

incredible views. There are 2 walks over the bridge. We walked the free one. There is a pedestrian walkway beside the road that can be walked to the other side of the harbour. The views from this level are amazing and the walk itself is easy as it is well paved and flat, however, getting to the walk way is by a set of steps each end

A spectacular walk--and free of charge!. Walked across the Harbour Bridge. Views in both directions magnificent! North Sydney was worth taking more time to explore on our next trip. Easy walk worth the time if you can't muster the courage to walk across the top of the bridge!

Unique architectural structure. Renown for the fireworks during the centennial midnight celebration, the bridge is a large structure that tourists, including me, must photograph. Some climb it in groups of a dozen, but that was not our goal. Sydney has a free central business district bus, the 555, that dropped us within walking distance. Climbing from the docks through the old town, now mostly restaurants, shops and museums, we stepped out on the free walking path and meandered out on the bridge. The din from light rail and cars changed speech into screech. The reward was an iconic view.

Bridge Climb! do it. I went years ago & it was amazing. Best ever way to see and experience the beauty of the harbour in Sydney is via. Bridge Climb! Whilst it is an expensive experience there is no view like it! It was a personal challenge too.

Glad I did it. On my last day in Aus, with my daughter who had done it once already, I climbed the bridge. It was Anzac Day and raining. Our group was 7 in total and all abilities and aged up to about 55. Our guide, Dean, was very enthusiastic, considering he must have done this many many times! The whole 'gearing-up' process has been well thought out, including the wet weather gear we needed. I am not the most fit (clicky knee, occasionally dodgy ankle) but am so glad I did this. I would say anyone can walk the bridge, but why not climb it - you should do one thing each day that makes your heart beat faster, this certainly did. Great views, even in drizzle!!

DO THE CLIMB ... Oprah did it so can you!. At first we weren't going to do this - so expensive for 8 of us. But we did it and were we ever thrilled with what we did and saw. No experience like it before or since - even on the S Island of NZ. We did it during the afternoon - night would've been even more awesome. Love the people who worked there and the safety they insisted on. Just kept telling myself that Oprah did this so I could make it too. And I did!

Don't Waste Money on the Bridge Climb - Walk Across For Free. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is spectacular and can be thoroughly enjoyed for FREE thanks to the protected walking path that goes from one shore to the other. For about $15 you can pay to climb the tower on The Rocks side where you'll get a great view of the Opera House and the harbour for picture taking, plus you can take in the history of the bridge in their mini-museum (the Bridge Climb office in The Rocks has a more comprehensive museum which is free to explore).The Bridge Climb costs about $350 which is about 3 times as expensive as it's worth. It's not that I didn't find it cool, but for $350 we should have been rappelling down the center or something much more adventurous. It's a very tame experience - hardly more exciting than walking across the path on your own, and the worst part is they don't allow you to take your own camera or pictures. In hindsight I completely understand why handheld objects that could fall on the highway are prohibited, but the whole reason we did the climb was so we could take spectacular pictures, so at the very least the company needs to clarify before collecting your money that cameras aren't allowed. The guide will take pictures for you and of you, but each print is $25 (who wants physical prints anymore?). They should have an electronic-only option that you can post to Facebook for $5-$10 (free marketing for them too).If you're from Australia where everything is more expensive than most cities in the US, the $350 fee may feel reasonable (it's all relative). We embarked on several extreme adventures in New Zealand that were less expensive / more exciting / and included a meal, so to us it felt overpriced. That said, if you're determined to do it, know that it can be uncomfortable for anyone with vertigo, even a tiny fear of heights, or even a tiny bit of claustrophobia (the ladder cages you'll climb are very tall and narrow).

Awesome experience but pricy. This was an awesome guided tour. Our tour guide Joe was top notch. He was very knowledgable, friendly, funny and approachable. Exactly what you want from a tour guide. The climb itself was great, at first glance it looks like it could be physically tough to get the top and back but it really isn't, it's just like a long walk but it just happens to be up a bridge. The views are fantastic. The only downside is the price, we got the climb as a gift so we can't complain but I don't know if I could justify paying the 250 dollars for it. I guess it's just not for your typical backpacker.

Bridge Climb Review. If you have the opportunity to travel to Sydney, do yourself a favor and if you only do one thing, do the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb!! It is $180 but a once in a lifetime experience you will regret if you don;t do it. How amny people get to have thier pictue taken from the top of the bridge, and the view of the harbour and the Opera house is spectacular. Do not miss this!!!!!!

Do the walk over the arches and pay your bucks but you can also get good views walking the public pathway. Do the walk over the arches and pay your bucks but you can also get good views walking the public pathways for free. Walk from Sydney side and then get a coffee in North Sydney, catch the ferry back
If you go, can you climb?. You can take a tour and climb to the centre of the Arc of this fantastic art-deco era bridge. I think its expensive though but worth checking out.

Fun to do. Although expensive this is now on my must-do list for visitors to Sydney (although I admit I would not have been able to afford it in my younger years). Great views from the top and lots of interesting stories along the walk. You cannot carry personal belongings so no photos except for the official ones you buy but a great souvenir. Easy steps but a few short ladders. Listen out for the tooting train whistles just as you descend onto the railway level - nearly shocked my socks off! The bridge is such an icon of Sydney it is great to be able to really get up on it and look down on the beautiful harbour.

excellent experience. Its absolutely brilliant!!! A must do in Sydney!! Many people are put off by the price but it is completely worth it. Views are amazing!!! Great company as well all of the staff are lovely.

Just a bridge...or is it?. My opinion of Sydney Harbour Bridge is slightly contradictory. First off, as a bridge to walk across (the standard walk along the road), it is actually quite boring, apart from the spectacular views down below of course. However, as a bridge to look at, as part of the famous Sydney Harbour, it could be the most famous bridge in the world, it really is amazing to photograph, and perhaps enjoy a pint in its shadow (or go to Luna Park underneath).You could of course also do the amazing Sydney Harbour Bridge Walk, which costs around $200 for the cheapest option in the daytime, and conquer your fear of heights! However, as the price is quite expensive, not everybody will be doing this. Rather, they will probably just walk across alongside the road, which as I said is rather boring.The get your fix of the Bridge, sail underneath it on a ferry on your way to Darling Harbour, or take some photos of it from Circular Quay.

Beautiful Place. It is a great place to go when you are at Sydney. It is very entertaining and interesting. Bring your camera because there is lots of picture to take.The place is very beautiful. You wont feel bored over there. So, i will recommend this place to my friends. THUmbs Up!

Climbing The Bridge. I am glad we signed up for the this. A nice way to see more of Sydney. I thought it would be very loud, with all the trucks, cars and trains going at the same time, but it was not. Our ears were covered and he told us stories of the area as we walked. The only bummer is that you can not bring a camera or video with you. They do take some pictures for you though, but you have to pay for them. Now I can say I have climbed a large bridge.
A big bridge. Pretty impressive.You have to pay if you drive over it, but you can walk on it and have a very nice view over the harbor and the opera house.
Must do attraction. You cannot go to Sydney without doing the bridge walk, the views are amazing and tour guides knowledge is fantastic, you will regret it if you don't do it !!!!!

It is a nice way to see the city. Nice and different way to see a city. This is great to see around the city and have a once in a lifetime way to do it. The down side is you don't have the ability to take your own photos due to the safety rules. It is a good event with friends or family of all ages. Nice as they take you in small groups so you can relax.

Bridge Climb is Awesome!. Been there done that, and it was Awesome! Was hoping for a good day, but even I was surprised at the amazing day we had. The guide Peter Hill was brilliant, the climb was fabulous, not scary at all after the entertaining and interesting training session, and the view on a sunny day is to die for. A definite experience to try on your new visit to Sydney, and it's an easy one to tick off the bucket list. We had a fabulous day and would definitely recommend!

Brilliant. What an amazing structure. We got off the train at Milsons Point and walked over the bridge which was fun. And free. Can get some great photos from there. My kids went for a swim in the pool under the bridge which they loved.

Drive over if you have a chance!. I drove over the bridge and it was amazing - the whole experience of getting closer and seeing the magnificent shapes of the structure. The Bridge definitely is an icon on Australian landscape and if you can get closer to it you should definitely do it. Just remember - there is a toll to pay i the way back to the city :-)

climb the bridge. The Bridge climb might be considered a little expensive. But when on the top of the bridge the $ spent is well worth the view. The climb is not that difficult. A few ladders but one is anchored on to a guide wire the entire time. You will not be allowed to take anything ANYTHING with you but are given a safe locker to store your things. Sign up is at the information center at the Rocks. Lots of options for times to choose from and they go rain or shine so really check out the weather before you sign up. They will take pictures of you solo or as a group. The heat can be tough to deal with. You are required to wear their jumper so dress lightly underneath. For safety you are given a breath test for alcohol. A brief training takes place as you wait your groups turn to climb. We had Ben as our guide. He was excellent. Gave good facts with humor. Answered all tourist questions with a smile!

Climb it – a must do. Growing up in Sydney I saw this bridge a lot, but climbing it is really something else and such a great experience. If you're visiting Sydney, be sure to plan your climb (it will set you back roughly $200 depending on season and time of day so if you have the budget, do it). The views from the top of the bridge of Sydney harbour and beyond are amazing. Otherwise, there are heaps of areas for you to take you photos with the bridge around the harbour!

The Low Road on The Bridge. We walked across the bridge at road level. You get a great look at the harbour and the surrounds without having to pay to do the bridge climb. We payed $13 to go up to the observation deck which gave a slightly better view but it was very windy. We walked from the Rocks area to the other side and back. It is an easy and pleasant walk
smaller that I imagined. It was great to see this icon of Australia but it was smaller that I imagined, but well worth the visit

Do the Bridge Climb!!. It is not nearly as 'scary' as it might sound; nor is it very physically demanding. We are both 55+ and found it to be an easy climb. Our friends who are both 65+ joined us and had no problems. The most physically demanding part of the climb is a series of three ladders that one must climb up (and later down) to get to different levels of the bridge structure. The climb on top of the bridge itself is not very steep, and is done at a slow speed with lots of stops for pictures. The path to the top is quite wide so one does not feel like you are close to an edge. Each climber has a safety line on that can only be disconnected at the end of the climb. The whole adventure was memorable and fun and the views are fantastic.
Best view in Sydney. Highly recommend a Sydney Seaplane trip up from Sydney Harbour along the Northern Beaches!!! Spectacular views from a WWII Seaplane!! I was there in 2008!!!

History, grandeur and views to die for.. Is it the bridge itself or what it represents in Sydney. Take the historic walk along the bridge, but brace yourself for the long haul up the steps from base first. Muse at the million and one declarations of affection in glorious (and quite literally) "Padlock" technicolour.

Adventure!. We did the bridge walk and it was an unforgettable experience. It is a long walk but not hard once you get up all the steps. After the steps up you just walk along gradually going up the bridge. The guide we had was funny and gave us lots of information. It isn't a hurry up type of walk just fun. The view was incredible and you can't get that view from anywhere else.

The coolest thing I have ever done in my life.. Walking to the top on The Sydney Bridge is one of the coolest thing I have ever done in my life. It has been on my bucket list for a while. I finally got to for fill my dream and walk to the top and it was better then I expected. Our guide Bec was awesome. She was funny and very knowledgable. You cannot bring your own camera or phone but they take your pics and they are a must for keep sake. For $90.00 you can get a disc with all pics taken. The walk is pricy but worth every penny. You won't regret it. I will do it again one day.

Walk along Argyle Cut, under the bridge and up Observatory Hill. It is historic, beautiful and peaceful. Best of all, so near the city as well. If you need some rest after all the walking, relax at one of the many pubs, cafe and restaurants at The Rocks

defaintly a sight to see in Sydney.. we sailed under it, walked under it, walked up it, visited the pylon bridge museum which is fantastic value, I also did the bridge climb which again is worth the $$$.

Awesome - Do the Bridge Climb, you'll love it!. If you are in Sydney and have 1 day you need to do the Harbour Bridge Climb if you don't do anything else. What a thrill and beautiful sites atop the Sydney Harbour Bridge.Is it Hard to do??? NO - I'm 55 and not in the best of shape and I was never struggling or out of breath. The Climb take about 3.5 hours from check in to suiting up to training, to the climb with stops for stories about the bridge and a few photo along the way. The steps are built into the curve of the bridge and are nice and low so it is less work than walking up stadium steps.
