The group photo is free & you can have a look at your other photos once the climb is over & decide weather to buy them or not.The actual climb takes abut 2.5 hours once you've got all your gear on & had the safety demos.I suppose it is a bit expensive but go on, treat yourself... you won't be disappointed.

What A View. I have wanted to climb the Bridge ever since its launch back in the late 90s and finally got my wish on Australia Day 2014. I opted for an evening climb so had all day to wait in anticipation......having many thoughts as to just how I would go. Finally my appointed time arrived and I joined the group for the 7.05pm climb. A wonderful guide talked us through safety issues, the do's and dont's etc. then got us suited and geared up for the walk. At first I was very apprehensive, but as we ascended higher up the walkway, I gain confidence and never looked back. Well, I did look back, and down and up and across. The view was magnificent.....the Opera House, the city surrounds, the twilight that grew into darkness, the fireworks on the harbour and in various spots in and around Sydney. Truely an amazing experience and one that I would love to do again should the occasion arise.

What a view. This is a very well organised and safe way to get the best possible views of Sydney. We did the 3.5hr guided tour on a day it wasn't really too hot ( just 25°c) and it was fabulous if not a little expensive. A super experience that I'd love to repeat but probably will not due to the cost.

wow wow. it took days to wipe the smile of my face. I spied the bridge between two buildings but the best was sailing under the bridge. one of those things you need to do. you will not be dissappointed
jesu. Did the guided walk , stunning , a feat of engineering , the " coathanger was built in the 30's , highly reccommend this tour .

nice walk, great views!. we walked from milsons point to the pylon lookout, great views, beautiful pictures. there's a section in the middle that has a bunch of engraved padlocks, cute! if we had known about it we would have brought one and added to the collection in "lovers' lane"

Wow. Doing the Sydney Harbour Bridge walk was amazing, so glad we did it. The views are just fantastic!! We did the walk at 5.30pm and it was a great time as it had started to cool off a little and the sun had started to go down so it was lovely lighting. Even better it wasn't classed as the Twilight walk so we didn't have to pay extra. The whole experience lasts about 3.5 hours but it goes so quick. It wasn't as scary as I thought it was going to be. I was so worried I was going to panic and not be able to move but I was absolutely fine and I loved every minute if it!! They take several photos of you up there allowing you to buy them at the end.

A must do. My wife and I after a bit of a debate decided to do the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb and did not regret our decision for a minute.Yes it is expensive, but if life is about experiences this is an activity which you must do if you are in Sydney. Ok we were lucky in that it was a clear warm sunny day and we had an excellent guide but the views of the harbour and the city were fantastic. This is a completely safe activity for which you are thoroughly prepared and the guide ensures that the walk to the top is done at a leisurely pace which means that unless you are extremely unfit it will be manageable.
Breathtaking. My husband and I did a twilight climb which was such a breathtaking event. Our guide was knowledgeable and entertaining - thanks Caroline.

It's a bridge...but in New Years Eve, it's phenomenal. Unless you're in to bridges this one doesn't exactly jump out and hit you as a design piece of history, though I am sure it is and others will correct me. It is a big bridge. However, on New Year's Eve it just comes alive. Amazing wonderful experience. On other days you can walk over it, if you so wish.

Simply excellent!. Doing the Bridge Walk is simply excellent and not to be missed. All the staff from reception through to walk leader were welcoming and very professional in their approach. Our guide, Nick, provided a blend of knowledge and humour to ensure we gained maximum enjoyment from the experience and dispelled any apprehension anybody might have. The views were amazing - well worth the effort - far less daunting than one might imagine. Expensive, but worth it.
I Will See It Again. I went running over the bridge. The views of the bridge and from the top of the bridge are spectacular.

Bridge Walk. The harbour bridge is more than an eyecatching monument, it also incorporates a daredevil walk over the top arch, which is fantastic. It is very safe, everyone is roped together and well secured, but it is not for the fainthearted!
Bridgeclimb. We did the express bridge climb which is fine if you have a reasonable level of fitness, as you jump ahed of other groups. The view from the top is amazing. Expensive but worth it.

An iconic landmark.. This old structure is a beloved part of the city. You will see it on harbor cruises and everywhere! You can walk the pedestrian walkway for nice breezes and views. We passed on the "bridge walk" along the upper structure; make sure to read the description to see if this suits you.
Beautiful Structure. Regret not driving over it, guess i have to live with just cruising underneath it. recommend this as part of anyone's holiday.

You have to do it, awesome, nothing is better!. I just want to say that I find it quite funny how people say in their reviews, 'overpriced but you must do it once' surely if you must do it, its worth it?! Our climb was 9.40 which ended at 12.40, the actual climb was about 2 hours. Our guide Michelle, was brillant. She was friendly funny & made everyone feel at ease plus when telling you history & stories of the bridge, she didnt sound like she was a robot & bored of telling you. The views are second to none, if your afriad of heights the start is the worst bit, apart from that its solid floor so dont be put off!

To the top. My wife and I did the bridge climb on her Birthday (also our honeymoon), the views from the bridge are amazing, including the iconic opera house. We had clear weather and could see for a good distance from all locations on the bridge.The instructor was great and we didn't feel unsafe once. Neither of us are the fittest but we both managed to complete the climb without any real issues, there were regular stops to take a breather and take in the views.

Great once in a lifetime opportunity. I got to go walk the Sydney bridge with my dad on a beautiful morning in Sydney. It's a very safe and professional set up. You go over all safety precautions and you are tied to the bridge at all times. The views of the city and harbor were amazing. You also got some informative information about the bridge and it's history during your walk up. If you can afford it, I highly recommend the bridge climb

great view from the bridge.. We walked up onto the bridge from steps at The Rocks and then walked all the way across ,it was very nice ,super views from both sides and convenient holes to take fotos .We did not do the climb however.

WOW!!!!. My wife did not want to join me because she is afraid of heights so I did the climb on my own. It is just a great experience. We had a very nice guide who made everybody feel good and took very good care of the "loners" like me. It is great to see the fundaments of the bridge, feel the history of this landmark and the walk on the bridge and the view is just spectacular. If you're not afraid of heights I'd say this is a must do!

Worth every cent. Not to be missed, this is the highlight of Sydney. The whole experience is professional, even the pre briefing & the suiting-up. The climb itself is informative, with of course stunning views. Although one knows there are groups just in front & behind, it's not a hurried experience. Savour it!

Great views of the harbor and "The Rocks". An easy walk from Sydney to North Sydney (Milson Point). Take the train or water taxi back or walk. Take great photo's from the bridge. Besides the dedicated pedestrian walk there is also a special bike path over the bridge.

On top of the Boro Bridge. Although not cheap the overall experience is worthwhile.Good explanations by the Guide throughout the trip and plenty of opportunity for great views (hope the weather is good for you?).Could make a better effort with the photo package - rather than a single photo in a cardboard wallet.

A Special Place. How can you put into words what an iconic structure this is especially when taken in conjunction with Uzten's masterpiece. One of those sights you could never tire of looking at. On a par with the Pantheon in my book. Wish it didn't cost so much to climb!

Hike it!. Great view and so many tourists around this place. View of the bridge from The Rock is great. I would recommend having a meal at one of those restaurants at Circular Quay overseeing the bridge. There is Hiking tour for the bridge. Must do!!

Must See day and night. The harbour bridge is simply one of those globally iconic things to see, especially at sunset from by the opera house.The harbour bridge "walk/climb" is also worth doing, i enjoyed this a couple years back and found the views from on top were superb and the overall experience both enjoyable and educational

Not just a bridge, it's art. A big, bold and beautiful iconic addition to the bay, which complements the Opera House and the bay area incredibly well. Great to drive over and you can even go on a climbing adventure.
Simply amazing.... I love walking and cycling on the harbour bridge... I will never tire of doing it, the harbour view is just amazing!
Iconic. We didn't journey over the bridge so it is hard to give an opinion of it as a way of transportation or even a view. But it does add to the look of the harbour along with the Opera House.
Must see. Iconic landmark. Worth a walk along the pedestrian access. Great views of the Opera House, CBD and harbour.

A Thousand Steps and A Million Steel Rivets. Impressive from afar, amazing from up close. Walking the length of the Sydney Harbour Bridge is an experience by itself. You get to see the shockingly beautiful view of the Sydney Skyline, framed by Azure blue skies above and Aquamarine Waters of the Bay. From this bridge, travelers can get one of the best photos of the Sydney Opera House as well provided you can get the lens to get through the lattice fence. Tip: Take the train on the NORTHSHORE line to Milson Point Station. That station is directly on the North end of the bridge allowing you to climb up stairs and out onto the bridge itself to walk along the pedestrian side back towards the city centre.If you can afford it, by all means take the Bridge Climb. But during Summer, it costs a stratospheric AUD $300 per person. Off-Peak season and it is still around AUD $200 per person. Not sure what tradition is it, but there are padlocks of different shapes, colours and sizes on the lattice fence, each with its own "XX Loves XX" message. Maybe it is a symbol of enduring love as enduring as the bridge itself? The walk along the entire length of the bridge from Milson's Point Station to the City centre does not take long at all, roughly 15 minutes at a slow leisurely walk. There is a lookout tower on top of one of the bridge towards the city centre but you do have to pay admission to get up there. However there are exhibits (upon payment of admission) that shows the history of the bridge and how the bridge is built. (A little history trivia: Melbourne, the rival city has always resented the Bridge because a significant portion of the financing of the Bridge came from Melbourne's city coffers during the gold rush that made Melbourne a prosperous and wealthy city. The Bridge was delayed and over budget during its construction. Sound familiar doesn't it?)Go during special days and events and the Bridge lights up with fireworks and amazing light shows.

wow .... Iconic and amazing to see from the outside but also so impressive on the inside. I took a walking tour which gives you a good insight to the history and the running of this amazing place. I have seen some great plays in the theatre and also if you are into Opera this is the place to be.
Iconic. Another must-see iconic structure in Sydney. There's plenty of places to see this famous bridge - The Rocks, Sydney Harbour, Circular Quay and Sydney Opera House to name a few.

A MUST See and DO!. The Bridge is beautiful from pretty much every angle, and it's history is equally interesting. We walked over the pedestrian walk to Kirribili on the other side: fantastic for taking photos! Make sure to visit the Pylon lookout. For a small fee you can climb up the Pylon for a gorgeous view, visit the gift shops and watch a very moving video on the building of the bridge.

Stunning!. We walked across the Sidney Harbour Bridge after deciding against the climb over the top. Think this was a good decision as the climb up to go over the top looked a bit scary. The walk over gives great views over the bustling harbour area. Well worth doing.

super fun. I walked across the bridge and did not do the bridge climb which was great.. the views either way are superb and there are safety guys on the bridge to answer questions if you have any. The walk is 1 mile each way
Not as stunning as you might think. It's just a bridge, nothing more than that! Complete disappointment. Rather look and admire Brooklyn Bridge or Golden Gate
Awesome. Great structure, Sydney history and a real icon. If you've got some money to spend and 4 hours left, take a bridge climb! Otherwise just walk around and enjoy!

Sturdy & Metalic. The harbour bridge has NEVER fallen down in the entire time I have lived near it. I have travelled both north and south over it and appears to be well made and solid built of some sort of metal or possibly wood. I would highly reccomend using this to cross the water. One negative I have found is that I often see people climbing to the top which I assume is people trying to commit suicide, so if crossing i would suggest bringing an umbrealla.

It's just another bridge.. I used to drive here many times. From Chatswood to Ultimo. The toll is expensive. Heavy traffic during the evening. Wanted to try that Harbour Bridge Climb, but realized that it wasn't worth it. Way too expensive and there are other spots where you can get splendid views of the capital (friend's apartment being one of them).

Over priced but should be done once. I booked the night climb for myself and my boyfriend as a birthday present. We were on a 'once in a lifetime' trip to Australia so this seemed like something we ought to do. I'm glad we did, it is so iconic and the views over Sydney are lovely. That said, it is very expensive for what you get - it's basically a one hour climb made into a three hour experience somehow. We were also particularly cross about the photos. You can't take your own camera - for safety reasons but I'm sure they're happy about that situation and the fact you have to buy their pictures. Never mind we thought - there's a picture included in the price. What was annoying is that the one picture is not one of your choice, i.e. you and your nearest and dearest. It's a group one of you and the other 15 strangers on the climb with you. Not something you are likely to ever display in your house and meaning you have to fork out an additional $25 for a picture you do want. Felt this was a bit of a racket given the price of the ticket. That said, it remains one of those 'must do' experiences if you are visiting Sydney, you will enjoy it.
Beautiful. Don´t miss the climbing! The bridge is amazing and was built 1932 ! Have a nice time and don´t forget to take a picture!

Walked over for free. Walking over the pedestrian bridge was a highlight for us. Got a bus to the Rocks and then walked to the start of the bridge. The views were amazing, took lots of photos along the way. Kirribilli suburb on the other side was a great little spot for a coffee, got to walk under the start of the bridge which was an awesome sight, highly recommend the views from here. We then got the ferry back to the CBD. Great way to spend a few hours.

DO THE BRIDGE CLIMB!!!!!!. What an amazing and fabulous experience doing the Bridge Climb. The Staff were attentive and informative. The views were magnificent!! Such a unique experience. We did in mid morning and the weather was perfect. Would love to do it again at night and see the lights.

A nice walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Lure by its picture perfect view of the Sydney's harbour front, we have always dreamt of coming here. An eight hour flight from Malaysia to Sydney passing nothing much on the way, perhaps some kangaroos hopping below. We stay at a hotel at the east side of the town, walking towards the harbour front, we passed by a navy docking and then through the Botanic garden. The view on the way already mesmerised us, such beautiful park in the city, perhaps that should be how all cities look like, garden as your neighbourhood. Navigating out of the garden we come to back of the Opera house (or should it be the side) keep walking along the edge of the water, you come to see the Circular quay and the harbour bridge at close up. To get on the Harbour Bridge walk way you first come to the Rocks, from here is a bit tricky, you will walk up the street called Argyle street beside the Museum of Contemporary Art about 50m or so, on your right you see the Argyle Stair, go up the stair walk across the road then you can find the stair way to the Harbour bridge. Don't walk towards where you think you can get up to the bridge, there were no access. A walk across the Harbour Bridge on a winter day is most rewarding, the afternoon sun cast shades of shadow on all buildings, the Harbour Front and its water was glistening in the golden sun. We walked the entire length of the bridge, got off at the end went below the bridge until we came to a ferry terminal where we took a ferry back to the Circular quay, we even took pictures of the underside of the bridge as the ferry went underneath it, it was really an experience which we will never forget.

You feel like you are on top of the world. I have done the harbour bridge climb twice now. Both times were excellent and highly recommend it. The guide entertains you with lots of stories and the climb is mainly a gentle slope. There are ladders you need to climb up at the beginning and end of the trip. It is best to go on a day that has good weather as if you book ahead and the weather is not so good you still have to go.The last time I climbed was mid week. I waited until the day and checked the weather. There were several sessions available. (Note that this was outside school holiday time.)The views are spectacular!!! If you visit Sydney you must do this :)

Worth it!. As you book something as monumental as a trip to Australia, you start gathering all the reviews you possibly can to maximize your trip. Knowing that the Sydney Harbour Bridge is expensive, because well it is. We looked if we could get a similar experience for cheaper. Well there were tons of options for this, but we kept coming back to thought that we were only in Australia once, and wanted to do it all. We couldn't be happier that we chose to spend our money. Great Views, Great tour guide, and Great people on our tour. It wasn't necessarily too scary or too physically taxing. But if you are looking for a bucket list item, this is it!
climbing the BRidge. Just fantastic and then to watch the fireworks frmom where we had just been incredible. A must for everyone to do. Great photos to share

iconic. Its a famous Icon, tricky to find your way up onto the bridge, but once done worth the view. Paying to get into the pylons we didnt think was worth the money, but if you do the bridge climb you get free entry and then it is worth it. Really you have to do the Bridge Climb!!!

The Harbour Bridge Climb is an absolute must - it is a truly awesome experience and worth every cent!. Do it, do it, do it! I'm an ex Sydney sider and I didn't do until I'd been gone quite a few years - I have no idea why it took me so long . I absolutely loved it and as I'm scared of heights that's amazing. The safety precautions are so thorough that you can't help feel comforted and that amazing feeling of standing on top of the world's most beautiful city is spellbinding. It was such a special day for us - just do it I say!

A must see. If you're visiting Sydney, it's definitely worth your time to walk across the Sydney Harbor Bridge. The view of the Opera House and the skyscrapers in downtown Sydney are really cool. The views from the bridge are probably even better at night, when the Sydney skyline is even more impressive.

Iconic Sydney must see. Pretty self-explanatory really. One of Sydney's most important icons. Always a must if you have not been to Sydney before. If you are lucky (and the wind is blowing the right way) you can see it from the plane when you land.

Awe inspiring. Great fun walking over it, but not if you are nervous about heights.Amazing to see all the joggers, the bridge affords superb views over the City. Access via The Rocks upper levels, brilliant!

The Bridge - Sydney. You can either stand in awe and just look at it from a variety of vantage points around the city or even further afield. Alternatively you can walk over it to Kirribilli and take a "reverse view" look at Sydney, or why not try walking over the top of the bridge, just to say you have done it! Or you could just buy the T-Shirt that says you have and nobody would know any different!

Once in a lifetime. I took a long time deciding whether to do this because it is very expensive (especially when I went during the peak Xmas period). However I'd wanted to do it for years so decided to go for it and didn't regret it.There was a lot of prep (you are told the experience will be 3.5hours but actually at least 2.5 hours are prep). A lot of it I thought was unnecessary, particularly the handkerchief around our wrists etc. Once we were finally on the bridge it was great, I went on a clear day and the views were amazing. The guide told us lots of interesting facts and kept us entertained. You aren't allowed to take anything up with you, including cameras, so you have to pay for any photos that are taken of you. I didn't really appreciate this given how much we already had to spend just to get on the climb, and the photos were about £25 each! So I definitely think the experience could be improved by not charging so much.

Great example of British engineering. We did the Harbour Bridge Climb at 9.15am which was the best experience of our stay without a shadow of a doubt. The visibility was as good as it gets.The meticulous preparation makes you think that the Climb is going to be more strenuous than you imagined. I was worried having recently had a back operation but all the staff made me feel reassured and offered a pair of braces to take the weight of the safety belt. In fact this attention to detail is essential from a safety viewpoint but the climb is no more than a leisurely walk. You have to remove all loose items such as hair grips, watches and bracelets. Of course you are not allowed to take any cameras or phones so they can get you in the photo booth afterwards at $25 for your first photo and $10 for each one after that. Who is not going to buy?It's not cheap but really worth it. Tick it off the bucket list and spend 3 hours on the must do experience in Sydney Do it!

Memorable experience. Not our cheapest tourist experience but definitely worth splashing out for. Getting to climb one of the most iconic structures in Australia was amazing. Our climb guide, Richard, was very experienced, and regaled us with many tales of previous climbs, history and personal experience during our trip.

A world icon. The bridge has amazing infrastructure, we only walked across it as a pedestrian. I am scared of heights so was reluctant to stand too close to the edge (even though safety railings are solid) but you get stunning views :)

Amazing. While we were here we all did the harbour bridge climb, it was amazing and a must if you are visiting.
2 were nervous of heights but you have a harness and the staff are with you all the time
Amazing!. Consider doing the bridge climb, cause is an unforgettable experience, worth the money and the views are WOW

A great experience. This is a terrific icon. The climb to the top of the bridge id exhilarating-it creates a sense of achievement. The health and safety aspects are meticulously undertaken but do not diminish the experience.As an addition to the bridge climb( or as an alternative for those who might be able to manage it) a visit to the accessible south east pylon is recommended. It has a fascinating exhibition about the construction of the bridge and offers fine views over the harbour.
Nice View. I walked on Sydney Harbour Bridge last week.Temperature was 25 degrees.Sea wind was strong,but it took 20 minutes on foot.View was nice!I want to walk on Harbour Bridge again.

best viewed from the water. visitor centre in the southern pier was not available to enter. take the Manly ferry to get the best and cheapest water borne views. also a ferry at dusk as the sun is setting is also a good idea.

Take the walk.. BIt difficult to find the stairway up, but it starts in the rocks area. Then you can follow the footpath right across the bridge from where you get good views of Sydney and the harbour. No charge and who needs to climb the expensive archway when you can do all this for free.
Beautiful Views...and It's Free!. Brilliant views of Sydney and all it costs is a little leg muscle. Once on the bridge, the walk is flat and easy and you will be so happy you made the effort
We climbed it. One of the two must see attractions in Sydney and not a disappointment. Saw it, photographed it, watched the fireworks and climbed it. Absolute must do!

Photo check - complete!. If you're in Sydney you cannot leave without a photo of the bridge. So go take it and be done with it. I mean, it's a bridge. DO NOT spend whatever ridiculous amount of money they are asking to "climb the bridge." You can get just as good of view of the Opera House and other sights from any a number of locations around the harbor area.

Sydney harbour bridge.. A must see with the opportunity to walk over on the pedestrian path or even on the topmost walkway on the huge arch of the bridge. A ferry from the harbour will allow you take pictures from below and then you realise how huge the bridge is.
Harbour Bridge. I would suggest doing the sunset walk. It did get a bit boring…needed to keep walking rather than to stop and keep taking pictures.

Worth a look. There is nothing to be written about it just like the Opera House. You have to see it when in Sydney else your trip is incomplete and that is a crime :) Harbour bridge looks the most beautiful when viewed from the Opera House. Make sure you are there at the NY eve and the rest....well the whole world knows.

Spectacular, awesome ... We have now walked over this bridge, done the Bridge Climb ( see separate review ) , train over and boat under. It's awesome .. Views are spectacular and can't be described. There is also a Pylon Lookout but havent done that as yet .. Every bit as great as it looks
New Year Celebrations. Watched the New Year celebrations from a friends balcony in the Pullman Grand Quay, what can I say, other than WOW! If you ever get the chance, do it!

Simply impressive. The coathanger, as the bridge is also aptly dubbed, is a truly impressive construction and a sight to behold. I did not do the 3.5 hour climb, so cannot comment on that.However, starting from the Rocks, I did walk across the bridge one early morning. The sight of the Sydney Opera House in the rising sun on that hazy morning blew me off my feet, and I shot dozens of pictures. On the north east side of the bridge is Kirribilli, where some cute coffee shops and a nice bakery can be found.There were quite a number of eager joggers around too, as is typical in many areas of Sydney.

lovely walk. It's really easy to walk over the bridge, it's not steep and you can go at your own pace. The view is spectacular and breeze always keeps you nice and cool. Really worth doing if you're in Sydney.

It's a bridge.. Just came back from San Francisco where you have the Golden Gate and the Bay Bridge. Unfortunately, as nice as this bridge is it doesn't quite match up. Still worth having your photo taken to show you've been. Might be different if you were walking over it.

dont pay the money to climb it. I personally walked over the bridge which obviously gives you great view to take pictures from. you can also climb the bridge for $250-$300 which to me seems like a waste of money. Its only an hour climb and you cannot take your camera with, so seriously what is the point. When you cross the bridge you can climb the tower where you have the same views as the bridge climbers and you can bring your camera with.

Nice walk, pretty views, do the climb if ok with heights!. One of many places to visit while in the heart of Sydney, walking over the bridge in the harbour, wonderful views great picture taking. Wanted to do the famous bridge climb, BUT I'm deathly afraid of heights, and it is quite high, but looked really fun watching others enjoy in this famous tradition! Go for it!

Worth going for a walk:). It takes around 30 minutes from one end to another end on the Sydney Harbour Bridge. One tip: bring warm clothing if you decide to go for a walk on the Bridge. Wind is pretty strong up there!

Good use of Sydney landmark. Trains, buses, private vehicles, pedestrians, walk the bridge, take photos of it. Surrounded by a lovely harbour. Wish Auckland had listened to Mayor Robbie - we'd have trains going over or under our harbour as well. Aussies - you should be proud of your Sydney transport system.

New Year's Eve Fireworks on Sydney Harbour Bridge. In answer to an earlier post, yes, we saw the New Year’s Eve Fireworks on Sydney Harbour Bridge. We were on the harbour on the catamaran ‘Aussie Magic.’ There were fireworks at 9.00pm, 10.30pm and midnight. The fireworks on the Opera House (a special event) was a bonus and quite superb. ‘Aussie Magic’ took part in the Harbour Light Parade, a parade of specially lit vessels around the harbour after the 9.00pm fireworks. The fireworks at midnight were stunning, especially the ‘waterfall’ fireworks cascading down from the bridge. Being on the harbour to see the fireworks gave us an excellent viewing point. The New Year’s Eve Fireworks on Sydney Harbour Bridge are a must see, particularly from Sydney Harbour where it is not crowded and the view is uninterrupted.

What a View. The Bridge is a must and you have 2 choices to cross it, you can pay a small fortune and climb to the top and on a bad day see nothing or there is a walkway across that the locals use to cross from North to South and the views are great and it is free and of course no time restraint so plenty of time for pictures.The walk takes around half an hour and nice eateries and bars at either end and choice of walking back or taking a train.

Climb it on your own!. You must walk across the bridge while you are in Sydney. It would be ashamed if you didn't - especially on a first time visit. Save your money though and forget the official bridge climb that charges a stupid amount of money to climb to the top. You can pay $10 to check out the museum, walk across the main level by yourself and still get awesome views of the Harbour.
Unique. We think its its a nice bridge. You can walk across it, take a train or even do the bridge climb to get a different view of the harbour.
Iconic and a must visit. If you are in Sydney you must visit the Sydney Harbour Bridge, even better climb the Sydney Harbour Bridge with Bridge Climb.

New Years Eve fireworks are like NO other!!! Here are tips..... Put this on your bucket list. Fireworks in Sydney for New Years eve is something everyone should see in person. I have never seen a freworks show like this. What an awesome show. It took my breath away. My friend and I camped out like the Australians to get a good view of the firework show. Here are some tips for people who are not from Sydney.1. Get there early. We claimed our spot at 10 am.2. Pack sunscreen, lots of beverages, food. If you have a cooler fill with ice because it got very hot. Make sure you have blankets are something to sit on. ( Australians had small tents)3. Pack an small umbrella. It started raining shortly.4. Arrange for transportation for after the show is over. All the ferries and taxis were not operating and we had to walk back to our hotel. I had a bad knee and that was a bummer.5. Make sure you have a jacket because it got cool by the time the show began.6. Use the bathroom because the queue for the toilet was 2 hours long. 7, The show lasted only 11 minutes but it was worth my trip to Sydney... Have fun and Happy New Year

Its A Bridge. Save your money for something REALLY EXCITING and don't worry about the Bridge Climb, you can walk across the bridge for FREE, you can go under it on a ferry on the way to the Zoo from Darling Harbour. I have seen much more exciting bridges than this. Unless you REALLY want to say you have done the bridge climb I would seriously think whether you want to spend that much money.
NYE fireworks - spectacular!. Sydney harbour fireworks on NYE is an absolute must do experience! This year we were on a boat watching from the water - amazing views and all round atmosphere

Spectacular View. Taking advice from the next table at lunch, we actually walked across the bridge to the Rocks. Holy Moley! What a view-we took so many pics. We were going to do a guided tour and climb to the top, but the wait was too long. Maybe next time.

Great city, opera house and harbour views - and its FREE!!!. The Harbour Bridge footpath is one of Sydney's gems and a must do if you have time. The path runs on top of the Circular Quay rail line so it provides excellent and changing views of the whole downtown waterfront area including the Quay, Opera House, Harbour Bridge and the Rocks before joining with the Harbour Bridge footpath on the eastern side of the bridgeThe path extends from lower Macquarie Street on the city side to Broughton Street in Kirribilli on the other side of the bridge. Kirribilli has lots of cafes if you need a refreshment, and if you don't fancy the walk back, just walk through the underpass to the Milsons Point station and catch the train back.Access on the city side is via the path on the or up the steps on the left immediately downhill from the motorway underpass (look for the sign saying Cahill's Walk) on Macquarie Street. Alternatively you can take the loop path across the road or the glass elevator on the eastern side of Circular Quay. There are a couple of flights of steps above the Rocks area, but otherwise the gradient is easy.Highly Recommended
Probably the best bridge in the world. Easy to get to, great to walk across, and fantastic views. You could be tempted to walk up it, or you could try the viewing platform.
You have to do it. We walked over and back from the Circular Quay side. Not a bad walk. Great views. And, it was free. Got some great pics of the harbor and Opera House.

NYE - at least once in a lifetime. At least once in a lifetime you should spend (spend being the operative word) a New Years Eve in Sydney. The fireworks are SPECTACULAR!!! The Harbour around the Bridge puts on a show like no where else in Oz.
The Bridge is such an icon. Thanks to the trip advisor reviews I took the ferry from Darling Harbour to McMahons Point the pathway to the Harbour Bridge, stunning views don't miss it

15-20 minute walk with bird's eye view of the Harbour. In pictures the bridge seemed really long and un-walkable but when locals told me that people walk on it all the time and its the best way to go to the Rocks from our place (stayed at Milson's point) so we tried it and boy it was great. We didnt do the actual Climbing the bridge as it seemed way too expensive but was thrilled enough with the views from the walk on the footway along the bridge. Can try it if you have time.

Nice view of the harbor. We walked from the circular quay through the Rock to the bridge and walked across . you get some great views of the harbor and the opera house from here . we did not do the pylon or the bridge climb.

Hanger of Sydney. Its the crown of SydneyThere are several locations from where you can enjoy it.Circular Quay, Kirribilli, Blues Point or by ferry from Circular Quay to Darling harbor/ Paramatta or Manly.
Take a walk. Take a ferry from Darling Harbour to McMahon's Point, then follow the path along the bay to Harbour Bridge and cross the bay on foot. Great photo opportunities along the way.

Magnificent view, interesting history. Definitely a must-see in Sydney. We didn't take walking tour, but we climbed the stairs to one of the bridge towers and I must say it was also a memorable experience. And if I remember it correctly, it was even for free. Once up on the tower one even doesn't want to leave =) But besides the beautiful view on the whole Sydney, this bridge has also quite interesting history that is explained inside this tower using many posters and video. I recommend you to take at least one or two hours just for the tower and then to cross it on both ways. It's absolutely worth it.

Wonderful. The view of the Sydney harbour bridge from anywhere is great. We did not do the harbour bridge climb but we took the time to walk over the bridge to the other side which I very much enjoyed. We saw some lovely views and was great to see the bridge up close.
very nice. We just drove through it but the view on it from Opera house and Botanic Garden was magical. We couldn't do the walk on top of the Bridge but I would love to do that.

Simply magnificent. I love the Harbour Bridge and the bird’s eye view that it provides of Sydney. Although the bridge can be crossed in so many ways, my favourite is to walk across it and take on all the details at a slow pace.

A great inconic backdrop to the Harbour. You can view the bridge from the harbour and watch at least 4 lots of climbers going up and down the heights to see Sydney from the top of the bridge. The NYE fireworks from the bridge are awesome. If you have time you can take a stroll across the bridge and look back into the harbour.

Nice to walk - great views - going up the pylon is a must. I recommend to everyone who stays with us to catch the train from our place in North Sydney, get off at Milsons Point and the walk over the bridge.You get great views of the bridge, the harbour and city, but the real highlight is going up the pylon which costs $13. From here you will have the best views in Sydney of the opera house, down & up the harbour, and get a sense for just how high & big the bridge is. There is also some good info on the construction of the bridge with artifacts and a short documentary if you're interested.

Grand Icon of Sydney.. You can spend hours around and below the bridge on a sunny day.Numerous dining options,many shops,cruise and ferries will keep one occupied.Alternatively one can just walk along or sit idle for hours among crowds of tourists of almost all the countries of the world.Simply awesome.
Fireworks. Did anyone see the New Years Eve Fireworks. Best show in the world. I love you England but Sydney kicked my poor little home towns butt. Sooooo beautiful!

Great scenic view. A first time visit to Sydney would never be complete without going to the Harbour Bridge, one of the country's icon. The view along the bridge is absolutely amazing. I was lucky to see a cruise passing through right under the bridge and the people on board the ship were cheering and waving at us! Give yourself about 30 - 40mins to walk to and fro the bridge and spend some time to enjoy the view and breeze.

WELL POSITIONED!!!!!. Sydney Harbour Bridge looks beautiful and is well positioned right next to the city. Some of the best views for photos are if you catch the ferry to Manly, or one of the destinations that would take you right under the bridge. I spoke to some people that did the bridge climb, who said it was well worth the money!

Over Xmas. Great a must well organised great views over the city and it will be a great experience. Very busy and you will not be disappointed . The views are wonderful and the guides are friendly. Informative and amusing . It is a a must do

Another must see area.. Every traveller to Sydney just has to visit this area - and it is well worth while, suggest taking the local ferry rather than the tour boats, much cheaper, you can get on and off and very convenient.

Can't climb? then walk!. I use a walking cane and obviously couldn't do the $198 Bridge Climb. So we took the train to Milsons Point and crossed the bridge using the pedestrian walkway. The steps at the north end are an easy climb. But there seemed to be more stairs at the southern end. The bridge and the approaches is about a mile (1.6 km) and takes most people about 20 minutes walking fast. It took me 50 minutes stopping to admire the view.
SYDNEY HARBOUR BRIDGE. We went on a dinner cruise and we were able to see the very beautiful Sydney Harbour Bridge from different angles.It was very pleasing to the eye.don't miss it!

Climbing the pylon and walking the bridge is a must. The pylon is really well priced and gives you amazing views of the city. There's also loads of great information and pictures of the consruction of the bridge.We didn't do the bridge climb because its extortionate but just walking over the bridge itself was great
See Sydney Harbor Bridge from ferry.. Took the Darling Harbor to Quay ferry and got some beautiful pictures of the Sydney Harbor bridge along with The Opera House and the Sydney skyline.
great view!. We loved the pedestrian walkway - well worth it if you are too afraid to walk above (which we were). just go for the great views!

Walk the Bridge is a must.. There is pedestrian walk way over the bridge to Luna Park on the other side. The views from the bridge are fabulous of the Opera House, skyline, and the harbor. Once you reach the other side you can either walk back, we decided to take the ferry from Luna park back to the harbor (cost $5 pp). There are also nice restaurants and shopping to enjoy.
Australia. Lots going on around the harbour plenty to do with shops bars cafes etc.plenty of sightseeing with different boats offering trips.
The Walk! What a Thrilling Experience.. This is also a "Bucket List" experience. Breaktaking and not for the faint of heart. Safe, and high above the harbor. Wow
Iconic and great views. We climbed it, cycled it and walked over it. Amazing views all around. Sydney should be proud of this bridge - it is so iconic.

Iconic sight. Breath taking to see close up
Expensive to climb
Lovely views over the harbour
A must see attraction whilst in sydney

Stroll the Bridge ... Say you did it. Although heavy trucks shake the Bridge a bit, there's a bit of a thrill seeing the Harbour under you and snapping a photo at the mid point.
A free, entertaining way to spend some time in SYD best followed by a cool cocktail at a Harbourside bar.
Walking this time. I have driven over it, sailed under it and this time walked across it, fantastic. Too old to climb it but it was certainly second best.

Awesome. That's what the first timer from the USA said about it from the side and walking under it - imagine if you climbed it ( I have)
This is a genuine must - every $$$ spent on this is well worth it - now wonder it's the most photographed place in Australia

Walk both ways. The walking via the Harbout Bridge never tires me. The views and scenery are changing by hour, not to mention the seasons. If you are in Sydney for a short time, surely you must walk it at least once. If you are here for longer make it a number of times. I am sure you will find a piece of magic on every crossing.

Great views. The walk is a great way to watch the activities in and around the Harbour. We walked from the Northern side over to the Rocks, watching the Bridgeclimbers, boats on the Harbour. And got some great photos. it is free, fun and great exercise.
The Windy Wonder. Spectacular view. Really windy and cold at the top, a pretty long walk to no idea of disembarking points in the middle.
Walking the Bridge. You can pay and do the walk across the top. Or you can quickly walk across the road/sidewalk section of the bridge ... Lovely views and great spot for photographs ...
Iconic part of Sydney Harbour. Cannot miss it if in Sydney. Essential must see if in Sydney. Easy to walk under and Bridgeclimb is a MUST if you have time.
Beautiful. The wife and I took a million pictures. Between this bridge, and the opera house we were in photograph heaven. Sydney is truly and impressive sight!!!

Very nice view and strong wind, worth going. Have to spend a little effort to go up to the bridge though (I feel like I'm going uphill all the time), the view is very worth it though, you can have a nice view of the Sydney Opera House and the business buildings. Also, quite chilling up there so if you're going there at night, do bring a jacket there.There's a pylon lookout where you have to pay about 12-13 AUD to go up and get a nice and much higher view, didn't go for it though, I'm a little afraid of heights. For people who are not, it should be quite worthwhile to go up there. Definitely should go, it's really a magnificent bridge.

Have a walk over the bridge. Well worth a walk over the bridge on the pedestrian pathway -- great views of the harbor, the city and the Opera House -- leave yourself at least an hour to enjoy the walk. Warning -- you will need to climb quite a few steps to get up to the pedestrian pathway

Amazing architecture. VIew of the bridge and the water is marvelous. You can climb the bridge for a cost. It will give you a nice view of the city. Nothing soo special, its just a bridge. But I appreciate that a lot of time and effort went into building it. Cost money to get into the city, using the bridge by a car.

Walk across or climb - it's great!. I've walked across a few rimes and also done the Bridge Climb. Either way, a visit to the bridge is really good. It's an icon and the suburbs around are worth a look too - the views are great and anywhere you walk around here is sure to uncover something interesting!

An absolute must whilst in Sydney. I haven't done this for ages but I think I will again very soon whilst I am here. The view from the top is amazing and well worth the cost, you can't fall off and there are people of all ages climbing so just do it.

wowza. The bridge is a awesome sight, So excited to see the bridge its so big. we chickened out climbing it but we walked across that was great! Its such a grand amazing famous structure Im so glad we have seen it!

If your visiting...don't miss out on walking across this icon. Please make sure you just walk across this icon if you are visiting, it is a must. Make sure you spend an hour looking out at what you see. Tonight a cruise liner left with 2800 passengers waving at you.It is Australia's number 1 icon, and is a must.
I dare you!. the amazing thing about this bridge is to see people walking on the top....I don't care if you are tied or not you will not catch me up there.....but what a sight!

"Coat Hanger" Icon. Sydney's Harbour Bridge is another of the harbour city's icons. It is a wonderful sight as one travels by ferry on the harbour, but the ultimate experience is to pay to go on a "Bridge Walk".This take you from the roadway level right up to the top of the arch. The experience itself is exhilarating, and the view from the top of the arch is stupendous. Don't miss this attraction.

Definitely not just "Another Bridge".. This is the heart and soul of Sydney. The first thing you see flying into Sydney, Where Sydney siders expect New Years Eve fireworks to be coming out of every span and arch. From here the rest of the world gets the first showing on TV of the New Year being brought in. The spot where Paul Hogan worked painting the bridge, Where history saw Colonel Francis Edward De Groot cut the ribbon with his sword, on horseback, on 19th March 1932, before the State Premier could get to the ribbon with his scissors. The place where one can see all, from the Harbour Headlands in the East to Parramatta in the West. (the Parramatta bit is an exageration). These days one can even walk over the arch, something I would never do being terrified of heights, but thousands do. Go for it, walk over the arch, have a Crocodile,Kangaroo and Emu pizza with a beer afterwards at one of the pubs underneath and have a ball.

The Best View of Sydney Harbour Bridge. Do you know where to take the best photo of Sydney Harbour Bridge? This is my tips. Walk across the Bridge to Milsons Point where the Luna Park is. Yes, you can walk across the Bridge, not over the bridge. It is a nice walk if the weather is fine. You can have a good view of the harbour up there. Then you can come down from Milsons Point and walk to the Luna Park. You are right under the Bridge and you can have a good view of the bridge from there. Also Luna Park is an iconic park in Sydney. Just take a photo of the entrance of the Park will already make you feel the festive atmosphere. Hope you enjoy the walk as much as I do.

Forget the climb - walk across it for free. You can access the pedestrian walkway from the Rocks. Walk across the bridge and climb the 202 steps to the museum and observation platform on the 1st pylon. The views are amazing. You actually get to look DOWN on the bridge climbers. Walk to the other side of the bridge and have lunch at one of the many restaurants in that neighborhood. Then take the train back to downtown.

Stand at the peak of the "Coat Hanger". The "Coat Hanger",the affectionate name the Sydneyites give their Sydney Harbour Bridge which stands as a massive iron sentry to the neighboring Sydney Opera House.If you want an experience that will give you a travelling high unequalled, take the Bridge Walk,literally walk "over" the curved arc of the Bridge ! You will view the whole of Sydney from the highest point of the Bridge's arch ...and never forget it!

Iconic Bridge. Obviously a trip to Sydney you have to have the Harbour Bridge on your program of things to visit. As a pedestrian you have the opportunity to cross the bridge on foot and enjoy the view of the Opera House, the Botanic Gardens and the harbor. The bridge begins in the middle of "The Rocks" connecting the northern districts with the city center. Was a bit windy when we went so lost my hat, but the sun was out and got some great photos which made up for it!

Walk across free and enjoy the view. If you don't want to spend on the Bridge Walk you can just stroll across at deck level, obviously not the view and the excitement of the Bridge Walk but pleasant, then stroll down to the North Sydney pool, Luna Park and Wendy Whiteley's Garden.

Great walk with a view. It seems like a massive walk, but the slope is gentle and there's a rest bench half way if someone in your group needs it. If it's a nice day day it's definitely worth the effort. You can do the bridge climb as well, but it's a lot of money.

Do the bridge climb-awesome!. The harbour bridge itself is an amazing Sydney icon. Walk across for an uninterupted view of the magnificent harbour but if you can organise it do a bridge climb and see what everyone is talking about. The harbour is beautiful and you can see for miles. The Opera House, Botanical Gardens, the architecture of the older buildings, the ferries and boats on the water....just magic

The cheaper option is to walk it instead!. The Harbour Bridge is also known as the 'coat hanger' and features on every New Year's Eve fireworks celebration. When the Bridge climb first started years ago, it was about $99 per person. I prefer to walk across the Bridge. Take a train to Milsons Point station and take the left exit to the stone steps that lead to the walkway along the length of the bridge. Walk along the Bridge which should take about 15 mins (fast walker) or a leisurely 30 mins. You'll end up in The Rocks area.

Beautiful Bridge. Lovely bridge in a lovely location makes this a bucket list sight to see. Beyond that, its design is nothing special and although it seems like it would be fun to take the bridge climb, the price north of $200 was off putting.
Loved the Bridge!. You can really appreciate the bridge more knowing the history of how it was built and what went into making it! Not only a beautiful view but extremely interesting facts behind it.

take a walk on the bridge is quite good. From milsons point to the rocks, downtown, need to cross this bridge. it takes about 15 mins as an adult. you can enjoy the view toward Opera house with lots of floating yachts and ferries... it is also nice in the evening to look at the night view. there is also a lookout and climbing point. it is only 2 stops to get the downtown but take a walk on the bridge is quite fun
Iconic view point of Sydney.. such a beautiful bridge,its an absolute must to visit when your in sydney, lovley views of the bridge from the restaurants/pubs infront of the Sydney opera house.

its a iconic bridge that changed with the times. Ok its the icon of Sydney but get close to it and there are Jump fences to stop people from taking photos from the bridge. It was a bridge to be proud of with Trains, cars and pedestrians sharing the same bridge but now. its become just another walkway for pedestrians to get from South to the North. Take a photo from a far and the bridge looks nice but during our nanny state where governments worry about why Jo blogs jumped to his/her death from the Sydney harbour bridge has now turned the Sydney bridge icon into a prison with barriers preventing from taking photos from the bridge, its just ugly. SHB is a good example of previous governments that could not solve the issue why people were jumping from the bridge and just put barriers up as the blanket solution. take me back to the good old days of no barriers

Nice views. I liked seeing the views of the city from the bridge. I took pictures during the day and night, and they look great. A cruise ship docked during my stay in the harbor and it was great to take pictures of the bridge and ship too.
Wow what a view. Having an eagle eye over the harbour is amazing...having a cruise boat go under us was the icing on the cake. Great easy walk once you get up the stairs from the rocks.

Bridge and opera house. We have just got back from our weekend in sydney taking our 3 kids for the first time, aged 13, 11, 10. They loved seeing the bridge and opera house, we did the speed boat ride around the harbour although costly great fun for all the family
once in a lifetime. Do you get to see the Sydney harbor bridge. Try to see it at different times of day. In the daytime, you will see the skywalkers tethered to the bridge...not me : )
See it from the Opera Bar... It does remind you of a coat hanger as they say - a walk on the bridge is definitely not for the faint hearted....although many do it.

Worth a visit while in Sydney. Iconic attraction in Sydney, be ready to have the climb of your life. Very interesting climb and the tour guides are awesome. View from the top breath taking. Definitely worthwhile

Great view and pictures to take. Great experience and a great place to take pictures from (especially of the opera house). The bridge connects Sydney City with the North Sydney district and it takes 30min to cross it by foot.
Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. Fantastic views, great guides who knew a lot of stories and told us anything to know about Sydney's/ Australia's history. Highly recommended - must do whilst in Sydney!

Sydney Harbour Bridge, Opera House Australia. These are of course two of the most iconic and instantly recognised structures in the world. If you go to Sydney, visiting them is a MUST.Best time is to go in the early morning before it gets hot. Go to the Opera House first. Just spending some time strolling around the building is a strange joy in itself. Then make your way to a nearby park and take in the sight of the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge.Around noon, book yourself into one of the several Darling Harbour boat cruise. The boat makes a leisurely circuit of the harbour while you have your lunch and takes in the sight.There is a bridge tour too, but IMHO its way too expensive.  And of course, checking the weather report for the day is always a wise thing to do.

Great entrance to the city. Whether you are coming in by car over the bridge or under by the ferry, I think it makes a grand entrance to the city. Great view and pictures to take if you are on the ferry coming in to Circular Quay. I was once here for New Year's Eve and the fireworks were fantastic.

Bridge options. The bridge dominates the view from the city. You can climb the bridge (expensive, half-day... wonderful views - exhilarating) you can go up in the south city-side pylon (low cost, great views) Or you can just sit somewhere near the Opera House, Milson's Point, Circular Quay... and look at it. Drive or catch the train across it...or walk across and enjoy great views of the city and the Opera House.
best at night. a wonderful feat of engineering and a symbol of a great city - but night time is the time to view it and daytime to view from it,
I HEART THE HARBOUR BRIDGE. Cannot fault this structure! I am going to climb it in the next couple of weeks!!! Thanks for the certificate Polly
Iconic. we didn't go on the bridge but we got to see it from the cruise as well as from the opera house. the bridge looks grand, nice pictures were taken both for day and night. a view worth seeing
Fun to Walk Across. Just take the stairs up to the bridge off Argyle Street in the Rocks area. It is free to just walk across to North Sydney and visit Luna Park.
iconic.. watched during day.looked nice .Watched at midnight ,--brilliantly lit-looked heavenly along with bluish lit opera house.

A unique experience. This is another must-do when in Sydney. Awesome being able to walk alongside this majestic bridge ...with the roar of traffic one side and the most fantastic views out over the Harbour and Opera-House on the other side. I like the new 'padlock-shows-we-were-here' trend. I am glad they have started cleaning up under the bridge as well. Great photos to be had. Give it a go !
Nice view point. However The bridge walk to the top is rather expensive so I would suggest walking across at street level and spend your money on the Sky Tower to get a better view of the city.

Must see, to tick off your bucket list. A lovely bridge, but only a bridge none the less. The climb, not for those with a fear of heights, is very expensive ($235 per person) but worth it for the views.
Gorgeous Night Views. I didn't take the walk over the bridge but did take a wonder around circular quays, I wish we had been there on the Saturday night for the fireworks.
The Bridge. A wonderful bridge, but just a bridge nonetheless. Worth a visit for sure. One of the main attractions in Sydney. The Bridge and Opera House together look magnificent.

Long time ago good times remembered. After a long time at Bondi, a tram into the city and a walk to the opera house ,then the bridge , what .A amazing view ,,,, I will go back in August after a month in Singapore and a few days in Mirimimbula , 600k south o Sydney ,,,, I have traveled the world since I was 17 , now 83 and still "up for it "!!!!! Don't waste a second ,,,,just go !! You will not be disappointed ! Have a saf and happy time. RAY

Amazing view! A must do as a tourist. Even though the bridge climb is pricy it's a must do if you're in Sydney! I paid a little extra for the sunset climb and it was beautiful! You feel safe up there and they give you lots of history and facts on the way up!
A must when visiting Sydney. We walked onto the Bridge, great view. Just amazing when you think where you are in the world - on the Sydney Harbour Bridge.
The view was awesome!. Managed to go on a sunny day. Staff is helpful and courteous and safe 100% of the time. Equipment is in good shape and they take pride in the operation.

Night climb is the best climb. Having done the daytime climb, during an earlier visit to Sydney, and thoroughly enjoyed it even though I'm not good with heights my wife & I had no trouble in pledging to do a night climb next time in Sydney.Did the night climb last Thursday night & we were both blown away by the magnificent views of the city lights. Seeing the opera house & harbour from so high up & at night was such a great spectacle.We have no hesitation in recommending this attraction. The focus on safety is superb, on ground staff are well informed & look after you well, climbing suits & gear is all perfectly maintained & clean & the tour guides are great, especially if they see you are a little nervous of the height.

A free walk across the bridge. Yes you can pay $200 for the climb but one of my favorite free things to do in Sydney is start in the Rocks and walk across the bridge to lovely Kirribilli for an amazing view of the harbour and city! There are also some lovely cafes and a great fish and chips shop over there to eat. You can walk back or take the train into the city.

Great views from the bridge. We would have liked to do the guided climb to the top of the bridge, but found it just to rich for our budget. So we went on the public pedestrian walk across the bridge. Well worth it. Photos of the opera house from the midway point turned out great.

Walking across. We spent a bit of time while in Sydney taking a nice stroll across the bridge. It affords great views, not to be missed. Also if you're there on a weekend, just on the other side there is a little open air market going on, with people selling nicknacks and clothing, and of course FOOD of various ethnicities. It's a nice little reward for your walk over!

Spectacular view. Loved going through the bridge every time I went downtown. It's a beautiful structure that makes room for cars, trains, bikers, and pedestrians.Decided to jog through the bridge one night. Got off the train at Wynyard and walked through the Rocks in order to get up to the pedestrian path of the bridge. (In hindsight, it would have been better if I had just gotten off at Milson's Point and went through and back.) The path is fenced and patrolled by police, I felt very safe while jogging/walking through. There were also a few look out points on the bridge, which provided pedestrians with a spectacular view of the Sydney Opera House.

Amazing Experience, Spectacular Views. We drove and walked across the bridge, we also did a harbour tour which took us under/around it, an amazing experience, we got some fabulous photos. We didn't do the walk up and over the bridge, bit too high for us !

Great views. This was are first stop on arriving in Sydney. We took advice from Fromer's Australia guide book and walked onto the bridge (so didn't have to pay the $180 for the bridge climb) It's a great view and a wonderful way to figure out the harbour and the city. I wouldn't have taken the climb anyway because I'm afraid of heights. A friend said it was amazing. But I'm wondering if it's worth $180 dollars just to go a little higher.

Walked Across The Bridge - Views were stunning. We did the twilight walk across the bridge and it was well worth every penny. Our guide was both informative and helpful in every respect.Was totally pooped when we had finished but it was worth it just for the views.
Landmark. No one can and should skip the Sydney Harbour Bridge when visiting Sydney. It is one of THE must-see landmarks. I have personally not done it, but it is recommended to climb the bridge!
biked across twice. loved the views from all angles surrounding the bridge. had a wonderful day bike back and forth and around Sydney. loved it.
Must see!. Seeing the bridge is a must-do while in Sydney. I nice tour around the harbor will give you views under and to each side of it (try the "coffee tour" leaving from Circular Quay)

A Sydney Icon!. Returning to Sydney for the first time 30 years after leaving for the US, my breath was taken away when I first caught a partial glimpse of the Sydney Harbour Bridge from Circular Quay Station during the train ride from the airport to our hotel. The Opera House gets all the hype, but the sight of the Australian flags flying high on the bridge viewed from the foreshore on a sunny day is just as iconically Sydney!
Awesome. Really looks awesome at night , nice brilliant piece of architecture which looks outstanding at night.

Like walking on top of the world.. Opened in 1932,the bridge spans the harbour joining the north and south shores.It has 2 railtracks and 8 road lanes and carries thousands of vehicles each way each day.It is easily accessable and you can walk over it and enjoy exalted views of Sydney and the harbour.A camera is a "must".Walking access is free but if you have vertigo,be prepared,its a long way "up".Theres is also a commercial bridge climb for those who want to go right up and over the span.BUT ITS EXPENSIVE costing from $200 to $300 a trip per time of day and you have to enjoy walking/climbing to do it..On the northern side [milsons point] there are little cafes to recover at and look around an old part of Sydney. There are walkways on each side of the bridge,so go north on one side and then go south on the other side and get to enjoy the prettiest harbour in the world.{Im biased}.

An amazing feat of engineering Built 1932. Every time I pass over this bridge I get a thrill. So much history.  Wonderful to walk over. Lots of building and boats to see.The trains and buses pass over quickly. Great to go over to Luna park via the bridge.
Marvellous view. I went to the top of Harbour bridge and the Scenery is Marvellous.I felt like I was in Heaven.Great time should't miss.
Spectacular at Night. It was great for my children to see an Australian Icon both during the day when you could see people doing the climb as well as at night when it is all lit up.

Nice view. Its quite an enjoyable path with many cafes around. Nice view for some photo shots. Walk slowly, no need to rush and enjoy every step of it. Prepare sunglasses and umbrella when the sun is shining for your comfy.

Sydney's world-famous icon. During our stay in Sydney, we didn't manage to physically walk on the Bridge, but drove over it instead. At the same time, while on the ferry from Pyrmont to Circular Quay, this was the first time seeing the Bridge from underneath, in addition to the amazing view from the harbor!

Great views of the Opera House & Circular Quay!. Walking on the bridge and catching all the scenery of the Harbour, Circular Quay & the Opera House were wonderful. From end to end of the bridge, the walk is 2 km and it was excellent to do it in the evening when it is cooler and you can even catch the sunset. It is very safe with many people around and the security folks too. You could walk from the Rocks side and then take a bus or train back. You gotta do it when in Sydney!
a must visited. we were here in october 2013very good view. you can get very nice picture to remember, and it'se free

Dont Need To Climb the Bridge. We were going to climb the bridge but with three of us doing it found it a bit to expensive £150 each, so decided instead to climb the pylon and visit the museum for $11 each, not disappointed, the views are just as good, amazing time

The view you never thought you would experience first hand.. Approach from George Street up Argyle Street and you find the walkway across the bridge. Take your camera, yep the proper one not the I one, and capture those iconic views of the opera house and the harbour. Go up the pylon for a higher view or take the bridge climb, but you need some balls to do this. Today was far too windy so we could not attempt this part. All in all a fantastic experience. Do it.

The Sydney Habour Bridge. If you wish you can pay and climb the bridge or you can simply walk over it. The views are amazing, stand and watch the ferries or the cruise liners that visit the Habour, all very relaxing.

Great views. Did the pylon lookout (not the bridge climb). There's about 200 steps to get to the top of the SW pylon. There's a museum inside with the history of the construction. Well worth a visit. It only cost $11, well worth it. Great views from the top, over Circular Quay, Darling Harbour and of course the Opera House.

One of a kind!. Definitely one of the best bridges I've seen. Stunning to look at day or night. You could climb up to view the whole harbor from the top or you could walk on the side walk of the bridge to cross over to the other side. Just wonderful!

Another wonderful Sydney attraction. Another wonderful part of Sydney, pity I didn't have the nerve to walk up it! the view from the top must be marvellous, it was pretty good from down below particularly in the evening when lit up.We were lucky to see the fireworks over it from the north side.

Beautiful. We were here twice during our trip to Sydney. First, during the night with the view from the Opera House. Second time, we took a ferry from Darling Harbour to Circular Quay. We were there on the day when all the ships came in for the fleet review and apart from the many ships and boats at the harbour, there were helicopters and the whole view was simply amazing.

A Must Do. If you are able to walk, this is a Must Do in Sydney. You have beautiful views of the harbor looking back at the Opera House which allows you to see it like you've seen in all the pictures.

A walk to never forget!. Walked the Bridge on Friday 4th Oct 2013 during the International Navy Review, it was amazing, I am in my 50's and had no problems. The guides are very good & the saftey was the best. It is one thing you must put on the bucket list.

Amazing. Make sure when you visit the bridge that you walk from one side to the other to really appreciate this bridge it only takes 25-30 minutes and you get to see a lot more. Also visit the Pylon tour to appreciate the hard work and sacrifice made by many to build this Aussie icon.

its Sydney. Great holiday atmosphere. A must see tourist attraction when visiting Sydney. Lots of visitors, crowded at times but who cares.. take your camera and avoid getting other people in your photos.

North to South or over the top. Driving over the Sydney Harbour Bridge is so special.... The excitement of the city and the wonderful restaurants and views from the north and an iconic bridge that dominates the harbour..the trains are passing and the bridge limbers are above. At the base of the bridge on both sides you can enjoy the view of the harbour and there are lovely reserves where you often come across a wedding party - no doubt for the amazing pictures they can create. A climb to the top is another option and a must for tourists.

Inspirational. The Sydney Harbour bridge is amazing we enjoyed our work around the Opera House and could believe the amount of boats/ ships in the Harbour and then looking up to the amazing bridge, what a great day, would have loved to have done the climb but going through chemo at the moment so not very strong.
Views. A nice easy walk from one side to the other. Wonderful views of the variety of boats on the water and loved the padlocks. Visit and you will see what I mean.
Icon of Sydney. Just love the view from the harbour bridge, even to walk over it on the pedestrian footpath, by train, climb it, or seeing it from the harbour, just magnificent.

so pretty. the view from the bridge is outstanding didn't do the bridge walk but other people we know did and they loved it.. its a pretty bridge and worth a look lovely shops below the bridge for souvenirs'

Humbling experience.. The harbour bridge has the quality of humbling anyone who visits it. It doesn't matter where you see it from- the Opera House, the Royal Botanic Gardens- or how many times you see it. It will always stun you into silence. I could not do the bridge climb (severe shortage of time plus a fear of heights) but when I left Sydney I was determined to come back and do it. That's just how magnificent it is! Make sure you walk the length of the harbour bridge. The Pylon Lookout (entry fee required for this), located midway, is a must-visit point. A climb up 200 odd stairs later you end up with a spectacular view of the harbour and the many ferries and boats and yachts and what-not's gliding serenely in the waters while the Opera house benignly looks on. After the climb up and down the stairs, there is a small area inside where they play a video featuring a photo montage of the history of the bridge. That is why the entire experience is so humbling- to learn about the men who put their all into making this bridge what it is today. Not to be missed when you are in Sydney!
Stunning and Beautiful. We left Sydney Harbour and went on a Cruise. It was amazing going under the bridge on your way out to see!
Very peace full place. Nice place to enjoy nature and have a rest from the noisy town .Very big selection of trees and flowers .

Iconic. Along with the Opera House, the Harbour Bridge is one of Sydney's iconic monumets and visiting it is a must. There are a number of options as regards how best to 'tackle' the bridge and you should not necessarily confine yourself to one of them. Obvisouly you can cross it (either on foot, by car, by train and so on), go underneath it (by boat), climb up it (to the top of the arch) or walk up to the top of the pylon where there is a good lookout point. I did not do the bridge climb (i.e. across the arch) but did do everything else and would thoroughly recommend it. The climb to the top of the pylon is particularly worth doing (a) because there is a good vantage point to take some excellent photographs (which I believe is prohibited if you do the 'bridge climb') and (b) there is an informative little museum on your way up.
Fantastic. Coming upon the bridge on cannot get over how picturesque it is on the harbor. It is worth it to splurge and do the Bridge Climb.
Get to the top. If you are going to do anything in Sydney, The Harbour Bridge climb is the top of the list, full 360 degree views of the city and what an achievement.

Iconic view!. We travelled by ferry to Manly Beach and the view back towards the city was incredible. Being up close is good bit moving away and towards the city and seeing the bridge was amazing. I am sure we will get to see the New Year Celebration at some stage!
Fantastic walk. Take your time and walk over the bridge, The views are just great. I would do the walk around one hour before sunset so you can see the Sunset and its not to hot

Breathtaking views. Magnificent structure joining Sydney City to North Sydney. An iconic Australian landmark. The kids got such a thrill driving over the bridge. The Sydney traffic.....well that's another story.....
A stunning Sydney Icon. Walked the bridge one Sunday and found it exhilarating. It is breathtaking to look out over the harbour to the Opera House and Kirribilli - costs nothing!!
Great tourist attraction. For a tourist trap they really do a nice job with making everyone feel comfortable and have fun. Nice info on history and facts of bridge. Very cool

Harbour Boat Tour. The Syndey Harbour Bridge was the central point of interest during our boat tour. To see the birds hovering over the bridge at night and cleaning up the insects was an interesting sight. We also had the pleasure of crossing the bridge in the Blue Mt. Tour and got a closeup up the bridge. This is an icon that really sets up the area and neighborhood during the Rocks walking tour.

Amazing. No matter how many times you visit Sydney you cannot go past looking at the splendour of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. If you don't want to climb the bridge just take a walk across it and catch a train back, it is still pretty spectacular.
Over it, under it and across it!. On the one day we walked over the arches, across the footpath and sailed under it on a ferry! The only thing we didn't do was paint it!

Simply Awesome!. I was terribly afraid of heights and the guide Alex put me at ease with his jokes and distraction.The climb is pretty easy and the view is awesome. Chose the mid afternoon climb so that you can see the city in the day and night ( depending on the time sun sets) It's once in a lifetime experience, go for it!

Walking in the Rain. The Sydney Bridge and Harbor are beautiful and should not be missed. Do the Bridge Climb, it's not cheap but the view is awesome and so is the experience. We went up on the night tour in the pouring rain and wind, it was amazing. This was our second climb, the first time it was summer, warm and bright. Also a great time.Stop by 'The Cut' restaurant or one of the Rocks many bars and restaurants after for a battery recharge. Its a gorgeous, lively and entertaining area.

Walk the Bridge. The view from the bridge is fantastic, the harbour, Sidney 0pera House and the bridge itself. I walked across the bridge and viewed Sydney from the other side. Had a little taste of ordinary life - school children playing in the field, lots of small shops, and cafe's and people not in a hurry.

WOW. Standing next to this bridge was a surreal experience! I am from Melbourne and of course I knew this was a tourist attraction however did not know how spectacular this bridge looked up close. It was just amazing to look at and I got goose bumps thinking wow how could I have not seen this sooner. I couldn't believe how good it looked! All visitors to Sydney - go have a look at the Harbour Bridge if even for a couple of minutes! It is great - I was more fascinated by it then the Opera House!!

Great to see such an iconic site after seeing it so many times on TV. We have seen this site so many times on television that it was great to see this iconic site for ourselves. Sounds daft but I was soooooo excited to sail underneath it and see both it and the opera house for myself. I loved Sydney it is such a vibrant city with so much to do and see.

Definitely a not to be missed experience!. This is definitely something you need to do if you are visiting Sydney (or even if you live in Sydney). Our climb was scheduled for 10.45am and we were greeted at 10.45. We were sized up for our climbing suites and climbing gear and did a quick training lesson on the ladders. The climb was amazing and our tour guide was extremely knowledgable and was able to answer questions ranging from different islands to fireworks. Views are spectacular from the top of the bridge and could only be beaten if you went on a helicopter tour. The whole climb took about 3 hours from start to finish. We were also given a voucher to climb to the top of the pylons.
Fantastic view of the bay and Sydney opera house. Loved the view also loved that it was safe. Didn't do the cross with the harnesses though but the walk across was invigorating
Impressive panorama!. Wonderful views of the harbour and the whole skyline. Definitely worth visiting. I recommend to everyone visiting Sydney to view this magnificent bridge!
Good Harbour Views. Great for pictures of the Opera House, The Rocks and city skyline, nice stroll to the other side. The harbor is very clean.
Beautiful. It really Is such a beautiful bridge, however in saying that it is just a bridge, not much else to do unless you have a lot of money to spare to climb it..(: lovely views though
