Great Views. We loved walking the harbour bridge. There are little peep holes to take unobstructed pictures of the harbour and the Opera House. I went for a couple runs across the bridge in the morning, which seemed to be a popular thing to do among the locals as there were several other runners. I suppose one complaint was that in the morning, you're taking in quite a bit of exhaust from all the commuters in their cars.

Awesome. My wife and I climbed the bridge on Sep 16 the 2013 and it was fantastic. The weather was not great we had heavy rain but the staff kit you out with wet weather gear and the rain in no way spoiled our enjoyment of the climb. Richard our tour guide was very knowledgeable and gave us the history of the bridge and surrounding area which was very interesting . The whole experience from the initial safety briefing to the climb was very well managed by all staff involved. This is a must do event if you visit Sydney.

Sydney Icon. The sydney harbour bridge is somewhere all tourists like to visit and a great focal point from the harbour. From simply admiring it from the ground, walking under it whilst at the Rocks or from a ferry trip or doing the climb or just going over it by car, bus or train it is easily incorporated in a trip to Sydney.

One of those things a tourist must see.. Don't want to pay to climb the bridge?Go to the Opera House to take photo of the bridge.Walk onto the bridge from Dawes Point (city / southern end) or Milsons Point (northern end).Take any government bus from Sydney city side at corner of Clarence Street & Margaret Street to cross the bridge, and back. (You will need MyBus2 or any unlimited passes)All free!
Good views. We took the train across to north Sydney and walk but across the bridge and then walk up in the museum that in the brigade very good and lots of old photos and information .very good

Jogging. When I first set eyes on this iconic structure I actually teared up, it was beautiful. However... my jog over the bridge a couple of days later served up beautiful views but toxic lungfuls of car exhaust. Not the best place for health benefits but great for a once-off run.
Beautiful.. Like the views from opera house. Nothing disliked. We also see the bridge from the cruise and also from the train. Every time we were exited. It was really different feelings.
something else. If Sydney Harbour is one of nature's great works this has to be one of man's. a fantastic piece of engineering, you cant fail to be impressed by the sheer scale of it

Loved it. I remember when the Sydney Olympics were on TV and they showed you the Bridge at the start of every programme. I Promised myself I would go there one day and I did, I just loved it, I have so many hoots of it I have bored everyone. It is iconic.
awesome. The bridge is quite somethin to look at and with out it the harbour definitely would look a little bare!
Beautiful bridge over the water. The place is just perfect, with bridge, view of Sydney Opera House and lots of water! It's really a place not to be missed while in Sydney.

Icon of Sydney!. What can you say about the Sydney Harbour Bridge? there are superlatives like, awesome, amazing, great, fantastic...all true...but the interesting thing is the harbour bridge has many moods, which makes this icon of Sydney something special. From every new years eve fireworks display, to groups and usually not just one but several walking groups climbing the bridge at any one time, wherever you are around Circular Quay and the harbour, the views are truly memorable, and the mood changes at night with sparkling lights, with the water craft continually cruising the waterways of the harbour, this is a spectacular must see of Australia.Took a walk from Circular Quay around past the Park Hyatt Hotel, taking in the sights of the harbour and ending up right under the bridge, that seems to be a popular fishing spot curiously!! To stand underneath with a view of the Opera House, you get to understand the strong magnificent effort put in to building this icon over ten years.The bridge links Sydney metropolitan area to the North Shore, home of some famous Aussies, and Luna Park and the Prime Ministers residence.The bridge climb is a must do, and depending on weather conditions on my next trip to Sydney, hopefully, can actually take part in a bridge climb for even more superlatives!!

Climb or Walk across- one or the other should be 'must do'.. In 2007 I did the Sydney bridge climb at the encouragement of my Australian hosts. It was a great experience that I have relished and described many times since. The climb is intimidating prior, but the logistics and staff are outstanding and very reassuring, making it easy for a non-risk taker but eager traveller. Expensive, but very glad I did it. This year, in 2013, my wife and I stayed near the bridge and got equivalent or better views from our hotel, then walked across the bridge at evening rush hour/sunset. Walking kept us in the city, rather than elevating us above it. The views still great but now we were able to absorb a greater sense of how the bridge fits in the life of the city. Wide walks on the eastern side accommodate thousands of walkers - commuters, exercisers, tourists and locals - very bustling alongside busy traffic and double decker trains. I think I enjoyed this even more than the climb. One is experiencing Sydney and the other is a minor feat. Walk takes an hour and is free, climb takes several hours - essentially a half day. One or the other should be a must if you're a first time traveller to Sydney.
walk and wine. nice afternoon walk from Sydney CBD with incredible views and photos and then enjoy a glass or two at Kirribilli before taking the train back,,

Bridge Walk. It is a nice walk across the bridge. You could walk from Milsons Point to the Rocks or Vice Versa. The advantage of starting Milsons point is you could catch the train to Milsons Point. This walk is FREE. The time is around 30 minutes. The bridge climb is Pricey and there are different rates for different times.

The Most Beautiful Bridge in the World. We walked from the Rocks up to the Bridge and paid the tariff to walk to the top of the tower on the SE end of the Bridge. The displays in the climb to the top told the story of the Bridge and the top offered great views of this beautiful City. A much better tourist offering than the tour of the Opera House. Don't miss this if you're in Sydney.
Can look at it for hours. This is such a Sydney Icon.. always book somewhere you get a bridge view and don't miss an opportunity to do a bridge climb while in Sydney.

Magnificent structure. Walked around and under the bridge and discovered what a massive engineering feat it is...would have loved to have done the harbour bridge walk but the winds didn't permit..will definitely attempt it next time
very nice. Amazing place to take pictures. For sure it`s betterto visit when it`s sunny outside, but if not sunny, it`s still okay to take shots. Probably good for any weather type.
Unforgettable. Bigger than you imagine it to be. When you hear stories about this bridge and how it was built it is mesmerizing. There's a sense of peace from just looking at it.
Wow, what a fantastic structure. This is a piece of art. The views from the ferry are great for photography. There isn't anything not to like.

Tour of a lifetime. One of the best attractions I hve ever seen. Long on my "bucket list" it was brilliant, well organized, grea guides, helpers at key points along the way etc. The views are out of this world.

Amazing.. Amazing view, and really great fun to travel across! I always enjoy my experience crossing the Harbour Bridge, be it by car, bus, train or walking. It's a great way to check out the views of the harbour, and strolling across on foot is definitely great fun! Try the pylon lookout if you're after some great views, be it of the harbour, or the bridge itself.As a Sydneysider, I am ashamed to say that I have never yet done the Bridge Climb, but it is on the bucket list, many friends have assured me that it is worth every penny, and an amazing experience through and through.
Great attraction. Great free attraction for the kids and all the family.Walking across such an iconic attraction is sure to be remembered forever.

A must. I am a Sydney girl (lived in Melbourne for nearly 30 years) and have never walked over the bridge - I am so glad I have finally done this - an absolute must for every one that has the time. If time permits walking underneath is also a must - the view has to be one of the best in the world
Absolutely gorgeous landmark. Magnificent piece of engineering structure! Truly iconic. Better seeing it in person than on photos.

aussie coat hanger. Did the walk from the Rocks area towards under the bridge. It is gigantic steel bridge. Massive and astonishing. If you are an engineering construction enthusiast you will be amazed.
Harbour bridge walk. Easy walk across bridge, access from circular quay lift, has a few steps at north side and also in the middle to navigate with pram.

Free activity, great experience. Took the glass elevator from circular quay up to the elevated walkway. Its probably about a 30min walk but enjoy the views of circular quay below. A little further on you can see the Rocks area and then the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Take your time, great views. Too bad you can only walk one side; neverthless you see the ferries coming out of Circular Quay and the Opera House. I suggest walking through the Rocks area coming out at Circular Quay.
Walk over the bridge as a pedestrian. Head through the rocks area towards the bridge, up the staircase and you can walk across the bridge as a pedestrian without it costing a cent.

Majestic. This 1932 single arch bridge dominates Sydney's stunning harbour, and like its nearby Opera House lend a special quality to any visitor's experience of this lovely city. We were lucky enough to be there when the bridge, the Rocks, Circular Quay and the Opera House were lighted up at night with a most unusually beautiful and colourful lazer show in late May. An ever changing design played across the Sail-like roof faces of the Opera House, and played onto the buildings which sit alongside the harbour. The bridge itself blushed with pleasure as the colurful searchlights lit up its web-like span. Wonderful!

Great views. If you don't want to pay all the moula/don't care to climb the Bridge, then you should definitely go here! Awesome views of the Bridge (where you can even see the little ppl climbing it), the city and the Opera House. It is a bit of a small space and luckily when we went there weren't too many people.
Fun to watch the bridge walkers. Fun to watch all the people walk the top of the bridge. Can see them from most any place on the harbor. They have guts and must have no fear of heights

Spectacular views. I visited Sydney Harbour Bridge with my family.We didn’t go for the bridge climb (which I know regret, so that will be for next visit!).Instead we went for a stroll along the bridge (including a visit of the Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon Lookout - see my other review).The walk is very pleasant as it gives you fantastic views of the city, the harbour and the Opera House.You can not only enjoy the views but also admire the structure of the bridge as you see all the details from close.It is just amazing!There is always a gentle breeze that allows you to cope with the warm temperature.The walkway is securely separated from the driving lanes by strong metal barriers.It is very busy with joggers, people who just walk across the bridge and tourists...I would say that walking across the Sydney Harbour Bridge is compulsory as it is such an iconic site and it is free.
Popular attraction. A great sight to see... If you have the money to spend, there's a bridge climb that you can do. It allows you to walk/climb up to the top of the bridge.
Just beautiful morning. Wow just love this Bridge, took some overseas guests down for breakfast at the Rocks!And a lovely walk around the BridgeAwesome sights f sydney
Did a walk across the bridge. Amazing views of the Sydney Opera house, Circular Quay, the Rocks & Royal Botanical Gardens. I got some excellent photo shots
A great morning run to remember. Looking for a fantastic morning run? Why not head down to the Rocks and get on the Harbour Bridge and jog the 3km across the it.

Bird's eye view. What a lovely, breath-taking way to see the city! Do the Bridge Climb--it's expensive, but worthwhile. You can run or bike across it, and the area around the base is quite nice to walk around as well.

Climb the bridge at twilight. Although the bridge climb might seem expensive it is well worth the money. You get stunning views of the city and surrounding area from up there. I'd reccomend the twilight climb when you get to see the sun dip below the horizon, it's breathtaking. The staff on the climb are very informative and our guide, John, was also very funny.

A lifetime experience. Must do activity in Sydney. The experience is worth the money we paid. Great experience and amazing view really made our trip unforgettable. The friendly and professional staff are well trained in the safety aspect and able to make all the participants felt confidence and able to breakthrough the fear. I would strongly recommend this activity to all my friends ....visit Sydney
Great to walk across. My wife and I walked across and took a train back. Very fun. Great views and good photo ops. The bridge climb seemed a bit much, though.
nice outing for family. for a family to have a good outing - nice views, proximity to the city area, eating options close by, pleasant wind, lots of parks, harbour bridge is a very good option.

Sydney Harbour Bridge. SYDNEY HARBOUR BRIDGESydney Harbour Bridge commonly known as the “Coat Hanger” serves as a crossing from the North Shore to the Central Business District which takes about 10 minutes when the traffic is flowing. However, during peak hours in the morning and evening, expect traffic jams with bumper to bumper car traffic and it takes at least an hour to cross the bridge, so factor in this time when planning to cross the bridge for appointments, meetings or dinners. There is a toll charge both ways for motorists and motor cyclists and free for pedestrians and cyclists on special lanes designated for them to the right and left hand side of the bridge. A railway line runs along the bridge from the North Shore stations into the city stations. As one crosses the bridge, the tops of the sail roofs of the Sydney Opera House can be seen. Sydney Harbour Bridge, a very well known landmark is the largest in the world standing at 134 metres above the harbour. It was reported that in 1942 American and Dutch pilots flew their airplanes under the bridge and in 1943, RAAF pilots flew under the bridge when one pilot changed course at the last minute to fly the plane over the top of the bridge, clearing it in the nick of time. This is not allowed today though flights coming in to land at Sydney Airport fly above the bridge so passengers can catch a glimpse of the majestic Sydney Harbour Bridge. There are scenic helicopter flights over Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney Opera House with Sydney Harbour Heli – Flight, check out their website at www.sydneyhelitours.com.au or fly in seaplanes with Sydney Seaplanes at website: www.seaplanes.com.au Sydney Harbour Bridge throbs with much activity on the bridge with about 160,000 vehicles crossing daily; on top of the bridge where bridge climbs are conducted and under the bridge where one can get a side view and of the under carriage of the bridge by taking one of the boat cruises or sailing under the bridge. Sometimes during a boat cruise, dolphins swim alongside the boat, so wonderful to see. On several occasions, the bridge has been closed for charity walks and charity runs. The highlight for any adventurous visitor to Sydney is to do the Bridge Climb. Catering for people of all ages and abilities, check out their website at www.bridgeclimb.com/FAQs/Gift-Certificate-FAQs/ to get answers to FAQs. Once a year on New Year’s Eve, Sydney Harbour Bridge is transformed into one of the most magical places in the world with the fireworks display. For over the past ten years the fireworks display has been designed by pyrotechician Fireworks Director Fortunato Foti. Over 1.6 million people from all over the world gather around the Sydney Harbour foreshore to watch this sensational show which is telecast to the whole world. The spectacular fireworks light up and sparkle in a multitude of glorious colours with beautiful designs that fill the night sky that one has to see to believe. With simulcasting of the sound tracks the fireworks dance in rhythm to the bursts of fireworks. The theme for the fireworks display changes every year. Revellers gather to enjoy and party the night away with lots of joy and laughter to bring in the New Year. To watch this extravaganza live from the Sydney Harbour Bridge, come join us on New Year’s Eve for at least once in a lifetime experience.
I just love this walk. And with the constant security presence you can even do it at midnight! If you come to sydney and don't mind walking a few kilometres - you really MUST do this walk!
A tick in the box. It was a pretty view but nothing you couldn't see else where in the city. But it was nice to be able to tick that box to say I have done it

Wonderful. My Mother's cousin was a worker building the Sydney Harbour Bridge in the early 1930's. I always consider it great to be able to drive over the bridge or travel in a train which runs on the railways lines of the Bridge. I have walked over it a couple of times in my life and it is a great experience viewing Sydney and the harbour from that vantage point.A couple from Sweden, who are friends of my husband's, stayed with us a year or so ago. The husband of the couple is a structural engineer and on about 5 of the days they holidayed with us in Sydney, he went and looked at and analysed the bridge from an engineering aspect for an hour or so before they continued on their sightseeing trips for each day! He admired it so much.
Nice walk. We took the ferry to the luna park and walked back across the bridge. It's an easy walk and the views are spectacular.
Iconic. That is probably the best word you can use to describe the bridge. We were lucky that we had a view of it too from our hotel room so literally saw it at all times of the day.

The "coat hanger" bridge. Sydney Harbour Bridge is best viewed from a boat or ferry - on a beautiful sunny day or at night when Sydney is 'turned on'. It is at its best (I believe) when on show every New Year's Eve! Being not so fond of heights, I have never climbed it but everyone I know who have braved the ascent only have superlatives to describe the experience.

Well worth a look. There are 2 main things you can do as part of your visit to the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Firstly you can walk over it. This is about a 25 minute walk and invoves some stairs but not too many. The walk is nice and gives you a good view of the city and harbour but there is a lot of traffic noise and some exhaust fumes from nearby vehicles.Secondly you can climb the bridge on "bridge-climb". This is a well organised adventure and provides the visitor with spectacular scenic views, although there are some steps involved but if you are used to moderate walking you should not find any problems.

Want to see all of Sydney Harbour? Get on the bridge!. Anyone visiting Sydney should have the Harbour Bridge on their attraction list. even if you don't intentionally want to see it, you will from the main roads before entering the city. For those who don't have e-tags and don't know the city well, always end up driving on it! The bridge connects the city to the north side of Sydney. You can drive on it, walk across it, catch a train across it and even climb the bridge! If you want to see all of Sydney in a day with ultimate 360 views, I advise taking the bridge climb. the view from the top is amazing and you can even see as far out as the blue mountains. Take some warm clothes too because it is really windy. if you are uncomfortable taking the bridge climb, walk across the bridge. Many of our staff members at Tile Factory Outlet have done the walk and advise taking a good pair of walking shoes and a bottle of water. Once you cross the bridge to the north side, there are a few good little boutique eateries and cafe's at Milsons Point. If you have the kids with you, take them to Sydney's amusement park, Luna Park. Guranteed fun day out. If this was helpful to you please leave a helpful vote.

Its a old style bridge. This is a old style bridge, i really didnt find it very special. It looks good though. The surroundings are even better. From the bridge you can have a good view of Sydney city, harbour side, Opera house.But just the bridge, I didnt find it that special as people say.

Beautiful as it was years ago. Return to Sydney after 35 years, the bridge looks just as pretty and elegant as before except that more and more high rises grow around it making the night scene even more eye catching. take your car to both north and south side to enjoy the full view of the bridge from different angles.

Best Views without a plane!. Sydney's Iconic Harbour bridge is a must do walk for all Tourists. You can easily walk from the City to North Sydney and back whilst enjoying some of the most spectacular views of the Harbour, the Opera House and Fort Denison.If you cross from the City side to North Sydney you will actually exit at Milson's Point where there are numerous coffee shops and restaurants. For those who want an easy ride back, catch the train from Milson's Point station back to Wynyard or Town Hall and you are back in the heart of the City.

Pylon Lookout Sydney Harbour Bridge. Not many people know about this spectacular Sydney Harbour lookout.Find the stairs that lead up to the bridge on Cumberland Street (see right). You can take the walk from Circular Quay up Argyle Street through “The Rocks“. If you are feeling thirsty stop at the Löwenbräu Keller for a litre of European beer. Go up Argyle Street then turn right up “Argyle Stairs”. You will come out next to the Glenmore Hotel.If you are still thirsty, hungry or require Australian beer go up the stairs inside the Glenmore to the rooftop bar that has great views of Circular Quay & the Opera House. The food here is usually good. Another pub very close by is the Australian Hotel with some beers brewed onsite.Take the “Bridge Stairs” almost opposite the Glenmore Hotel up to Sydney Harbour Bridge pedestrian crossing. Walk about five minutes North along the bridge walkway until you reach the pylon. There is a signposted access entry.There are around 200 stairs up to the lookout with three main levels. The first level is where you pay the ($11 Adults, $6.50 Concession, $4 Children 5-12 years) entry fee with movie theatre room & information displays on the construction of the bridge. It is surprisingly big on the inside of the pylon.Level two has a balcony on both sides, only the Western side is accessible. Also toilets & a gift shop.On the way up to the top a couple of mannequins depicting workers are suspended from the roof top & a replica copy of the golden scissors used for the official (ribbon cutting) opening of the bridge.Inside the lookout level has further information panels & early images of the completed project. Outside the room on the lookout balcony can be be very windy.The balcony provides excellent views of Sydney Harbour, Opera House, Harbour Bridge & Circular Quay. The lookout is not quiet as high as the bridge climb peak, but here you can take & use your own camera.http://things-todoinsydney.com.au/sydney-harbour-bridge-pylon-lookout/

An Icon You Can View For Free Everywhere!. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is iconic but best of all, you can view it from all directions for zero cost. Of course you can do the Bridge Climb at great expense if you wish but if you don't have the budget, and you want to go up, you can visit the South Pylon lookout which certainly gives you great views. Or you can walk across the bridge for free at any time. You can bicycle across or just sit in the top carriage of a train or bus and enjoy the views. Ferries run on Sydney Harbour from Circular Quay which is almost at the base of the bridge so its wonderful to get on the harbour and just sit back and relax as you admire this famous Coathanger. Its also a great sight to visit whether you are single, a family, a couple, kids, business, friends or whatever, enjoy!
SYDNEY ICON. A famous landmark on Sydney harbour.Walk across it.Climb it - costly but the view at sunset is just amazing.

Walk on the bridge. Walk atop the bridge and you feel on top of the world. It's an amazing thrill. If are low on budget just walk through the bridge and climb to the Pylon look out. walking in that wind is a treat as well.

An icon. Walking across the bridge at road level is a great experience. Even better is to climb the South East Pylon - it's relatively cheap and the views are almost as good as climbing the bridge itself. Great by yourself, as a couple, or with children

A Must. You dont have to spend the dollars to Walk the Bridge, if you dont want to. The Bridge climb is awe inspiring, however the pedestrian footpath and pylon viewing for free encapsulates the whole Sydney Harbour views and you do get close to the Sydney traffic as well. Nice walk and everchanging scenery.

Fantastic Views. The Sydney Harbour Bridge or 'The Coathanger' is a Sydney icon and links north and south Sydney. I can not recommend too highly the bridge climb. It starts on the southern side in the Rocks which should be explored before or after your climb. The Coathanger has such an interesting history and is inexplicably linked with Sydney and its development. The views of the Opera House, the CBD and up and down the beautiful harbour is worth a million dollars and should not be missed.

Sydney Harbour Bridge. You have several choices when it comes to enjoying one of the iconic structures of the world. First of all you can walk across. Not easy for a tourist as you need to find out how to access the footpath but once on the bridge you appreciate its size. The footpath is on the Eastern side of the bridge so you get a good view of the harbour and opera house. Next you can catch a train across the bridge. The railway is on the Western side of the bridge so you get views of the Blue Mountains in the distance (on a clear day). Cost of the train will depend whether you buy a single journey ticket or a combined ticket for train, bus and ferry. Finally you can climb the bridge. You need to be OK with heights and be able to climb a short but vertical ladder. as usual with outdoor experiences, the weather can play its part but the view is awesome whether sunny, windy, wet, hot or cold. If the bridge is an icon then the Bridgeclimb is something you have to put on your bucket list! Forget all those big Ferris wheels in London and Singapore, this is in another league.

Great attraction. This is one of the biggest icons in Sydney, sure there are many but the bridge is fantastic, if you want to climb the bridge, everything is very well organize, go to the twilight as you will be able to see day and night time with the city cover with lights, great attraction.

They call it the coathanger for obvious reasons. This bridge is a piece of histor, you can take a train ride across to north sydney , best viewing time at night time is new years eve when a spectacular fireworks display happens

an easy, free walk with views!. You don't have to pay lots of dollars to appreciate views from the Harbour Bridge - catch a train to Milsons Point station, the first stop on the north side of the Bridge, exit the station on the eastern side turn towards the city and look for the stairs leading onto the walk across the bridge on the same deck as the cars and trains. Walk back towards the city with great views of the city, Opera House, ships, yachts etc and you will exit in The Rocks, the historical, early settlers, part of Sydney.

"Cannot be Missed" in the Sydney CBD. If you travelling to the heart of the Sydney central business District one cannot avoid "seeing" the Sydney Harbour Bridge. If you are strong at heart go on a early morning sunrise "bridge climb". The view from the top is spectacular looking across at the eastern half of the harbour including the Opera House, Fort Dennison, Sydney Botanical Gardens and Admiralty House in the foreground and looking further towards the horizon, Shark and Clark Islands, the eastern suburbs of Sydney (including Bondi Beach), the eastern board coastline, the heads (north and south heads for the harbour entry) and the ocean blue horizon coloured by the rising sun over the ocean. P.S during the winter months some lucky people get to see Hump Back Whales frolicking in the dawn harbour waters prior to the busy peak hour passenger ferry traffic.

Fabulous Walk Over The Bridge. Milsons Point in Sydney is the only place you can walk across the harbour bridge all the way into the city and down to the rocks...its a fantastic walk across the bridge you can see the climbers walking over the top of the bridge and all the action happening on the Glorious Sydney Harbour below....take some great photos and just enjoy being on this Wonderfull bridge...best of all its all free :-)))

ICONIC. The Old Girl is 84 year old now and still going strong, what an amazing structure, there are pedestrian lanes, so can be easily walked from one side to the other.A great option, is to take the Bridge Climb, something that should be on everyones " bucket list" the views from the top of the Bridge are sensational, The bridge climb is maybe a little expensive, however well worth the money, The operators, are one of the most experienced, I have ever come across
Its huge!. The bridge is beautiful and so massive. My mum and I decided to try and walk it only to stop and turn back around

A Sydney Icon. One of the most recognisable bridges in the world its arch spanning our magnificent harbour. The Opera House on one side, Darling Harbour, Pier One, and Luna Park on the other. You can walk or jog across it or you can climb it. The view of the sunset from it is also amazing. It is also the focal point of our New Years Eve fireworks

Always worth a visit. I've walked through this bridge so many times and I just love to. Great view. One of the world famous bridge that you can not miss it. I didn't climb to the top as it was costly to me. I had a friend who did that and took photos, all I can say is "wao...amazing", it is stunning view. Very good design on this one as it connects North and and city land. Doesn't matter how many years gone by, it still look good.

Lovely walk over the bridge. On Sundays, we often park at one of the many train stations on the lower North Shore, catch the train to Milsons Point and walk over the bridge to the rocks. On a sunny day, it is a wonderful thing to do. The rocks markets are a nice place to browse through and there are lots of lovely old pubs in which to have a lunch time beer. Walking over the bridge in the sun is glorious, and you will have lots of fellow walkers with whom to admire the views of the harbour and the opera house. We live here and we never tire of it. At the end of the day, you just catchnthe train back to your car. If younare staying in town, walk through the rocks market, have lunch, walk over the bridge and then catch the train back.
The Bridge. You cant beat a view of the bridge a great day out and do the climb. This is a full day of fun and sites so get out there and have fun. Sydney is a great place to see.

Sydney Harbour Bridge. As a Sydney sider I walk across the Sydney Harbour bridge at least twice a year and travel across it regularly - it is a great experience always (even in the peak hour traffic). Walk across during the day or night, the harbour is always spectacular. Climbing the bridge is even better. I suggest taking the sunrise or sunset climb - this is unbelievable and a memory to treasure forever.

Walk or cycle. Everyone knows that you can spend a lot of money to climb the arch to the top of the Bridge with it's splendid view of the harbour. But, for free, you can walk or cycle across the Bridge. A lovely way to get to the other side!

Great Views from Bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge completed in 1932 connects Sydney city to city north and carries thousands of cars, is the rail link north to south, and has a people walking deck. From either the walking deck or its spans you can see spectacular views of all of Sydney, its natural harbour, the Opera House and this is the reason thousands of visitors have done the Sydney Bridge climb. There are many great vantage points on or around the bridge, so take the time, it will be worth visiting.

One of the most recognisable structures in the world. I have always loved flying home into Sydney just as the sun comes up and looking down at the bridge the the harbour. I don't think I will ever get sick of seeing it. Doing a bridge climb is an amazing experience and not nearly as scary or strenuous as some people may think so if visiting Sydney it is well worth considering. But a climb can be a bit expensive for a family and there is also age restrictions. A cheaper option and one our family has done a few times is to catch the train to Milsons Point and walk back across the bridge to the city. There is a bench seat at the half way mark to take in the view and then you can visit the South Pylon Lookout. Climb the stairs up to a small museum and lookout. There is a fee but it is no where near the price of the climb and it's a good view. Then head on down to The Rocks or Circular Quay for a nice meal.

A great experience. This is one of the iconic bridges of the world yet so accessible and free to walk over. Take a bus to North Sydney or train to Milson's Point and walk back to the City. Bicycles are limited to the west side, while pedestrians walk on the east side of the Bridge, with wide pathways for freedom to stop and take photos of the Harbour, Opera House, Kirribilly House etc without hindering fellow walkers and joggers. The Bridge Climb may seem expensive but it really is worth it for the views from the top (although I couldn't take my own camera up when I did the climb a while back) and the sense of accomplishment afterwards.

Walk across it for best experience. If you are staying on the Lower North Shore, start at Mlsons point and walk across stopping as often as you like to really take in the views. End with refreshments in the Rocks. From the city side, start in The Rocks and walk North, ending at Milson's Point and Kirribilli, keep walking just a bit more . along the foreshore towards the Olympic Pool and have refreshments at the cafe there with one of the best Sydney Views.

Known to the locals as the coat hanger!. Read about the Opening ceremony of the bridge. Lovely to walk over. Get the ferry to Darling Harbour and you will go underneath it so will be able to see how massive it is.
Sydney Harbour Bridge. the one and only...........looks fantastic from all angles especially at night.........worth every $$$$

Relax and enjoy. Walk through the Rocks, bite to eat - then to the Argyle cut and along the bridge (towards nth Sydney) enter the pylon. This is a wonderful incite on how the bridge was built- all of the hardship etc... Climb to the top- on a clear day you can see all. Walk back to Circular Quay, listen to some buskers and catcth a ferry to Manly. A day where time is yours, no particular schedule...enjoy.
This Bridge is a knockout!. Whether climbing the bridge doing a bridge climb or just walking over it, the views are sensational & not to be missed while in Sydney. Enjoy & have fun!
Visiting Sydney. it was a great feature to see as very very interesting on the structure of the building, as IO havenot seen this since 20 years previous

Sydney icon. Much photographed but the best experience to get a feel for Sydney is to walk across or over the top. The Brdgeclimb is stunning but walking from Milsons Point to the Rocks is free with panoramic views of the Harbour, Opera House and harbour action.

Excellent views from this historic, iconic bridge. We stayed at a nearby hotel in the Rocks for 5 nights. I jogged across the bridge and back with my kids two mornings, and walked it a third morning with my wife. It is very popular with joggers and strollers and offers excellent views of the harbour and Opera House. Also a good place to watch the sun rise over the harbour. From the Rocks area, it is a short jog across and back, with about half being slightly uphill and the other half slightly downhill.
A great experience. A really worthwhile trip although I thought a little over priced and you didn't even get a free photo !
Worth a visit. Its a big bridge! If you don't want to walk over it, walk on it or take a trip on a bus over it. Great views from it in all directions.

this is iconic Sydney. As a tourist, the Harbor Bridge is a Kodak moment. If you are adventurous, then do the bridge climb...the view from the top is amazing. For locals, the bridge is just that, a way for cars to cross the harbor. It is always exciting though to ride across for some reason....I guess its the view of the Opera House you see.

An Impressive Landmark. You can see the bridge from planes and almost anywhere in Sydney. There are tours that walk over the bridge structure. Did not do that one. We went over it on a bus. Painting the bridge is a never ending project. One person told us that Paul Hogan, the Crocodile Dundee character was a bridge painter on this bridge before he got into the movies.

Very Safe. Don't worry about the heights or a feeling of being unsafe. The entire trip is at a comfortable pace--maybe even too slow. You are well watched and fully hooked up--so not falling. Obviously, great views to be had.

Amazing view of Sydney harbour and opera house. This is the place where u can make some of the breath taking photos of Sydney harbour and opera house (that u had seen before only in travel catalogues). The view is amazing. U should take a bridge walk, climb some more stairs and pay for some extra view. It s worth it and there is also a small museum of history of the Sydney harbour bridge.

the walk (free) gives you the flavor. You can walk to the center and see the view, or you access the top of one of the support structures for a modest fee, or can walk high expensively. Getting close th the bridge gives you a feel for its mass; there are better ways to see the harbor, such as getting gout on the water.
brilliant. the views are awesome, the price is good, you feel very well assisted, the level of customer service is the top! love this place is very special and unique

Engineering masterpiece. Climbed the bridge on a previous visit and that was an awesome experience - we made our descent from bridge at dusk just as Sydney illuminated - quite beautiful. This visit we stayed in Kirribilli and walked across the bridge each morning - such amazing views all around - stunning.

Better than Golden Gate SF. Everything is together here, the amazing harbour downtown Sydney and the North Shore of Sydney.. and the Opera House. All in One. I liked the Golden Gate...its long. This is an amazing bridge architecturally.You can get a nice view from the public train.

Best Seat in the House Looking In. Everyone should take the time to walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The view is spectacular and it's very easy to do. The bridge offers such a great look back into Sydney and other parts of the harbor. The water taxi's and ferries are constantly going in and out. The is so much to take in. Walking across the bridge is not the same as climbing the bridge. Walking is free, climbing is expensive. As your walking across you will come to the Pylon lookout. For 11AUD you get to walk up 200 steps up into the stone structure. There is a museum and outside lookout that is outstanding. This little find is pure gold. Easy to over look so don't miss it. It wasn't crowded either. Make this a part of your travels as you visit Sydney, Australia.

Great Piece of Engineering. As an engineer, this place was great there was allot of information about the bridge and the views of the opera house from it are famous. Walk over to the other side as the views from there are also great.

Crown of Sydney harbour. If Sydney harbour is like a beautiful princess, the harbour bridge is the crown of the princess. I have been living in Sydney for more than a year now and I have seen this bridge hundreds of times but it's beauty still amazes me each time I visit. I have traveled under the bridge by ferry, on the bridge by walk, bus and train and even I flew over the bridge by helicopter and each view of the bridge is just amazing. The bridge effect during the New year's eve midnight fireworks will last forever in your memories. I know it is a mere steel and concrete structure and is not one of the tallest or longest bridges in the world but still it is one of the most beautiful bridges in the world. I strongly recommend a visit to this bridge if you get a chance.

Truly iconic!. How could you go to Sydney and not see the Opera House or the Harbour Bridge?As soon as we had checked into our hotel we walked to the Harbour Bridge and caught the sun setting... Absolutely beautiful. We returned a couple of days later during the day and it looked as magnificent as ever still.It's a must see! :)

Out of breath but worth it. Loved the views but not the onesee we had to wear - long way up but wow we could see for miles - the opera house looked very small. Glad we did the climb on this trip and not when we were any older.

Simply spectacular. The view, the moment & scenery was simply spectacular. One of my best vacation places! You got the Sydney Opera House as part of the scenery & lovely Darling Harbor! There was a hot dog seller during the weekend at one end of the harbor bridge, the best hot dog I ever eaten, if you are lucky maybe u may bump into him during your trip!
Stiff Neck. There is so much to see from different angles, that I really did have a stiff neck. It is one of the greatest bridges I have ever seen, and I've been all over the US of A.
Beautiful architectural and cultural landmark!. From all angles it is most impressive. I loved seeing the pictures of it being built at the open marketplace, too. Amazing!

No better activity to top off a trip to Sydney. It's possible to go higher in a helicopter, but in my opinion the climb up Sydney Harbour Bridge is not all about the view, its about the walk and being on THE bridge. We did the Express Climb, which takes you through the bridge's structure rather than just over the top, so to mind, more interesting. We were told that to do the Express Climb you needed to have a good level of fitness but we found it quite easy even though we wouldn't consider ourselves fit as fiddles. Our guide was very experienced, patient and friendly. She certainly helped make the trip as enjoyable as it was.You really do need to pinch yourself on this activity, that you are actually on Sydney Harbour Bridge! I don't think the experience could have been made any better by any other means; the activity is a very well oiled machine! The photos taken are very well done and pretty good value. It helped that we went on a blue sky day.Totally recommend this trip.

Pictures from all angles. I have been under it by ferry, over it by bus and walked it. It is truly spectacular. I didnt realise how big it was till I was there in person. It is a great landmark. You have to see it, explore it, when you visit Sydney
Amazing structure.. It really is as amazing at it looks on TV!!!! Definitely don't miss it if the opportunity arises. Watched people climbing - I'm not that brave!!!
Magnificent. Everyone knows the Harbour bridge. But only when you walk across or see it upclose do you realise how big it is in reality. It gives great picture opportunities at night.
Fair. It is pretty amazing but sorry that I can't really see how spectacular it is. The best location for taking a photo of it would be catching a ferry across the Harbour!

One of the landmarks of Sydney besides the Opera House. This Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the famous landmarks of Sydney besides the Opera House. We were lucky to have a local colleague who knew the right place to take some memorable shots with this bridge as the background .......

If you can't climb the bridge, walking across it is the next best thing and its free!. Great views from the Opera House and Sydney. For a fee you can go up one of the towers, it is worth it if you have the time/money.

it is one of the main attractions. after the opera house , this is one of the main attracions of the city it is a jewel of ingenering, and if you have a good condition you can climb it, but if you feel giddeness, forget about it, then you better have a drink in some of the many bars arround and enjoy the view.

AMAZING!!!. This bridge has a great story, known as the coat hanger, and it was one of my favorite things to look at in Sydney. When it was built, it was an architectural phenomenon, and even today, it is magical! I loved it!
fantastic views!. the walk didnt take long, its cold even on sunny day. maybe better in summer. great views of the harbour and opera house.

great bridge. From almost every angle, the bridge takes centre stage. Drawing your gaze toward it. Loved seeing people walking all over this piece of historical engineering and at night time the bridge just continued to stand out.

Expensive but Fun. Our adult kids did the bridge climb and really enjoyed it. It was very well organized and safe. A bit expensive but I guess it's a unique experience. We bought one picture for $25 which came as a Facebook download as well as on a CD. While waiting in the lobby one can enjoy free wifi ( something that is very rare in that part of the world) which we used. The speeds of the wifi were better than in some other places we used it at.
Iconic. All God's children come to or visit the BRIDGE!Iconic view from the Harbour!Somme might enjoy the bridge climb; however, given a week in Sydney, we found much more to do.

The highlight of the harbour. Exactly, in my opinion, this is the beautiful part of the harbor, not the Opera House. It is nice to walk around it to see all its gorgeous angles, nice to walk across it if it takes a little bit, nice to climb to the pylons to see great views, and nice to climb on the bridge itself if you have the time, money and stamina. But you absolutely must at least walk around the harbour to see how beautiful this bridge is.

Worth going. Well, if you are in Sydney, you might as well go, because you have an awesome view over the central business district and the opera as well as the river. Definitely nice, just the heavy traffic is a bit disturbing!

Amazing bridge - love the views!. This is one of my favorite bridges in the world! The architecture is beautiful and for a fairly "new" bridge, the story of its creation is awesome. You can see the bridge from all over Sydney. I was fortunate enough to do the bridge climb once, and while it was an amazing experience, it is very pricey. Last time in Sydney, I walked up to the Pylon Lookout instead - for only $11, it was well worth it and had the same views you get on the bridge climb. However you choose to spend time on the bridge, you're sure to have a nice experience in a beautiful setting.
An Icon...!. The Bridge, The Opera House & an enormous Cruise Liner all in the same photograph .... magical ! Go see it for yourself.

Nice bridge. Okay, the Aussies are proud of their bridge. What is amazing is the foresight of the designers during the depression. It is one of the most versatile bridges in Australia today. A walk up the bridge costs a couple hundred dollars. I didn't do it so I cannot comment if it is worth it.

Iconic. The Harbour Bridge was such an integral part of my stay in Sydney! Really enjoyed walking under it and over it to the North Sydney side. Finding the staircase up was a bit of an adventure! It offers the best views of the Opera House and the bay as you are walking across. Would love to do the climb across the top arch of the bridge some day!
Best Bridge Ever!. Probably the nicest bridge I've ever been on. Climbing it is worth the time & effort as well. Do it!

It's a bridge. Not much to it, unless you climb it.. It's iconic, it's historical, but it's just a bridge. Not very impressive in my opinion. The Bridge Climb is expensive, but very safe, well-organized and overall worth the money. The best photo ops are from the RBG's McQuarie's Point and from the Manly Ferry.
awful. what is all the fuss about, if this is the best that australia can offer it is a sad state of afairs, i couldn't see the charm, it's just a bridge FFS

Fantastic Photo-Op. Although we did not physically go up the walk about on the bridge, the Harbour Bridge did provide us with a lot of photo opportunities from a distance, Try to shoot during early mornings/late afternoons or from a Manly Ferry heading out of Port.

Magnificent structure. It's just another bridge but consider someone built it years ago when technology was an infant. Such an interesting sight which marveled me. Just stood there for 15 minutes gazing at it from end to end, then walked some distance away and spent more time looking at it. It's architecture, shape and location gives a lasting impression. It was exciting to look at a structure that shows how much mankind have archived and a sense of pride on human achievement as a whole. This magnificent structure is walking distance from any part of the city and surrounded by lots of restaurants and entertainment spots. A must visit if you are in Sydney.

runners. Loved the fact there is a pedestrian/cycleway across the bridge. We ran most mornings around Sydney, its a great way to explore the city and didn't realise you could run across the bridge and found the walkway by accident.Great views from up there, the bridge climb would be spectacular!

Amazing views. Certainly worth to walk over!. I walked over the bridge and the views on the city's skyline, the Opera House and the harbour are amazing. Its worth walking around on both sides of the bridge, as there are plenty of small streets and stunning old and new houses.
Beautiful bridge. Beautiful bridge to look at, but really distinctive when you look closer and notice all the people climbing up it and walking on top of it.
A must do!. Harbour bridge is unquestionable landmark of Sydney same as Opera House. It is very well organize and safe with breathtaking views of Sydney specially on a nice day.
Amazing. Great view from the harbor but our Golden Gate can not be surpassed. In the long run this one is in sydney.

Harbour bridge. You can walk the harbour bridge path for free any day, climb up either end in Kirribilli or Sydney city side, and walk over , you may want to climb up the very top which is considerably more expensive but if you are on a tight budget walk for free.

Peaceful stroll around Sydney's iconic structure. It was sunny, peaceful, clear sky, and walked around during a break from a city tour. I don't know what else to add that hasn't been said, I thoroughly enjoyed it.

Great walk - but not worth the climb. Excellent walk across the bridge for free, walk over to the funfair and catch a ferry back. The cost of climbing the bridge is ridiculous - just not worth it when you can walk across at your own pace for free with the same views!
The great Australian icon. Looked fantastic during the vivid light festival what a fabulous back drop over the harbour .would love to do the bridge climb next
A Must See. Lovely to look at and especially to walk under at 2am in the morning. Really enjoyed seeing this icon in Sydney while on holiday.

Just phantastic. I took the ferry from Olympic Park just to see Sydney, the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House for the first time in my life. And it was worth it - simply phantastic to say "Hello" to this wonderful town.Another highlight was to watch the firework at New Year´s Eve there 2011 and 2012. The best you can have in the whole world.

Iconic must-see in Sydney. On our recent trip to Sydney, we had views of the bridge from several vantage points- on the bridge, looking up at the bridge during the Vivid Sydney light show, and from a ferry. It is a beautiful structure, and easy to get to if you are at Circular Quay or the Opera House. We didn't go on the bridge climb, but felt that we were able to see and experience the bridge without needing to spend the big dollars on the climb.

Sydney Harbour Bridge. Very interesting bridge as a tourist attraction. Very scenic and lovely during the light up especially when on-board a cruise ride.
I really enjoyed the lights as they were very beautiful .
The only thing was being on-board you cant really capture a good shot since its moving.
Right time for holiday during vivid sydney

World famous bridge. It is incredible weather you are on a ferry below it or doing the bridge climb on top of it the bridge is a focal point of the harbor and just stunning. Its beautiful during the day and just as amazing at night all lit up.

Iconic. World famous and a not to be missed walk across the bridge with a visit up the SE pylon recommended. You could do the bridge climb but if not up for the thrill or the dollars the pylon is a great alternative
Cool bridge that allows pedestrians to walk. I like this bridge as the pedestrian pathway allows great pictures to be taken, no need to cross again to return, simply take ferry, train or bus.

Still special every time. No matter how many times you see it, it is always worth a comment - it is special and helps define Sydney. The readers below have described the bridge climb and everyone who has done just raves.At the weekend though sitting under it, I wondered about the "ants" above - the bridge climbers.It must be quite wonderful but they seem so small from down below.
bridge walk. walked along the bridge to the other side , fabulous views of the sunrise over the harbour & the opera house & it's free ! great way to get a feel of the city and it's layout .

Do IT!!!. The walk across the bridge is MAGNIFICENT. I don't know that I would necessarily do the climbing tour, as it is very expensive, and not a whole lot higher than just simply walking across the bridge anyhow.

Cross the bridge by foot on a sunny day!. Great experience and a great place to take pictures from (especially of the opera house). The bridge connects Sydney City with the North Sydney district and it takes 30min to cross it by foot.
Great views. It is amazing to have the opportunity to look at the city from there. It is also fast to walk through it and great as a tourist attraction
The harbour area. It is great to have a walk around in the ancient centre of the city near the harbour bridge. Learn about the first settlers and convicts that arrived here.

Whether you walk over it, under it, or see it from afar.... This is one of the quintessential must-see's if visiting Sydney. A short walk around the Boardwalk from the Park Hyatt (where I recommend you stay) yields sweeping views of the bridge. :) You can take tours that will walk you over the bridges trusses...or you can walk along the pedestrian walkways for nice views as well...either way, you won't regret the time it may take you to incorporate this into your itinerary. :)
Its a big bridge. Don't know what I can say other than that. Its very impressive to see, stand under or walk along and it goes over the harbour

wondeful and amazing. Liked everything. Interesting structure and photographed it from just about every angle! I had done the Bridge climb on a previous trip (expensive but worth doing) and this time walked around it, cycled over it (see Bike Buffs) and took the ferry under it. Sometimes I just sat and looked at it. This bridge is so iconic and, coupled with the Opera House, sums up Sydney.

Simply magic!. I was lucky to witness the kaleidoscope of lights dancing around the city buildings and the Opera house. Lovely restaurant with live music in front of Opera House facing the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Balmy autumn evening... lovely wine and food...what more can I ask for....
Great view of the harbour. We went across at night and the views are great recommend the night crossing as the harbour was lit up and all the small boats were coming and going with music and dancing

Spectacular view of the harbour. You can walk for free across the bridge or pay $200+ to climb another 200 feet up and over the arch. The view is the same. Take the ferry over to Luna Park and walk up to the bridge and back to downtown Sydney. Taking the Manly ferry back at sunset gives you a great view of the bridge as the lights come on.

A fulfilling experience. Heard a lot about the bridge...nice to see it too. The start point is just a short walk from milson point station. The bridge itself is a long walk.It is a good idea to walk until circular quay. If you are an avid walker or jogger, you are going to love this experience. From the bridge, at a great height, you see a beautiful Sydney...Make sure, you take the walk during the day time to have a fulfilling experience.

well worth the view. well worth visiting you won't be disappointed, make sure you go mid afternoon, walk to the opera house and around circular quay so you can get photos with the sun setting and then also evening shots

Wonderful View. Should go for a morning walk along Harbour Bridge..will take about 1 hr to walk from The Rocks to end of the bridge & return back to The Rocks...Can see amazing view of Circular Quay & Opera House from there
Amazing views. The views from the bridge are amazing, and if you just want to walk the bridge rather than climb or bungee jump then it's completely free!
Beautiful views. Walked right across it for the first time this year and thought it was great (lots of photos). Also a good option for those not willing to shell out $200 for the Bridge Climb.

Well worth a wander. A great chance to just wander across this iconic Sydney icon. We didn't do the bridge climb as short on time but it was lovely to walk around the rocks district then up onto and across the bridge. Great place to take photos and lots of others using the bridge for sight seeing and travel. A bit of a shame that the tower look out costs more than a few $.
Aussie Icon. Walk, it climb it or just look at it...it's special. Meet friends nearby, where there are lots of cafes, bars and restuarants and definitely take heaps and heaps of photos.
More than a bridge.. Iconic landmark and an integral route of transportation. Climb it, walk it or just look at it, worth taking a picture of it even if you live here.
Amazing. Brilliant masterpiece .Beautifully made.Looked great with lights by night as well as in the morning.

Excellent View at Night... Spectacular view. Cannot get bore of looking at it. There is also an option to go to the top of bridge walking steps but it was too costly so i skipped it.Only one minor problem I felt was reaching harbour bridge as directions were not clear.

Walk across bridge.. If you can't afford the cost of bridge climb, take a walk across the bridge. Take the elevator at the eastern end of Circular Quay up to the Cahill Expressway & follow the path which takes you eventually to Milson's Point. Spectacular views, visit the southern pylon if you wish, a cost free alternative, easy walk at your own pace.
It's just a bridge. If Sydney is a layover, then sure, come take a look, but do not make this a required stop on your itinerary. It's a lovely town, just like every other town.
It never gets old.. I personally think this bridge is much more stunning than the opera house, I see it all the time and it never gets old gawping at it.

The bridge. As I am afraid of the heights i did not climb the bridge, but have seen it from the water on the ferry ride. It was majestic structure and had every bit of "wow" for me. I was very happy to see it for myself as I was watching many a shows with the bridge in it and wanting to experience it. Loved it

A walk across. There is a lot of publicity about the Bridge climb, it is great to do but there is something I feel that is just as good,, well maybe not as spectacular.You can walk across the bridge for free, and it can be an adventure just getting to the start at either end.The views are great, if the weather is fine, and the wind is mild, the walk is one of the pleasures of Sydney, and many hundreds a day do it just to get to work in the morning, what great way to start the day, the bridge walk is open 24 hours, almost 7 days a week. 365 days a year. You enter via the Rocks at the south side, or Observatory Hill, and exit at Milson point on the northern side, did I mention that there is a special bike lane as well.See you on the bridge, one day.

A fun hike with a spectacular view. we walked up and over in late afternoon with long view of harbor and opera house. We didn't take the high route on the top of the bridge but we had as good a view for less cost and effort

This is the most reconizable bridge in the world .. It is an iconic structure on the most beautiful harbour. The view from the bridge walk on top of the arch is breath taking at anytime of day. It is also a delightful walk across the bridge.

Skip the Bridge Climb and choose the Pylon!. Save the $300 to climb the bridge and take the 12 or so flights up the bridge pylon! You'll get the same view for a fraction of the cost AND it's a real photo op kind of place. The pylon also contains a museum dedicated to the construction of the Sydney Harbour Bridge - so it's a total win-win situation.

A nice walk after a long flight. We took a slow stroll across the bridge stopping to take photos of the opera house and the Sydney skyline. It's a popular walking route as well as jogging route. We tried hard to stay out of the runners path. There were even a couple of seats for my disabled husband to rest a few minutes.
Take the walk to the top!. At my age I opt'ed out... but regret it. Others said it is the best site in Sydney. I can believe that by just studying it from the Rocks

An icon. You can't miss it, it's huge and visible from far away. Great to take photos at it (from the harbour, opera ir from the ferry) and also to take photos of the city whole you are in the bridge. Great views all around. You can walk along the bridge for free. I don't recommend the bridge walk because it's quite overpriced and you can't even take your own photos. Go to the pylon lookout instead, it's much cheaper, you also get a good view all around, some info about the bridge and you can take your own photos as you please in you own time.

The lower level was just fine.. A nice place to get a great view of Sydney Harbor. We looked into the bridge climb option, but they were far too expensive for me to justify. It did look nice and if you want and adventure go for it. I'm sure it would even be better than the lower level. PS It is hard to find the entrance to the bridge walk. Keep asking every few hundred feet as there are many ways to get there and it's very confusing to find. Again, just ask directions often.
great. its so big and high, We claim up the bridge, the view is brilliant. But its hard working to get there,
Nice place to work. I occasionally work at the SHB and love the view. It is a very old bridge and important landmark for Sydney. Love it...

Good views. Free to walk over! Takes about 20 mins. Then you can take the ferry or train back. Stop off in Luna park for a couple of rides, especially at dusk - the ferris wheel gives some lovely views. You can walk up a pylon half way along the bridge.

Landmark Attraction of sydney. This is like the photo point where you would want to have your photo clicked. It just symbolizes Sydney after the opera house. There are hiking tours available where people walk on the top of the bridge, while we didn't do that, found it exciting if weather favors you.
Amazing structure. Interesting history. A must see up close for any Australian or tourist to Australia. Nice to see the structures that form our identity in reality.

Not as grand as I had imagined. Harbour Bridge is a must to visit although I couldn't help thinking it's not as grand as I imagined it would be. Forth rail bridge far bigger and imposing. Although we did enjoy our visit.
Great views. Awesome experience to walk over one of Australia's icons. Great to view from on the bridge then also the bridge from the ferry.
Beautiful Bridge. A beautiful bridge that can be seen from almost any place in Sydney. The structure is iconic and must be seen. If you the adventurous type, you can go and climb it too.

things u can do at sydney harbour. you can take a walk along the harbour...visit opera place...or simply sit on the lawns along the harbour and chill out with a glass of chilled white wine while you watch all the locals go crazy enjoying water sports .....awesome!!!

You've got to walk over the bridge!. Well....we walked over the bridge and drank in the view from this amazing location. Didn't go up the lookout but make sure you go and have a drink and a sit in the park at the other end and watch the harbour life go by.

Unique, exciting experience. We walked the bridge across and back. You walk on the right side. It looks like you can walk on the left but that is for bicycles. The trick is getting up on the bridge. You have to walk on the street from the rocks on the right side until you see the steps up. Just ask someone. During the walk, you can climb the first tower, for a fee, for a better view. It is a completely different experience at night, so try both.

Great walk in the evening, beautiful scenery. You can actually walk across the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge. Beautiful views at night! It is quite a long walk, so get comfortable shoes and bring some water. Very good exercise!!
View!. Sydney isn't Sydney without the Harbour Bridge. Go for a walk along the pathways along the harbour and sit on a chair just under the bridge.

Walking Over The Bridge. I walked over the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge. You can see the Opera House, the city, boats, beautiful water, people walking and running on the bridge, and vehicles whizzing by. The bridge is manned by security guards and cameras.
A great Sydney Icon!. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is a must for all that viist Sydney. It has a very interesting history and is much bigger than one would have thought.

Fabulous. We stayed with our daughter in Kirribilli, on the northern shore, for several weeks and frequently opted to walk across the bridge, to enjoy the lovely weather, get some gentle exercise and enjoy the terrific views from the bridge. Although not doing the 'climb' as it would be a little too strenuous for our aged limbs, I recommend every visitor do the crossing on foot at least once. There is a museum in one of the pylons, which we believe is interesting, but we didn't visit as it involves a climb up many stairs!

A must see.. While I didn't climb the bridge as it is a bit pricey, a visit to view the bridge is a must see on any trip to Sydney.Combine this attraction with a visit to the Sydney Opera House and the Botanic Gardens and you are in for a great day.Indulge in Harbour side fine dining or grab a take away sandwich or burger and sit on the grass.Don't forget to bring a camera!
Dare you ?. Well if I was twenty years younger I might have joined the brave few who did the bridge climb as it was I was happy enough to just walk across it
Beautiful Bridge. One of the most impressive bridges ive ever seen. A nice walk up and over it from the rocks. Great views of the harbour and opera house from the walkway no need to climb it.

Awesome,. Having seen it so many times in adverts books etc it was good to see the bridge for real, there is plenty of information available on its history as well as the opportunity to climb it as part of a group but this is quite expensive and not for those with a fear of heights.

This and The Opera House spell 'Sydney'. We did not climg the bridge like a lot of you did, but is awe inspiring to just look at it. Mighty by day and pretty by night. It, like the golden gate bridge in San Fransisco defines the city.

It looks just as good when you finally get here!. It has taken a long time to get to Sydney to view this fantastic bridge - we have a similar one back in Newcastle, England but a tad smaller! Also quite amusing to see the groups of people walking over the bridge - they looked like ants from afar. We sailed away on our cruise under the bridge and will forever remember the sights.
nice walk. Wonderful view up the harbour from the middle. This is a pleasant walk to do on a nice day. For an extension explore Kirribilli on the other side.

Great to walk across at night....did not go up on top. We opted not to pay the big bucks to climb up on top of the bridge. Instead, we simply walked across at dusk and early evening and the views were sensational. Once we got to the other side, we hopped on the streetcar to come back to our hotel in Sydney. Overall, a GREAT evening!!
bridge. It had a great view of the harbour. It was a nice walk to the bridge and also on the bridge but rather windy.
Amazing. Sydney Harbour bridge is one of attractive place in Australia.Design is great.Location is perfect.It's also beautiful bridge like America's Golden gate bridge.

The signature of the city. The Harbour Bridge or the Coat hanger, as the Aussies affectionately call it not only joins the Northern suburbs of Sydney to the downtown but also is a place of all festivities and celebrations. Fireworks from this bridge heralds the onset of New Year and those with good cardio-respiratory reserves dare to climb it too! The bridge carries pedestrians, cyclists, motorists, bus and train commuters and is an important lifeline to the posh northern suburbs. The photo opportunity both of the bridge and from the bridge of the Sydney harbor and the Opera House is fantastic. The general design was prepared by Dr J.J.C Bradfield and officers of the NSW Department of Public Works, while the detailed design and crucial erection process were undertaken by the contractors consulting engineer Mr (later Sir) Ralph Freeman of Sir Douglas Fox and Partners and his associate Mr. G.C Imbault. All this history and a lot more can be found out while visiting South Eastern Pylon for the bridge climbing. The collosal steel structure can also be seen from the plane as it circles the harbour before landing!

Special. Do like us and do the free walking tour, which goes underneath one of the on ramps to the bridge via the Rocks, then up to a great observation point to get a chance for some super pics of the bridge and opera house. This is a lot better value than doing the bridge walk for best part of $300.
Sydney Bridge. Very beautiful at night. Great view during the day especially when looking at it from a ferry or from the Royal Botanical Gardens.
Breathtaking!. Such an awesone sight! It was like seeing somebody famous! Took so many photos, I could print a book!
Nice walk. A must if you visit Sydney. Crossing the bridge on foot is free. But if you want to climb it, prepare your credit card

Maybe don't walk it?. You don't have to pay the exponential amount to climb this fantastic piece of architecture to fully enjoy it. In fact, being on it is nowhere near as impressive as looking at it from every other angle, be it port, Mrs Macquaires, or pretty much anywhere in Sydney.
Awesome views from an iconic structure. If you get the opportunity and are not afraid of heights walk the bridge....you won't be disappointed. Truly magnificent views.

Thank to NYE everyone knows it now. The fireworks on NYE have brought this wonderful bridge to everyone's notoce. Known to Sydneysiders as the "Coathanger" its great to stroll across. One of the Pylons is also open dailly to climb.
Great structure. You can see from circular quay and take a boat to Darling harbour to have a closure look at this great structure.In the nights it will be illuminated .

Sydney Harbour Bridge pylon lookout. As another option consider walking to the top of the bridge pylon above the Rocks. It has got to be a lot less scary the the other option. The view at the top is 360 degrees.Make your way up from the Rocks to the pedestrian walkway that crosses the bridge. You enter the pylon from this walkway.There are approximately 200 steps. There is a museum half way up, that is dedicated to the construction of the bridge.Extremely good value for young and old alike.

Pylon for the under 10's. We couldn't do the bridge climb because my daughter is under 10 yrs old however we did 'climb' inside the Pylon for a great view of the Harbour and surrounds.Well worth the effort for the great photo opportunities, cheap price too.

from south to north. syydney without crossing harbour bridge? no! maybe not to climb for everyone, but this is worth it! when you are on top after the long way over those endless steps, it will take your breath away!crossing it on foot is without any effort manageable, lots of folks and joggers around!

Cycle over and surrounding the bridge, cheaper way to admire the bridge. Cyclists or joggers shall try to cross the bridge. From Sydney side, left lane is for cyclists and rightest lane for joggers. Fine for using wrong lane, 500$.After that cycle down under the bridge and view different angel of operah house and Sydney

Walk across it, the best bridge and view in the world. You can walk across this , from one side of the harbour to the other, and its free. Perfect view of arguably the most famous modern building in the world - the Sydney Opera House. Great walk in the open air, look up the harbour and marvel at its beauty and get the train back into the city. If you are a tourist who has the use of your legs, walk over it. Most Sydneysiders haven't even done so which is astonishing given its probably one of the best natural views in the world - for free!

Save some money and walk across the path. We walked up the stairs from The Rocks then across the footpath to North Sydney. Great views of the opera house and east harbour and it's free. On the otherside walk down to Luna Park to catch the ferry back to Circular Quay.

It is a beauty!. Adding to the overall picturesqueness of Sydney Harbor, the bridge is a graceful addition. However the cost of climbing it was prohibitive for us, at $180 apiece! (And no cameras allowed.)

An excellent way to get across water. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is my favourite part of Sydney Harbour, always stealing my attention from the opera house. I haven't tried the bridge climb and don't know if I would, at the price they're charging. You can get great views by climbing the pylon, at a fraction of the cost (about $15 as opposed to $215). If you're seeing it for the first time then I would get the train to Milsons Point and walk across so you get to see the views from the bridge of the opera house. Then you can view the bridge when you get round to the Circular Quay area. Or, if you take a ferry to Manly, you get really good views of the whole lot. Do it on a sunny day and you'll get some good pictures. Oh yeah...and if you're lucky enough to be there on NYE then you get to see one of the best firework displays on the planet. I got a ticket to view them from Luna Park, near Milsons Point station and it was pretty incredible!

Iconic bridge. We did not want to climb the bridge, although we could see why people want to do it. The bridge can be seen all around the harbour area and I have taken lots of photos from many angles. Some of the best were taken from the top of the hop on bus and the Manly ferry.

real sydney. Just amazing, this is what Sydney means, such a good vibe around here. if you dont want to do the popular walk across the "coat hanger" you can walk along the flaty bit - but noisy with traffic but gives you a close up on just how magnificent the structure is.

priced NOT for the casual traveler. All excited to conquer my fears and go up the Sydney Harbour Bridge. We get there and it is $225 to do it. I just wanted to do the climb, not sleep over on it!!! What a disappointment. Also told us it takes 3 hours because of all the infor the tour guide gives, whew, that would have been too much info. Only good part is you can go into the museum for free and an excellent movie to watch and great info on the history of the bridge project. For 10% of that cost, we took the r/t ferry to Manly Beach and really enjoyed ourselves.

Great. Take the walk across the bridge.No charge Go up the supports for $10. The view is just as good as from the top of the bridge and a $100 + less.Then walk around Lavender Bay.Get the ferry back to circular Quay

You can't miss this one. There is in essence no way to escape it. As soon as you arrive at the harbour, you will see it. And you will make a lot of pictures, trust me. I wonder myself. There are many "nicer" bridges in the world, but this one "has it". Best is you take a ferry or a harbour cruise to view

Worth looking, walking, climbing, running over and under it ;. Great view of the Sydney harbour and the surroundings, great to run on, to take pictures of the Opera House and the surrounding harbour/saling area. Great to even run under it's main pylons during the night!Walk it. It's easy and a must!

Consider the pylon. We considered the bridge climb but considered it too expensive, we heard about the pylon which is part of the bridge only costs $11 each and takes up 89 metres over the bridge giving you similar views as from the top of the apex of the bridge. Interesting splays and an interesting film as you decend.

Views,views and more views.. From a boat trip under the bridge to a walk over it, it never fails to impress. At night, the lights give it a whole new dimension. Without paying for a climb, it is still possible to walk over the bridge deck, although my friend, who suffers from a fear of heights found that she couldn't do it, so we caught a taxi over instead. Ultimately it is just a bridge like any other, so it's a great job of marketing, Sydney!

Do the bridge walk. We did the bridge walk. The walk really isn't that far, around 30 minutes, then take the ferry between Circular Quay/Luna Park. The views are incredible and you really get an appreciation of the activity and beauty of the harbor.
WOW,WOW!. It is such a marvel....whether you walk it, climb it, or just admire it. We saw it as a cruise ship passed under it. It just sets a fabulous backdrop for the harbor.

Iconic, with fabulous views but oh so expensive for the climbs. This would have merited 5 stars from me without doubt, were it not for the extortionate cost of doing any of the actual climbs. You can see the pricing on their website. It is a beautiful construction (made in Middlesbrough, England and shipped over) and you can view it from numerous places especially the Opera House and some of the ferries. Day or night it is an awesome sight. What you can and indeed should do for free, is to walk across it. Allow reasonable time as you'll want plenty of photo stops. There is a dedicated footpath which shares the bridge with about 8 lanes of traffic, railway tracks, and a cycle path. You'll get fine views of the harbour including the Opera House, Circular Quay etc. Interestingly considering how exposed it is you still get a heady intake of exhaust fumes, but don't be put off by this.
