I was amused by the numerous security guards on duty, presumably to stop jumpers. I'd observe that you'd have to be pretty determined as the entire walkway is fringed with an arch of fencing that has a barbed wire dressing on top. Despite these last two points, I'd still award 5 stars were it not for the charges. Along with the Opera House this is a Sydney must-do.

Good workout. Walking across the bridge is a good work out and will take a while, but you can enjoy the lovely views. At the other side next to the theme park you can have an amazing view of the sydney ski-line and we also spotted a sting ray in the water :)
Amazing. What an experience walking over the sydney harbour bridge at sunset trying to dodge all of the joggers and taking amazing pictures of the scenery below including the opera house. Must do!
Iconic landmark. You cant miss it but just wander down to the opera house and get a coffee and chill out admiring this modern day masterpiece.In my opinion much better than the Opera House

Harbour Bridge. I see and travel on the Harbour Bridge often. It is an amazing bridge, an important Australian Landmark and a must see. If you can You should do a bridge walk everyone in Australia talks about how it was the best. You could also catch a boat /ferry around the harbour.

FREE walk across the bridge from Milson's Point train station. Walked across the harbour bridge from Milson's Point on the Opera House side and it was well worth the trip. Having lived in Sydney 10 years ago for 4 years the bridge is not a new sight for me but I'd never walked it. I chose this option after seeing the extraordinary cost of the official climbs though if I had an overflow of disposable $ or was a foreign tourist looking for an adventure I would probably splurge for a climb up high. Given the walk is free, not crowded, offers amazing views of Opera House, a docked cruise boat, the harbour, government house & Kirribilli you really must consider this activity as part of your trip or a fun & family friendly activity. Looks like some people have tried to start up the trend of placing locks on the safety wire installed, like the famous Parisian bridge but its not taken off and the random locks look a bit silly. The safety wire is also at an awkward eye sight height but you can peek through with effort for a clear view.I would top it off with an upmarket pub meal at the Glemore pub on the other side & a stroll around the Rocks & Circular Quay.
World famous. This bridge, now 80 years old is still in a great condition. The hotel we stayed in, had a view of the bridge from one of the windows

Stunning. We walked up the pylon as my youngest child was too young to walk over the top, but that gave us a fantastic view over the bridge and the history of the build of the bridge also. It included a short film about the building of the bridge which my children liked and helped them to understand its importance to the city. We wished we had gone on a train along the bridge too, but we simply ran out of time. Next time eh!

Friendly staff. I booked for two relatives to do the bridge climb. I'm giving them five stars because I mistakenly booked the 'discovery climb' and they were able to change it to the 'bridge climb' on the day of climb.Needless to say, my relatives enjoyed the climb.

gorgeous fantastic terrific unique pretty ! wowwwwwww walk !!!!!!!!. i walked back and forth like twice .so much i liked it. what a gorgeous view and between monddaine centre of sydney and elegant kirribilli area and north sydney business centre.really fantastci views to the opera house and supersafe with cameras ,fences and guards everywhere. so no way to jump hahareally an impressive building. just the fact that tey charge you like 20 us in case you wanted to climb up the pylon was kind of exaggerated, but then, you dont need to do it. the view is as nice on the bridge as from the pylon. really beautiful ! in case you want to take a train back, just on the other side is the milsons point train station which takes you back to sydney in 2 minutes.... fantastic !

Bridge Pilon views are great and best value. We considered the bridge walk but did the pilon instead and had wonderful 360 views from the top (and we could take pictures!). Much cheaper than doing the bridge climb and less strenuous, although there are lots of stairs still to climb

Go to the Lookout !. Take the time to seek out the "Pylon Look Out" it ia a lot cheaper than the Bridge Climb and offers historical information on the building of this Great Icon.Fantastic 360 degree view all over Sydney Harbour

Short of cash.... if you can't afford the bridge climb which is a truly incredible experience try visiting the pylons on the southern end of the bridge. For a much smaller fee you can see the history of the bridge inside the pylons and climb up the stairs to the viewing area. Not as good a view as from the top but still fantastic!
It's a bridge. It's a bridge that so happens to cross a harbour and gives a lovely backdrop for photographs. Cannot remember how much it costs to climb it but ultra expensive.

Incredible views. It is incredible weather you are on a ferry below it or doing the bridge climb on top of it the bridge is a focal point of the harbor and just stunning. Its beautiful during the day and just as amazing at night all lit up

There is a reason why this is a great tourist attraction. The Sydney harbour bridge provides great views of the harbour and an excellent view of the opera house. Climbing up the bridge is a must do, day or night it is a great experience.

Stunning. The bridge has to be seen in real life to be believed. It is breathtaking, elegant and an engineering masterpiece. If you have time, walk to the bridge on the footpath above the rocks and go into the South Eastern tower which is open to visitors - you'll get breathtaking views of the city from the top.

An awesome sight. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is an awesome sight from many vantage points. You can take a tour that goes right on the top of it. Our bike tour went halfway across it and back. It's part of Sydney's charm.

Walked, didn't climb. Just looking at it from Circular Quay was not enough. Within minutes of getting settled in our hotel room, I needed to walk across this famous structure. We had looked at the bridge climb, but after learning that we could not take our own pictures, I decided to walk across and take my own pictures. Well worth my time and effort. Besides, how many Yanks can say they walked across the Sydney Harbour Bridge?

It's just a bridge but...... Well, you go to Sydney and your thinking, so much for city life, what to do?Go to the circular key and take your pick however the harbour bridge is the icon. Forget the opera house, the pubs ( yes proper pubs!!!), the cafes, the gardens and parks - the bridge is the place for that perfect, never forget photo! You can climb it, take scared photos of people at the top, drive on it, walk on it etc. it's no golden gate, or forth rail bridge but its special, and its near the opera house and some pubs!,,

Never got tired of looking at it. Just so Iconic. We stepped off the plane and within 20 minutes we are standing at Circular Quay train station looking at The Sydney Harbour Bridge. It took my breath away..

An awesome sight where all tourists will not leave without a photo.. We say that dreaming is real good but seeing a place you've been dreaming to see is real magical.This is how I felt upon seeing the Sydney Harbour Bridge were I have had the best shot ever!! Me standing near the harbour with the Sydney Bridge as my background, real cool!!!

"Awesome". Walked to the bridge , but everything considered , the "Bridge Walk "was a tad expensive , so settled for the cheaper option of a walk inside the Portal, the view was every bit as dramatic , in my opinion a good choice .
Fantastic Harbour Bridge. We wish that we had such a stunning harbour bridge in Auckland like this the traffic runs well and the bridge in amazing
Good place for a run. Great place to run and see the city from high up, however stay sharp because tourists pay no attention while they are walking and you may run into a few.
Harbour Bridge. Beautiful to look at and provide great photo opportuities. A lot of people will climb it, but it's not for the feint of heart or pocketbook

Huge bridge. we were informed by some friends that to climb the bridge was expensive and to climb the pylon instead. we checked the price and it was dear so decided to climb the pylon instead. we were not disappointed, we could see the bridge climbers and a very similar view which was incredible. the sydney opera house looked small from that side of the harbour. you can also walk along the pedestrianised walkway, where there are many joggers.

Stellar views, excellent way to spend a morning.... The Sydney Harbor Bridge is such a beautiful landmark. What better way to spend a morning than to walk across it? We got an early start, parking in The Rocks area, which is also beautiful and we walked up to the bridge entrance and embarked on a tour of the bridge itself. For the adventurous, check out the Bridge Climb outfit, that gives you full mountain climbing gear and walkie-talkies and allows you to literally climb onto the bridge structure (takes like 3 hours). We stuck to the pedestrian walkway. The views are just stunning! Looking back at Sydney Harbor and all of the other landmarks such as the Opera House is great. Wonderful photo opportunities abound. The bridge is just a few years older than the San Francisco Golden Gate Bridge, and the walk is lovely but I was missing the unimpeded views from San Francisco, since the GG Bridge does not have a "cage" surrounding the walkway. And yes, more people jump for that reason. At Sydney, the walkway is almost surrounded by fencing, but they do at least leave a little space open to look and take pictures. Since the bridge is beautiful it is a must-do activity to walk it when in Sydney. We were a bit too early to enter the pylon to go to the top of the support for even better views. But note that, like most things in Sydney, this is a for-fee part of the bridge - costing $11/adult. It opens at 10am.

A worthwhile reason for a walk. I would not classify the Sydney Harbour Bridge as a must do activity while in Sydney (it is a walk across a bridge). Certainly, there are great views but you will be constantly reminded of the nearby traffic. The more interesting walks are on either side of the bridge. There is a bridge climb that we did not do (it is quite expensive). We also did not do the tower near the middle of the bridge that also charges a fee.

Best bridge in the world. Every time I see a picture of this bridge it only makes me smile. I love walking along the bridge to get the views of the harbour in both the day and night and to just look at the bridge itself is amazing. The architecture and story behind the bridge is worth exploring to have a greater feel. It is great in the evening to sit across the bridge with a coffee and just take in the view and people watching is great fun.
Fantastic to see. Was really excited to see the Bridge, and wasn't disappointed. We walked across it - great views. Big climb to get up to it from the Rocks.

Walk it, you'd enjoy the exercise. Our hotel was next to the Sydney Harbour Bridge, so visiting it was a must. At first we were lost in how to get to the level to walk across it. But after several minutes we found our way and off we went. The walk across the bridge is amazing. The view of each side of the harbor is beautiful. If I wasn't tired due to lack of any sleep the night before, I would have asked my partner that we explore the other side of harbor. We considered doing the Bridge Climb, but I am glad we walked across instead. Being tired, I would not have lasted the bridge climb. But this was a better choice. Beautiful views and it's free.
Awesome sight to see.. Awesome sight to see and there were peoople that went on the walking tour and went up to the top. Not something I do because of bad knees, it is to hard for me to climb
Out & About in Sydney. Its an amazing sight, and you can take it all in, if you go over the bridge itself, youll have some amazing views.

Iconic Bridge - the "Coat Hanger". This is one of the world's most famous bridges and makes a great photo from any angle. You can spend a lot of money (about $300 last time I was there) to climb up to the top, but you are not allowed to take cameras or anything else with you, and there are no restrooms at the top - the round trip takes about 3 hours or more. As a keen photographer I used it as the backdrop for numerous photos of other vistas.
Sydney Icon. The bridge dominates Sydney's harbor, and it and the Opera House are Sydney's icons. Walk onto it and under it for fabulous views of downtown Sydney and the harbor.

By far one of the most beautiful bridges in the world!. The bridge climb is supposed to be incredible. family members have done it on previous occasions and rave about it. My wife and I just climbed the 200 steps to the pillar. The price was very affordable and the views incredible! This is an absolute must do for any visit to Sydney.If you have trouble with steps, at least take the walk to the bottom of the pillar. this will put you on the bridge itself, which affords very good views of the city. The walkway is very safe and separate from the traffic areas.

Imposing. It seems to me that the Opera House gets all the limelight but I think the bridge is by far the better structure and you really need to walk right down to the Piers on the road to see the sheer scale of it.The only bad point is the cot to do the walk up to the top of the steel structure - it was just so expensive and even though I'd spent $550 on helicopter trips whilst travelling, I was not going to pay the ridiculous amount they were asking just to climb up - Sydney - sort it out!I also found it a bit alarming that were guards on the roadway as you walk over the bridge (yes this bit is free to do) presumably there to stop suicide attempts?

Wow, what a hight!. We didn't end up doing the bridge climb (too expensive for a family of 4), but went inside the pilar and climbed the 200 steps, which to me was super worth it. The views are amazing even from up there and still affordable!
Under and over the Bridge - spectacular. My husband and I didn't have the courage to do the Bridge climb but would recommend it to anyone who was considering an extremely spectacular experience

Awe inspiring. A repeat visit to simply look this time but we have climbed it. The organisation is so safety conscious you need not have any worries and the exhilaration on getting to the top will bring a grin to your face. Just hope for good weather.
Great Views. Walk across it in both day and night you will get a great view twice! There's a train on the other side of the bridge so you can just ride it back if you don't feel like walking.

You don't have to do the Bridge Climb to get a good view!. Walk across it from either North Sydney or the Rocks. The walking path is on the side that gives you the view of the Opera House. If you are cycling, you'll get the view of the other side of Sydney. I did both ... cycling from The Rocks to Luna Park and return. Locked up my bike, then walked half way to get the breathtaking views of the harbour and the Opera House.

great to see. didn't do the walk over the bridge tour, but went for a look while on a bus tour around the area. What an amazing bridge, it's huge.the way the convicts cut the rock out and around is amazingworth a look and if you are game do the whole tour
An Aussie Icon. Awesome Australian icon that is a must see for local and foriegn tourists alike. Great place to grab a snapshot just to proove that you have been there!
Really worth the money. Good and interesting museum explaining the history of the construction of the bridge, and furthermore nice views from the hight.
great walk, even on misty days!. We loved the walk across the bridge, and enjoyed the view from the bridge. It was nice to see the views of the water, the architecture, and so on...

Good walk, great views. Walking on the Sydney Harbour bridge is a good experience. One can see the Opera House, the water views and the city and it does not cost anything. The traffic can be noisy and distracting but it is easy to ignore and concentrate on the views. I am glad that we made the effort to walk it.

Walk across Sydney Harbour Bridge!. I initially wanted to do the bridge climb but when I found out you could just walk across the bridge, I opted for that instead. Much easier and a great experience too! And it's free.You can get onto the bridge from the area near the Circular Quay and walk across on the pedestrian walkway, stopping to take photos along the way. The Opera House will be on your right as you head across from the Circular Quay area. Once across, you could either walk back or head to your left toward Luna Park where you can catch a ferry to Darling Harbour if you'd like.If you have the time, I would definitely recommend walking across the bridge!

Iconic Bridge. Reminds me of Newcastle on Tyne and the Tyne Bridge but bigger!! Stunning views from the bridge walk and right opposite the Opera House - must be one of the most lovely views in the world
Looks good and can cycle and walk. it looks great. the fact that you can walk and cycle on it makes it better than the Auckland harbour bridge. the train goes through it too

Most windy bridge!. The Sydney bridge is very nice and still well maintained.
There is an offer to climb it but the price for it is only for wealthy people! What a pity! Walking the bridge is a unique experience, even though it can be very very windy and a bit loud.
In any case we enjoyed it a lot.

A must see in Sydney. The Harbor and the Bridge are definite must see's when visiting Sydney, I found some helpful info for planning my visit to this area at www.thesydneyharborbridge.com (and also found the history and facts really interesting). Climb the bridge and visit the Pylon lookout, you won't be disappointed!

Just walk over. We did not do the up and over walk on the bridge just strolled over the footpath surprising how long it is as you go over, security guards onit are happy to chat, and had lovely view of the Opera House and harbour, there is also a view point from the tower but rather a lot of stairs to climb for us , but was told that was worth doing and not as expensive as the other climb.

Classic. Well maintained and the color itself gives the classic look. Never had the guts to do the bridge climb though. Wonderful view if you take the ferry and go pass under the bridge. The bridge can also be perfectly viewed as you have dinner at Circular Quay or Darling Harbour.

A city's icon - worth a visit. A walk across the bridge is always spectacular. You can walk up from The Rocks or get off the train at Milsons point station and make a one way trip into The Rocks. It you have time stop and walk up the pylon

Great walk. Great walk at dusk. Looked like a Richard Scarry illustration. Boats passing by below, flashes of photographers on the shore, trains and cars whooshing past, sunset, nightlife coming out...

Nice Bridge. Since we live in the general vicinity of the Verrazano Narrows Bridge in New York and have seen various other bridges around the world, I was not particularly impressed with the Sydney Harbour Bridge. That is not to say that there is anything wrong with it. I, like all other tourists, took many pictures of it, especially on Australia day with the flags flying. It is probably spectacular on New Years Eve with the fireworks.

nice walk. fantastic walk fantastic views of harbour and opera house the bridge climb is very dare and no cameras are aloud so recommend the walk over bridge some lovely homes on the other side took some great photos highly recommend
Must do at Night. It's free to walk across. I went at night and got some amazing pictures of the harbour and the opera house. I used the ledge as a tripod and got some amazing photos!
A must do. This was such an amazing experience. If you visit Sydney it is definitely a must do. Quite daunting to start off with but once you are up onto the main arch really great.

This is still better than the Opera House. Of the 2 landmarks in Sydney I still prefer this old bridge. From a distance and up close it is worth looking at. Drive down below and look up at it, go under it on a ferry or even climb to the top it is amazing from all angles.
Ageing Grace. They call her the Coat Hanger. Beautiful and timeless. A must see for every tourist. Stand and admire her or take the walk to the top. Another world wide recognised icon.

Bridge and Tower views. On our 2nd trip to Sydney, we took our visiting family to walk across the bridge and see the views of the harbour. It is always fascinating to get out on the bridge and see all the traffic that goes back and forth. Walking across the bridge is free - climbing it is not. Save your money and walk it then go to the Pylon Tower and pay the $11 to climb up the stairs to the top where you will have awesome views of the city and harbour. A local told us about this after I was afraid to do the bridge climb. They were right on the money. The Pylon Tower has all of the history of the making of the Sydney Harbour Bridge. From how much money was spent, to how long it took and crazy photos of the brave men who risked their life everyday just going to work on the bridge. There is a gift shop and restrooms close to the top of the tower too. If you feel you can't make it to the top, there is some history and also a short 6-8 minute film when you get to the entry area to watch for free. Enjoy the views at the top of the tower if you climb all the way. It's great!

Sydney Harbour Bridge Tower. What a fantastic experience we had on our Christmas Holidays. We walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge on the most beautiful hot summers day. Followed by climbing the tower to see even a better view of Sydney watched a informative moving on the construction and opening of the Bridge in 1932. The kids just loved the whole experience and I thought the view was breathtaking. One of the most fantastic things I have done. I have been to Sydney so many times and travelled by car over the bridge often but the pleasure I received from our venture today was truly great.

Great view, worth the walk. Walked across the bridge during afternoon, the view out over the harbour is fantastic, great views of Opera House etc as well.Not so good for photos of your or your friends as the security fence impedes on the background.
An hour's walk across the bridge.. Avoided the Bridge climb and walked across the main bridge. stunning views at no cost. Do this if you don't like heights.

Save your money, walk the bridge. Not wanting to spend $500 to walk OVER the bridge, we just walked across the bridge at dawn, free. The pedestrian walkway is on the east side of the bridge which we accessed from a staircase down at street level in the Rocks. The view of the harbor and Opera House is outstanding.
Bridge Tower. paid 11.00 to go into and up the bridge tower, great view from both sides and historical information during the stair climb. Missed the bridge climb due to time.

The coat hanger. I come from the western side of Australia and we have nothing like this. Driving over this bridge was the highlight of my trip to the other side of the country. Great views can be had from any side of the harbour

Amazing piece of engineering. The Sydney Bridge is amazing in many ways. When you tour around by bus, car or cruise it keeps appearing in unexpected places. It really is incredible. It is also a very advanced system for drivers with a dashboard gizmo to take your toll money so that there are no traffic jams. You also cross it on the train.

Yay, a bridge!. I am not trying to be a downer but there is nothing special about this bridge. Suprisingly they charge you a ridiculously high price to climb up to the top and see the city from the same view as any local hotel room. Save your money and just go look at it from the bottom.
Bigger than life.. The bridge over shadows the bay area. Be sure to take a walk across to get the views from the bridge.
what a view. we had the most sensational view for Free !! great walk across and back --with the freedom to take photos and enjoy the view at our leisure

awesome. its one of the most important landmark of the city and its just awesome. tghe view from the ferry was amazing and in the night it looks even much better. v went to d bridge but it was all fenced so no point going ther .
Walk about. Time to take in atmosphere. There is a lot to see on foot. I hear the bridge climb is an awesome experience (I have height issues)
walk across for great views of opera house. We strolled across and back. a Bit windy, but worth it for the great shots of the opera house we got from the bridge.

Worth a visit even if you're short on time!. If you have time then I'd go for a walk over the top with the organisation who run daily trips but if like me you don't have the time then just going for a walk along the bridge and getting some snaps is a lovely way to spend an hour or so in sydney. One of those must do things whilst on you're visit to the city!
An other. thing you can't miss when you are in Sydney is this amazing bridge. From some spots, just to the right of Opera House (looking to the north), you can have a picture from both!!

See the world's biggest coat hanger. That's the nickname - coat hanger. huge structure and iconic. beautiful. float under it on a Ferry (i'm not sure harbour cruises are worth the $ unless you want to eat while cruising, as i've mentioned in other reviews - would've preferred an informative cruise). climb up the pylon lookout for just $11, and do the bridge climb if you have $ to spare (over 1 million people have done it)

Wortht the walk. On Australia day I walked the bridge. It was spectacular. The ferry's, tall ships & spectator craft were leaving circular quay to position themselves in readiness for the ferry race. No doubt this is a must do walk for visitors & residents of Sydney.

Awesome. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the most efficient bridges I have ever seen. It has multiple traffic lanes along with a train, dedicated bus lanes, pedestrian and bike lanes. It is also one of the attractions that Sydney Harbour can brag about.

" NICE VIEW". This was my first time in sydney, have always seen the bridge on Tv. I got a chance to watched the fireworks on new years eve from campbell cove and wanted to see the bridge up close. It takes a little walk just to get to the bridge but once there perfect view of the harbor & Opera house.

Don't miss!. When my wife suggested walking across the bridge, I couldn't think of anything worse - traffic, fumes and noise, but I am so glad I went. Make sure you pick a clear, sunny day because the views of the city, Circular Quay, the Opera House etc are stunning. Certainly the best place to take pictures of the Opera House. We were not keen to do the climb, neither of us were brave enough, but we did climb the Observation Pylon. Well worth the $11 each with fantastic views of the whole harbour, as well as a bit of history on how and why the bridge was built.

Go up the pylon; great photo opts of Opera House.. The walk of the Sydney Harbour Bridge is a must. The Bridge Climb may appear a little expensive, especially when you cannot even take pictures with your camera (which you must leave in a locker). The Pylon closest to the Opera House has stairs and, for a much smaller price, one is able to go to the top. This vantage is much higher than the bridge level. Worth the climb and the price.

Don't miss it. Although I did the Bridge Climb several years ago and would definitely recommend it, this time I chose to walk across the pedestrian footpath to the other side and back. The views are fantastic and I have some wonderful photos to cherish.

Another great Sydney Icon. This is great to drive over, catch the train over, or if your adventurous enough you can climb it.everyone who visits sydney should atleast experience this one way or another.
Don't miss the museum. We didn't want to climb the bridge but we wanted to learn about it so went to the museum. It has an excellent display and very good film of its building.

majestic. We have yet to take the bridge walk. We heard that was excellent. However, we have driven through this bridge many a time. It is still feels wonderful, and you can take a glimpse at the harbour and opera house, dependong on which direcrion you are coming from

#1 Free thing to do in Sydney!. Sydney is not an inexpensive city - but not every experience has to cost a fortune. My #1 recommendation is to walk the Sydney Harbor Bridge. We started at Milson's Point - a short walk or train ride from North Sydney - up 60 steps to bridge's well enclosed walking path. On a nice afternoon the path is packed with tourists, walking commuters, and people of all ages out for stroll. On the Milson's Point side, the walk first overlooks parks and trees, and then, of course, the Harbor. The view is spectacular... the Opera House, of course, ferries, and we went, a huge ocean liner pulling into Circular Quay. The walk over the bridge is not long at all - maybe 20 minutes. On the other side, you land at The Rocks - the drop off point of the original convict settlers. It is an easy walk to the many Rocks dining spots, down to Circular Quay for Ice Cream, trains, ferries, or buses to continue your Sydney exploration.

Wonderful sight!. So iconic. And fascinating to watch all the tourists tripsing up and over the top of the bridge. You can't beat deep blue sky, Sydney Harbour, the Opera House and the Bridge all in one sweep!

Climbed it and walked over it.. The bridge is the most amazing man made structure to walk over or to climb. If coming from North Sydney by train, get off at Milsons point and walk over to the other side. Terrrific views and all for free!
bridge walk. Do the bridge climb & pylon climb. Both are great! We also walked across the bridge one evening to Luna Park (lovely old-fashioned amusement park). Nice views from mid-bridge.
Not just for a bridge climb. You can walk over the bridge for free and get almost the same views as the bridge climb. THere is also a an optional climb up one of the towers (for a fee)

Sydney. The Sydney Harbour Bridge, fly over it, walk next to it ,go under it (on a ferry) drive on it, catch a train on it, or better yet climb it. You cant go to Sydney and not do one or all those things.

walk across!. Looks nice from far. It's massive close up. It took about 15 min to walk across, fantastic views. One of the pylons also has a look out and museum. If you don't climb, walk is a must do.

Australian icon. I waled the leangth and breath of the brided and can say its great but greater still if you can book the tour to walk ABOBE the gridge. So scary, thrillling, wonderous, awesome, mind testing and just palin must do. Its safe and well run and the feeling unbelievable.At both ends of the bridge are facinating gardens/ parks and walks. The City side offers Obesevatory park and a very pleasnat tea house. Great just to soak in the atmosphere and see poele relax and children play.The Northshore end is more interesting with paths around the small coves making upsydney harbour but alos LUNA PARK. Just a great well maintained fun fair!!!Plenty of cheap eating ares and good cofee aboundsA good half day can be spent exploring the bridge area and get the feel of the country.

Beautiful. This very impressive structure is beautiful to look at from all angles.We walked across the bridge and back and it was an exciting experience. Not only do tourists walk the bridge, but locals use it to get about, jog and walk their dogs. We watched the more athletic types going on their climb of the bridge, which I am sure is something they will never forget. The views of the harbour and the Opera house from the bridge are absolutely outstanding and make for wonderful photo ops. I was quite entranced with the bridge and it really is such an emblematic feature of the city of Sydney.
Sydney must do. View from the top is dazzling and delightful. Spent many hours on different days just appreciating the beauty of the Bridge and the surroundings.

Sydney Harbour Fire Works New Year 2013. A tick on the bucket list ! Stayed at hotel very close to Darling Harbour - 2 days before dropped into the Darling harbour information centre. Enquired about location to watch the fire works - decided to take a cruise on a captain cook boat to view the harbour fireworks. At the time thought the expense was high ($299 per person) but found out later this was one of the cheaper options ! It was one of those experiences that " you had paid the huge costs to fly from NZ, stay close in an overpriced hotel - but just had to see the fireworks from the best spot" Amazing a must do - the harbour was dotted with festival lighted boats - we seen all of the harbour highlights and of course the fireworks. Easy walk back to hotel, took our own nibbles and drinks served on board. A new years to be treasured - another must do !!!

Give the Coathanger a Go!. A must do in Sydney - either a Bridge Climb: amazing! Or a simple walk across and maybe back from Milsons Point (trains, ferries are available). Just do it - the views are stunning both ways and the history of the Coathanger is simply fabulous!

Very scenic sight to see!. The bridge is very impressive when you're up close and personal to it. Skip the expensive bridge walk. You can take in plenty from the ground. Definitely need to see this while in Sydney!
Best of the Best!!. A brilliant place to have a walk with your girl/boyfriend!! A beautiful view with the breezing view. So enjoying! Never miss this stop when visiting in Australia!
An Up Close View. See and cruise underneath the Harbour Bridge by taking a boat cruise with a full description and narration during the boat tour.

Don't miss it. Fantastic harbor views, beautiful experience and easy to climb up. This is my third time on the bridge, and the first for my wife. Even if was my third time, I just loved it again. You start down below, where the metal meets the concrete and stone, in the shade, where you can still see the faces of the people in the street looking up to you walking under the bridge and anyway above their heads. Then a series of ladders, suspended in the void, with the water below and the sky above. You reach the arch, and you start walking up. The ascent is not so difficult, easy most of the time, now you are far from the streets, people are just small indistinguishable faces, the cars below are small too, nothing above you anymore and around you can see the entire harbor. The opera house, circular Quay, Taoranga, the sail boats, the ferry moving around. It's just fantastic. We were lucky, the day was glorious, the sun perfect and the breeze refreshing. A must do in Sydney.

I am 30 and from Brisbane but love this bridge every time I see it. It's an awesome man made creation Brisbane does not have the same scale bridge It's just a cool "must see" when in Brisbane The history behind it is interesting as well

Walk across the bridge. We walked across the bridge. It was a wonderful view of the harbour and its a magnificent bridge, great to see it up close. To get up to the walkway level there is a glass elevator at one end of circular quay or there are stairs in the rocks area. Once across the bridge we walked to Luna Park and caught the ferry back to circular quay.

Can't Miss It Because It's There. Missing walking under SHB is like passing up breathing. A walk across the bridge is good for the heart and legs and easy to do. The views are fantastic and you can always catch a train back into the city.

Sydney Harbour Bridge - Take a walk across. A beautiful sight. We walked across which gave a wonderful view of the harbour and surrounding areas. On the other side we walked around and found a ferry to take back. You can also climb the bridge if you are adventurous but it is very expensive.

a great walk. We didnt do the official walk where you climb on the bridge, however we did our own walk over the bridge. The views of the city are lovely and there are some great spots over the other side.

separates North from South. the bridge is 5 min walk from my place, and I walk it everytime i want to go to the city, it's a 15 to 20 min walk and is awesome. you get the best view and fresh air from the middle of the bridge and you meet a lot of people on the way.

We climbed it!. I never tired of seeing the bridge as we travelling back and forth daily on the ferry from Circular Quay to the north shore. Taking photos at every angle in the varying light of the day, either from the ferry or an open top bus. Then I surprised my husband for his 50th birthday and treated him to the Bridge Climb. Have to mention the NYE fireworks too, we were there to see in 2013 and saw it lit up in all its glory!

horrible industrial architecture that should have been replaced decades ago. ugly, poor on function, dominant position ... all round yuk!They could use their economic strength to put up a beautiful bridge such as the many in France.
Visit this icon! It's a must. Walk over it, across it, sail under it or just watch it from any vantage point in the Harbour. Just beautiful!
Beautiful. The Harbour Bridge is an unique landmark of Sydney and it is a must of visitor to see. The nearby scenery is very good too.

An excellent view of both sides of the harbour. The walk across Sydney Harbour Bridge is a great addition to a good sightseeing day in and around Sydney. The total length of the bridge is around 1.1 km so it's an easy walk for the most part. While on the bridge you get an excellent view of the entire harbour, and if walking from south to north, looking back, you get an outstanding view of the Opera House and the Sydney skyline in the background. The first several hundred metres of the bridge has small steel beams that may get in the way of the perfect picture, but mid-way it opens up much more. On the either side of the bridge you can climb up to the top of one of the pylons (about 200 stairs) and it gives you a great vantage point of the harbour. If you're feeling up to it, you can do the bridge climb for around $200 Aus dollars. Overall a great walk with some spectacular views!

Awesome views. Great views for free! You can do the 'guided' walk which takes you up on the top of the spans but the free one along the side is probably just as good and doesn't cost $212/pp. No wonder there are only pictures of movie and rock stars on the guided one!
Best view of Sydney!. Lovely to walk across, and there's a look out (a bit pricey but worth it) - you get the best view of the Harbour from here!
Sydney Landmark. Very popular for doing the Bridge climb. Historic landmark which is great on New Years Eve with the fireworks display

Walk on the Bridge. If you are on the CBD side of Sydney Harbour, North Sydney may seem like a long way away. But a walk on the Sydney Bridge is definitely worth it, even if you only go half way. the views are incredible. Just stick your camera between the fencing and use a little "telephoto." making it all the way across is actually pretty easy, and there are some nice little restaurants in Kirribilli. I'd stay away from Luna Park unless you're nostalgic for a poor man's version of Coney Island. If you're pooped from walking, you can take the bus or train or ferry back to the CBD.

Amazing bridge. I did not do the climb but even without that I can appreciate what an amazing feature of the city this bridge is. The bridge majestically spans the harbour and is an awesome sight from close up and from the sea.If you have the courage I think the climb must be quite amazing experience. The climb will cost you AUS$198 This bridge came alive with fireworks on New Years Eve and it was one of the most exciting experiences ever.

What views from the bridge !. We didn't do the walking over the top of the bridge, instead opting for the simple walk straight over - but which ever you do - the views were stunning. However, once you have walked over, don't expect anything on the other side, you need to turn around and walk back, but it's something that has to be done. A lovely way to see some spectacular views.

Joining two worlds. The best way to cross the bridge is over the arch on a bridge climb, but that's rather expensive. We enjoy walking across at road level because the difference between the CBD and North Sydney is so marked.
Great walk and views. Not a lot to say, just do it! Brilliant attraction! The kitting-up process takes longer than expected, but otherwise well worth the time and effort.
Simply wow!. Great walk, panoramic views of the harbour, the Opera and the city line. A must for every visit in Sydney.
A True Icon. The sheer scale, history and atmosphere of the bridge are simply stunning. A must see 'up close' to encounter it fully. Just wonderful.

A Good place to see Sydney 360.. A hike up to the bridge was not too long. We did not take the stairs up to the bridge, but rather the elevator from the harbor up to street level and then walk to the bridge. You really don't need to walk the whole length of the bridge. Only go half way and you will get a very good view of the harbor and Sydney. It is a fun thing to do, and recommend it

A Bridge too far.. Its certainly a major focial point from anywhere in the city commonly known as the coat hanger for obvious reasons. We went over and under it quite a few times and watched people walking over the very top. At the end of the day a bridge is a bridge

No words. A must for everyone, even locals- especially on a perfect day we had. Take a walk from the Opera House to the Bridge. Enjoy a drink & food at the many restaurants that sit on this gorgeous harbour.

You have to go on the bridge. Well, it's the Sydney Harbour Bridge!The views from the bridge over the water and harbours is great.You can pay to go up one of the towers to take a view from up a little higher, this is probably better for taking photographs.You can also walk on the top of the bridge structure itself by taking an organised tour/walk.I'd recommend taking in the bridge whilst in Sydney, it's iconic!

One day I will climb it. I seem to end up in Sydney with no time to climb the bridge, so find myself taking a large number of photos of this bridge each time from below. Take the time to climb it, I have heard that it is amazing, but it is great just looking at up it from various different locations.... the shore, the rocks, the harbour on a ferry.

Great architectural achivement. Coming from Sydney, I take the bridge for granted a bit... but having travelled the world I do appreciate it. Best of all - it's free... well, to walk across it (not up) or view anyway! Climbing to the top is apparently very expensive but friends who have done it say it's well worth it.
climb it. do the bridge climb - it was a lifetime experience and worth every penny! The views from the pylon lookout are well worth the effort to climb the 200 steps too.

Walk the Bridge!. Great walk across the Bridge, even if the traffic noise is somewhat deafening. Difficult to find the access from The Rocks end but the frustration was worth it, and you can take the train back from the other side!
Great views and its free!. We walked along the walking lane of the bridge and got the train but in time to see the sun set- just magic!
Walk it or climb. This must be one fo the best bridges in te world and you can work up the courage to climb to the top if you have the money or just walk across and view the harbour and opera house
Not much to see. Not much to see here except some of the best pictures of the opera house. A little boring for kids. We did have a great view of the cruise ships leaving sydney

wow! amazing!. What a great experience to walk on this amazing bridge and look down to the city harbour and the surroundings. It was really stunning view in Summer. We couldn't dare to take the risk to walk over the bridge. The fact that it is very pricy is one thing but we actually can't stand the heights!..Those who have kids and others who have fare of heights have to be careful!

Walk it for free. Walked across the Bridge without having to take the expensive tour across "The Coathanger" which has to be booked ahead of time, non refundable and alot of rules. If you want to go higher, take a tour with Sydney Helitours which seriously worth it.
Harbour Bridge. The kids always enjoy walking across the bridge, and then picnicing on the water front watching the boats is wonderful.
Magnificent. The bridge for me is Sydney. Walk across it on the Opera House side and climb the turrets for the view $11 adults Jan 2013

The 'Coat Hanger'. I personally have a fascination of bridges with this one being no exception. The views that are afforded whether, walking, driving or taking a train, are in deed memorable from all angles. From a distance 'she' looks peaceful almost, majestic,across the waters that are Sydney Harbour Bay. Well worth time spent walking across; to get the full 'picture' of not only the stunning views however to realize also the praticality of such a bridge to this vibrant city.

Walk across the bridge a must. Walked across the bridge for the first time in years and can recommend it. The walk only takes about15 minutes one way, at a relaxing pace and the views are spectacular. A great alternative if you don't like heights or can't afford a Bridge climb. We walked across into The Rocks and then had lunch at one of the Pubs there. Caught a ferry home. A cheap and fun day out in Sydney.

Catch a view of the harbour and Opera House from the bridge. Walking on the bridge is like walking on any other bridge, but you're able to catch great photos of the Opera House and the harbour from the bridge.

Iconic. This iconic bridge really does make Sydney. We did a daytime climb which was great even in the drizzly rain. The views were spectacular. If you eat near circular quay you can have a front row seat of the bridge lit up. Fantastic

On the low side. We walked across the bridge, on the low side. We went up in the bridge observation area that had a pretty cool history of the bridge. We didn't do the high bridge walk partly as we were a bit freaked out but also due to the cost of 300.00 and the amount of time it takes. You can still enjoy the bridge on the cheap by walking across the pedestrian area and paying 11.00 to go to the observation area.
Awesome sailing beneath it!. It was fantastic sailing beneath it on the Pacific Jewel (with 6m to spare!). My friend Tania had just walked across it the previous day :)
if you not afraid of height. try to walk across the bridge,it is so beautiful to view the sydney harbour from the top of the bridge.

Noisy but spectacular. We are in our mid to upper 60's and we walked all the way across the bridge from Circular Quay. Then we walked to a garden area on the other side of the bridge. Then walked all the way back and watched a cruise ship sail under the bridge and head out to sea. The noise from the vehicles is quite loud, but the walk was wonderful and the walkway is separate from the vehicle traffic.

NYE fireworks over Harbour Bridge. OMG - everyone should experience this at sometime in their lives. Wouldn't have missed it for the world. We were lucky enough to get free tickets for the Cahill Expressway. The view was out of this world.

Train, car or walk. Wether you catch a train across, drive, walk or view from afar it's impressive to see. For the best experience though go on a Bridge Walk and see Sydney from the best viewpoint in town.
New year right here!. If you ever want to celebrate the New Year this is the only place to be, absolutely fantastic, the best fireworks display ever !! Sooo much fun Ozzie style!

Fantastic from every angle - A Daily Delight. I walked across the bridge daily for 3 years when I lived in Kirribilli and now that I live out in the North West I travel on it daily on the Bus. I love it!, It is picturesque and functional, many years ahead of it's time when it was built.
Iconic structure. As good as I had been led to believe. Dominates the harbour yet complements its natural beauty. Well maintained icon of Australian culture
View to die for!. My husband and I walked the harbour bridge on dusk which had the most amzing views. This is a must I think everyone should have added to their bucket list!

Take a walk across and enjoy the amazing views.. While it is wonderful to walk around the hoarbour and catch ferries to see the Harbour Bridge taking a walk across is so worth doing. You can access the bridge from either The Rocks or North Sydney. Its much cheaper than doing the Bridge Climb and the views are still amazing. We usually walk both ways but you can walk one way and catch the train to North Sydney or catch it back to The Rocks from there. On a Saturday morning you migh be lucky to catch street markets at both ends.
Iconic Landmark. Brilliant, stunning backdrop to Sydney Harbour, get best shots from near the opera house and Mrs Macquaries seat in the botanic gardens, also get good photos from the Manly Ferry
Breathtaking bridge. This elegant work of art graces the harbor like a tiara. It's ironwork is intricate and very Victorian, it arch graceful. Unbelievably beautiful structure.

A Must See Day & Night. I have been twice and it never ceases to amaze me. I've walked it, climbed it, and toured the grounds around both ends. It is an amazing structure. Stay at the Harborview Hotel to get the best view of the bridge with the Opera house in the background. You'll also have easy access to trains and the downtown areas. The Rocks(shopping) are just to the Southeast. There are loads of other attractions nearby as well. These include the aquarium and the wharf. You can also cath a ferry to a number of spots on the bay below the bridge. Stay near the bridge if you go. It's breathtaking, historic, offers access and transportation, and can save you $ vs. staying downtown.
Always awesome. No matter whether it's looking at the bridge from the ferry, the Rocks, the Opera House or Circular Quay... it's great and the kids loved it when ever they saw it.

Cool bridge. I cycled across this bridge and I must say the designer/architect
Behind this is really cool! An engineering feat and this bridge is really one of the top best bridges in history!

WHAT A SIGHT. Every time we drive past or go over the bridge I am in AWE. This makes the harbour. We had dinner at a resturant at the Rocks and through some miracle got the best seat in the house, on the corner of the verandah overlooking the harbour, bridge and opera house. How lucky were we!
Geat sights and impressive structure. What to say about the most photographed Sydney icon? Imposing structure. Good views from car or train (used both to get across). Even impressive from below.

C'mon, Mate, get your Walking Shoes On. I have walked the Harbour Bridge on every visit to Sydney, and will do it again next time I'm there. It's that good.I usually start in The Rocks. This time, I started at Circular Quay, took the elevator up to the street level overhead, and walked straightaway to the bridge from there. It was actually easier that way than finding the entry from The Rocks. The bridge itself is a bit of an architectural masterpiece - the longest steel arch in the world, or something like that. There is a tour you can take inside one of the bridge supports that describes the construction. I didn't do that tour this time, but have in the past, and it's worth doing.The real treat is walking in the open air with the Opera House and Sydney Harbour stretched out in front of you. The walk along the top structure and arch (you know, the one Oprah did) is by reservation and costs $200+ and requires a sobriety test, but the walk across the pedestrian part of the bridge is free.
Best free activity in Sydney. Dont bother with the expensive "Bridge Climb" just walk across on the pedestrian walk-fantastic views of the harbor

Walk the Bridge - it is awesome. We landed up in Sydney with a hotel booking and 48 hours with us. We started checking out the various brochures with the hotel concierge, figured out a few things to do. What none of them had (and we checked out 15-20) was a walk on the Harbour Bridge. An uncle who lives in Sydney recommended this to us, and we are eternally grateful for the same.The walk has two end points - one at The Rocks, and the other at Milson's Point. The second one can be found very easily from the Milson's Point train station. The one near The Rocks is a little more difficult to find. The walk takes 25-30 minutes, and you get amazing views of the Opera House.Would recommend it to anyone going to Sydney.

Amazing. It was worth the walk. Beautiful bridge. Not for the faint hearted. I walked over it and the heavy traffic caused it to shake a tiny bit so I got a few nerves which was part of the fun I suppose. The bridge is well looked after though.
Lovely views.. A great walk across the bridge with amazing views of the city and harbour. We considered the official bridge walk but for the two of us it was going to cost a massive 540$.

Best from the Manly Ferry. Much as I like travelling every time I come back to Sydney and see the Harnour and brige I think how beutiful this place is, best from the Manly Ferry or the North Sydney pool!

Do the bridge walk. You can do a walking tour of the bridge. Ignore the literature as it can be done by practicaly anyone, disablities excepted.
It allows some impresssive views and sites.
Well worth doing.

Don't worry about the bridge climb!. Save your cash and avoid paying for the top of the bridge experience, simply walking over the bridge gives some fantastic views of the harbour and beyond. Take a walk up the bridge pylon a snip at $11 for even higher views that you can take your camera to capture.

Iconic but?. What can you say about sydney harbour bridge that has not already been said? The bridge is called the coathanger(because of it's design and shape) if you care to take a car trip across the bridge or perhap's the train) or if you have the money you can climb the bridge. before I can climb the bridge I shall have to break my piggy bank open as the cost of the climb is quite steep, certainly out of my reach at the moment, however it is on my list to do on my next visit. I took time out on my visit in november of this year to have a good look from ground level and I must say it is truly impressive and I am starting to look forward to my climb on my next visit.

Grand Bridge. Te bridge itself stands tall joining the 2 sides of Sydney. This stunning bridge provides a walk over the top that offers the best views in Sydney or you can drive over it and look up to see the maze of metal that holds it all together

Do the climb - well worth it. A fascinating bridge built back in 1932 from British steel (yeah!), this iconic landmark can be photo'd and enjoyed in so many ways. Cross it on foot, bike across it, take the subway train across it or drive across it, but nothing beats doing the Bridge tour and paying a few dollars (well, quite a few actually), to get kitted out to climb it. Well worth it. In fact, don't even um and argh about climbing it. If you have a head for heights, just do it, otherwise you'll sit on your return flight home cursing yourself that you missed out on it.

Beautiful. A very attractive bridge and iconic to Sydney. The bridge can be climbed with tour leaders, appropriate suits supplied. A perfect way to see the city surrounds and the Harbour. Wonderful on New Years Eve!

Symbol of Sydney. The symbol known as the one representing Sydney as well as Opera house.you can walk to the other side through the bridge.I tried walking in the early morning and found sea brilliantly shining thrown back by sunrise.Just a day can make you happy.

WOW. Went on the bridge walk. It is beyond anything I have ever done. Wear comfortable clothes and shoes and make sure you make a reservation. It is not for the faint of heart. The guides make sure everyone keeps up and share interesting things along the walk.

Go under, across, or over!. You can cross the bridge by car or by City Rail from Wynyard Station. But get off at Milsoms Point and walk back across the bridge to get more of an idea on scale.By car, you'll not see much if you're driving.Take a ferry from Circular Quay to Darling Harbour or up river to Parramatta and you'll pass under the bridge and realise how huge it is.If you book well in advance and / or are flexible on date and time, you can do the walk over the Bridge. You need to be fit and dressed properly for walking. It will take 3 - hours but you'll get the best view of the finest harbour in the World and plenty of photo opportunities. It's all done with safety in mind.

Take your time to walk across it. It takes a while to find the pedestrian access onto the bridge, you need to head down Cumberland Street and look out for the stairs next to an astro-turf playing field. You can walk all the way across it along the pedestrian pathway for free but you can go up the Pylon Lookout for higher views for $15, where there is also an exhibition showing the history of the bridge. We skipped the bridge climb as we thought it was too expensive (for adults $198-298) and we had a great view anyway from the pedestrian walkway. It's a fantastic bridge to cross although a little smaller than I imagined!

Scaled the Bridge. If you aren't up to doing the full scale bridge walk, you can walk the bridge to look out point and take the 200 stairs up for some great views and photos. But, the best view is at the top!
An Icon of its age!. It lived up to all my expectations!! Just to stroll around it and view it from its many angles was impressive. If you have the time, take the guided tour as well.

Walk across the bridge for free...great views!. With a small amount of effort we were able to find the stairs off Argyle Street that lead to the upper street level where you can find other stairs (across the street if I remember correctly) up to the bridge. Then you can walk all the way across it on the pedestrian pathway. I'm scared of heights so there was no way I'd do the bridge climb or even go up the pylon, even if they were free.Pictures of the opera house are fabulous from here, just don't look down! It was a great experience and didn't take long at all. We were just going to go part way out, then realized we were almost halfway across anyways so we walked the rest of the way, then used our handy mymulti pass to catch a free ferry ride back to the harbor. You have to walk to the other side of the the bridge to the Luna Park Ferry wharf, but they come pretty often and it's a pleasant, short ride back.
Great views of Sydney's harbour and surrounds. It can not be argued, that from this vantage point one gets a great view. It's a pleasant stroll to get to the other side.

What a view!!. We didn't walk all the way across, but walked out a good ways. You get incredible views!!! I think there was an elevator, but we did the stairs. It wasn't that bad. There is a large walk way. Worth the walk!!
What a thrill to see this familar land mark. It was strange to see something up close that you know so well from TV etc. At night with the harbour lit up it is stunning.
Huge highlight of trip to Sydney. Bridge climb - just do it!We are from Newcastle and to see the 'Australian Tyne Bridge' was fantastic. To climb it was magical.
Spectacular. What can one say about one of the most iconic buildings in the world? It's spectacular. Do the walk over it if you have time. Its well worth it to see it close up.

Arrgh! The signs. I wanted to cross the bridge. The signs to get on it are really really poor (the look good, but they aren't accurate).On my first attempt I found myself facing a locked gate saying "No pedestrians". I then went round to the other side of the bridge (not easy) and tried the path ... once you get there you find it is cyclists only (and a friendly security guard enforces it). Talking to friends, they've all run into problems crossing the bridge the first time. Be prepared to spend 30 minutes or more finding your way onto the bridge :(

Gorgeous up close and from a distance. I travel along the Harbour Bridge every week and the view of the harbour is lovely. You can't visit Sydney without seeing the bridge! One of the most iconic landmarks of Australia.

Walk the Bridge. My partner and I walked the Sydney Harbour Bridge on our recent trip over for the weekend. We had a wonderful time, if you ever travel to Sydney, walking the bridge is a MUST. We had two Canadian travellers on our walk, an elderly man who would have been at least 80 and two young boys around 12. For any age group to try and well worth the money. Plenty to do in Sydney from visiting the famous Bondi Beach to the sights of Kings Cross. So many lovely bars and restaurants, the Opera house and Chinatown were all on our agenda.Stayed at the Bayview Boulevard hotel which is in walking distance to the train station at Kings Cross and we walked pretty much everywhere we needed to go, except Bondi but the train and bus systems were excellent. I would definitely go back and stay at this hotel, very comfortable and friendly staff too. Loved Sydney, my first time there but wont be my last!
okay. The bridge is somewhat underwhelming when you actually see it. Definitely not as impressive as people claim.

A Site to see. A trip to Sydney is incomplete without a visit to the Sydney Harbour Bridge. As the name says it, it is located at the Harbour. The best place to view it is from the Opera House and given the chance, you must try doing the walk up the bridge for an amazing breath taking view of Sydney
Climb of our life!. We did this 10 years ago and still loved it the second time, and now they give you a souvenir baseball cap!
Magnificent. When you sail into the most spectacular Harbour in the world, this magnificent structure is like a backdrop to a classic painting!
Best known symbol of Sydney. Never done the bridge climb but I am told it is terrific. A walk across the bridge is a nice way to view the harbour.

I can not afford to take my wife to a restaurant with views as good as this!. Walking across the Bridge is wonderful any fine day. To be superlative work out when the moon is rising early after sunset and one can watch the moonlight reflecting off the Harbour waters towards the Bridge. You rave about it once you have seen it. Good restaurants at Kirribilli as one descends from the pedestrian walk way. Why spend the money with Bridge Climb when you can save say $150 and treat your girl friend to dinner in Kirribilli!
super view. I usually just walk on, don't do the trip on the top!But just this is fabulous, a stop to make some beautifull picture and that it!!!!
Fantastic . Must do when in Sydney. My husband and I did the walk to celebrate our 15 year wedding anniversary . It was fantastic. We loved every minute of it. It's not scary , it's a must do thing.

Walk across is free and breathtaking. We walk across the Harbour Bridge at least 3 times a year and every time we have visitors. Usually we alight the train at Milson's Point and walk across. There are a number of stairs at either end but the walk across is gradual and relaxing. There are now security guards which I found interesting but suppose that it good. They sure weren't busy. Perhaps they could be friendlier and say Gidday given their job is probably on the No.1 tourist attraction our country offers. You can still go,up the pilons and get a bird's eye view if actually climbing the bridge is out of your budget or you can't book or health reasons. make sure to snap some pictures from Observatory Hill on the western side when you come off the bridge on the city side. It is very pretty. You can take a picnic and enjoy the Park.

Expensive - but worth it. Thanks to strength of $, slightly baulked at price for two of us. But, if you have a clear day and a decent guide you'll enjoy it. We had a stroke of luck in that we were the only two booked for our visit so it was like a private tour.Nothing to be scared of - my wife who up until the last minute didn't want to go, thoroughly enjoyed it. Nothing strenuous and the pre-briefing covers all the procedures to ensure you remain secure. If like us, Australia is a once in a lifetime visit, swallow the cost and do it.
Love this bridge!. Beautiful location! We went over it, under it and even climbed it and got pictures from every angle.

Harbour Cruise. Brilliant shining water...diamonds sparkling! Tour of the harbour allowed us to see major beaches and small coves, Pinchgut Is and other islands like Clark and Goat. Wonderful sights and sounds of a busy harbourfront.

Yet To Walk Across It!. Australians view it as 'The Coathanger'. It had a controversial beginning in which it had to have the 'ribbon' cut twice! One of the most recognisable bridges in the world, in stands today as the symbol of our nation. Looking at the 'Bridge' conjours up other signifiers of Australia.

Walk the lower level. Nearly the same view, save time and 200 Dollars. It is a great experience. You have to choices. Claim the bridge, a complex, time consuming and ridiculous expensive affair. Or you can just walk 40 meters below, similar view, faster and...free. The claiming is just and incredible rip off.

Good But a Bit Over-rated!. Heavy traffic roaring by made a walk on the bridge somewhat un pleasant. Yes, there is a great view from the bridge,but it remains simply a bridge. If you are an outdoorsman, and have climbed mountains, the walk over the bridge is a bit mild, not as "terror" inspiring as all the hype!
Its a Bridge. Links one bit of land to another. to me it looks like the Tyne bridge and has loads of building work going on at the moment .You have to see it once in your lifetime though

Awesome. well i couldnt afford to do the bridge climb but I did walk across it which was well worth it for the view of the opera house and circular quay. You can go up the tower for a small fee which i didnt manage to do as they were closed at the time.
Magnificent view!. One of the beautiful landmarks in Sydney. A must visit place. Take the ferry to enjoy a better view of it ;)

Is an icon and a thrill to visit and walk on. If you can't afford or don't want to climb the bridge you can still enjoy the famous bridge by walking across it. We've also climbed by the pylons which was surprisingly scarey as there is a lot of shaking on the bridge due to the traffic. I have also run across it in a fun run a couple of times and if you ever have the opportunity to do this - well worth it! And even if you don't want to spend the time walking across it - you could go over to the North Sydney side and catch a train back - there are many fine locations around town to snap a great picture of it.

Wow!. An absolute feat of engineering. If you can't afford the climb (which we couldn't), at least have a walk across it. We went across at night and the views of the harbour were stunning. You can't go to Sydney and miss this!

Such an easy walk from Kirribilli to the Rocks.. How cool is it to walk the bridge and just stop. Taking in the beauty on all sides ~ looking east to the harbour entrance ~ south to the Opera house, west to Luna Park and Darling Harbour ~ you are at the top of the bottom of the world.

Amazing views. We were surprised how small the bridge was, although high enough, we walked acoss the bridge but didnt do the bridge climb, but everyone we spoke to says its a must if you have a head for hights, its all very well organised and safety paramount.

Walk the Bridge, because it is there. Sydney is a lovely and expensive city, and sometimes a bit over-rated, but it has some attractions that are not to be missed. When you have taken your harbor cruise, shopped for opals and had "pancakes on the rocks", a walk along the iconic Harbour Bridge is a must. It doesn't cost anything unless you pay for a tour (which I wouldn't recommend unless you are up for a physically demanding and pricey "Climb the Bridge" adventure), and it will help you work off some of the pancakes. The view is lovely, and if you pay around $10 US you can climb to the top of one of the bridge pylons. I chose not to pay the fee, as the view from the bridge is still very good for photography. There are small restaurants and pubs on the other side of the bridge, but no real attractions unless you are going to the Luna Park amusement park (about which I know very little other than parts of it were transported from Melbourne in the 1930s)MOBILITY: If you are in a wheelchair or have reduced mobility, getting on to the bridge can be a difficult and time-consuming effort which I probably wouldn't recommend. KIDS: No problem with kids, though for small ones, walking all the way across the bridge might lead to complaints.

Magnificent view at night. The view at night is the best! You have the fair right underneath it that is all lit up and reflects off the water. Fantastic structure and interesting architecture. Didn't climb it, but watched people do that. Looked fantastic.

Walk the bridge, not the tour.. Nice long walk across the bridge and then you can take the Luna Park-Harbour ferry back. Great views and it is totally free. Obviously not a short walk, but it isn't difficult. Just be sure you don't walk the bike path.

This is what makes Sydney unique. I am sure that the bridge climb is wonderful but walk over at road level and climb up the tower on the south east side. You will get the same great view. It will cost very little and the permanent exhibition will explain the engineering and honour those who died building it.

Walk it at road level for FREE. Whilst the views from the top will no doubt be spectacular, they do come at a price!! Try doing it at road level for free, on the eastern side, approached from The Rocks area. (The cyclists do it on the western side)

Nice bridge, but it was just a bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is to Sydney, what the Golden Gate is to San Francisco it really identifies the city more than anything else (except perhaps the Opera House).The bridge has a history behind and the architecture is something truly unique that you'd rarely find elsewhere. It is however, a long bridge...and it's still in use. So while walking on the bridge is a good experience with a nice scenic view of the harbour and the Opera house--the novelty soon dies off, and what you're left with is a long walk on a bridge with traffic and dust and exhaust fumes.So while I recommend it (you really can't go to Sydney without going to the Bridge), don't have too high hopes on it.

Walking the walking lane accross the Sydney harbor bridge. This was a highlight for me because right beside the bridge is the "Rocks" markets, so could do both.The walk over bridge was great for viewing and taking great photos. I liked that it is safely fenced off from the road and that only people walking/running can go down it because bikes have their own lane on other side of bridge. Was great to be walking on it to say "we have walked accross that" :)

What a great walk. Weather was great and we walked from the Opera House across to Lunar Park. Great views of the city and the harbour. Wide walkway with lots of people in both directions. Great photo taking spots too.

Iconic. Wow fantastic- its the bridge and harbour you've seen in all the photos of Sydney- look closer and it carries pedestrians, cars and also trains. You can also buy the change to climb over the top of it.

Harbour Bridge Delights. Sydney Harbour bridge is iconic symbol of Sydney. No trip to Sydney should occur without a glimpse. Whether that be lying near the bridge (near Circular Quay) watching the ferries and the world go by, or climbing the bridge at sunset. I did both and loved it all!
Breathtaking. If you are able, I highly recommend that you take the tour. This was the pinnacle of the trip to Sydney.
Best views. Best views to see the harbour bridge is from the roof top from YHA the rocks (EVEN THE BEST ON NEW YEARS EVE!!) of from the opera bar, of even from the ferry to Manly Beach.

Experience of a lifetime April 2012. Sydney Harbour Bridgewalk is world famous and one of those experiences on some peoples 'bucket list'. Although you cant miss the birdge, finding where to enter and where to book the bridge walk is a different matter, as this is not at the foot of the bridge, but higher up where the road runs beside it. Once inside the staff are firendly, there is a cafe and displays about the bridge. It is expensive though, over 100 dollars, so take plenty of money if you intend to do the bridge walk. Tours run regularly throughout the day,the staff guide you through the saftey procedures and equpiment. You also have the option to purchase a photograph taken at the top of the bridge. A fabtastic experience , well worth doing providing you are not scared of hieghts, because it is very high !

Spectacular!. The Sydney Harbour Bridge provides a wonderful backdrop as you enter Sydney Harbour. It embraces Sydney and holds the pride of the nation. Even on a dull day, the Bridge never fails to give a spectacular performance and will truly delight and fascinate tourists from all over the world.
Great to view. Great sight to view. Went up tower at one end. Wanted to climb on bridge but was VERY expensive. Looked good fun, people tied on to each other and climbing up over the bridge!
Not to be missed.. Whether you climb over, sail under or simply walk across, this is one attraction that is worth seeing up close.

It's a bridge. Growing up in Pittsburgh and seeing the Golden Gate Bridge in San Fran, I was less excited about the Harbour Bridge. It's still a site to see but I was more focused on the opera house, botanics garden, The Hunter and downtown Sydney.
Harbour Bridge. Beautiful work of art.I would like to try the walk if my kids are up for it.The surrounding is lovely to walk around and have a drink and watch the sunset.

Great Walk. Was thinking of paying the ridiculous cost to go across the top of the bridge, but opted to just walk along the pedestrian walkway across the bridge and it was a delight. Hard to keep walking when there is so much to see in the harbor. Took great pics of Sydney as the lights came on, great shots of boats and skyline and the Opera house. A free and fun must!!
Walk it. This bridge is one of the icons of this beautiful city. Sail under it (from Parramatta) ride over it (by car or train) or climb over it. Either way you will always remember it.

The Old Fashoined Bridge experience. Just before sunset is ideal - so one warm winters day walk across it from Milsons Point then up the south east pylon for a great view of sydney and it surrounds $15 includes your photo on a fake girder - just for fun. Cant think why I didnt do it earlier!

Don't pay big money to walk on the bridge.. The foot path on the Opera House side of the bridge is accessible from Cumberland Street ( The Rocks) or Milson's Point. There are fantastic views of the Opera House and general harbour traffic.A great place to watch cruise ships arrive/leave the harbour. It is absolutely free and takes about 1/2 hr to walk across . The Southern Pylon has a viewing area for a small fee.

Sensational views. Sensational views up and down the beautiful harbour. The bridge is a Sydney icon. In terms of a structure it is not really that wondrous but what its spans is. You can take a leisurely walk from Observatory Hill on the south side to Milson's Point on the north side or vice versa and catch a bus or train back.
Nothing exceptional. Didn't think much of the bridge. A bit tatty. Views were ok. Better views from the mainland. Didn't climb up so can't comment.

An Amazing sight. I live here in Sydney and i never get tired of seeing the bridge, it welcomes you to the best city in the world and the bridge climb is not to be missed, walk it, see it , love it :)

A bridge of dreams of Australia. The bridge was everything I thought it would be. Have been waiting most of my adult life to see the bridge and it did not disappoint. Did not do the climb but it was still exciting to see.

Walk the Bridge. Follow the signs or ask someone in the Rocks area to find where the stairs are to the Sydney Harbour Bridge and then take a twenty minute stroll one way and enjoy the best view (and its free) of the Harbour and Circular Quay and the Opera House. On the other side have a coffee by the water and if your tired take the ferry back to Circular Quay or walk back the same route. The Rocks area has great little eateries and a wonderful button shop on Nurses Walk. The area first settled by convicts is home to the Rocks Markets on the weekend where you can see craftspeople sell their creations. If you havetime take the ferry to Manly where you enjoy the quiet beach of the Harbour or the ocean beach on the other side. A great day by foot and if you dont want to spend any money then you can enjoy yourself as much as if you did.

Cycled across this bridge !!. Brilliant experience my husband and I cycled across the bridge twice we were on a bicycle tour of Sydney ,just unbelievable fantastic views,would have loved to do the climb ,it was fantastic to watch the people climbing the bridge they were like little caterpillars on top of the bridge.

Expensive but.... visited last dec. price - quite expensive. used to be free. but few idiots left glass bottles & trolley on top, since then u need to pay to visit.view - breathtaking. cant find anywhere in sydney. but depends on weather too. conclusion - if u plan not to visit sydney. u have to take trip. its quite costly but for a memory that last forever. worth every penny.

Did Not Climb. We did not climb the bridge but walked across instead. Fantastic views also. Of all the pictures that we took of the opera house, from boat or on land the 2 pictures from walking the bridge were by far the best. Noisy from the traffic but did not bother us. There was a great flea market going on the other side.
Majestic. An incredible site that if you pay $200 you can walk over the top of it. If I was younger I would have done it, but I passed. Got scared just watching people doing it!!

Beautiful scenery. The walk across the bridge took me 35 minutes, with stops for pictures. To walk across the bridge and have the Sydney Opera House right in front of you is awesome! I would have love to climb the bridge but the price was a bit much.
Iconic. A great view of the Sydney Harbour Bridge from the Manly ferry. A day ticket that covers all public transport is great value for money!
Beautiful Bridge, but not to climb. It was easy to see that hundreds of people were climbing the bridge. I don't do things like that. A beautiful bridge though.
Beautiful Bridge. We have always love the bridge and its history. We climbed the bridge on our last trip to Sydney. There is nothing we dislike about this wonderful structure.

Interesting and free!. We walked down underneath the Sydney Harbour Bridge to get to Circular Quay. It was night time and the lights lit up the bridge, you can see all the rivets and get a really good feel of how big it is. There are birds flying above the bridge, it's really quite nice.

the bridge means.
