During my short time in Sydney, I have cycled and walked across the bridge many times in day/ night although unplanned.I think maybe its because the bridge is a central sightseeing theme in sydney. One of my favourite moments was taking a ferry across to restaurant (beside luna park,under the bridge, cant remember the name but I think its called ripples) and walking back across the bridge at night.

IF you're ready for a "WOW". The regular walk over the bridge is a great bit of exercise and if you're not afraid of heights with some bumps there should be no problem. There are a couple of nice breakfast/lunch spots to stop at on the far side of the bridge before the return trek

Sydney's coathanger. The largest single-span arch bridge in the world (at least until a copy cat bridge in New York went a couple of feet further). Many views can be had from a distance but size best appreciated by walking around the base of the pylons on either side and walking (east side) or riding a bicycle (west side). I think the best way is to start from the city side and after you get to the northern side, you can either take a train back into the city (Milsons Point station on the northern bridge approach) or a ferry (from near Luna Park). Then there's the bridge climb where you walk across the top of the arch from the south side to the centre and back - you're attached to the bridgework by a harness that makes it completely safe. The complete walk (including 'safety instruction' takes about 90 minutes or so - a bit pricey - very popular and you may need to book ahead - walks may be suspended in high winds and bad weather.

Wonder of the World. Must do!. Having travelled the wortld, seen everything and done everything, I rate this as one of the best. Everything about this climb is superlative, you will remember it forever. Little energy required but common sense is essential. Even the checks you go through to establish your preparedness to do the tour are sensible and smooth. Do it! You will leave wanting to do it again!

The first Australian icon. Whether you drive over it, under it, or sail around it or climb over it (as I have done - not to be missed) it represents everything that is bold and beautiful, yet functional, about Sydney Harbour.
Wonderful views from Harbour Bridge Walk. Was a Christmas gift to grand-kids but extra family members tagged along. Great views of Sydney, was tiring decending last stretch on home run.
Lovely Bridge - Very regimented bridge climb. The bridge is lovely to walk across and view the harbour. Dont bother to spend $$$ on the bridge climb.

Amazing!. Never fail to love the views from and of this bridge. It's enormous! Probably the most recognisable landmark in Sydney. Fantastic views of the harbour and opera house but many steps up from the rocks area.
Amazing and Impressive!. What foresight the engineer had to create and build such a magnificent crossing! Takes your breath away.
Awesome Half Day Trip. See Sydney in all its glory from the top of the bridge. Learn it history, & get your picture taken with the opera house in the background

visit the museum instead. forget the expensive bridge climb now about aud 200 if u walk over the eastern side of the bridge accesable via staircase you can walk to the top of the pylon and basically get the same view for about 9 dollars instead of 200..and it has a musem which u can get the story of how the bridge was built well worth a visit.
Amazing!. Bigger than you'd think, and a must see for any visitor to Sydney. The darling ferry is a great way to take photos of the bridge
Still an awesome bit of engineering. The sheer scale of this piece of engineering only becomes apparent when you're going under it in a boat.
Walk the Bridge. It is simply amazing to climb this and watch boats sail underneath and see all of Sydney from the very top.

Spectacular Architecture. It is indeed a beautiful bridge, so spectacular and huge, adding beauty to the skyline, from afar, from the sea.. from all angle. It is rather expensive abt AUD300 for a bridge climb thus we choose to go to the plantoon (side of the bridge for the view)
Great views. Provides great views on Sydney Harbour and the Opera House. Entry is not well sign posted however, required some walking at The Rocks.

A great bridge. We passed on the option to climb to the top of the bridge. We just did not want to pay the price. However, we walked across the bridge and back. The view of the Harbour and the Sydney Opera House from the bridge makes walking across the bridge worthwhile. You also get a nice view of those climbing to the top of the bridge.
Stunning views. The bridge is beautiful. A picture with the Harbour bridge and opera house in the back ground says "I was in Sydney".

Driving in Sydney is not complete without crossing the bridge. We drove over it at night but it was still lots of fun to cross this landmark. Rates up there with crossing the Golden Gate in SF or Tower Bridge in London!
Walk across it on a Sunny Day. It can be a bit crowded sometimes, but a walk across the Syd Harbour Bridge is a must. Perfect views. Don't go during peak hour.
Walk Across for Free :). We walked across the bridge and took the ferry back. Great views! The security folks are happy to take pictures of your group.

Scenic and functional harbour. Sydney Harbour is one of the nicest harbours in the world with picturesque houses on the foreshores and off course The Harbour Bridge and Opera House. Also has many ferries criss crossing to Manly, Parramatta and Balmain.

Take a walk over the bridge for good views and breath of fresh air. An easy walk over to the other side (cute suburb) and either walk back or take train back into the City. Nice break, great views of the Opera House and the harbor is really beautiful.
Magnificent. A Magnificent feet, especially when you understand it was built in the 1930’s. To climb that bridge is a real must for locals and tourist alike. Go do it, you will love it.

Great views. There are many great locations to photograph this bridge in the surrounding area. There is a walkway that goes across the entire expansion that is free to do. You can ee the Opera House and Circular Quay area from the bridge. There is a tour that actually has you climb the Harbour Bridge, but you need to book ahead and it costs about $250.00 per person to do it.

Good old Coat Hanger. Together with the Opera House, this bridge defines our skyline as uniquely Sydney. I recommend a bridge climb if the weather is behaving for a unique perspective on the bridge itself (Hw large it is can surprise you) as well as amazing views around Sydney as far west as the Blue Mountains. If you're staying in town and have a spare hour or two then it makes a pleasant walk along the eastern walkway of the bridge. Spend an hour watching the harbour (all day if you like!)

What's not to love about this bridge?. Everything has already been said about this magnigicent bridge. I've been over it a number of times, have done the bridge climb and my great grandfather dies during construction on it.Please stop by the South East Pylon to view the plaque dedicated to those who dies during the bridges construction (16 in all which wasn't too bad considering the time!).Also, there is a museum and lookout within the South East Pylon which is well worth a visit affording views similar to the climb at a fraction of the cost.

A picture paints a 1000 words. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of those images you will never forget the first time you see it in real life in all it's glory particularly if yor are lucky enough to view it against the background of a clear blue sky. The other time to see it in all it's glory is when it is all lit up at night. You can view it, climb it, drive or easily walk across it! Great vantage points are from The Sydney Opera House or from one of the many ferries that take you across the harbour to places like Manly or Taronga Park Zoo. There is no need to pay for an expensive Harbour Cruise as you get the same view when you take the Public Transport Ferries. From the city you can catch a train over the bridge to Milson's Point Station and walk back over the bridge to Circular Quay. I think this is the best direction to walk over the bridge as when you walk you can take in the sights of the Sydney skyline and the magnificent opera house.

Stunning. Absolutely mesmerized with the stunning view of Sydney Harbour Bridge. Its jovial beauty has taken me to a timeless experience; my eyes couldn’t stop gazing at the Sydney's burgeoning skyline, blue skies.

Beautiful views. Wonderful to walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge from Milsons Point Station to either The Rocks, Circular Quay or Macquarie Street. Spectacular views of Sydney while walking across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. If you decide to use a bicycle to cross the Sydney Harbour Bridge, you need to use the special bike lane and you will be given views of the western side of Sydney Harbour.

Worth the walk. The bridge is great to look at, but it's also well worth walking across it. It's free and you can stop wherever and whenever you like. The views are fabulous and you get a good sense of its size and structure. Set aside about half an hour for a lesiurely walk.
I Still Call Australia "Home". I know I'm "home" when I see the Sydney Harbour Bridge. See my Youtube video called Sydney - The Jewel of the Pacific" to see why I love it so much. AW (Tony) Scott

harbour bridge. The locals in Sidney call the bridge the coat hanger because of the rounded shape, it is worth climbing all of the steps to get to the road and pedestrian deck level as the view from the centre area looking at the oper house and the Manly ferries toing and froing isworth seeing.
Great Sydney Icon. Love driving over this great engineering feat and checking out the beautiful harbour! Great first thing in the morning before the city traffic madness gets under way.

Don't miss walking the bridge. You can do the bridge climb if you have the time and don't mind the cost and are not afraid of heights. But if you just want a nice walk with beautiful views and a great experience, just walk across the bridge and up the 200 steps of the pylon to see the views. Its quite an experience.

A wonder built and designed by British steel, Teesside. You really cant go to Sydney and miss this!
The size and structure its an icon for the locals and rightly so.
Travel over it by car its a toll but worth it or for the brave walk over the structure stop at the top and catch those rays and views. OMG its worth every penny!!!
fantastic vieuws. this iconic bridge is a must do for all Sydney visitors. On the bridge you'll have the most fantastic vieuws over the city, the bay and of course the opera house

Great to look at from any angle. this Icon is such a feature of sydney that no matter where you go you can usually see it. one day we even went to the zoo and the views of this bridge in its setting were fantastic

Beautiful. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the main attractions in Sydney. It is a must for everybody at least to take a picture. It is possible to climb on it for some hefty fee; however we preferred only to access the normal walkway. But the views from the walkway are already stunning.
beautiful. when I first saw the bridge I thought of the fantastic fireworks at new year.we crossed the bridge by car, walked under it, but we did not do the climb

Fanstatice views. Amazing views, Given as a gift for 50th and what a great present.
Great Views, lots of stairs and you are given a bit of history about our famous Bridge.
Truly somethingthat should be a Bucket list.
beautiful bridge. we walked across this bridge on our day off and took the train back from milsons point to wynyard station. was a lovely walk and weather was great
Bridge. As long as you don't have to drive across it in an auto mobile. Northbound trains from Circular Quay and Wynyard stations give a good view. The entire public transit system is wonderful.

Gorgeous. Wonderful views- tip: if you don't want to pay $100+ to go to the top of the bridge for the bridge walk, pay around $9USD to climb the pylons. Gorgeous views, a little exercise, and a lot less money.
Sydney's Famous Bridge. The Sydney Harbour Bridge, what a fantastic jewel in the Harbour. We have walked over it, driven over it, sailed under it and climbed it.

Brilliant views.. I admit I had a perfect day to walk across the bridge, but the views are second to none. You can do the Bridge Climb and there is a viewing platform in the South Eastern tower, but I just enjoy the walk. Wear good shoes, the path is in good condition, but it is not as short as some think. You can catch the train back if you don't want to do the return journey - that is also worth the trip.

definetly worth a visit!. we didnt even manage to do the walk or drive across it, but just looking at it from the circular quay, from ferries, and on foot just was incredible enough.beautiful views and plenty of good photos can be taken from all angles. dont forget your camera!

stunning. One of the landmarks to visit in Sydney is the Sydney Harbor Bridge. They also have 'Sydney Harbor Bridge climbing tour' we did not do that but we heard it is fun. The Bridge , the Harbor and the Opera house is very picturesque make sure you take your camera with you.
What a view. If you get the chance a once in a life time experience Walk the Bridge WOW I cured my fear of heights
Awesome, must do!. The best thing to do in Sydney even if you're afraid of heights. Enjoyed it thoroughly. Plenty of stops for those who are less fit. Gotta do this one!

Hidden Treasure at the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the iconic symbols of Sydney. Not many people know that there is a museum and lookout. The Pylon Lookout is located at the southeast pylon. To get to the lookout, you pass through a museum dedicated to the history of the Harbour Bridge. To get to the top where the lookout is, you will have climbed about 200 stairs - but you take your time and look at the exhibits along the way. Well worth it! The walk across the bridge is also an enjoyable outing.
A Once in a Lifetime Walk. That walk was definately worth the money, I enjoyed every step of it, and there were plenty of steps.
Breathtaking views mixed with a good dollop of exercise. I loved this long walk, lots of great picture taking advantages on this walk, of the opera house and Sydney at its best.
take a walk across the bridge , or over the top for the fit.. When in Sydney you must take a walk across the Sydney Harbour bridge , or over the top for the fit. The view is fantastic
A perfect place to get a photo clicked!!. The view is breath taking and it sure is worth the money to get up on to the top of the bridge and click photos.
Unbelievable. You see the place on Tv and you are in aww. Up close in the flesh is even better. Always lively and vibrant, the place is simply beautiful.

Picture Perfect. The harbour bridge is a nice background for your Sydney photos.
It looks amazing at night.
We did not try the bridge climb as the weather was too cold. But the locals we met recommended it.
Take a walk. Great view of the city if you walk halfway across the bridge. Definitely a good way to get some exercise

Must see, wonderful view on the whole city and bay. We went by night, it was a wonderful view. Nevertheless, it was quite challenging to take photos with tripod due to the grids. Just behind the first pylon was enough space to put my tripod and to make some amazing photos.
impressive. didn't go all the way up. but was very nice to see. very touristic area though. we took some really nice picture with it as a background..lol.

Good for a free walk. It is good they don't charge to walk over it, as it wouldn't be worth paying. There is so much construction around the walkway that you don't get a great view. But it is a famous bridge and there aren't very many free things to do in Sydney so lap it up!
Reminds us of Newcastle, UK. Lovely bridge and it felt good very time our boat went under it. Just reminds us of newcastle back home.

Absolutely love this place. When you visit Sydney you just have to go here, it's so iconic and definitely worth the visit. If driving then you'll have to pay tolls (you must phone and pay within 48 hours of being here), and you can park all day close by at the secured Wilson car parks-cheap rate for weekends only).

Walk across the Bridge. After finishing up a bike tour we decided to walk the bridge just as the sun was setting. The view of the harbor and the Opera house from the middle of the bridge was beautiful. Unlike the climb the walk was free. Would recommend it if you have an hour to spare.

Great way to spend half a day - suits most levels of fitness. This only takes half a day but is well worth it for the history and the spectacular views. The tour is very professionally run and suits most levels of fitness - we are in our mid fifties to sixty.

Pricey but good. Although I think it's majorly overpriced this was a fantastic activity to partake in Sydney. Tourguides - outstanding tourguide called Pete, got to know every single person that was going up with him (about 8) and made sure he knew all of our names. Very experienced, and a great knowledge of the local area. Made all persons in our party feel at ease and safe at all time, making sure we had no issues at all. The experience of this was unreal and will never be forgotten, amazing way to see the city and learn a bit about the bridge and Sydney. If it wasn't for the price this was have a top rating all the way through but a well recomended activity is you can justify spending $200 per person.
It is functional and eyecatching. Whether you walk across it, over it, stare at it, or drive over it, the bridge is part of Sydney that will end up in one of your photos.
Amazing. Love in the air and view icon of Australia :) Blue sky , i love it with with cloud and use ferry to see all this.
Loved it!!!. Loved the Harbour bridge. Great tourist site and great for pictures. We also had breakfast in the quay. It was well worth the trip. Parking was very expensive.
Have a climb. The climb is well organised and very safe. Definitely worth doing if not for the views then the experience of climbing over such an iconic landmark.

What an experience!. A fantastic experience for young and old, views are amazing and the climb is not scary at all. It may be 134m high but it is not physically exerting and a couple of members of our party didn't like heights but they still enjoyed it and were so glad they did it! I'm not adventurous at all but this was something I really wanted to do and really felt I'd achieved something. The climbs are very well organised, clothing is provided apart from footwear (you need to wear rubber soled shoes or trainers) and you are secure at all times. You are looked after by a member of staff at all times. Our guide, Alfie, was brilliant and very informative about the history and construction of the bridge.You will have read about not being able to take your camera and purchasing photographs is expensive. As we were a group of 6, we bought a USB between us for $99, and you get 12 photos for this.

Instantly recognisable. Whether you are at the Rocks, or at the Opera House or even on the Ferry in Sydney harbour, you will see the grandeur of this bridge. If you have the energy and are not shy of heights, do the bridge walk, its worth it! A huge world landmark and instantly recognisable to everyone like the Opera house, this is one of Sydney's treasures. See it via Ferry you can get some great pictures.

Do the bridge walk. What a stunning way to spend 3 - 4 hours - the history, the views, the friendship, We took this walk as a birthday present - and it will certainly be one birthday that will not be forgotten. The whole experience is amazing - the whole team make you feel special and keep you informed all the way - even had the group (only 9 - so nice and small) singing Happy Birthday on the top - if you have a choice try to get Michael as your guy - he is a real scream - making the whole expeience great fun. Would recommend it to every one - even those who are little unsure about the height - you never once feel unsafe - and you get a picture to recall the whole event.

It's a bridge.. I'll be honest, I felt let down by the harbour bridge. I'm not sure what I expected; maybe to be blown away by its presence or something. But I wasn't. Just like the Tyne bridge in Newcastle. The harbour is nice, with some nice eateries, and we also took a ferry around Darling Harbour which was very good, and a great opportunity to get some photos of both the bridge and the Opera House.

Amazing - not to be missed. If you are like me and a bit scared of heights then worry no more, the safety checks before you go out onto the bridge are very reassuring as is the guide you have (we had Jack), just let them know before hand they will pay extra attention to you. The view is amazing and is an experience not to be missed.

Inspiring. I did the pedestrian walk and was impressed by its size and structure. It's a noisy walk, but one worth doing. Views of the harbour are great. If you're close to the bridge, you should walk across it.

One of My Favourite weekend walks is Sydney Harbour Bridge to Milson point then ferry back.. Perfect walk across the harbour Great views stunning any day of the Year. I always walk from home in Potts Point through the Botanical gardens , Opera House, Circular Quay and Over the Bridge Love it.
Great place. to take photos from would have loved to do the Bridge climb. Nice park near the bridge (forgot the name) to hang out and have a quick bite

Fantastic views. I walked along the bridge on my first night and couldn't believe the views of the harbour and Opera House. I even had a chat with one of the security guards who explained that there is security on the bridge 24 hours a day plus cameras everywhere. I walked over it several times during my few days - an unmissable experience.

Walk over for lovely views of the Opera House and Sydney. There are several flights of stairs to get to the bridge level but walking over the bridge and back is a fairly easy stroll. The views from here on a sunny day are lovely. I have several 'post card' worthy pics I took from here.
My 60th Birthday present. Having driven over the Bridge for half my life, I had the best day Climbing the Bridge. An amazing construction and so different from up on top. The best view of Sydney.

Nice to visit. The views are nice. But is heavily fenced.
It's a good walk. But if you want to climb it, you need to be early around 9am because the tour takes about 3 hours including queuing.

Bridge Climb is a great experience!. I took my two teenage sons on the Sydney Bridge Climb and we all had a great time. The company does a good job orchestrating the climbing groups and the leader gave us lots of information about the construction of the bridge. The views from the top are fantastic! It is actually a much easier walk/climb than I thought it was going to be. I thought it would be too much for my 10 year old, but you are tethered to the bridge at all times and there are handrails the entire way. He definitely could have done the climb. Only drawback is it is very expensive.
NZ family hadnt been to Sydney and loved seeing the bridge. Even sat underneath the bridge so the could see all the rivits and told them that Crocodile Dundee used to be a painter on it

The Bridge Experience. You really can't go to Sydney and not have some sort of bridge experience. Your choices are walking (or running) across it on the pedestrian way, climbing up one of the pylons or signing up for "bridgeclimb" which involves being tethered to a bunch of people, walking up the outside of the bridge to its arch and coming back down. The pylon climb costs $12 and you can take some great photos of Sydney Harbor with 360 degree views. The bridgeclimb experience costs about $200 and they dress you in an overall suit and take away every single piece of personal property from you so nothing can fall from the bridge. While you do get a group photo of the experience, you can't take your own photos. Thus, we opted for the pylon climb and had a great time.

Amazing experience. This is no small walk! It is a bit complicated to actually GET to the entrance, but once you are there you realize that you are in for a serious climb. Just putting on the outfit and getting breathalized(!) takes an hour. You are completely outfitted and tehtered to the bridge at all times, so even if the wind is blowing at 60mph at the top (as it was for us) and you are terrified (as was my 10 year old), you are safe. Not for the faint of heart but definitely not to be missed if you are at all adventurous.

It's just a bridge. This bridge is tired - it carries a train line, a pedestrian walkway and several choked lanes of traffic which lead into a bottleneck in the city. I have travelled over it many times, walking, train & car and it is nothing outstanding

What they won't tell you about the bridge hike. We just did the bridge hike last week. I kept asking the gal at the desk why the hike took 3.5 hours. She tried to explain there were stories and history to share. But I kept reasoning...The hike isn't that far. Less than an hour into the hike, I discovered why. The first morning hike (unless you do sunrise) for that day was at 9:00. We were in the second group at 9:35am. Before we were ever fully geared up, we were on the heels of the first group. That continued the entire time. The guide made us stop to look at rivets, and boats, and whatever else the guide could come up with because of the group in front of us. This continued until we reached the top--where the people doing the higher beam hike cross paths with the people doing the express hike--pretty soon we're surrounded with four groups of 14 people each. And we have to all keep stopping to have our picture taken so they can make additional money off the add-on photos. So combine too many people, with annoying pictures, and suddenly this magical hike feels more like a cattle migration--slow, crowded, and unpleasant. The views are great (but you can find similar views elsewhere). But if you're going to book this: ONLY BE IN THE FIRST GROUP OF THE DAY. IF YOU CAN'T BE IN THAT GROUP--DON'T DO IT. IT'S NOT WORTH THE $200-PLUS A PERSON. The owners are trying to maximize profits and with revenue exceeding $40 million a year--they're doing it--by packing people into a slow, delayed, annoying experience.Be first, or skip it.
Took the ferry over and walked back. We took the ferry from Circular Quay to Luna Park and then walked back across the bridge. Great views and a nice walk!

It's a rush!. I lived in Sydney in 1999 but couldnt afford the climb. I promised myself I would do it eventually. I returned last year to visit my brother so we both did the climb on his birthday. It was amazing! Safety is paramount and you undergo training and a breathalyser test. The whole experience takes just over 3 hours but the time flies by. Phenomenal views, a history lesson en route from our guide Ben (who was fantastic), and passes for the Pylon Tower when you're done. It is not cheap, nearly 400 Aussie dollars. Once in a lifetime experiences are never cheap but are ultimately rewarding. If you are in Sydney give it a go.

The Coathanger. Ahh! Home. The Harbour Bridge is Sydney as much as the harbour is, Go on New Year's Eve and watch the fireworks blast off the top of the arch or cascade down from the roadway. Walk across the pedestrian footway on the eastern side (free) and take photos of the Opera House, Fort Denison, Circular Quay, Botanic Gardens, or spend lots of money and walk over the arch. Take the train to Milsons Point station, exit and follow the signs to the Bridge. When you reach the city side, walk around The Rocks, visit the Garrison Church or have a drink at the Lord Nelson. It's a good day out.

Definitely recommended. Sydney Harbour Bridge is the place to go if you love scenery and taking pictures of extraordianry things. It is just amazing. I love looking at it and even driving on it! I have never climbed it since I'm too scared but think it is a great place for anyone to enjoy, including kids.

Amazing. Did the bridge climb a few years ago, but it's still the same. There are two walks, 1 over, 1 through, we did the over. what a brilliant experiance, you don't realise how high you are even on the first part that just takes you over the road to start. Your guide gives you loads information about the building of it , how long it took and how it was done. We did an early morning climb as it takes a couple of hour's, that way your down before it get's to hot, because your exposed to the sun most of the time, but they look after you really well. It's something you MUST do when in Sydney, as you probably only get one chance and you will regret it if you don't.

Climb is a waste of money but the bridge is awesome.. I had heard from various people that the bridge climb was a waste of money but after looking on trip advisor and seeing all the rave reviews I decided to do it! I was very disappointed. It's very professionally run and the guide was enthusiastic and told us about the bridge which is really interesting as is being able to see the engineering of the bridge up close. However, you go through about 45 minutes worth of introductions, safety briefing and getting changed and then do the climb/walk which is not remotely scary as you're nowhere near the edge and have high railings either side of you. I would describe it as "just a walk up a few hundred flights of stairs and a nice view" - definitely not worth $218!!! The views from the bridge were great but I felt like I'd gotten a much better appreciation of the harbour and views of it all by going on a cycle tour of the city and seeing the harbour and indeed the bridge from loads of different angles!! Much better!!!! You can't take cameras up the bridge. You are given a free group photo at the end but the photos they take of you individually or as a group are very expensive to buy. Wish I'd saved my money.

Bigger In Real Life. Quite a sight, big bold and beautiful. Drive across it and guarantee you never forget it. Numerous lanes of traffic in both directions and trains. You can pay to hike up and over the top of it but the price is prohibitive. We hired a helicopter and flew over the whole city and the bridge for less than the cost of the hike. Simple math!
Useful.. Imaginative design built at a time when it was bold to do so. Well worth walking over. I've been told that the climb is worth the effort.

A Tale of Two Cities. Before this engineering marvel was built, the two cities were split by water and a ferry took passengers over to the North side. The bridge allowed the two side to fully develop and today allow us 'Northerners' to be able to cross over and come into the dynamic city that lies on the southern shore. Thankfully it was built to last and is still going strong. It is the glue in Sydney that joins us all together.

Walking the bridge. We took the metro out to Milsons point and then walked the bridge back to the city. The view was great - just slightly hidden by the high walls. Definitely a nice outing while in Sydney.

The Bridge. It is such a focal point and the backdrop of so many photos. The actual bridge climb, I feel is very expensive so the alternative is to visit the Pylon where you can get spectacular views from a great height. Excellent value!

Walk the Bridge - a Unique Experience. Our son bought us tickets as a gift and we went, a little apprehensive, not being the great adventurous types. It was incredible and so safe. You are attached to the bridge by a wire cable, they provide a one size-fits-all jump suit (and it does) and you walk up gradual slopping stairs, not too demanding. So now you have no excuse - just do it, the view is literally 'a bird's eye view'.
A shade of golden gate. It so happened we drove over the Golden Gate bridge in San Francisco in Jan, and over this harbour bridge in August. Well, this is a shade of it... charming, but no biggie.

Best enjoyed from the harbour. Best views from Mrs Macquaries Chair (Botanic Garden) or Blues Point (near North Sydney) for full view of the bridge. At night it is beautiful when lit. Also the walk between Kirribilli and The Rocks is gorgeous - taking in the best of Sydney virtually for free!

Great Walk. We regularly walk over the bridge to the city and it never ceases to please me. There is always something to look at on the harbour, and for any tourists, the views are great for photography.
The Bridge by night. Floodlighting on pylons and the bridge itself makes for great photo opportunities. Also Opera House and Sydney by night nearby adds value.

Sydney Harbour Bridge - FREE. This great icon from whose deck you experience a magical sunrise or sunset, you can do for free. You walk across the deck on the pedesterian accessway. Follow the signs from the Rocks or if you are on the North-Side (Milson's Point Station) and walk across the bridge. The views are amazing without the big $200 or more price tag attached. Just don't do what some people have been doing of late - attaching a padlock to the mesh. Such behaviour is not only destroying the enjoyment of the bridge for others, this is not China or Rome. It is Sydney. If you walk from the South to the North, you will be rewarded by the best views of Sydney (from under the bridge on the North side) and if you do it at night, Sydney glistens. You can also walk around Luna Park, catch a ferry back to Circular Quay or get the train back into the city or walk back into the rocks. Put on some sensible walking shoes and be open to experience views of Sydney city and across the harbour the postcards boast about.

Like the harbour itself, it defines Sydney. Another example of how lucky we are - we look at the bridge and think how wonderful it is - both an engineering feat and a thing of beauty.But I have read the books on its history and seen the options of what might have been and think how wise our decision makers of the time were.Some of the alternatives were both hideous and would have become non-functioning but the engineers and politicians of the time had more vision than perhaps some of our current people.It clearly brought the city and the northern suburbs together and perhaps diminished the use of ferries to many of these suburbs but it made the city a more cohesive one.
Different View. This is a fairly easy walk and gives a different view of the Opera house and Sydney skyline.Great photo opportunities and if you have kids is a good way to get to Luna Park.
Sydney Hobour bridge. Fantstic view, a life time experience when I walked across. Amazing engineering design. Seen it in pictures but have been there.
Stunning view from the top of the bridge!. Interesting history, what a structure, and..most of all, the view from the top of the bridge. Walking up to the top of the bridge is must!
Bridge Walk. Did the Bridge Walk and it is just sensational! The expertise of the staff and the rewarding views are a "Bucket" experience.

A must!. You have to visit the harbour bridge, thats what sydney is all about! A bit of a longer walk than expected, but well worth it. Beautiful walking down by the sea on the other side which is really secluded, peaceful and great for photos.

I recommened the pedestrian walkway on the bridge. Great views just from the walking path on the east side of the bridge looking back to Circular Quay, the Opera House and City. There is always a constant procession of people going up and down on the bridge climb but this didnt really seem worth the money and time to me.The pylon lookout on the southside of the bridge would get you better views if the walking path isn't enough. If you are visiting Sydney you have to walk across the bridge at least once

Can be done on the cheap :). Rather than spend hundreds scaling the giant coat hangar, we visited the pylon lookout for a much more reasonable price (I think adults cost around $15 each?). Also, unlike the other attractions in Sydney such as the wildlife park, wax museum, aquarium and Sydney eye, we weren't herded through like sheep and forced to pose for a photo that needed to be paid for at the end. There was a photo taken, but it was complimentary and was given to you on the way out. Lots of stairs and can be tricky to find, but worth the effort.

"Seeing is Believing". Well its to see is to believe the iconic landmark of Australia! I took the train from the airport and got off at circular quay, at arrival point, you'd be witnessing the two most famous icons of Australia, took a walk to the Opera house and towards the Rocks, the close up view of the bridge is just spectacular! Great weather to top it all off!

A must do part of any visit to Sydney. We took a taxi to the north side of the bridge and walked back. Great views, and the pylon tower nice at the end. Not too long a walk and sheltered somewhat from th winter wind by fairly high walls.

Climb and Enjoy. My wife and I climbed the bridge arch on dusk with an organised tour operator. Before climbing the bridge we checked the sunset time and timed the climb so as to be at the top as the sun set.The initial briefing took about an hour from arrival. It entailed chanding into special climbing gear and being briefed. The gear supplied included a special clip that attached to a stainless steel cable that wasnt able to be removed from start to finish. Detail to safety was first class. The main walkway on the bridge is quite wide and even though I dont like heights, I wasnt the least concerned.We climbed from the city side in beautiful blue skies and had fabulous views of the Opera House and up and down the Harbour. As we reached the top the sun set and the city lights came on for our climb down. FANTASTIC!We were fortunate that our day was sunny and an ideal temperature. For this type of weather it is best to pick April or September. Although in these months it can still be quite wet. Unfortunately the tours operate in all weather conditions.Overall (as we live quite close to Sydney and visit regularly) this has been the best tourist experience we have done in Sydney. However, it is quite expensive! I believe the operators now run dusk tours and charge more for them.If you find this is too expensive- you can always walk or bike across the bridge for no fee. There are still lovely views of the Opera House and Harbour.

Bravo the Bridge. Great iconic landmark and a great experience to do the Bridge climb for great views from the top. Especially recommended at sunset as the lights of Sydney come on. Worth the expense and the odd scary bit. Just going over the Bridge is an exciting experience too, if you can negotiate the traffic and manage to get into the right lane. Sail under it as well on the the Paramatta ferry, a great Harbour trip.

Beautiful bridge.. This is a beautiful bridge. There is the Harbour bridge and also the Harbour tunnel links you to Sydneys North Shore. The bridge is a beautiful design and you can see the Bridgeclimbers walking up the stairs to the top, seeing the view of Sydney. The Harbour Bridge has stunning views of Sydney, and being so close to the Opera House, it's a feature you must see.
Wonderful. Have not walked it as yet but have driven on it many times it is such a wonderful old bridge its great to look at and gives a great show on new year.
View is stunning. You just have to see it as it is the defining part of Sydney. Plenty of photo opportunities from the Opera House.
Amazing but impressive. Walk for free on the bridge (by taking the stairs in the Rocks). Amazing view to the Opera house. The bridge moves a little and it is quiet imressive but it worths it !
Great adventure. It's a great adventure climbing the Harbour bridge. Lifetime experience. The winds blowing, and breath taking views. Feels just amazing. A must do for all adventure geeks.

The Best Part of Sydney. For me personally, this is the best sight of Sydney. I found the bridge to be one of the most fascinating and interesting constructions built by human hand and the views over the Harbour and towards the Opera House are absolutely magnificent. If you are visiting Sydney, make time to walk across the bridge at least 2/3 times - it will be worth it!
Nice place to visit. It was windy but nice place to be, probably summers would be much better. We were feeling cold.There are lots of information centre to help tourtist

The Sydney Harbour Bridge completes the postcard. Yes Sydney is the Opera House but your gaze will also be drawn to the wonderful Sydney Harbour Bridge. For one of the best free views in the city, walk across the bridge to Milsons Point. You can visit the markets on the way on a Saturday or stop and enjoy the day at one of the many cafes in Milsons Point/Kirribilli.

You must do the Bridge Climb. The iconic Sydney Harbour Bridge is amazing if you are walking across it, over it or looking at it from afar. Wonderful structure and great to hear the stories of when it was made
Unique. Iconic, unmistakable, recognizable, accessible in so many ways for so many people. A must see and experience.
Best Birthday Gift Ever. The group sang happy birthday to me on top of the harbour bridge, it was a gorgeous sunny day and the best birthday gift ever. Guide was extremely knowledgable and friendly.

Very photogenic especially at night. It is a landmark structure of Sydney and is used in virtually any celebration in Sydney as the focal pint and for good reason It is an engineering feat of which there are relatively few bridges and the setting of the harbour bridge as the focal point of the "water views" in Sydney is well deserved

I always enjoy my Walks across the Bridge. The bridge has one of the best pedestrian walks in the world and I make sure I always do one every time I visit Sydney.The best time is early in the morning and views of the city are fantastic.

This was amazing!. In 2010, my wife and I spent a week in Sydeny and the surrounding areas and this was, by far, the most amazing spectacle of our entire trip. The experience is not for the faint at heart or for those with a fear of heights... however, you really have nothing to fear.First, you watch a safety video. Then, everyone in your group harnesses in a jump suit and saftey belt which CAN NOT detach from the safety cables that is strung all through the structure of the bridge. It IS quite a walk but not one that takes a great deal of effort even for a portly person like myself.The view is worth every penny and every step.My recommendation... as soon as you get to Sydney - head straight for this tour.

Bridge Walk is a MUST DO!. it is a little pricey, especially if there are a few of you doing it, but it is well worht it. the guides are full of local and historical knowledge and the views are amazing! (i did a morning walk but I hear the sunset is great too)

Bridge Walk. Yes it's expensive but we did the Bridgewalk and loved it. The walk is relatively easy and well worth the experience of seeing Sydney from the top of the bridge with the wind blowing, birds and helicopters flying by, and the noises of the city far below. The guide was very knowlegeable and entertaining.

Gotta walk the bridge!. Sydney is the most beautiful city in the world because of its harbor but, one thing you must do while in Sydney is walk up the bridge, ride the ferry out to Manly beach & get lunch there, see Bondi beach, go up to the Centrepoint Tower, hang out at Darling Harbor, eat a meat pie at Harry's at Woollomoloo...endless things to do and see and this is only Sydney!!!
Icon structure, some great views. The bridge can be seen from all over the city, it's in a wonderful setting. Great when view from The Rock pier and the Opera House.

Great sight!. This is one of the most well-known bridges in the world and worth stopping at/near for a photo or two. A lot of people RAVED about the Bridge Climb which actually allows you to walk to the top of the Bridge for excellent views of Sydney. Unfortunately, the tour is VERY expensive so I had to skip out but I've never heard a bad comment about it from any who have gone.

Good place to take in the city. Walking across most if not all the Bridge is a good place to view the Opera House, downtown, the harbor, and the Rocks. There are a few different access points to the bridge. I started by taking the lift near the the Train station but jumped off after walking across the bridge and back in The Rocks areas and visited the shops in this area.
Massive!. The Coathanger! Big, beautiful. What a picture. Can 'lead' you to many places! Excellent things to see nearby.
Harbour Bridge,. Driven across the bridge on many occassions but as yet have not walked to the top, probably a bit wary of heights and will never do it but my daughter has and said it was fantastic

Great views, can climb,walk, cycle, drive or train across. Much talked about the bridge was a whole lot smaller than I expected it to be. Really wanted to do he climb but I felt it was just too expensive at almost 300AUD, so I walked across, went up the pylon (15AUD), drove across, went over via train and bus, walked with the daily commuters and thoroughly enjoyed. It provides stunning views of he Opera House and surrounding waterways.Just over 1100 metres long it took 356 days to build and has a whole lot of interesting stories attached to it.Its a good way to get from Kirrilbilli to the Rocks.
Nice walk. I walked from Circular quay via the Harbour Bridge, was nice and had some magnificent views of Sydney.

Do it.. This has always been on my list of things to do and I finally climbed it! I chose to do the 'twilight climb' and it was absolutely picturesque the sunset was amazing and the view of the Opera House and buildings was just gorgeous. I'm not one to be scared of heights but a few people in my group were and I must say the staff were amazing and professional in making sure we all were feeling comfortable. Even though my tour guide had climbed it numerous times that day she was still energetic to do it again and she made it all worth while. So thank you Bianca. This is the best way to see what Sydney is really made of and the view of the harbour is breath taking.

We climbed the bridge.... We did the BridgeClimb and loved it. The weather couldn't have been better. Our guide was so knowledgeable and we enjoyed the time they allowed us to just view the sights. The attention to safety is amazing and we felt completely safe throughout. It is a must if you are visiting Sydney.

Overwhelmingly enormous. The Bridge is an iconic entity that takes your breathe awy when you finally come upon it. It looms so largley in the distance so when you come up close and personal it is simply breathtaking.
Do the bridge climb if you can!. I did not do the bridge climb on this trip, but have done it a few years ago, and it is really fantastic. Highly recommended!

A must when in Sydney!. Climbing the Sydney Harbour Bridge is a must-do when in Sydney! I climbed the bridge with a friend during the day & saw some spectacular views. Our guide was fun & informative. The climb itself is relatively easy & you practice some of the climbing elements prior to setting off which helps. The climb may seem expensive, but I'm not often in Australia!

If its not on Your Bucket List then Shame on You. 3 and a half hours of laughs and amazing scenery, the time just flew. I did the Harbour Bridge Climb with the wife and friends, none of us are young uns and one has a fear of heights, gets wobbly standing on a chair, but had no issues doing the climb, you just feel so safe. From the amazing guides who put you at ease and have a wealth of knowledge, the professional preparation area, the bridge experience itself and the final wrap up it was well worth the money.If you can, book a tour that finishes during twilight so you see the lights in the city and the sun go down as you come down from the top of the Bridge.I want to go back next year and do it at night as it would be spectacular.

Wonderful way to view Sydney. Our family (youngest age 14) did the climb together. We chose the sunset climb. It was worth every penny we paid. We started the climb during daylight & got a view of Sydney harbor, the Opera house & the city in daylight. The sun set during our climb so we also got to view all the same things at night as well. The climb was easy & not scary. The guide was excellent. This was our favorite thing in Sydney!
Sydney arbour. I was at the Sydney Harbour. The view is brath taking. Iwill highly recomment to take the Ferry that goes to The zoo and you will get great view of the Harbour and the Operah House

Bridge climb. I did the Sydney harbour bridge climb a year ago and it was worth every penny paid. Some people think it is expensive which it may be but to me it was well worth it. The guide was first class and was a local and new all about the bridge and places around
Walk across the bridge. Walkimg across the bridge consider climbing up the closer pillion, it only costs $15 per person and you get great pictures of the harbor!

bridge climb. I did the the night time bridge climb in winter in 2011 and even in the freezing winds it did not take away anything from this incredible experience. The staff were super friendly and helpful and made me feel welcome even though I was climbing alone. Because it was icy wind on the night I did my climb they gave us beanies gloves, trackpants and fleece jumper to go over the top of our coveralls.

Magical Sydney. I visited last year 2011, to take the ferry from Darling Harbour and see the Harbour bridge for the first time and the opera house its magical. An experience I will never forget. Cannot wait to go again, so many lovely beaches and attractions.
Beautiful from any angle. Sailed under it, drove over it, looked at it from every angle it truly is an iconic structure. When the kids are older will climb it

Beautiful as always. We noted groups of people walking on top of the Sydney Harbour Bridge! Looked pretty scary even form ground level! The bridge is so distinctive and looks idyllic in the late afternoon! A "must-see" in Sydney

walk it. its amazing to me that when this bridge was planned there were only 4 cars living on the other side yet it was planned with a vission of the future. why dont governments work like that anymore

Just a walk away. no need to pay for a bridge climb! Just bus over to north Sydney, (m20 bus to Gore Hill),get off on the first stop, and walk back over to Sydney Harbour by the footpath of the bridge! you get to see everything from there for only the price of one bus pass!You'll finish the bridge and land in The Rocks district to continue exploring!
BRIDGE CLIMB. Amazing......Was a hot day, views fantastic, need to do this again, maybe at sunset.......this is a must if you are visiting Sydney.
Stunning. the real icon of the city; even more amazing than the wonderful opera house

Great view despite weather. The day we walked across the bridge, it was very overcast and just started to rain. However, it didn't really matter. The view is incredible. You cannot leave Sydney without walking across the bridge. We didn't do the climb, because it was rather expensive, but I don't think we regretted not going. The view really was spectacular. I was freaking out the whole time, just with the fact that we were actually there :)

Bridge climb. Did the bridge climb and it was fantastic...got a bit emotional at the very top as we were held back so that a guy in front could propose to his girlfriend at sunset...what an experience. It's very windy and difficult to hear but we were assured she said yes... a risky place to be if she'd said no!!Great value for money and friendly staff

Climb was very stop/start. For the extortionate price you pay it could have been better organised. They bragged about taking 1000 people up a day and a group every 5 minutes but on the climb the group is stopped every 5 mintes for 15 minute intervals whilst waiting for the previous groups to move. They try to break it up with photos and history talk but there is only so much they can do. All in all with the safety talks/getting dressed in the gear they provide/practice/the extended start and stop walk + buying pics at the end the whole experience lasted 4 hours. To get to top of bridge and back could be done in half an hour so felt like a wasted day but the bridge and it's views are breathtaking. Glad to say i've done it but they need to speed things up.
Awesome view.. I'm scared of heights so doing the bridge walk is not going to happen.However, climbing the tower nearest 'the Rocks' affords you brilliant views & some history as well.

THE CLIMB OF MY LIFE. I simply had to climb the bridge, its worth every penny, you must go through various health & safety procedures before you get going, and its so worth it, and you get checked for alchole, so dont drink the night before otherwise you will not be allowed to do the climb, you het to climb Half of the bridge, so its up to the top and back down the other same side, and you get 3 seperate photos included, and a certificate to prove you did the climb, and for £56 quid, Brilliant
Iconic sydney landmark. a must see hen in Sydney. If you are impressed by the view try seeing it from the air

breathtaking. With a bit of trepidation about heights normally, was very happy to say that you are totally put at ease from the start and there were no anxious moments from start to finish. Very exhilarating but check the weather forecast a couple of days ahead as even though they go up in all weathers, its so much better on a fine day.
Loved it!. Try the Twilight bridge climb on a full moon -Spectacular fun!!

24/7. Open to walk across 24/7 thanks to extensive network of security cameras and 2 or 3 guards on the bridge all night long.Safe for a run, even if you keep odd hours.The panoramic views of Sydney, the Opera House and CBD skyline go without saying?

Sydney Harbour excellent eating & view. Hey Guys My son and I sat down to a excellent lunch while celebrating my 60th birthday and enjoyed this excellent view before going on a 1 hour boat trip around the harbour which is a must do,even in winter.

Nice photo opportunity, gas fumes present while walking across. This review is specifically about crossing the Sydney Harbour Bridge (free) - this does not review the climbing tour experience ($$$!).I have crossed the Sydney Harbour Bridge several times as part of various running paths around Sydney. Accessing the pedestrian bridge is a bit tricky from the Rocks area - one can follow the bike path uphill to find the covered stairs. Once taking the stairs, note that the entrance is not at the top of the stairs, it is one level before the top.The walk is easy and does provide a fantastic photo opportunity of an "aerial" view of Sydney Harbour and the Opera House. Note, one would have to take shots between the protective fence links. There is a pylon about halfway across the bridge which one can climb to obtain additional views. The path is safe and there is always a guard at the pylon view.Because the bridge also provides access to cars, I do not enjoy the experience as much because of the fumes/exhaust. This is worth one visit for the photo opportunity, but there are several other Sydney sites to visit that are more enjoyable.

Iconic Sydney. Sydney is synonymous with its iconic Harbour Bridge and for good reason - this impressive structure frames many of Sydney Harbour's greatest views. I have lived in Sydney for over 10 years now and I am still blown away by the Harbour Bridge - I love seeing it from different angles and it is still thrilling for me when I catch a glimpse of it through the highrises in the city or when driving towards it from the North Shore. There are so many ways to experience the Bridge - a walk across it on a sunny Sydney morning is glorious and offers fantastic views of the Harbour and the Opera House; for the more adventurous, the Bridge Climb is a must, giving interesting information on the history of the Bridge and its construction as well as some even more impressive views over the Harbour, city skyline and Opera House; walks near Mrs Macquarie's Chair and also the Observatory Hill provide fabulous views of the Bridge itself.I've just read some other reviews and have realised that I've been waxing eloquent about the Bridge itself, when I am supposed to be reviewing the Bridge Climb... so here is a bit more about the climb itself which I did a couple of years ago. While a bit pricey, it is definitely worth doing - both by people who are on their one and only visit to Sydney and by residents of the city. What's great about it is that the Bridge Climb operates in all kinds of weather except during electrical storms. So whatever the weather, you will be guaranteed a unique perspective of the city. The guides are very knowledgable, confident and able to answer all sorts of questions about the Bridge. You are not allowed to carry your own cameras, but the guides take some cheesy shots of each climber/couple/group so you will still have a memento of your climb.

Loved it -going back for the twilight climb. I was initially somewhat anxious about the height but I felt very reassured by the professionalism of the pre-climb orientation and our guide so the height wasn't a problem at all. Did a 1pm climb and blessed with the perfect weather, middle of winter but almost no wind and sunny, awesome views. It was so good I'm planning to do it again at twilight.I was very impressed with the professionalism and attention to safety and detail - I felt safe at all times. A complete orientation beforehand prepares you for the climb. You will be breathalyzed and must have a 0.00 BAC.Took approx 3 hours in total & it just flew. There are a couple of ladders and lots of stairs but very gently sloping so it's a fairly easy climb. One of our party was nearly 70 and had no trouble.Wear comfortable shoes, runners or sturdy walkers. You will be provided with a suit and all weather jacket. See the website it gives comprehensive details.A bucket list must do - awesome experience - worth every cent.

Spectacular sights. Sydney harbour bridge offers spectacular views over the city and Opera house, the tour is well organized and is something to remember this fantastic city by.Your group will have people from many far and distant places and your group photograph on the top of the bridge is one you will treasure for the rest of your life.

A must-do. It's pricey, but it's worth it. Pick a clear day and you'll be treated to fabulous views as you inch your way up and down the bridge. The guides are professional, knowledgeable and confident. Can't recommend this more highly!
Nice. beautiful scenary and view from there... used to travel there a lot

Still amazing. It still takes your breath away no matter how many times you see it. I don't think you can really say you've been to Australia until you've had your picture taken with the bridge and the Opera House.

Spectacular!. walked all around the bridge, was great at night time! amazing to think what went into constructing the bridge! been before when the Vivid light show is on and its spectacular! must see!

Sydney Harbour Bridge. Great views towards the east (Opera House, Circular Quay, Fort Denison, Mrs Macquarie's Chair and the Heads) from the Bridges' eastern walkway (bicycles are only allowed on the western part of the Bridge). The walk from one end of the bridge to the other takes 30-45 minutes depending on how many stops you make to take photographs. One of the best views of Sydney Harbour and Sydney city is from the Harbour Bridge. Keen photographers should consider a walk across the Bridge but do so in the late afternoon as the westerly sun is behind you. The sun is directly in your face in the mornings so photography is not the best at that time. There are cafes, restaurants, shops and hotels (public bars) on both sides of the Bridge so hunger and thirst can be quickly quenched after the walk. May to July is probably not the best time to visit as it may get windy and cold. The tourist cruise ships visit in the summer months and many dock at the Overseas Passenger Terminal at Circular Quay. A great view of the cruise ships can be obtained from the Harbour Bridge walk.

Love the bridge under and over. It is great to walk across the bridge on the walkway and my children love playing underneath where the pylons are. I walked on top afew years ago and that was an amazing experience. Try to pick a fine day as you can see for miles and get a whole different pespective of this beautiful city and Harbour.
The Sydney Harbour Bridge. We passed on the harrowing looking bridge climb but loved walking the entire bridge in spite of the heat...the views of the Harbour and the Opera House were INCREDIBLE!!
Best Place to see Sydney from above!. This is definitely the best place to see Sydney from above. The guided tour is very imformative.
Historical.... Took the day tour bus to go there and the recorded commentary about the Habour bridge's history was worth a listen... Gr8 spot for taking pictures..

Walk under it, over it, above it.... I'm a local but never get bored of the Bridge. So many ways to get across it, and no matter what angle you are on it, you're bound to get an interesting view of some sort. For a quick look on the way to the Norther Suburbs, catch the train - its a spectacular view of the entire Harbour going from Wynyard to Milsons Point. My favourite part of the bridge is actually under it and being able to inspect the magnificnet structure and architecture while making an interesting backdrop with canons and harbour views.

Must see landmark!!. This bridge is absolutely amazing. Having watched the bridge change over the years has been really cool and interesting. I don't think any other landmark has moved with the times and yet kept true to its' origins like the Harbour Bridge has. The pylon museum has all the history of the bridge and details the construction along with a look out at the top. Also the Bridge Climb is spectacular, even with the corny picture stops every 5 minutes! The Bridge Climb is not cheap but worth the money no matter what time of day you go. Even if you only just walk from one side to the other, definitely make this a point to visit.
Beaut Bridge. This wonderful, ageless bridge gives the finishing touches to the stunning Sydney Harbour and city of Sydney.

Another Iconic Sydney Attraction. The Sydney Harbour Bridge was on my jogging route every morning during our stay in Sydney. Sometimes you would see a tourist team climbing it or huge cruise ships passing by. I loved to run on this bridge and see the beautiful views every morning.

WOW. Not much to say except YOU MUST CROSS THE BRIDGE - whether it be in a taxi, bus, under in a ferry or take a walk its absolutely brilliant.The walk over took us approx 1/2hour and that allowed for photo opportunities too.

Great view. The Sydney Harbor bridge is certainly a site to behold. I tried to view it from different perspectives (e.g., from the Royal Botanic Gardens, the Opera House, from Circular Quay, from the Manly Ferries and from Luna Park) and each provides a very different but equally beautify view. The view from Mrs. Macquarie's Chair in the Royal Botanic Garden, with the Sydney Opera House anchoring one end of the bridge, has got to be one of my favorites.I've also climbed it with the Sydney Bridge Climb, and it certainly provides a different experience. Will provide a detailed review of that under that category.

awesome to say the least. i did not go on the bridge walk but walked over the bridge from milsons point to the rocks steps on a warm afternoon was a way to go but it was a hell of a way to spend a few hours in the brillant morining sunshine

Climb the Pylon!. Walking across the bridge from the city, be sure to visit the Pylon for intriguing bridge photos and facts, as well as incredible views of the bridge itself, the harbor and Opera House. Well worth the admission fee ($11/adult and less for child).

Fantastic!. The Bridge Climb is a wonderful experience if you have the opportunity. The view is amazing. If you can't climb the Harbor Bridge, you should at least walk across it or climb the pylon for a great view of the harbor and the Opera House.

A great piece of coathanger. What Ozzie doesn't like this bridge, you can ride on it by car, train, bike, bus or walk its just so accessible. Its the best site you can see when you are flying in and best of all you can climb it, what else do you need. And the sites and scenery from it are unbeatable

The Bridge. What an amazing structure, if you do the "bridge climb" you are up close and personal with one of Sydney's best constructions and views, it doesn't get much better than this on a warn Sydney day.

The most amazing experience!. You won't be disappointed in this. Even though now a little pricy you will fall in love with the view and Sydney. The walk up is very secure, far from the edge and a very gentle walk. Not scary at all.
Sydney Harbour Bridge. Nice to see the fireworks fro, the bridge on New Years Eve
Great fun. This is a must when in Sydney, fun walk with great staff, view is awesome and you will learn a lot re the history of the bridge and sydney.

We did the bridge climb and it was a highlight of our trip. While in Sydney we decided to do the Harbor Bridge Climb. They offer a host of climbs depending on your time and interest. We took "The Bridge Climb" which takes a little over 3 hours (1 hour of preparation and a little over 2 hours on the bridge). They also have an "Express Climb that takes about 2 hours and is a bit more strenuous. We had a really great time. Our guide Kate was fun and really informative. She really enjoyed her job and made our climb a great experience. The climb in not hard at all as we had a number of seniors with us and they had no problem with the level of exertion. You don't have to worry about the height as the bridge is so massive you don't really feel like you are that high (you are also tethered in). The views are fantastic and the information about the bridge was very interesting. If you have the time while in Sydney it is a great family outing.

Walked it and loved it!. The express walk was awesome and although they said it was a bit harder than the others, we never felt physically under pressure and we're not that fit! Amazing staff and views incredible!
Stunning to marvel at. I drove over the bridge yesterday and never stop marvelling at the magnificence of it.
Its just so big!. I loved going underneath it by ferry. Worth seeing at night time too.
What a view. A great view of Sydney from this iconic bridge. A climb up the tower closest to The Rocks gives a really wonderful view and much cheaper than the climb up the bridge.

Bridge Climb is great!!!. It is a must do at least once in your life. View is amazing while climbing. Although it may sound like a very challenging excercise it is actually not hard.
It is rather expensive, but worth it :)

underwhelming. We were looking forward to seeing Sydney harbour bridge but felt underwhelmed by it. It wasn't as spectacular as we had hoped.
There's plenty of seating along the harbour walls and apparently there's a firewirks show every Saturday night to highlight the bridge

Excellent Construction. When you are over the bridge you are just mesmerized with a view you get from there. Bridge its construction, lighting and they way the harbour looks for the top is a feeling that you will never get in a casino, this will be a true feeling of natural beauty!

A must-do when in Sydney. (A long-overdue review) Our guide, Grace, was awesome. The climb was fun. The view is breath-taking. We did a day climb and enjoyed it thoroughly. This is an activity definitely worth doing. I would recommend it to everyone and anyone.

Wow, what a drive. I did the Bridge Climb in 2003 and really enjoyed it! This time however we drove over the bridge multiple times in my friends convertible with the top down. The views coming over are just magical.
Nice to work with manay Security Guard. Walk along bridge and see nice scenery and very fresh air
Bridge climb. If you can cope with heights then do the bridge climb - the views are superb and its a great experience

A little disappointed. We were very excited about visiting Sydney and going to see the Harbour Bridge as it is such an icon for the city. However, it seemed much smaller than we expected.
It was only a little disappointing though as it was still great to see the bridge and opera house together.

A great experience.. My wife and I recently visited Sydney and she was a bit worried about climbing so high. But she gave it a go. WE both had a great time, the guides were very well trained and looked after any nervous people. We found the climb very safe being restrained at all times. The views of Sydney terrific and well worth the $208.00 each.

Birds eye view. Some of the best views to be had of the city are from the bridge. You can pay and do the bridge climb but this is quite an expensive option. We decided to do the pylon viewpoint which in my opinion is just as good for far less money. A must when in Sydney.

Beautiful!. An amazing bridge
My mother did the bridge climb whilst us others just walked it at 'car' level (too young at the time)
Tiring for the little kids though
The best bridge in the world.. Do not take this bridge for granted. It is beautiful, walked across it and the views are breathtaking.
Great to walk over. We walked next to the traffic rather than up high. We had a great view of the harbour, I highly recommend walking across.

Magnificent!. It was amazing to see this magnificent bridge in person. I absolutely wanted to go and climb it however i couldn't due to time constraints. While i was there I got to catch the light show vivid going on in the city and that was magical!!

Sydney Harbour Bridge Walk. Awesome view walk on the bridge, from The Rocks to Milsons Point Railway station, just a great feeling. PS during peak hour traffic on the bridge there will be heavy petrol smell I hate~
Walk it!. Often walk across this to Luna park with the kids when staying at the Rocks and walk back. Surprisingly easy, and the view any time of day or night never fails to impress.
Wow that things amazing. In awe of the scale of the bridge, it's a surprisingly beautiful thing!

Behind the scenes story - fascinating. We did NOT do the bridge walk - it was raining and would have been a bit treacherous. The museum inside the pylon was very educational and the view almost as good ( :o
Lots cheaper at 11AUD per person than the bridge walk.

If you're in Sydney you MUST take a stroll across the bridge. It will take at least an hour and you will be tired from doing the trip, but if you have the time and the health you really should take a stroll across the Bridge.Three options are recommended:1) Take a Ferry from Circular Quay to Luna Park and then walk up to the Milsons Point train station. Get on the Bridge there and walk across towards Circular Quay. You will come out on The Rocks area.2) Take a train over to Milsons Point station. Get on the Bridge there and walk across towards Circular Quay. You will come out on The Rocks area.3) The opposite way to 1 and 2 above, which is to start at The Rocks and walk over to Milsons Point.The view is spectacular all the way across, but be sure to have some warm clothing if you are doing this in the evening/night in winter. It can get very cold. This walk will probably give you the best photos of the Sydney Opera House you can get. You can even climb up the Lookout Point half-way through. But be warned, it is 200 steps to the top! So you need either a healthy constitution or a lot of patience and determination.

Excellent views of the Opera House and the Harbour. Initially I was content just viewing the bridge from the Circular Quay and the Opera House. But curiousity got the better of me and we decided to walk on the bridge. And it was a good decision, somewhere near the middle of the bridge, you get excellent views of the Sydney Opera House and the Harbour. I got some of my best pictures here. One thing to note: The winds are strong, so don't wear hats!

Take longer than you think to walk across... Which we found out the hard way, ofcourse. But it's fine, as it was a beautiful day in a beautiful city. A long walk across was fine. But the sunburn was not. So kids, remember to wear sunscreen, and don't buy the cheapest crap like we did, get some better stuff. We would've loved to of done the walk across the top of the bridge, but 200 dollars (in january 2008) was far too expensive for two penny saving backpackers like us.

A must for your visit "don't look down!!". Take time to walk over the bridge to look back at the operahouse and other sights from a different angle. We walked over at night when the traffic was less (less noise). You can always get the train back via the station on the other side.

A true wonder. It is one of the modern wonders of the world...or should be! Take a trip on a ferry to kirribilli, mosman, taronga zoo, manly or rose bay to see it from 'the good side' (ie: with the opera house in front for photos)

Do It!. Coming from a city with an iconic bridge, San Francisco, it is obligatory to cross other cities' iconic bridges. This one was no disappointment, on a beautiful late fall day. Best views in Sydney, especially if you pay the few $$ for a lift to the top of the pylon. And if you are really daring, you can also pay to climb the cables to the top (I passed). The suicide barrier is more than a minor impediment to the views, but I am guessing effective at saving lives. (Still under debate for the Golden Gate in San Francisco.)

Thankyou Dr.John Bradfield...... Most tourists arriving in Sydney take the Harbour Bridge and the Opera House for granted- they are there to be looked at ,enjoyed and photographed. As a Sydney resident they are a part of our everyday scenery-but when I, as a Sydney resident look back at the history of this city and early transportation there was this big gap between north and south of the harbour with ferries and all sorts of other means of getting goods and people across Fortunately there was an incredible vision Inspired by Dr. J.J. Bradfield in the 1920's to 30's with engineering ability to consruct something like the Sydney Harbour Bridge....in era a of a few cars the Bridge was built to cater for cars,trams and trains is still coping with Sydney traffic with help from the Harbour tunnel.....Do the "Bridge Climb" if you can....or else just walk over or around and appreciate the marvel that we have here in Sydney...No current politician would even dare to approve a project on this scale and expense-but it has served us well for 80 years...
Best day of our lives.. Brilliant! Our guide Tyra was so polite and the trip was beautiful.
not a climber. opted not to climb due to wind and choice to visit other sites, e.g. Toronga Zoo, Manley Beach, and great view from ShangriLa hotel, and hop on hop off bus tours.

Panoramic view of the Harbour. . Navigating your way to the access points if the bridge walk way can be challenging. Once on the right path the walk is enjoyable and presents a panoramic view of the Harbour.
A Famous Bridge. After seeing the photo's of the bridge, it looks better when you have the chance to actually see it and walk across it.
Walk across the harbour. I have been to Sydney many many times over the years and never realised that you could actually walk across the Harbour Bridge via The Rocks. Loved it!!!
great engineering. It was amazing! But too nervous to walk up the steps on the Sydney Harbour Bridge. From Mrs Macquarie's Chair, it looks stunning. Not to be missed.

The Coathanger. Australia travelBy: Zdenko KahlinaThe Sydney Harbour BridgeIt is the most famous bridge in Australia. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is located opposite the Sydney Opera House and close to Circular Quay. You can certainly find the Sydney Harbour Bride on most postcards, souvenirs and any tourist guides. The Sydney Harbour Bridge and the Sydney Opera House are iconic images of both Sydney and Australia. Complete review including the pictures can be found here:http://zkahlina.ca/eng/2012/04/12/the-coathanger/

Always good!. Any time on or by Sydney harbor is a good time. In summer (or any time) catch the Manly Ferry and enjoy the harbour activities. You can pay for a harbour cruise with meals or use the Ferry to move about. Always fun crossing the heads in a swell and smashing into the waves.

What a way to the the view. A walk over the harbour bridge is a must for any person visiting Sydney. The history of the bridge and the walk is right up there with other landmarks around the world, put thin on your bucket list.
Wow. Seeing on tv or in movies is great but seeing it live or even at sunset is just amazing!

May 2012. We took a Sydney Ferry from Sydney Harbour (buy a pass so you can use all of the transportation for "free") over to Luna Park and walked down the paths and random streets until we came upon the Sydney Harbour Bridge so that we could walk back towards the Harbour.I agree with everyone here that the Bridge is a must. We walked over it for free and enjoyed great views of the Sydney Opera House, the Harbour and the bridge itself.We debated whether or not to do the bridge climb, but the fact that you can't bring your own camera (and honestly, I think their reasons are bogus; cameras can be clipped to you so they don't fall!) stopped us from spending the $200 each to do it. We have no regrets because the views we got just from walking over the bridge were fantastic. Definitely take the time to do this!
WHAT A VIEW!. This is one of the best things we have ever done! It was a great view, and a thrill to climb.

Breathtaking. There is no better way to see Sydney than from the top of Sydney Harbour Bridge. The climb takes a few hours and is a little expensive but what an experience. The only thing I didn't like was that you can't take your own camera on the climb, this is for safety reasons in case you drop it down onto the roadway beneath.

Bridge Climb is a MUST. Climbed the Harbour Bridge on my birthday. Amazing, beautiful views of the harbour and city. Absolutely breathtaking. The climb is not vigorous, so all ages can enjoy this experience. We had sunny, crisp weather and an informative and fun guide that also added to the enjoyment of this experience.

Beautiful view. Standing under the bridge, you'll have the perfect view of the Opera House. If you want a spectacular view of the bridge and want to get some exercise while you're at it, go for a swim in the North Sydney Olympic Pool (next to Luna Park). Float on your back and enjoy the view!

Suggestion for cheap A1 experience. Walking across the harbour bridge is a must for all Sydney visitors and obviously Bridge Climb is an excellent addendum but it is very pricey. Our visitors are usually hand to mouth back packers scrounging a free bed and board so a standard outing which has proved successful is to go to Circular Quay board a ferry for Kirribilli which should first cross under the bridge to Lavender Bay before going to Kirribilli. The steps up to the bridge are only a short distance from the wharf. Walk over the bridge towards the city and you descend down the steps into The Rocks. Lovely morning out.
Love that bridge. walk beneath & look at the size of the pins that hold the whole bridge together.
