Only Walked the Bridge!. We chose not to climb the bridge. We found it an easy walk to walk over the bridge and watch up to see those that were climbing it. I think we would have gone on the climb if it didn't cost so much!!
It's the bridge. It seems sureal to be there. The fireworks were amazing, real life is always best.

Stunning. It is just such a great icon and also you realise what important role this bridge plays in terms of transport. I don't think you need to tell too much about this, because I cannot imagine you will miss this on your trip to Sydney.
Highspot of harbour. Take a walk across it. Go into exhibitions in turrets. Walk over it - scary but worth it. Go under it by ferry.

Climb it if you have the time - it's worth it. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of those few things that everybody in the developed world immediately recognizes. Driving (or taking the train, or walking, or cycling) across it is spectacular enough and rewards you with great view of the Harbour itself (although there will always be a safety fence between you and the view), but there are also two ways to see the bridge from a different angle. The first is to climb one of the bridge pylons on the south side of the bridge. Entry is cheap, and it gives you a great view of the city and the bridge itself. The other is climbing the bridge. Yes, climbing it! You will have to book in advance, and it costs several hundred dollars per person (more expensive around sunset time), but I found it very worth it - definitely an adventure to remember, and totally safe.

Bridge Climb. We really enjoyed the bridge Climb and would highly recommend it. Our guide was wonderful and the views from on top of the bridge were breathtaking. It is such a recognizable landmark whenever you see pictures of Sydney Harbor and you can think..."I was standing on top of that!' I will caution that the climb can be strenuous. There were some in our group that were self-admittedly out of shape, but our guide took us up slowly, stopping to be sure everyone had enough time to rest before continuing. It should not be difficult for people of reasonable fitness level and ability. Very fun!

Beautiful structure on Sydneys skyline. Able to be seen from many areas. Enjoyed walking over the bridge and being able to look down on the opera house and people moving abour below as well as see all the boating activity on the harbour.
A Sydney icon. It was fun to watch participants on the bridge climb. We were unable to do the climb this trip but hope to do it in the future as we have heard many positive reports.

Best in the world. So much is going on around this iconic shaped bridge. Underneath there are hotels, The Rocks, restaurants and shops and transport and views. Circular Quay just there where there are boats and ferries etc to take you to other parts of Sydney Harbour and if you are lucky, they will go under the Bridge and that;s a great experience. Also climbing over the top which gives you a great view of so much of what Sydney has to offer.

Beautiful!. It is pretty. Don't do the bridge climb... it is overpriced and you won't get a better view than from other tall buildings in the area. If you climb the pilons (used to be$5) you get a similar view

bridge climb. We did the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb. It was an awesome time, the price is a bit much but its a most if its your only visit to Sydney, You can see all of the city even to the Blue Mts. Just make sure the day is not to hot because you have to wear jump suits and the metal and sun make for a very HOT situation! Worth the money!

Must do. Enjoyed seeing it from the Ferry , from the Opera House. Enjoyed taking a train to Milsons Point and walked back. Went up the tower for $10 which was well worth it, great views. To expensive to wear a boiler suit and be tied to it. loved to see it day or night

The Sydneysider's Icon. Sydneysiders actually consider the Sydney Harbour Bridge more of an icon than the Sydney Opera House. It's big, it's useful and it feel like home.You can climb over it (pretty expensive, booking required), walk or bike across it (separate paths). The best, however, is to go up the observation deck in the south-east pylon. Reasonably priced, nice view and a useful history lesson in the construction of the bridge.

Childhood. I first saw it when my father brought me to Sydney from Victoria after my mother passed away, when I was 9 years old. We stayed within in sight of the bridge at a B&B in Kirrabilly, and I have loved it ever since.

Nicer to look at it from elsewhere.... Don't think I'd bother walking across it as its always packed with people, and you can't see much due to the barriers and fences. The roar from the traffic and trains make it a bit unpleasant really. If you are prepared to shell out the big price for the Bridge Climb, it is pretty spectacular....and scary if you don't like heights.
Under the bridge. After dinner we went for a walk to look at the bridge. It's massive! Sat down on the grass and there were really nice views from underneath.

Nice to do but overpriced and too long. I did the climb with two friends. It was nice to do and you get really cool views but I wouldn't recommend doing it.It is way overpriced and you can't take photos. The photos the guide takes are really expensive to buy which is a bit much given that you pay a lot to do the climb.Also the climb is far too long. It takes about 3 hours when it could be done in half that time. You stop too often to look out at slightly different viewpoints. I would have Rathered a faster pace.
Like the Pictures. It was pretty cool to see it but to let you know if you use the public transport river boat its 3/4 of the price of the rip off cruise lines to go under the bridge :)

Worth a few hours.. You can climb it and pay but we were just as happy to just go up one of the pylons and also walk across it. It's a great structure and you get good views of the city. On the other side we wandered down to the ferry wharf to return. A nice couple of hours.
More impressive in person. Great to see from far away and great to walk across. Didn't do the bridgeclimb but looks really neat!
An experience like no other.. Do the walk, fantastic experience and I was scared of heights but it was awesome

Walk, climb, ride all recommended. The bridge is the heart of the harbour. It is recommended to walk across the bridge -the views from the pedestrian walkway are fantastic and go up inside the pylon to get even better views. For those who are fit and can afford it is possible to climb the bridge span. Walking from Circular Quay to Milson's Point across the bridge and then taking a train or bus back gives the best of both worlds just avoid peak hours

A Bridge Walk Worth the Money. Australia specializes in activities and sights that cannot be found anywhere else on this small planet. Sydney excels in this respect. An activity that tourists should not miss is the Sydney Bridge Walk. It is expensive but worth every penny. Reasonably challenging for sure, but surprisingly not scary. Our group of 5 all survived the experience without suffering any of the vertigo we had half joked about prior to the climb. We were fortunate to witness the start of the Annual Sydney to Hobart Sailing Race below us in the Harbour and surprise, surprise, to see Bill Gates and his family follow us on the Bridge Climb. That is the closest we will ever be to one of the richest people on this planet. He seems to tie his shoes the same way we all do.

It was OK (The Sydney Harbour Bridge). The view and everything was Excellent but we wanted to go on the top bridge which was located at the top of the Sydney Harbour Bridge but when we went almost all the place trying to find where we must go to climb the man said that we have to go back all that way s we just walking on the bridge but it was a bit Scary and VERY tiring
Spectacular views. Spectacular views....enjoyed my walk across the bridge.

Sydney City and Harbour Views. The Bridge connects North from South Sydney. You can walk across or climb to the top - The Bridge Climb takes about 3 hours as training and dressing takes 1 hour. This is very interesting specially at sunrise or sunset. However there are buildings (Hotels near the water) which also offer similar views.
Iconic. You can not visit Sydney without seeing it, going on it, under it or over it!
What across the bridge. The Harbor Bridge was magnificent lit up for the New Year. The New Year's Eve fireworks on and from the bridge are indescribable and not to missed.
Walk Over the Bridge. Even if you cannot afford to do the bridge climb, spend an hour walking on both sides of the roadway and look at Sydney. It is an amazing structure.
Climb it Cross it or Sail under it.. The view from the Sydney Harbour Bridge viewing the magnificents of the harbour is worth every minute of your visit.

Got to be done. The Harbour Bridge is one of Sydney's icons so must be visited. We couldn't afford the bridge climb so walked across and have to say so well worth it. Great views back to the Opera House and city. Nice cafes on the north side near Luna Park.
Just a bridge.. Not worth walking on, the views from the harbour are fantastic, its better to see the bridge from there. The opera house for me was the highlight of the harbour.

"The" Sydney icon. Just about everyone who takes a picture in Sydney gets a snap of the Harbour Bridge. Day or night it is just big, unreal and had a powerful presence. A walk under the span at the Rocks is an adventure back in time, and a walk over the arch, if you are game, is a lifetime highlight.
One of the runners up in the wonders of the world competition.. If your in Sydney gotta see the Harbour Bridge if you get a chance take a walk over it.
Fabulous. On a clear day you can see forever. If your squemish with heights you should still give it a go
Just a bridge. Just an ordinary bridge, bottled necked every day with vehicles, "A huge Toll Paying Car Park" Nothing compared to bridges around the world...

The Coathanger. The harbour bridge is another icon of Sydney along with the opera house. You can cross it by car, train, cycle or by foot. You can go into one of the South pylon for a small fee and do the bridge climb for approx 200 (depending on the time of day). A great vantage point for the bridge is from Mrs Macquaries chair.
Iconic. A walk over the Harbour Bridge is lovely. Take the ferry back!
no words!. It's so beautiful and it is lovely to walk or drive over, as long as there are no traffic jams!
a Sydney icon. this almost defines Sydney as much as the Opera House and is easier to visit than say the Golden Gate, and you can walk across it more easily
What a photographic city. Sydney is one of the most picturesque cities. From everywhere you get glimpses of water.

View of the city from the bridge is not to be missed. The walk over (or at least to the middle) is a Sydney "must-do" Just make sure you are on the side towards the Opera House. The side towards Darling Harbor is for bikes only. Some friendly riders got us out of the bike's way...then we noticed the painted bike icons on the pathway! Views from the bridge are great. The only negative are the wire protections which mar the photographs. You can get your camera through the gap, but it was impossible to get a shot of us and the Opera House or city skyline. Security guards were present 1/3 of the way across. There is always something different to see because of all the harbor activity. Sydney takes this bridge to heart. I overheard a local saying, "I hate the cruise ships that come in because they make our bridge look small" The bridge is not small. Make sure you also visit the shop/museum where the bridge climb starts. The short video and displays will only add to your bridge walk experience.

This is a must visit structure.. I took pics of this bridge from every angle and was blown away by the sheer size of it when i walked on to it.It has six lanes of traffic(including one bus lane) one bicycle lane,trains running opposite directions across oh and yeah the pedestrian side which i was on but had to leave quickly before a thunder storm hit for over an hour that Evening.Here's an interesting footnote or two i think for them to put one coat of paint on that bridge it takes over 340,000 litres of paint which is supposed to help stop rust from developing and the actor/comedian Paul Hogan from the movie Crocodile Dundee used to be one of workers who helped maintain the Sydney Harbour Bridge before he became famous.

Excellent view. A beautiful structure to begin with, where you can see both sides of the Sydney Harbour. I was surprised to see that there were not only cars and buses on it, but also walking people and even trains! A walk from North Sydney to Circular Quay is strongly recommended for those who want to exercise and look at the most beautiful harbour at the same time.

AN AWESOME VIEW. I found the upper portion of the bridge quite pricey and I'm afarid of heights so I did the walk from the highway level. Its an easy access from the Rocks and there are signs to get you there too .. your can take nice pics of Circular Quay Opera House etc .. just fit it through the mesh .. there is a viewing area about half way across .. at a small fee which is a detraction to most?The walk across was nice and once there .. lots to see on the other side .. spend a few hours exploring the area .. get a map and all will be fine .. restaurants and coffee shops are close too!!A different perspective of the downtown exporation .. good exercise too!!!
Love it. when ever i see this I know that I home and it is so amazing and an amazing engineering wonder.

Second time and just as good as the first. On a recent visit to Sydney I went across the bridge for a second time. It is a very well run operation staffed with keen people who are passionate about their job and the city of Sydney. It is well worth doing (even in the rain) the views are great and it helps put the city in perspective

This Bridge Takes Your Breathe Away. No matter how many times I come to this great city there is one place that just seem to speak to me and that's the Sydney Harbor Bridge. Take the time to explore the bridge in many ways..If you are a lot more barve than I am then take the tour over the bridge. However if you realized a long time ago that some of us are built to stay on the ground explore the areas that the bridge touches. Especially on a Saturday morning- You will have a great time at the booths that the locals sell all kinds of wares at or walk on up with a bottle of wine in the afternoon and take in the music that is always being played my various musicians at the top of the rocks. What a way to relax...great wine, great people and a great bridge. Oz is the land that we wished we could visit a lot more often.
Bridge Walking!. The bridge is an excellent walk! Got to do it. When you walk over from North Sydney check out the restaurants and shops at the Rocks.

Great View & Experience. We have all seen the Harbour Bridge from various aspects around Sydney. But have you seen Sydney from the Harbour Bridge? We decided to walk across the Bridge from the Rocks side and it was awesome. It is a bit of a hike but well worth the effort - just follow the signs. You should also climb the stairs at the south east pylon (not to be confused with the "Bridge Climb") and get an unimpeded view of the city scape and harbour towards the heads for $11. Make sure you bring your camera, comfortable walking shoes and plenty of drinking water!

"Largest Coat Hanger". This is the Landmark of Sydney which one can never get tired of looking.It is huge and one should take a walk across the bridge to appreciate it.I love photographing bridge in all different lighting.Best time to be around the bridge is on new years eve fireworks.A sight not be missed.

Amazing Scenery and very relax atmosphere. I come on winter to australia, my first destination is perth then to melbourne,sydney,cairns,last stop is gold coast. Im enjoying my time in there,i love the weather,even its cold,but i love it very much,its relaxing and amazing feeling,me and my brother do really enjoy Australia,especially the memorable moment when we are at harbour bridge,we oftenly spent our night there,we take alot of scenery,we love to see the ferry around,the crowded,and also sydney opera house,sitting around harbour bridge in winter???why not????trust me you will got amazing feelings combine with hot chocolate and your coat for sure!!!!
Amazed on every visit. always amazed at the size and spectacle of the bridge both when driving over and walking beneath. only when driving over it becomes confusing which lane to take eeikkk.
Walk across it one day. It's lovely to look at from afar, but the walk across is also really good. Definitely worth doing!
Excellent visit. From here you can go anywhere by boat, well worth hopping on one of the goverment cruises does not cost as much as the other private ones and are just as good

Don't walk in the morning. My husband and I walked the bridge on the morning of a 30 degree day. VERY little shade options here so got extremely burnt. The views were fantastic. We didn't pay to climb or go up the bridge tower as I couldn't see the point with such great views already. The walk back across in the afternoon was well shaded making it much cooler :)

Sit and look. It is such a wonderful Bridge. I can sit and look at it for hours. I don't know how many photos I took of it. The whole area is great. You can explore all the different views of the bridge.

Sydney Harbour Bridge Walk. This is a must - an experience of a lifetime even if your legs really ache the next day!! The tour guide Romeo was fantastic and the safety talks and practise ladders were very helpful. Our group had various ages and levels of fitness but we all thoroughly enjoyed it. Highly recommended.

What a peice. Although we saw this Harbour Bridge from a distance, i.e. during our City Sight Tour on Hop On and Hop Off Bus on 1st January, 2012, we also took an opportunity to visit the same from nearby and that's why after our Blue Mountain Tour on 2nd January, 2012, we went to see the same in the evening and enjoyed.
Iconic. Lovely to see.Went across it on the train.We went under it but didn't go on it....it looked way too high to walk across.....brave people climbing it....
Sydney Harbour. It is a very well looked after harbour so the views are spectactular :)

An Amazing Structure, With an Amazing Story!. It is understandable why Sydney is famous for its Bridge & Opera house, they are beautifully positioned in the harbour. A must see!Recommend doing the Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb too :D
Climb at dawn and experience Sydney waking up!. Excellent tour leader with loads of local knowledge on history of the bridge and Sydney. Fantastic experience all round

See it, Walk it. You can get a great view of the Harbour Bridge from Circular Quay where you can also take a ferry to see it on the water or walk around to the Opera House for another perspective. Also from the quay you can get a lift up to the express way that leads onto the bridge itself and walk across to Milsons Point/Kirribilli where there are some good eateries. Walk back or take the train at Milsons Point back to the city. You do have to pay to visit the museum up one of the pylons and you can book ahead and pay for a walk over the arch of the bridge.
Magnificent icon....the jewel in the crown!. Great to wander around, at ground level, on both sides of the harbour & to walk across. Did the Bridgewalk a year or so ago, brilliant experience!

Best view in the world. Sydney Harbour on a sunny day is unaparralleled! The bridge is an icon of Australia and is a must see for every traveller. You can pay a reasonable price to actually climb the bridge to the top of the arch which is a definate must do for tourists visiting Sydney.
Walk across for free. Take a stroll across the bridge for free for some great views of the city. Didn't seem to be much on the other side though but a great way to pass a few hours.
wot a view from heaven. best view in sydney ,climb the bridge and enjoy my sydney ,paradise on a stick

The Coat Hanger. Perhaps one of the two sights associated with Sydney Harbour the Sydney Harbour Bridge can be walked across the deck or for the more daring who are not afraid of heights a bridge climb over the arch is recommended and will provide a panoramic view of the city and harbour from the top of the arch.

It aint a bridge, it's an entertainer !. Climb it, drive through it, go on a train over it,cruise under it or just fly around it. And if you need a life changing experience, witness the firework's show on it in New Year's eve. Awesome place to be,anytime of the year.
Stunning Structure. Stunning Structure. Try to do the bridge climb if you can. If not make sure you walk over the bridge for some great views

I love the coathanger. What is not to like.
It is one of Sydney's iconic items and am so proud to be a Sydneysider
nice bridge-. i did not do the bridgewalk but traveled over via train and car and it is a beautiful iconic bridge and great view
Magnificent Structure. The bridge must be one of the world’s great manmade wonders. A truly magnificent structure with brilliant views on the harbour.

It's something you have to do at least once in your life!!. It's a part of Sydney and Australias history. AMAZing
Don't let a fear of heights stop you from doing this!!!
I'm scared of heights and at no point did i feel scared of threatened!
nice to see. take a cruise and get a postcard picture with opera house in the arch of the harbour bridge

What would Sydney be without its "coathanger"?. Walk across on the pedestrian walkway on Australia Day and see the ferry races or the parade of boats. If you don't mind heights and you have some spare cash, try a bridge climb----great fun and a souvenir photo at the top of the arch to prove you did it! Or save your money and go to Luna Park----you can see the smiling clown mouth at the bridge's north side----or, if it's hot, swim in the pool.

Awesome Photos, Walk Rather than Climb. So the climb is not cheap....I did not do it due to the cost and time it takes, though it does seem like a great experience. There were lots of people at all times doing the climb.Walking across is much more affordable and easier on the legs :) After a long flight there is only so much physical activity one can handle. You can get views from just about anywhere near the harbour, though I would recommend taking a harbour cruise to get a closer and different look at the bridge.

Iconic Coast Hanger you can actually walk on.. You can walk over it. on top of it, or under it. View it from every angle. Walk from one side of the harbour to the other. The view from there is magnificent.
Sydney's Harbour Bridge. Uniquely designed, strategically set in the worlds most beautiful harbour, the Harbour Bridge is unmistakably and iconically Sydney!
Sydney. You feel the power of such an icon surging through your veins.

Impressive. This is very impressive. You can walk/cycle across the bridge and get some great views of the harbour/city. Some adventurous souls climb the structure but this is for the brave only. Not for me!!

Our beautiful famous bridge. The bridge is the longest single arch span in the worldanyone can travel across it by train car bus bike or on foot it links the north of Sydney to Sydney city centralIt is also possible to do a tour and climb right to the top of it where incredible views across the harbour and Sydney can be seenThe bridge is magnificient on New Years eve when it is the main attraction for Sydneyss display of fire works

Why did we wait so long?. Having received the Harbour Climb from the family as a joint birthday surprise, we finally made the tip up the Bridge.And it WAS FANTASTIC. A cold and windy day with good visibility saw us rugged-up by the staff including mitts, beanies, and multiple layers of clothing. So whilst it was pretty chilly up there, we were snug and able to enjoy the climb, and the view. The climb is a pretty long one as the first part, which seems to go on forever is simply to get you to the climb, which is easy owing to the low well spaced risers.No cameras, watches etc allowed, but pictures including personal requests atre take nad not too expensive.All in all a great outing and highly recommended.

Scenic view. My favourite bit about this bridge is to take a pic of it together with Sydney Opera House. Really great scenic view! I took the ferries so many times and everytime the ferry went pass Sydney Harbour Bridge, I couldn't help it but took more shots.

Iconic and beautiful. Iconic and beautiful, Sydney Harbour Bridge is a famous Sydney landmark known to many. Joining both sides of the harbour, you can train, walk, cycle or drive across the bridge. There are climbing tours on the bridge. On New Year's Eve, Sydney harbour bridge is the famous landmark for amazing fireworks.

A must see and do in Sydney. There is a very good lookout on the top of the southern pylon. This is an inexpensive way to experience the Sydney Harbour Bridge. You climb stairs inside the pylon which you reach from the footpath on the bridge. There is also a an exhibit and film about the building of the bridge and a giftshop.

Great experience. I actually went here a few years ago before I was a member, this is a 'must do' in Sydney and is worth every penny. Its just amazing, the views are great, I still talk about it now!!

Amazing. Built in The 1920s completed 1930
It's great to walk under it or sail under it
Amazing sight

A free walk on the Bridge. If you are looking for a fabulous free treat for visitors to Sydney, it is hard to go past a walk on the Sydney Harbour Bridge. I don't mean the expensive walk over the top! Catch a train to Circular Quay and walk through the historic Rocks and up the hill to the pedestrian walkway on the Bridge. After crossing (and ooing and aaahing at the wonderful harbour views), walk down the stairs and catch the train back from Milsons Point Station to Wynyard. Grab a bite to eat while on the north side, too. This walk never ceases to amaze and is absolutely free (except the train fares).

Spanning our city's life. The harbour of excellence.. It's the most spectacular harbour in the world. The bridge provides many viewing points and activities from many aspects and is prominent from many locations in the Sydney basin. Explore for yourselves its beauty.

Magnificent.. Such a big, beautiful bridge! We sailed under it, and I couldn't get over the complexity and sheer size of it. I would love to do the bridge climb one day, but don't know if I would be brave enough.

Such an icon. What a great icon, walk across from the Rocks side and the first "turrett" you come to has a pay observation deck with history and great views and photo opportunities of the Opera House.

Worth every penny!. After 3 visits to Sydney we finally did it... why we waited, I don't know. The experience is too cool to describe. It's not at all scary and not nearly as physical as I would have thought. I have to say the operation was most impressive. Tourism attractions from around the world should study what these guys have done, first class all the way. Worth every penny. It was so much fun we're going to go again next time and do the sunset tour.
a friendly site standing out in the city. A great stucture - stands out as an icon - more so than the opera house in my opinion. We did the bridge climb - wow!

Not for the faint hearted. Professionally done to make you feel safe, with plenty of kit. Whole trip takes about 3 hours. Great views but lots of stops for staff to take photos of you and I would have like more background information. Memorable though.

Architecture and views. This iconic bridge is beautiful and there is a tour in the middle of it that is suppose to be nice but I skipped it due to my tight budget. The walk across the bridge is pretty easy and I did it mainly to get a better view of the Opera House. If you're a runner this is a great path to take as there are small parks at both ends of the bridge.

Something for everyone. If you like taking pictures, it's got it, if you like just sitting and admiring the view you're in the right place. And if you enjoy thrill rides by climbing the bridge wow just go for it. Lastly, if you're just someone who appreciates an amazing piece of engineering, this giant of a structure will leave an impression for a long time
Iconic symbol of Sydney.. Iconic symbol of Sydney. Ride the bus or train over it and enjoy the views or walk from end to end. The adventurous can climb the arch.
That Bridge again !. Climbed it twice now and photographed it heaps. Just never tire of looking at it. - and its British made !
great place to visit. The view from the bridge tower is magnificent. We walked all the way across the bridge afterwards and loved the views. great trip back on the ferry

Don't pass on this one!. The bridge climb is a wonderful experience even for those afraid of heights, like me. They are so thorough with safety measures that you never feel insecure. The climb is not hard and they do go slowly. The view is breathtaking! You will feel very proud of yourself for conquering this fear and making the climb. I know I did after fearing it for 6 months.It's not cheap but then again, nothing is cheap in Australia.
Iconic.. The good old "coat hanger" just says Sydney ! Have climbed it, walked it, ridden over it, trained it, bussed it and driven over it.
Walking on the bridge. The bridge walk is an awesome experience. It's not too strenuous and the views are spectacular - you'll feel like you're on top of the world.
The famous coat hanger. A beautiful site. I believe well worth the climb ( however I hate height so haven't done it ) It comes alive on New Years Eve. Truly spectacular.
Amazing sight. try to clim the bridge... it is expensive but worth doing
SYDNEY ICON. an amazing icon a must see for any traveller or local
Engineering marvel. Despite busy traffic on the bridge, visitors can climb the bridge.
Wow. No better place to be...a must for tourists on New Years Eve. You can even take a walk over the arch of the bridge...views spectacular.
Loved the Bridge. It was such a landmark. We did the Bridgeclimb and thoroughly enjoyed it. We had great weather and we were not afraid at all. The views were fantastic.
Definitely worth doing. I did the Twilight bridge climb. It was amazing, a little dear but once in a lifetime opportunity.

No holiday is complete without at least a walk pver the bridge. The Harbour Bridge is a beautiful structure linking the north and south of the city. Climbing the bridge is the superlative experience but even a walk through the Rocks to the under side of the bridge, a climb up the stairs and a walk across the bridge is a wonderful experience. Finish it off with a drink at the Opera Bar at the nearby Opera House and take a photo with the bridge in the background
Wonderful view from the pedestrian walkway. A great way to cross the harbour and see the. Ridge.

Walk across the bridge - for free. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is amazing. This iconic edifice can be seen from the most of the harbour area. Together with the fantastic Sydney Opera House this is a wonderfull view. Are you an adventurer you can climb on the top of the bridge, but this is rather costly. Instead you can just talk a walk across the bridge for free and get the most beautil view from the 'seaside'. At the same time you will get the opportunity to see the Kirribili, Milsons Point and Luna Park area just across the bridge.
Iconic landmark. It was great to finally see the harbour bridge and opera house. It is a spectacle worth seeing.

Great from any angle .... but particularly from on it. View it, Climb it, walk along it, ride a bike along it, walk under it, swim under it at North Sydney Pools, climb on top of it or if you are up to something a little unusual .... do the Pylon Museum Visit. Not many know about this wonderful little museum and viewing platform in the South East Pylon. You can even take some fantastic photos from the viewing platform and watch all the others who have paid hundreds of dollars more than you to get nearly as good a view as what you will get from the top of the Pylon.

what do you want from a bridge with 10 or more lanes of traffic and a railway line on it.. Well it's over a beautiful emerald harbour, with a spectacular building near it, what else do you want from a motorway bridge, not something i would walk over, don't like hieghts.
A Must do!. The views are spectacular. A bit pricey but you only live once. Do the twilight climb and see Sydney at day & night!

pricey but a must do. There is no denying that this attraction is a very expensive day out however it is one of those must do things when visiting sydney! The staff are great and we got some very nice pics

Walk half the bridge. Having received this as a gift we were excited to take the walk across this iconic structure. Well, what do you know; you walk up one side and down one side – not across. Apparently there are regulations on the side that limit the access.None the less the total experience was pretty interesting, albeit that I am sure it could be done in 2 hours and not 3 and half. We waited around quite a lot whilst on the bridge – for those groups in front.You can’t take anything with you when you walk – nothing/nada. I even had to remove my Livestrong wristband?!We took the suggestion and only wore underclothes under the “climb suit” we were given to wear.The planning and organization is something special and I have to admit, for me, that was the highlight. They have everything so well organized from the 1st minute you start – right to end and I commend the management on the strict adherence to the program.The walk is simple and the guide entertaining. On our day the weather was over cast and we had a little drizzle on top. It was no problem – still a great experience.Just allow enough time and afterwards, you can go to one of the towers and take your own camera to take great pictures of the Opera House – from up high.

Do the pylon and the free walk. The Harbour Bridge is just a spectacular part of Sydney. While many will tell you about how good the Bridge Climb is, there is a far cheaper option. One of the pylons is open to the public for a small fee. Going to the top takes you back in history, with some historical displays, some original signage, and the lookout on top virtually as it was almost since the bridge first opened, giving you spectacular views of the main part of the bridge and Sydney. You can also walk right across the bridge at road level for no cost, which is fantastic to do. If you want to save yourself a couple of hundred dollars, this is a great alternative to the touristy Bridge Climb, and what's more you can take as many photos as you want on your own camera without having to pay a cent for the privilege.
It just fits so well. the iconic coat hanger, looks fantastic spanning the harbour, fits in so well with the Opera House and The Rocks and Luna Park.Its classic photo stuff.
WOW.... Great from every angle. The walk over it is amazing too...
a sight to see. Wow the views are tremendous from the deck of the bridge, I did not do the bridge walk as I believe it was quite expensive.
A great stroll. My bridge trip was limited to a stroll across the bridge, but that was a great trip! An easy trip, so be intimidated!
Iconic. Australians dangerously overuse the word iconic, but the Harbour Bridge deserves the label.
Wonderful. I adore this bridge!! One of the most remarkable things I have ever seen!
Walking the Bridge. We only walked across the bridge, didnt climb it. It was nice to see,but it was pouring rain after we started and it was the only day we had time. But it was still good.

A walk. I ventured by foot from the Darling Harbor. Easy directions and followed the walking directions to cross the bridge. Wonderful views of the Opera House and downtown. After crossing the bridge I stopped at a cute bakery right off the footpath for a snack and water before my trek back. A must do if you go to Sydney.
"The Famous Bridge". Didn't try to climb it. Costly and strenuous as well takes too long

Sydney New Year's Fireworks. If you have not yet been to Sydney but are planning a trip, make sure you come for New Years Eve to see the fantastic fireworks. You won't be disappointed. There are numerous places around the Sydney harbour foreshore where you can take a picnic and join the crowds to experience this wonderful firework spectacular. I suggest you get there around lunchtime and the fun you will have meeting the people around you, eating and drinking until the first firework display at 9pm. These are the smaller of the two shows but still the display is amazing. Fireworks are coming from several buildings in the city, different locations around the harbour and then at midnight the main fireworks start and again come from all directions around Sydney CBD and of course the bridge is the main focal point of interest. This year they were truly amazing. We also had an aerobatic flying display over the harbour just before the 9pm fireworks. The sight of all the boats moored in the harbour, the fireworks and the well controlled and happy crowd make it a must see.
What an experience!!. Everything,amazing views, thrilling ,excellent safety precautions,good company. Top guide.
Easy to get to from Milsons Point. It's free and give you the very best views of the Harbour

Great Views and Walks & Visit the Pylon Museum. Easy to walk across the bridge at any time. Views are excellent.Start from East Circular Quay by taking the elevator(lift) to the Cahill Expressway and walking along towards the bridge.View the sights of the quay and any cruise ship that may be in port.Climb the South East Pylon to view the information display and museum. Fee applies.Continue your walk across bridge to Milsons Point. Get a ferry back to Circular Quay from the Luna Park ferry wharf.Take your camera.The Bridge Climb is another option. It requires more advance planning and booking.The fee is a lot more than the entry to the pylon museum.http://www.sydney-harbour-bridge.bos.nsw.edu.auandhttp://www.sydney.com.au/bridge.htmlandhttp://www.pylonlookout.com.auandhttp://www.bridgeclimb.com
Walk to the Rocks. Sydney Rocks is such a great area to visit and to see the bridge from underneath. You can also go up and cross the bridge (free), with amazing views
The most beautiful harbour in the world. What can I say....it';s a spectacular harbour. Whether you are on the harbour in a boat, sitting by edge or walking around......it's just beautfiul.

Take a Bridge Climb. The bridge climb is fantastic. The views are spectacular. If heights are an issue for you, just stroll the pedestrian walk along the bridge, to view one of the most beautiful harbours in the world.

Loved it. My sister and I walked the Sydney Harbour Bridge when we were visiting family. The experience was amazing. Before the walk there was a full safety instruction talk whilst you got kitted out and demonstrations were carried out about how to use your safety wire etc.The walk itself was out of this world, the views were amazing and you don't realise how high it is until you get up there. I would advise to go early in the morning or the evening when the sun is low so you don't succumb to the heat but hats are provided. The guides are really friendly and are full on fun facts on the way. Totally recommend it .

Nothing like it in the world!. Best place to be on NYE is watching the fireworks at the bridge! Earlier in the week we walked over the bridge (not the pricey high walk, but the free pedestrian walk) for great views of the city.
Awesome. Beautiful setting and a wonderful sight to behold. I would advise getting a ferry to Darling Harbour so that you could get the view from all angles. New Year's Eve fireworks were brilliant.

Picturesque SYDNEY. Climb it or just look at it, this sydney icon is worth your time and your time for a photo or two. Best view for both the bridge and the opera house at luna park or near circular quay..

Walk Across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. Great views of Sydney from the Harbour Bridge. You can walk across the bridge and experience the thrill of walking across one of the best harbours in the world. Great views.

Majestic Views. We travelled the bridge every day from the hotel to work, but seeing the bridge at night was most impressive. The lights even on a night it wasn't lighted was very pretty. We were at the opera house taking pictures of the bridge.I would have liked to see the fire works display on new years! That must have been amazing!
Iconic structure.. A world recognised engineering feat & an internationally known structure forever identified with Sydney Harbour.
i havent done the climb yet.... walked yes views great and if you can ever have the chance to see the fireworks in new years then i think you ll never forget it

Bridge Walk is as good as Bridge Climb!. We walked Sydney Harbor Bridge from our B&B in Kirribilli to the Rocks in 40 leisurely minutes. The views were exceptional. There was no reason to do the Bridge Climb.

Interesting. If you take the time to read about the bridge in the Pylon museum and hear the history by taking the Bridge Climb, the bridge has a fascinating history. Definitely worth the time and money.

Interesting. If you take the time to read about the bridge in the Pylon museum and hear the history by taking the Bridge Climb, the bridge has a fascinating history. Definitely worth the time and money.
Harbour Bridge. Take a walk over the bridge and around both sides of the bridge. Take a walk aroud the Rocks and the areas
Must do in Sydney. well worth the price. I would schedule the last day appointment possible, this way, you can see the sunseting as you climb down. Highly recommended

A great place to cycle over.. A cycle way provides a safe route to cross the bridge with excellent views of the harbour, Parramatta River, Luna park Lavender Bay, Cockatoo Island and much more The crossing on bicycle takes about 10 minutes with a ramp on the south shore (near Observatory Hill) and two flights of stairs on the North Shore.
A bridge that gives you the great feeling. It may look like an ordinary bridge. But it is more than just an ordinary bridge.

Bridge climb and walk - superb but book in advance. There should be some clarity as the reviews of the bridge walk include those who just walked across (free, at road level) and those who took the bridge climb and walk. I am only referring to the latter in this review. I have gone before, but this time took my family, including 2 individuals who were scared of heights. This didn't stop them enjoying this great 3-hour experience. Standing on top of the bridge looking around the beautiful city has to be a real highlight of any trip. However, tickets are booked early, so as soon as you plan to come to Sydney suggest you book them on-line. They are expensive, however, but definitely worth going if you come to the city
One of the world's most famous bridges.. Didn't climb up but do it if you can. Very expensive though.Great bridge and views at the harbour though.Go and visit and enjoy the views in the sunshine.
the coat hanger. A bit dissapointed as it looks more impressive in the tourist guides than in real life.
view from the top..... great to see but even better to climb on a sunny Sydney day. Guides give an insight into the building of the bridge and other historical Sydney stories.
Bridge Climb - Must Do. Must Do Bridge Climb .. once in a life time experience. You can also think about you anniversary or b'day gift.

One of the unique icons in the world. Visitors to Sydney are fortunate to be able to see and experience one of the unique icons of the modern world.When in Sydney ensure that you not only look at the bridge from afar, but also walk across and climb it if possible.This is when you will appreciate it's spectacular structure and design.The bridge can be approached easily from either side - a short walk on the city side if you are staying centrally or a short train journey across the bridge to Milsons Point. There is a stairway to the walkway from there. The walk across the bridge takes about 30 minutes with lots of stops to admire the view.A trip by ferry under the bridge is also a must. Ferries leave from Circular Quay and you just ned to ask for a ferry ride that will take you under the bridge. From below the bridge you can get a perspective of how large this bridge really is.

Must See Landmark. Right next to the Opera House sits the famous Sydney Harbour Bridge. You can walk accross, climb up, bicycle, or take a train across and you will have such stunning views, thrills, and be on a world famous bridge! Great spot to go!
Walk to other side.. It is free and worth walking to other side of the bridge. Easy 10 min. walk - see Sydney from other angle.

Spectacular Experience for Anyone Visiting Sydney. My wife and I climbed the bridge on our recent trip to Sydney. While it seemed an extremely "touristy" thing to do, it was a tremendous experience. We traveled throughout Australia and New Zealand and this remained one of the highlights of the entire trip.The views of Sydney are breathtakingly spectacular. Our guide was enthusiastic, knowledgeable and passionate. My wife is not a big fan of heights and she was completely comfortable, so don't let this prevent you from undertaking this adventure.We did our climb very first thing in the morning, which was awesome and we would recommend it. But I'm sure the night climbs are equally fantastic. One thing to be aware of is how long the climb takes. We did the regular bridge climb and it took nearly a full 4 hours to complete. So plan accordingly.A truly wonderful, unique and exhilarating experience.
Bridge Pylon Lookout. One of the best Value Lookouts at $11.00 for an adult $4.00 for a child and $6.50 for students and seniors. Great place for Photo's of Bridge & Opera house.

Walk across Sydney Harbour Bridge. You do not need to pay to walk over the top of the bridge, you can also walk accross, or cycle across the bridge for free, and maybe stop for a coffee on the other side before returning. You need to walk up through The Rocks to find the entrance to bridge which is a good 10 min walk from Circular Queay. I think it could be signposted a little better and clearer.
nice bridge. great view and makes a great background for photos

I have a walk across. I have a walk across the bridge to Milson Point. It was magnificent views from different angle of Sydney Opera House.Recommended you to do it when dawn, do not forget to carry your camera with you.

The best-known bridge in the world?. The mere sight of Sydney Harbour Bridge on a normal day is enough to trigger all the thoughts/feelings one might have about Australia and its people. To see the bridge on New Year's Eve is something everyone should try to do at least once in their lives, IMHO, of course!

Worth the walk. Walking across is impressive. It is so high and the views of the harbour great. Its a little noisy due to the traffic driving across. you can get to the bridge from the lift at circular quay, but that means about half a mile of walking next to the motorway - not great. The better way is to climb the stairs behind the Rocks which brings you out just at the start of the bridge.

Brilliant to walk on top of or across. Here's a local tip - you can spend a lot of money to "climb" the bridge, but if you don't like heights or don't have the budget, walk across the bridge. The pedestrian access is excellent, you can walk from the city to Kirribilli and have a coffee, walk around to Luna Park then walk back. Walking over the top is fun too, but as far as I'm concerned it's a lot of time and money for something you can do for free.
An icon, always striking. It's just as good as the brochures, if not better, when you meet "The Bridge"
It's ok, but nothing special. Everyone carries on about the Harbour Bridge. Perhaps I'm not into the history of it all, but I didn't find it a significant attaction that is a 'must see'.
Harbour Bridge. It was interesting to see, but not overwhelming. Darling Harbour has alot of things to do and see.
Expensive to climb but worth it.... Once in a lifetime activity, expensive but great fun and truly memorable!
A Grand Lady. Iconic, every traveller should at least once in their life stand beneath this beautiful bridge and just marvel. If your game make the climb.
The great icon of Sydney. Immediately, the view is captivating when you land in Circular Quay. The longest single arch in the world. Do the BridgeClimb ... it'll be worth it.

Amazing Experience. The bridge climb is not just for tourists, its an amazing experience for anyone really!! I live in NSW and recieved the bridge climb voucher from my parents for my birthday and the veiws take your breath away. I'll be climing the bridge again sometime in the new year and cant wait!!

The Coathanger. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is an iconic structure - a practical, but beautifully balanced piece of architecture and engineering. It's known the world over and affectionately nick-named "The Coathanger" by locals. On NYE, it is transformed into a wonderful structure to show case one of the finest fireworks displays you'll see anywhere tin the world
Walk across the bridge. If you don't fancy the popular bridge climb, then just walk across the bridge after visiting the pylon lookout. It is a relaxing walk with spectacular views.

Sydney Harbour BridgeClimb - Part of your Bucket List!. The BridgeClimb was one of the most exciting things we have ever done, and well worth the expense. Before starting out on the climb, people are given special suits to wear and an intensive training for an hour or so on how to negotiate all the steps and ladders on the way up. No cameras or anything that can be dropped are allowed to be taken, and even we were shackled to a safety line that ran the whole way of the Bridge. The climb truly is exhilarating, and photos are professionally taken right at the very top, both as a group, and individually with the amazing backdrops of the city and Opera House. Do try this and make sure it's on your bucket list!!

A view like no other. It was awesome climbing up the Sydney Harbour Bridge for the views and they really did a good job telling us about the structure and took great pains to stress the safety aspects of the climb.The climb is well worth it although it is quite pricy A$ 202 per person.

You HAVE to do the Bridge Climb. Despite the cost ($250 or so), you have to do e Bridge Climb. It would be like going to Paris and not going up the tower. Spectacular, once-in-a-lifetime experience that affords you the history of the construction from a top rivets view. Perched 440 ft from water and overlooking traffic, watercraft, and airplanes, you get a unique view of the Quay, Rocks, Harbour, and the Opera House.Add to this the fact that you are literally tethered to a wire - you get the sense of what it would have been like to work on this special and iconic structure.

Do the Twilight Bridge Climb!. If you choose to climb the Sydney Harbor Bridge, I highly recommend paying the extra for the Twilight climb. This truly is a unique view, as you can't go to the pylon lookout at night. Yes, it costs more, but you get to see the city in the daylight on the way up, then watch the sun set, see lights coming on, and then you have a night view. We were lucky enough to have a full moon that night, too! The Bridge Climb staff were great. We felt very prepared and safe. And we had fun! We did buy 2 of the pictures at the end because they turned out really nice. One was taken in daylight and the other was after the sun set. If you don't do the Bridge Climb, at least go to the pylon lookout. There are exhibits, too, so you learn a lot about the bridge and its history. I know the Bridge Climb guide gave us facts about the bridge, but I remember more from the pylon visit.
Simply stunning. If you're staying a while in Sydney, it's well worth paying the money and actually doing the bridge climb.... Awesome!!
Excellent. Excellent site to visit in Sydney. Except climbin bridge is expensive.
The Coat Hanger. Better viewed from the Opera House or from a ferry travelling on the harbor or be there for Australia Day on 26th January to see the fireworks display. Too much traffic on the bridge
Shame it rained half way across.. We walked across the bridge, it has wonderful views.

Inspiring. I LOVE the Sydney harbour bridge, its so beautiful and climbing it is even better, the stories you get told as you are climbing give you a real appreciation for how it was built... and the view up the top is incredible. We are a lucky country, and a wonderful city
Must See the Coathanger. All visitors in Sydney must see this wonderful achievement at least once & do the bridge climb if you have time.
bridge climb. A must. This provides some of the best views of the harbour . Do it first thing in the morning on a sunny day. It's not a climb, more a slow walk. No need to be fit.

Great engineering marvel - well worth getting close to. There are plenty of ways to see one of the world's most famous bridges, built in the 1920/30's, it is still considered as one of Australia's most significiant engineering feats.Take a ferry, boat, etc. under it, do a bridge climb over its arched top, but the cheapest way to do it (i.e. free) is walk across it's pedestrian walkway, next to the traffic lanes. You can access the walkway from the western end of Circular Quay by walking along George Street then up Argyle Street until you come across stone stairs that lead up to Cumberland Street. There is a signposted 'Bridge Stairs' entrance to a stairwell in a stone pylon that goes up to the walkway itself.Take time to soak in the views & if you want, the south pylon (the tall stone structure) has a lookout & exhibition open to visitors (entry fee payable). Keep on going across to the other end & down to Milson's Point, where you can reward your efforts with a short walk to Luna Park. There is a ferry terminal there too if you don't want to walk back!Interesting fact: looks can be deceiving, there is not one curved steel beam in the entire bridge.
Always takes my breath away!. Seeing this in December makes me long to see it again on new years eve. The most amazing fireworks display I have ever seen. It is a very impressive bridge!
BRILLANT. love the harbour bridge and recomend it to anybody to climb or ride underneath it

Walk for free and get to use your own camera too. Couldn't see the point of paying through the nose for the totally controlled Bridge Climb, when you could walk across freely and for free.The view difference can only be minimal and there are plenty of unrestrictive vantage points at the lower level.and you get to use your own camera etc, ( not get fleeced again by having to buy their pics from the climb people).So enjoy the stroll at your leisure take in the little park on the right hand side to enjoy backwards views of the Bridge / Opera house and stroll back.or jump on the ferry for the return.to the other side).We could have afforded to pay, for the bridge climb, but for the price I would have expected a piggy back up and down both ways.So we freely elected not to get ripped off, and frankly, we don't feel we missed a thing.
Awesome to look at. I didn't climb it and I didn't even walk over it. I'm a chicken and scared of heights. That being said, sitting in a cafe looking at the bridge on a sunny day is magical.

The coat hanger - for free. Interesting construction. You can basically just walk under the bridge and see a lot of interesting things. The climb over the bridge is just an exageration in time (3 hours) and money ($ 180)
Blows your mind!. Amazing from any angle and always looks even better when seeing it for real
A world icon. A world icon. A must for any visitor. Take in the view from the Opera House of the bridge, walk across it from Milsons Point station, or climb it with Bridge Climb!

Beautiful views on a clear day.... Walking on the bridge will give you really beautiful views of the Sydney Harbour. You can see the world famous Opera House. The Rocks and downtown Sydney, to name a few. It was quite windy while we were there, but the walk and views are well worth the effort. Best place for views!

Walk across the Syndey Harbour Bridge from Kirribilli. If your budget doesnt extend to Bridge Climb then a walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge at street level is a good alternative. Yes there is a lot of traffic noise but the views are great, you can stop where you like and walk as fast or slow as you like. If your staying in the city catch the ferry to Kirribilli, have a coffee at one of the many cafes and then walk back to the city. Perfect!

incredible. the whole experience of climbing this amazing structure is incredible. From the time you start, with the protective dooning of the jump suit, to taking the steps one at a time to the top of this masterpiece. The views are amazing, the climb should be fine for any level of fitness, but possibly not too good for those frightened of heights. However, you are securely latched on to guide rails, and capably supervised, encouraged and helped by experienced guides, so just do it.

Interesting view. I mainly enjoyed the view from the harbor and ferries as we passed beneath it on our way to Darling Harbor. There's a train that crosses over the bridge taking people from either side of Sydney to the other.
Nice!. All that area around the bridge is worth to be seen. You have nice view of the city from the bridge.
Great view from the bridge. Views are great even if you just walk along the bridge at no cost.
If you can't do bridge climb, at least walk across the bridge. I have climbed the bridge on previous visits to city, but even walking across the bridge is a wonderful experience

Iconic but look out for the options. Fantastic and iconic but be aware of the options in terms of seeing the bridge. The 'bridge walk' is heavily advertised and is clearly very good but at $208 without photos is quite expensive. You can also get a great view by climbing up the public access to the bridge and then going up one of the pillars which gives almost as good views/photo opportunities but for only $11

walk across for free!!!. loved the walk across, if you go down the stairs at milsons point there are a few coffee shops and restaurants where you can grab a takeaway snack/drink and sit on the wall under the bridge and gaze back at the city...... a million dollar view for free
Views to die for from Quay Grand Hotel. Wow, wow, wow. Daytime and nightime, stunning views.

the views are absolutely beautiful. I've done all you can do on the Sydney Harbour Bridge; walked across it, cycled across it, took a ferry under it, climbed it and watched New Year's Eve fireworks over it. No matter what, the views across the Harbour are the BEST! Make sure to check out the history of the Bridge at the bridgeclimb entrance off of Cumberland Street. The walk across takes about 20 minutes, depending on fitness level, but it wasn't strenuous. Make sure to stop along the way for your photos of the Opera House. If it's summer, do the walk across in the morning before the heat moves in, but try to avoid the rush hour traffic. There's a wonderful restaurant on the Milson's Point side of the Bridge, walk from the Rocks to Milson's Point.

Do the CLIMB!!!!. The bridge climb is a must!!!! I wasn't going to do it but when you lay eyes on the bridge for the first time and can just about spot people climbing it I thought 'I have to do that!!' - it's quite expensive but worth the money for the memories you will get!
climb the pylon for a great view. The view from the pylon is great, not quite as high as the bridge climbers, but it's $11 compare to $200!

Dare you to walk the bridge. Not a cheap experience but soooo glad I did it. It's safe and well organised, but not for the feint hearted. A bit too close to traffic and trains when you climb the narrow staircases outside. Just DONT look down as the paths are just mesh in places.

DO the climb!. Whatever you do in Sydney, do the bridge climb. It's worth every single cent and just brilliant. Obviously if you're scared of heights, don't! It's not strenuous and you get 2 whole hours of guided tour/climbing.
Magnificent. So unique, and feels so close when viewing from the Opera house. Very romantic to walk around the harbour in the evening and view the bridge under lights with Luna Park underneath.

one of the best. What a lovely sight and incredible construction. Overlooking the opera house and Circular Quay....and as it is Spring time, lots of Jacaranda in full blooms. Really a wonderful place to visit

Amazing sight yet pricey. I could only afford to go on the Pylon Lookout and while the view is not as good as from the top of the Bridge itself, it is incredibly overpriced considering that lack of exhibits and information provided on your way up the many stairs. The gift shop area was also rather expensive, but it does not distract from the fact that this national icon is truly amazing to see up close and should not be missed regardless of the price. I hate to think of how moved I would have been had I been able to afford the bridge climb, but I still enjoyed the visit very much.

nice walk!. we die the bridge walk and it was great although unfortunately it was raining.The guides were very good and funny.just a little bit expensive from my point of view and considering the price at least you should get all the pictures they take for you.A very nice experience!

A nice walk. Take the upper causeway at the Circular Quay and walk along to the Harbour Bridge and over to north Sydney. There is a nice area to the right of the bridge which affords views looking back towards the city centre and the Opera House, with cafes for a quick cup of coffee before walking back. Its a very easy walk and most enjoyable away from the crowds.
Good view from The Pylon. If you want a view without the effort and expense of the Bridge Climb, the tower on the city side is worth the effort.

Majestic Piece of Art!. Apart from the Opera House, Sydney Harbour Bridge is another iconic piece I can't have enough of. Simply breathtaking & such a magnificent piece of art. A must see if you are in Sydney!

spectacular. the bridge it's very impressive. it gives sydney skyline a wonderful touch. there are trips that take you to the top of it. along with the opera house it's really representative of the city and from it you can take good pics of the bay and the opera house. it's quite easy to reach if you walk through the famous district of the rocks.

Iconic. Iconic, for good reason. You've seen it in photos all your life. To see it in person is absolutely breathtaking. It is the bridge in the middle of one of the most gorgeous cities in the world.
Spectacular. It's absolutely big, high, full of cars that cross it; it's "closed" to the opera House. They seem two indivisible friends. Spectacular view
Walk across the bridge.. You can walk across the bridge without doing the "bridge climb". This is spectacular for photography.

This is as "Sydney" as you are going to get!. I have done the bridge climb before and it was BRILLIANT! But today we just walked across the bridge one side to the other. It was FREE and we got to take in the beautiful Sydney skyline and harbor. So for those who are little scared of heights and don't want to the climb.. walking across the bridge is a lovely alternative. Don't forget your camera!
An amazing bridge. Brilliant to be able to walk across such an iconic feature

Impressive and great for photos. Take a walk over the bridge as it is great for photos and view. Best of all it is free. If you are very brave book a walk over the top of the bridge for the absolute best views.
What can I say. What can I say, it is an amazing structure. Especially considering it was built so long ago. Very imposing.
Size Does Matter. I never can get over how *huge* this bridge is. It is absolutely incredible. Make sure to head down to the rocks at night with a tripod and a camera to get some gorgeous shots.
Beautiful. The toour in the submarine was great and the place is simply beautiful

Just a major part of the Sydney Skyline. You have to walk across the bridge...best thing is it is free. If you walk from the Rocks side (South) go down to Milsons point and have a lunch or coffee. If you walk from the Milsons point side (North side) go down through Circular Quay and onto the rocks. Great views and there is always something happening on the harbour. If you have the time go up the Pylon on the South East corner of the bridge...the views are even better. It does cost a few dollars but is well worth the view. If you want to lash out do the Bridge Climb...well run and just the best way to see the harbour.
Fantastic. We went over it by road, under it on the ferries, and loved it. Friends did the brdige climb, we were not so energetic. It is an amazing bridge.

WOW WOW. So easy to do and so life changing. Don't be concerned about safety, strenuousness or heights on this tour. They make it so easy and walk you through many stations and practice stations to get your through. You will be amazed. The outer arch walk is the easiest part. You get their after you walk through the lower (open) platform and climb up 4 sets of vertical ladders. You are secured to the bridge the entire time. Age is no restriction. Weight might be as some of the passages are narrow.
Great View. My wife wanted to do this and we decided it was a once in a lifetime opportunity - DO IT!

Cheaper than the Bridge Climb. We decided not to do the bridge climb as we found it too expensive; we were advised to do the Pylon Lookout climb instead. It's a bit difficult to find (approach it from The Rocks) and there are, of course, a lot of steps, but you are rewarded with a super view of the Harbour, the Sydney Harbour Bridge, the Opera House, Circular Quay and the Botanical Gardens. You can also watch people doing the bridge climb! The 'pylon' contains a small but very interesting museum which gives you a good idea of what an engineering feat and feat of work the bridge itself is. The Pylon Lookout used to be run by a lady who even had a cattery at the top of it - but there are no cats there today.

Don't miss this. Too much fear of heights to consider the real Bridge Climb, but walking the pedestrian path part way across was well worth the time. We were initially discouraged by a local who said the views weren't worth it due to safety barriers in place for pedestrians. We definitely disagreed, and found the walk quite enjoyable. There were great views. We thought this should be one of the things you do in Sydney. We parked in the Rocks area, under the bridge, and walked up a couple of flights of stairs. Parking was A$ 2.20 for an hour.

A Great Walk. I wanted to do the bridge climb, but our budget for the trip didn't allow it, and my wife wanted nothing to do with that, so we decided to just walk across the bridge. We started in the CBD and walked to the other side and back. It's not a very long walk, it looks bigger than it actually is. It was sort of difficult to find the sidewalk that went up this way, but once you're on it you can't get lost. You are well separated from traffic while on the bridge, and there are no shortage of great views. Security guards are regularly patrolling the bridge and there are surveillance cameras everywhere. Combined with large fences and razor wire you have no ability to climb up on any part of the bridge. Once on the other side, there is a nice park to walk through that will take you under the pillars, so you can see the structure of the bridge quite well. it's also less than a 5 min walk from this point over to Luna Park. We sort of walked slowly and explored a bit, and the whole thing only took 2 hours or so. The nice thing is if you want to get a head start on your day, you can do this before anything else opens in Sydney. I would say this is a must-do.

best experience of my life. incredible!. I dont even know where to start this was an amazing experience. it was a present for my 17th birthday. My best friend and I travelled from the gold coast to do this. It was a friday night. During the day we were revving ourselves up as we were very nervous. Towards the afternoon it started to become very overcast and windy which didnt settle our nerves. Once we arrived at the bridge climb, the staff were extrememly nice and the lady in the shop was telling us about all of her trips up the bridge (9 times!). Anyway it came to about 4pm when we were taking into a room to fil out a pre-screen health thing and then we were suited up. This takes about 30 mins. We were introduced to our guide. (I wish I knew his name but he was very friendly). We headed out with about 8 people to start the climb. My friend and I were nearly sick with nerves now so we went up the front with the guide. As we headed out onto the bottom frame it was very cold and there was a horrible wind but we pushed past it. Let me tell you, the worst part of the climb was going up these horrible ladders. My mouth was dry, I felt sick and I was shaking something cronic. We waited about 20 mins fo everyone to come up. The next part is the easiest and trust me when I say this..the best! Your now on the outside of the frame. After the guide takes some pictures at different vantage ponints you pretty much walk in 3 parts up the bridge. You walk 1/3 and then wait for the rest of the group to have pictures and you continue up. I didnt like the part where you wait on your own and the guide is behind you but there are headets which you can talk through. I was still pretty nevous at this point but adrenelin had kicked in as well. We were holdng on extrememly tight to the railings as it was soo windy! the guide said it was about 70km/h and the ususally wont climb it after 80km/h. The top of the bridge is amazing. We got to catch the sunset and then we saw the beutifully lit city at night. Its beyond gorgeous. The decent is quite fast but the guide got us down quickly as the wind had picked up alot and we were all feeling very uneasy. We all had windburn and a bit of chill once we got back inside but its all good for the adventure you go on.Overall, it is a great experince. If you can do it, you have to. I will be returning to do it again. If your nervous, trust me they go away once you start admiring the scene around you.

YOU HAVE TO VISIT THIS PLACE!. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is the best thing to visit in Sydney, well the Opera House is still pretty good. The Sydney Harbour Bridge lets you climb it, buy gifts, books, clothes. You have to be about 11 to climb it and a certain height too. It took 6 years to build, started on in 1926 and finished in 1931. They waited a year to open it. The total length of it is 1149 metre's. In 1976, the one-billionth vehicle crossed the Sydney Harbour Bridge. The first 500 million crossings took over 33 years while the second 500 million took less than 11 years.You have to see and climb the Harbour Bridge. I went there with my parents, 45, 55 and my brother 11 and me 14. So I would go their again and again!Visit it now!!!
Amazing Bridge climb. The Sydney Harbour Bridge climb was an awesome experience. It was 3 hrs long, flew by so fast. i am not a fan of heights, but did not mind the climb at all.Lots of fun!!

Must do. Many people will undoubtedly want to do the Bridge Climb, but that option costs a bomb (albeit a worthy one), and if you're short on time, you can walk across the bridge (starting point is along Cumberland St on the Rocks, and walk across to Milsons Point, and then take the train back.We took the walk, and the views of the harbour from the bridge is amazing. You can optionally pay to walk up the Southeast pylon, from where you'd get a view just about as good as what you'd get from the top of the bridge if you took the walk.I think this is a must do for anyone visiting Sydney - the view is spectacular, and you can do it for free if you just walk along the pedestrian walkway.

Breathtaking views. It's worth the climb up to the Pylon Lookout for the breathtaking views and to learn a little about the bridge's history. To get to this lookout you first must use the Harbour Bridge pedestrian walkway - accessible either from the stairway just above Argyle Street at The Rocks, or you can follow the walkway all the way around from Cahill Walk (above Circular Quay). You enter through a door at the southern pylon tower. Entry is $11 for adults, cheaper for kids and concessions. Be aware there's lots of stairs! There's some historical tid-bits about the bridge, a short movie to watch on the way out, and a souvenir shop about half way up. Views from the top are wonderful - take your camera.

Nice view...but why all the fencing and barbed wire?. No visit to Sydney is compete without seeing the bridge--it's such an icon--but it is surprising how unfriendly and unpleasant that it feels to walk over the bridge. Unlike my 'home bridge' (the Golden Gate, another icon), the pedestrian pathway all along the water's edge isn't just a railing--it's a 10 foot (3 meter) high fence topped with barbed wire. This is in addition to police officers stationed all along it about every few hundred yards. It felt like a prison. You could only take pictures through a little 8 inch high gap in the railing and fencing. One can pay $$$ to climb the bridge, but this is not an option for families with younger children, and walking to the top of the pylon--apparently hundreds of steps and also $$--is also not really a reasonable option with younger kids. The bridge should be able to be enjoyed by all, not just enjoyed as money-making venture.

The Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb - a memory which will stay with me for years.. The Sydney Harbour Bridge itself is impossible not to see whilst travelling around in Sydeny, but to get the best of it, do the 'Sydney Harbour Bridge Climb'. Book online prior to travelling to avoid dissapointment as it gets quite busy. You arrive to an efficient and friendly welcome at the HQ underneath the bridge in The Rocks. You are then issued your climbing gear, treated to sfaety briefs and a short lesson on how to use the kit. The instructors are very friendly and professional and this short process only took around a half hour. You are then led out onto the bridge and commence your climb! We were in a goup or six + the instructor so the staff to visitor ratio was very good. The instructor tells you all about the bridge on the climb and has numerous annecdotes to keep you occupied. The climb itself is not really a climb - the girders themsleves are abour 5m wide and there are steps all the way with hand rails. Although exhilarating, its physically only mildly arduous - just prepare for a lot of steps! when you reach the top, the view is increadible and well worth the effort. To watch the traffic beneath you is also cool. There are a few climbs you can do. We did the express (2 hrs ish) and we found that to be plenty! Its not cheap (about $180 each) but the expense reflects the professionalism of the crew and I guess the high costs that they incur from insurance. A must do if your in Sydney.

Wow! wotta trek...we walked across and enjoyed every view. TERRIFIC WAY TO SPEND A SUNNY DAY. we walked across and enjoyed every view along the way. Amazing feat of engineering for it's time. Gives one a fine appreciation for the Aussie spirit and competence. highly recommend over the super expensive options like dinner cruises and 'jumps'... This was very worthwhile for us.

Panoramic - you can really see what the city of Sydney has to offer. Don't worry if you don't have the right footwear and/or if you feel the cold. The guide will suit you up with everything; even down to the handkerchief for the wet noses.

Fantastic - even if you're scared of heights. Being quite scared of heights I had no intention of doing the Bridge Climb until I was actually in Sydney. We went up the pylon (if we’d done this after the climb we’d have had a free voucher but never mind) and I saw that the steps along the arch were solid steel and you couldn’t see through them. As my vertigo kicks in when I can see through what I’m stood on I started to think that maybe I could handle this after all. We went to the office to enquire about availability and to be honest, I thought I’d get out of it as we were leaving Sydney the next day but no, they had plenty of availability so in a snap decision we signed up. I fretted for the whole night but I needn’t have been so worried.As many people have noted this is not the cheapest activity in Sydney but you do get quite a lot for that. All in all it takes around three hours. You start by getting breathalysed then don the fetching gray jump suit with all accessories (gloves, hat, sunglasses etc) securely attached. Then there is training of how the bridge climb works and how you move around the various parts. Then it was time to go. As others have said, the hardest bit is the first part when you are under the bridge as it’s a narrow cat walk though there are bars on either side. From there you climb up some ladders, through the road and emerge at the foot of the arch. I remember singing Patsy Cline’s ‘Crazy’ to myself as I climbed up; there was no better song to fit the situation! Time for picture one. It got a lot easier once on the arch. It’s so solid and safe. It’s also shallow so I didn’t find it an effort to climb. A second photo was taken half way up and then another two from the top. You can’t take your camera with you and I found these pictures to be very expensive seeing as you are already paying a lot for the climb. The whole experience is narrated by your guide who you are attached to (as you are the rest of your group). Ours was brilliant and really brought the history of the bridge to life. Despite my trepidation I am so pleased that we did this. I have to disagree with another reviewer who think that you can get the same views from the path below. The Harbour Bridge is enclosed by wire fencing and the views aren’t as good; there are also several lanes of traffic and trains so it’s pretty noisy. From the top of the bridge you can see all over Sydney and to the ocean. It’s the sort of activity that you do once but probably wouldn’t do again on a repeat visit due to the cost and time involved but the photo from the top that is now on my fridge never fails to make me smile.

one more off the bucket list. Definitely an experience not to be missed! if you're lucky to get a clear day the views are stunning amnd it's something to look up at it from below later in your visit and think 'I was up there'Tip for those on a budget: if you have limited funds visit the bridge pylon instead for only $11 where you can take photos of the bridge and watch other people climb it.

climb the pylon instead!. the bridge is a masterpiece and should really be explored and viewed from different angles. i highly suggest walking across the bridge. Not many people know this, but the right hand side heading outbound is dedicated to walking traffic (the other side is dedicated to cyclists). It was a beautiful walk across, with great photo opportunities. As we walked across, we went up one of the Pylons. Much cheaper then the bridge climb ($14) and only 200 steps each way and still great views to be had.
