We then had lunch in Kirabilli and explored Luna Park and the surrounds before catching a ferry back a cross. It gave us a whole other view of the bridge - from underneath it! Then once off the ferry, head to the Opera House for some more happy snaps of the bridge from a little distance.

Beloved Bridge, fascinating to cross on foot, road or train. I often cross this bridge, whether you walk, I prefer North to South, drive or are a passenger including the train (sit upstairs) its a joy to see. There is something special about the way the curved interlaced girders look as you pass through and under them. The view if you walk isn't bad but not as spectacular as you would expect. For me the Brooklyn Bridge is the best viewing platform whereas the Sydney Harbour Bridge is the best for looking at.It is also good for looking at from under its North Pylon in particular and the foreshore parkland is a joy in its self. Whilst you can climb the arch for a fee, few are ecstatic about that afterwards. There is also a pylon with a museum, the SOuth East one but having been once I feel no need to repeat it, I am happy to wonder drive or ride across! Bicycles are permitted on the western side pedestrians on the Eastern!Takes about 20 minutes but allow more time as you have to get to starting and finishing points, say 40 mins all up.

Not the bridge climb, but great views from the water. I saw the Harbour Bridge from a slightly different angle - from a ferry at water level! With Circular Quay just next to the bridge, all the ferries from the terminal there pass by the famous bridge. Just make sure you are on the right side of the boat! The eastern point of Farm Cove also provides a great view of the bridge, with the Sydney Opera House in the foreground. Just watch out for the wedding parties taking photos there!

Not Worth the Money. We did the Sydney Harbour climb and paid around $250 per person (canadian). There are so many groups going up at that the same time that it actually takes you quite a while to make it to the top. Once there, you've already seen everything from the first vantage point. Plus, then you cross over and walk back down, you dont actually do the full climb from end to end which is dissapointing. We did the dinner cruise the evening before and it was only $60 per person and SOOO much better. Honestly, I wouldnt waste your money on this.

Many ways to experience this engineering wonder. Before we left home we knew we would visit the Pylon Lookout and walk across the bridge but we didn't want to do the bridge climb. It's so expensive and you can't even take photos from the top. We loved the Pylon Lookout for the views and learning opportunities. For about $9- you climb 200 steps with stops along the way to learn how this beautiful structure came to be (and use the bathroom if needed). We were so surprised by what we didn't know about Sydney's famous bridge. At the top the 360 degree views are stunning with many photo opportunities. You can see almost as much from inside the room at the top without going out on the external viewing balcony. That is very good for people who are not sure if they can handle the height. I am a bit wobbly with heights and had to sit down a few times and retreat into the inside room until I felt like I could face the outside again. As someone who doesn't cope fantastically with heights I am so glad that I went up for the view. Make sure you stop and read the information boards and look at the models on the way up, they are very interesting and add to the whole experience. On the way down you go a different way and there is a short 8min? video of historical photos and events about the building of, and opening of the bridge.The next day we caught a ferry to Luna Park then walked back to The Rocks along the bridge. A large freighter ship passed under us along with many smaller vessels. I was quite excited by this (I know...small things....). Again the view was great. But also checking out the traffic lanes and passing traffic and saying hello to the ever present friendly security guards was all part of a lovely stroll across the harbour.

Pylon Lookout - A Great and Cheap Alternative To The Bridge Climb. I was directed to visit the pylon lookout by a former colleague of mine who has resided in Sydney now for 14 years, his words were "why pay a huge amount of money to walk up something that you cannot photograph once you are on it?" The cost of walking up the 200 or so steps was A$9.00 each, and the views are just as good as those you would see from the crown of the arch, although you do get not to wear special suits, or get a commemorative certificate for your efforts. This attraction is not advertised as widely as one would expect, and it is not signposed that well. The only pylon (pier) that is accesible to the public is the South Eastern one located at road level on the bridge approach spans, whch is best approached from the steps on Cumbernauld St which in turn can be accessed from the steps off Argyle St in the Rocks area.

awesome views. instead of paying 192 dollars to walk the bridge arch pay 9.50 dollars to go up the concrete bridge support city side.you get just as good views and you can take your camera up as well.no restrictions and you are almost at the same height as the apex of the bridge.well worth it and you also have money left to spend on something else.

Pylon Lookout and exhibit well worth time and small entry fee. Harbor Bridge pylon lookoutTake the steps near the YHA in the Rocks area to go to the bridge pylon lookout.  Note..lots of stair steps.  The museum alone is worthwhile and the views are excellent as well, without the time or hefty expense of the commercialized BridgeClimb (where you spend more time getting safety briefings and waiting on everyone in the group to get photographed rather than climbing the bridge and taking in the view).

Great Views from the Pylon. This is a review of the Pylon lookout point ($9.50AUD) at the Sydney Harbour Bridge, and not the BridgeClimb experience ($200-300AUD). We decided to do the lookout rather than the bridge climb since many reviewers on TripAdvisor said the views are very similar. I would tend to agree. We walked up the few flights of stairs to get to the end of the Harbour Bridge (it's not entirely easy to find the proper bridge approach - I recommend stopping at the Visitor Information Desk in The Rocks for specific directions) and then walked along the bridge walkway. Be careful that you don't go up one extra flight of stairs onto the highway portion of the bridge itself - that is not for pedestrians. From this end of the bridge, the lookout Pylon (and only the Pylon on the South Sydney side has a visitor lookout) is about a 15-minute walk. You enter and go up a few flights of stairs, pay your fee ($9.50 or $6.50 depending on whether or not you're a senior) and then climb 10 more flights of stairs (each flight 13 steps). There's a gift shop after 6 flights to stop at and rest benches at nearly every flight. At the very top, you walk out onto an enclosed balcony that affords beautiful views of the Harbour, Opera House, and City. You can see the people doing the Bridge Walk from here, which also looks fun, but is only about 50 meters higher than the Pylon lookout. After we took photo's and descended, we decided to walk across the rest of the bridge and have lunch on the North Sydney side of the bridge. Excellent choice -- the food is just as good and HALF the price as in the touristy side of Sydney!

Try the Pylon Climb. I didn't climb the Bridge due to $ constraints, but for $9.50 you can climb up one of the pylons and the view is great from up there. And you can take your own photos from the top of the pylon, unlike the bridge climb. I'm not sure anything can top the bridge climb experience, but if what you want is the view and you don't have $200, then I would recommend climbing the pylon instead.

A walk across "The Bridge" is free.. If you want to walk over "The Bridge" do Bridgeclimb (a whole other awesome but $$$ experience). If you simply want to walk across, that is free and easy. The walkway (there is a cycleway too on the western side) is on the Opera House side and affords the most stunning views 24/7. Can be accessed from Cumberland Street, The Rocks on the city side.The Pylon Lookout is open 10-5 everyday if you have a spare 30mins where you can ascend stairs to a lookout for b/w $4-$9.50 depending on age. Has a great pictorial history of the bridge & her special place in Sydney.

A Must Do. The views were amazing and our guide was very informative about both the bridge and Sydney itself. The staff is very professional and the whole experience was enjoyable. Our trip to Sydney would not have been complete without this trip. Well worth it!

BEAUTIFUL, STUNNINGG. Wife and i walked accross the bridge and loved the experience so much. we departed at 5.30 and arrived at milsons point at abotu 6.00pm. oen of the best expereineces in sydney. loved to see the sunset. even thought abotu proposing again while i was on there. had a great tiem in sydney. great people them aussies!

pylon lookout, cheap, fast and great views. As we were in sydney for 2 days, we did the pylon lookout instead of the bridge climb. We also were disappointed that we couldn't take a camera on the bridge climb too. The view was great and it was cheap to get into. It was hard to find though...... From the Rocks, go along Cumberland street past the bridge climb place, and go up the stairs sign posted for Botanic Gardens. Along the side of the road and you will come to the pylon. You can also walk across the bridge and get the 'sydeny explorer' at the other side.
Great View!. The bridge is a Sydney icon; we wouldn't have left the city without walking on the bridge.
Nice view. Get on here and feel the fresh air every morning.Feel so comfortable and relax,if you guy got a chance to come sydney,dont miss the sun rise and sun set.It's just bautiful

Just walk across the bridge for free. My review is not for the costly "The Bridge Climb"; it's simply for walking across the bridge for free. This was a great experience. We did it on a Sunday, when traffic was less, and moving quickly. It actually might be better when traffic is congested - a bit quieter. Nonetheless, this free experience provides terrific vistas of the harbor and the Opera House, as well as the bridge itself, an impressive feat of engineering and design. While we enjoyed the walk across and back, we noticed those on The Bridge Climb. None of them was smiling, chained to their safety wires in their suits, looking a bit miserable and sweaty. While their wallets were much lighter, creating our own free experience lightened our hearts and spirit.

Pylon Lookout Review - not the Bridge Climb. First, I want to emphasize that my review is on Pylon Lookout and not the Bridge Climb. I am very surprised that TA has bunched up the 2 attractions together... each one offers a totally different experience.The Lookout is fabulous, inexpensive, and the views are great. The climb itself is not too tiring, there is a gift shop & rest area roughly half-way up. We enjoyed the Pylon's short video presentation about the history of the bridge, why the pylons were added though not needed during the construction.I would recommend this during a nice clear morning, the views are wonderful - sites are marked on the glass...

Walk to the other side for great & cheaper restaurants. The Thai restaurant on the other side of the bridge had the best Thai food and it was cheap. Not like the Famous Chocolate restaurant in the Rocks which was ok and overpriced. If you're planning to walk across the Sydney Harbour Bridge anyways - eat on the other side!

Thrilling Experience. I'm someone is extremely scared of heights, and no... this experience did not make me overcome my fear, I just never knew how I could have so much fun, yet be so scared at the same time. hehe

We didn't pay to walk to the top, we just.... We didn't pay to walk to the top, we just walked across to the other side and took some great pics of the city and opera house. When you get done you can just take the train back to the city.
Matt Sorenson
Austin Texas USA
Fantastic but the do it yourself option is a lot cheaper. You can walk across the Bridge for free - for about $10 you can climb one of the Pylons that gives spectacular views. Its well worth doing

See, Walk, or Climb a Must Do. Will be the first of many breathtaking sites you will see in Sydney. Do not pass it up! For those wanting the cheap thrill, walk across the bridge, it is free with a great view. Tip: go in the morning and you will be the only one on the bridge. If you want to learn about the bridge without breaking your wallet then go up the Sydney Harbour Bridge Pylon Lookout. It is well worth the price and you get a great high up view of the city and the opera house. We did not do the Bridge Climb because it cost too much and took too much time.
Best way to see Sydney. This is by far my best experience in Sydney. I am usually scared of hights but I felt really safe and secure and would do it again.

it grew on me..... At first I thought the Bridge a bit of a disappointment, looked old, like GW Bridge n NYC, not immediately impressive like Golden Gate or Verrazanno Narrows. But it grows on you and you get used to it being there as a background to most photos. One morning we started to walk across it (bottom road level walkway, not the climb across the top), great views although I could only do the first turret because of a foot problem. I would advise going a bit later in the morning to avoid the getting into the morning rush of walkers across the Bridge and to see the Museum. The Museum was not yet open when we were there. . A great view of the Bridge is from the streets behind the Holiday Inn outside the Info Center, from the park in front of the Hyatt (especially at night) , from Mrs. McQ's Seat at the Botanical Center and from the Darling Harbor Ferry as it passes under it. Lots of brave souls climbed across it on the high route, I would imagine the view to be spectacular.

It is worth a walk across this bridge!. Two weeks ago, my 8 year old daughter and I walked across the Sydney Harbour Bridge. We were staying with friends on the North Shore so took a train to Milson's Point and walked up the stairs to the bridge. The walk is easy and flat and from end to end takes approximately 20 minutes. It is very popular with joggers. On this side of the bridge, no bikes, skateboards and the like are allowed. They must travel on the western side of the bridge, so you can walk the bridge without the fear of being runover! It is security patrolled and they have security cameras along the walkway. Makes you feel secure even to walk it at nighttime.My daughter and I also decided to do the Pylon Lookout, cost was $9.50 for me and $4 for her. We spent about 30 minutes inside, learning about the bridge (I've done the bridgeclimb in the past and alot of the info the guide tells you is in the Pylon Lookout) and going to the top. The views are spectacular.So, if money is an issue and you are undecided about doing the bridgeclimb, then don't miss the Pylon Lookout. You still get the fantastic views from the top, and it only costs a fraction of the price of the climb.At the end of our day in Sydney, my daughter and I walked back across the bridge to the Milson's Point train station. So we walked it twice. I thought it was well worth doing again and to see the sights at night from the bridge.If I can give one piece of advise, it would be to walk across this bridge and stop and take photos of the Opera House etc. I wonder why I hadn't made an effort to walk this bridge on my many other trips to the city. I'll definetely do it again, next time bringing my Aussie husband, who has never walked it before either.

A must-see landmark with lots of different options. The Sydney Harbour Bridge is one of the two main things people know about Sydney if they have never been there, the other being the Opera House. It is an amazing structure which you need to take some time to enjoy. If you don't feel up to doing the bridge climb, which can be quite expensive, then there are several ways you can enjoy the bridge.1) BridgeClimb - Thought I'd mention this way anyway. This is by far the best way to experience the bridge. You spend about 2 hours on the bridge itself, plus another hour or so in preparation / leaving the base. You are shown something you can only experience in the climb. You see, and are told, all about the bridge and its construction as well as the surrounding area. It also provides the best views of the Harbour. Cameras aren't allowed but the climb leader has a camera with him with photos available after your climb. I highly recommend this option if you can.2) Pylon lookout - This is a much cheaper option if you're on a budget, or really don't like heights. It's in one of the 4 pillars (pylons) that border the bridge. There is a museum which tells you all about the bridge and some really good views from the top too. You have a good view of people doing the Bridge Climb too so if you're not doing the climb but know somebody that is then this is a good place to take a photo. The views from here are great - just not as good as BridgeClimb. BridgeClimb climbers get a free ticket for the Pylon lookout so you can do both and compare them.3) Harbour Cruise - You get some really great views of the harbour bridge from any boat on the harbour really. You can do morning coffee cruises, dinner cruises or one I found really good - a hop on hop off pass for several locations around the harbour.4) Circular Quay - If you're on a VERY strict budget and want to see the bridge for free then walk from the Opera House around to the other side of the quay and towards the bridge - youll get some great views. Probably the best view is from the elevated highway that goes along the bottom of the quay. There is a glass elevator that takes you up there - it's a popular walking route and provides some really good views of the quay and bridge.5) Cross the bridge - This can take some time as the walk up to the bridge itself is quite long but you get some good views of the bridge and harbour.6) Explorer buses - the red explorer bus crosses the bridge but its really too quick to see much of it or to enjoy the view. I would recommend it though as it's a city tour,7) Mrs MacQuaries Chair - The peninsula that contains Mrs Macquaries chair can be reached by a 20 minute walk along the bay from the Opera House or by using the explorer tourist buses. It provides some really great views of the Harbour, Bridge and Opera House and is a tourist attraction in itself.Whichever option (or options) you decide on make sure you spend some time to just enjoy the view or you'll be missing out on something special.

Fantastic. We did the pylon look out as we didn't get chance to book onto the Bridge climb. The pylon lookout is only $9, so cheap to get views as fanstastic as the bridge climb itself (I'd imagine it's just not as exciting). The bridge is amazing and can give some brilliant sights of Sydney. We also walked over the bridge and the area the otherside of Syndey City was lovely and quiet. We then took the ferry across to Darling Harbour. Well worth having a wander across.

Pylon Lookout - cheaper than Bridge Climb with beautiful views!!!. We decided to go to the Pylon Lookout rather than doing the Sydney Bridge Climb. It was only $9.50, as opposed to $179 and up for an adult ticket on the Sydney Bridge Climb. This allowed us to take as many pictures as we wanted with our own camera (cameras are not allowed on the Bridge Climb) and the views were fabulous! I have not done the Bridge Climb so I can't comment on it, but from pictures that I have seen, I think the views from the Pylon Lookout are very comparable (I've attached some of mine), so if you don't want to spend a lot of money, it might be a better option for you, as it was for us!

Pylon Lookout - Hidden treasure. This is a review of the bridge itself. The BrigeWalk is a couple of spaces down. The Pylon Lookout for $12 AUD is quite a bargain. We went up at dusk (5 PM as it was winter) and it closed at 6 PM. Great views. Admission includes a short movie and stop at small museum. There is even a gift shop up there. The climb was not bad at all and there is a drinking fountain half way up. Walking out there was half the fun. Check it out.
